analyzed: jarā cakkhu viññeyyā hoti  āyunaḥ indriyānam imehi pana padehi kāla atikkameya iva abhibyattāya  āyu khaya cakkha ādi indriya paripāka saṅkhātāya pakatiyā dīpitā tenassime pacchimā dve  pakati niddesā ti veditabbā tattha yasmā jaram pattassa āyu hāyati tasmā jarā āyuno
translated: For aging is not cognizable by the eye.🔽By the words “diminution of life” and “maturing of the faculties” the aging that is evident through the passing of time is indicated by the natural aging called the exhaustion of life and the maturing of the faculties of the eye, and so on. Therefore these last two

original: saṃhānī”ti phalūpacārena vuttā. Yasmā ca daharakāle suppasannāni sukhumampi attano
analyzed: saṃhāni iti phala upacārena vuttā ca dahara kāle suppasannāni attano
translated: should be understood as the description of the natural aging. Herein, since the life span of one who has reached aging diminishes, aging is called “diminution of life” by a figurative use of effect for cause.

original: visayaṃ sukheneva gaṇhanasamatthāni cakkhādīni indriyāni jaraṃ pattassa paripakkāni
analyzed: visayam sukhena iva gaṇhana samatthāni cakkha ādīni indriyāni jaram pattassa paripakkāni
translated: And since the faculties of the eye, etc., which are clear and keen in youth and are capable of easily apprehending their respective objects, become matured and

original: āluḷitāni avisadāni, oḷārikampi attano visayaṃ gahetuṃ asamatthāni honti. Tasmā “indriyānaṃ
analyzed: āluḷitāni a visadāni oḷārikam pi attanaḥ visayam gahetum asamatthāni honti tasmai indriyānaṃ
translated: and they are not clear, not bright, and are unable to grasp their objects distinctly. Therefore, “the faculties are not rightly directed.”

original: paripāko”ti phalūpacāreneva vuttā.🔽Sā panesā evaṃ niddiṭṭhā sabbāpi jarā pākaṭā paṭicchannāti duvidhā hoti. Tattha dantādīsu
analyzed: paripākā iti phala upacārena iva vuttā  sā pana esā evam niddiṭṭhā sabbā api jarā pākaṭā paṭicchannā ati duvidhā hoti tattha danta ādīsu
translated: They are sluggish and dull, unable to grasp their objects even when these are gross. That is why it is said with reference to the fruit that “the faculties are matured.”

original: khaṇḍādibhāvadassanato rūpadhammesu jarā pākaṭajarā nāma. Arūpadhammesu pana jarā
analyzed: khaṇḍa ādi bhāva dassanato rūpa dhammesu jarā pākaṭa jarā nāma arūpa dhammesu pana jarā
translated: This aging thus described is twofold, manifest and hidden. Herein, aging in material things is called manifest aging because it is seen in the form of the breaking up, etc., of teeth, etc.,

original: tādisassa vikārassa adassanato paṭicchannajarā nāma. Tattha yvāyaṃ khaṇḍādibhāvo🔽dissati, so tādisānaṃ dantādīnaṃ suviññeyyattā vaṇṇoyeva. Tañca cakkhunā disvā manodvārena
analyzed: tādisassa vikārassa a dassanato paṭicchannajarā nāma tattha yvā ayam khaṇḍa ādi bhāvo  dissati saḥ tādisānam danta ādīnam su viññeyya ttā vaṇṇo yeva tat ca cakkhunā disvā mano dvārena
translated: but aging in immaterial things is called hidden aging because it is not seen in such a mode.🔽Herein, the breaking up, etc., that is seen

original: cintetvā “ime dantā jarāya pahaṭā”ti jaraṃ jānāti. Udakaṭṭhāne baddhāni gosiṅgādīni
analyzed: cintetvā ime dantāḥ jarāya jaram jānāti udakaṭṭhāne baddhāni go siṅga ādīni
translated: is only color. And having seen it with the eye, having cognized it with the mind, one knows aging thus: “These teeth are struck by aging.”

original: oloketvā heṭṭhā udakassa atthibhāvajānanaṃ viya.
analyzed: oloketvā heṭṭhā udakassa atthi bhāva jānanam viya
translated: Just as by looking at a cow’s horn fixed in a place one knows the presence of water below.

original: Puna avīci savīcīti evampi ayaṃ jarā duvidhā hoti. Tattha maṇikanakarajatapavāḷacandasūriyādīnaṃ
analyzed: puna avīci savīci iti evam pi ayam jarā duvidhā hoti tattha
translated: Again, ageing is twofold as “without interval” and “with interval.” Herein, ageing “without interval” is called “ageing without interval” because the difference in colour, etc., is hard to recognize in gems, gold, silver, coral, the moon, the sun, etc.,

original: mandadasakādīsu pāṇīnaṃ viya ca pupphaphalapallavādīsu apāṇīnaṃ viya ca antarantarā🔽vaṇṇavisesādīnaṃ dubbiññeyyattā jarā avīcijarā nāma, nirantarajarāti attho. Tato🔽aññesu pana yathāvuttesu antarantarā vaṇṇavisesādīnaṃ suviññeyyattā jarā savīcijarā nāma.
analyzed: manda dasaka ādīsu pāṇīnam viya ca puppha phala pallava ādīsu a pāṇīnam viya ca antar antarā  vaṇṇa visesa ādīnam dubbiññeyya ttā jarā avīcijarā nāma nirantara jarā ti  aññesu pana yathā vuttesu antarantarā vaṇṇa visesa ādīnam su viññeyya ttā jarā savīcijarā nāma
translated: and in hands, feet, etc., and in flowers, fruits, leaves, etc., because of the absence of any interval of such things as joints, etc.,🔽as there is in bamboos, sugar-cane, and creepers. The rest is as already stated.🔽Ageing “with interval” is called “ageing with interval” because the difference in colour, etc., is easy to recognize in the things already mentioned,🔽because of the presence of an interval in the form of joints, etc., as in bamboos, sugar-cane, and creepers.

original: Tattha savīcijarā upādinnakaanupādinnakavasena evaṃ dīpetabbā – daharakumārakānañhi
analyzed: tattha sa vīci jarā upādinnaka anupādinnaka vasena evam dīpetabbā dahara kumārakānam hi
translated: Herein, ageing “with interval” should be illustrated as follows. In the case of young children,

original: paṭhamameva khīradantā nāma uṭṭhahanti, na te thirā. Tesu pana patitesu puna dantā
analyzed: paṭhamam eva khīra dantāḥ nāma uṭṭhahanti na te thirā tesu pana patitesu puna dantāḥ
translated: for instance, the so-called milk teeth first appear, but they are not firm. But when they have fallen out,

original: uṭṭhahanti, te paṭhamameva setā honti, jarāvātena pana pahaṭakāle kāḷakā honti. Kesā
analyzed: uṭṭhahanti te paṭhamam eva setāḥ honti jarā vātena pana pahaṭa kāle kāḷakāḥ honti kesāḥ
translated: the teeth appear again, and these are white at first, but when they are struck by the wind of ageing they become black.

original: pana paṭhamameva tambāpi honti kāḷakāpi setakāpi. Chavi pana salohitakā hoti. Vaḍḍhantānaṃ
analyzed: pana paṭhamam eva tambā api honti kāḷakā api setakā api chavi pana hoti vaḍḍhantānam
translated: The hair is reddish, black, and white at first.🔽The skin is reddish.

original: vaḍḍhantānaṃ odātānaṃ odātabhāvo, kāḷakānaṃ kāḷakabhāvo paññāyati. Jarāvātena pahaṭakāle
analyzed: vaḍḍhantānam odātānam odāta bhāvo kāḷakānam kāḷaka bhāvo paññāyati jarā vātena pahaṭa kāle
translated: When struck by the wind of ageing,

original: ca valiṃ gaṇhāti. Sabbampi sassaṃ vapitakāle setaṃ hoti, pacchā nīlaṃ. Jarāvātena
analyzed: ca valim gaṇhāti sabbam pi sassam vapita kāle setam hoti pacchā nīlam jarā vātena
translated: it takes on wrinkles. All the crops are white at the time of sowing, and later they are blue. But when struck by the wind of ageing,

original: pana pahaṭakāle paṇḍaraṃ hoti. Ambaṅkurenāpi dīpetuṃ vaṭṭati eva. Sā panesā khandhaparipākalakkhaṇā
analyzed: pana pahaṭa kāle paṇḍaram hoti ambaṅkurena api dīpetum vaṭṭati eva sā pana isā khandha paripāka lakkhaṇā
translated: they become pale. It is also possible to illustrate it with the sprout of an unripe mango. But this ageing has the characteristic of the maturing of aggregates;

original: jarā, maraṇūpanayanarasā, yobbanavināsapaccupaṭṭhānā. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva.
analyzed: jarā maraṇa upanayana rasā yobbana vināsa paccupaṭṭhānā sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva
translated: its function is to lead to death; its manifestation is the destruction of youth. The rest is clear in all its parts.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā idampi suttaṃ arahattanikūṭeneva desesi, desanāpariyosāne ayampi brāhmaṇo
analyzed: evam bhagavā idam pi suttam arahatta nikūṭena iva desesi desanā pariyosāne ayam pi brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: Thus the Blessed One taught this sutta too with the peak of arahatship. At the conclusion of the teaching, this brahmin

original: arahatte patiṭṭhāsi saddhiṃ antevāsikasahassena. Aññesañca anekasahassānaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ
analyzed: arahatte patiṭṭhāsi saddhim antevāsika sahassena aññesam ca aneka sahassānam dhamma cakkhum
translated: was established in arahatship together with his thousand pupils. And the eye of Dhamma arose

original: udapādi. Sesaṃ vuttasadisameva.
analyzed: udapādi sesam vutta sadisam eva
translated: in many thousands of others. The rest is as in the previous case.🔽The commentary on the Cūḷaniddesa,

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya
translated: the illumination of the true Dhamma,

original: Puṇṇakamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: puṇṇakamāṇavasutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 4. Mettagūmāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Mettagūmāṇava Sutta

original: 18. Catutthe mettagūsutte – maññāmi taṃ vedagū bhāvitattanti “ayaṃ vedagū”ti ca “bhāvitatto”ti ca evaṃ taṃ maññāmi.
analyzed: catutthe mettagūsutte maññāmi tam vedagū bhāvitattanti ayam vedagū iti ca bhāvitatto ti ca evam tam maññāmi
translated: In the fourth, the Mettāgussūtra, the phrase “I think he is a knower of the field, a cultivated one” means that I think he is a knower of the field and a cultivated one.

original: Aparittoti na appo. Mahantoti na khuddako. Gambhīroti na uttāno. Appameyyoti minituṃ🔽na sakkuṇeyyo. Duppariyogāḷhoti avagāhituṃ otarituṃ dukkho. Bahuratano sāgarūpamoti
analyzed: aparittaḥ iti na appaḥ mahantaḥ iti na khuddakaḥ gambhīraḥ iti na uttānaḥ appameyyaḥ ti minitum  na sakkuṇeyyaḥ duppariyogāḷhaḥ ti avagāhitum otaritum dukkhaḥ bahu ratano sāgara upamaḥ ti
translated: Not limited means not small. Great means not small. Deep means not shallow. Incalculable means not able to be measured.

original: bahūnaṃ dhammaratanānaṃ ākarattā anekavidharatanasampanno mahāsamuddo viya bahuratano sāgarasadiso.
analyzed: bahūnam dhamma ratanānam ākarattā anekavidha ratana sampannaḥ mahā samuddaḥ viya bahu ratanaḥ sāgara sadisaḥ
translated: Hard to fathom means difficult to enter into and descend into. Rich in treasures, like the ocean means rich in treasures like the ocean because of being a mine of many treasures of the Dhamma, like the great ocean which is rich in many kinds of treasures.

original: Na maṅku hotīti na vikuṇitamukho hoti. Appatiṭṭhitacittoti dosavasena na ghanībhūtacitto. Alīnamanasoti na saṅkucitacitto. Abyāpannacetasoti na pūticitto.
analyzed: na maṅku hoti iti na vikuṇita mukhaḥ hoti appatiṭṭhita citto ti dosa vasena na ghanībhūta cittaḥ alīna manaso ti na saṅkucita cittaḥ abyāpanna cetaso ti na pūti cittaḥ
translated: Not embarrassed means not having a distorted face. Unwavering in mind means not having a mind that has become solid through hate. Not depressed in mind means not having a contracted mind. Not having a mind of ill will means not having a putrid mind.

original: Diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattoti cakkhuvisaye rūpārammaṇe diṭṭhamattoyeva taṃ ārammaṇaṃ bhavissati,
analyzed: diṭṭhe diṭṭha mattoti cakkhu visaye rūpa ārammaṇe diṭṭha mattaḥ yā iva tam ārammaṇam bhavissati
translated: In the seen, the seen alone means that in the visible-data base, in the form object, the seen alone will be the object.

original: kattā vā kāretā vā natthi. Yaṃ cakkhunā diṭṭhaṃ vaṇṇāyatanameva. Sutādīsupi eseva🔽nayo. Api ca diṭṭheti dassanayogena vaṇṇāyatanaṃ, savanayogena saddāyatanaṃ, mutayogena
analyzed: kattā vā kāretā vā na atthi yam cakkhunā diṭṭham vaṇṇa āyatanam eva suta ādīsu pi esā iva  nayaḥ api ca diṭṭhā iti dassana yogena vaṇṇa āyatanam savana yogena sadda āyatanam muta yogena
translated: There is no doer or causer. What is seen by the eye is only the visible-form base. The same method applies to what is heard, etc.

original: ghānajivhākāyāyatanāni dasseti. Ghānassa gandhāyatanaṃ, jivhāya rasāyatanaṃ, kāyassa🔽pathavī tejo vāyūti phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ, viññātayogena dhammāyatanaṃ dasseti. Diṭṭhe🔽anūpayoti cakkhuviññāṇena diṭṭhe rāgūpayavirahito. Anapāyoti kodhavirahito appaṭigho.🔽Anissitoti taṇhāya anallīno. Appaṭibaddhoti mānena na baddho. Vippamuttoti sabbārammaṇato
analyzed: ghāna jivhā kāya āyatanāni dasseti ghānassa gandha āyatanam jivhāya rasa āyatanam kāyassa  pathavī tejaḥ vāyū ti phoṭṭhabba āyatanam viññāta yogena dhamma āyatanam dasseti diṭṭhe  anūpayaḥ ti cakkhu viññāṇena diṭṭhe rāga ūpaya virahitaḥ anapāyaḥ ti kodha virahitaḥ appaṭigho  anissitaḥ ti taṇhāya anallīnaḥ appaṭibaddhaḥ ti mānena na baddhaḥ vippamuttaḥ ti sabba ārammaṇato
translated: Moreover, “seen” means the visible-form base is shown by the method of seeing. The sound base is shown by the method of hearing. The bases of nose, tongue, and body are shown by the method of touching. The tangible base is shown by the method of knowing. The mental-data base is shown by the method of cognizing.

original: mutto. Visaññuttoti kilesehi viyutto hutvā ṭhito.
analyzed: muttaḥ visaññuttaḥ ti kilesehi viyuttaḥ hutvā ṭhitaḥ
translated: “In the seen there must be no lust”: he is free from lust in the visible-form base seen by eye-consciousness. “No hate”: he is free from hate. “No delusion”: he is free from delusion. “No attachment”: he is free from attachment. “No bondage”: he is free from bondage. “No fetter”: he is free from fetters. “No obsession”: he is free from obsessions. “No obsession left”: he is free from the remainder of obsessions.

original: Saṃvijjati bhagavato cakkhūti buddhassa bhagavato pakatimaṃsacakkhu upalabbhati.
analyzed: saṃvijjati bhagavato cakkhu iti buddhassa bhagavataḥ pakati maṃsa cakkhu upalabbhati
translated: “The eye of the Exalted One exists”: the eye of flesh of the Exalted One exists.

original: Passatīti dakkhati oloketi. Cakkhunā rūpanti cakkhuviññāṇena rūpārammaṇaṃ. Chandarāgoti taṇhāchando.🔽Dantaṃ nayanti samitinti uyyānakīḷāmaṇḍalādīsu hi mahājanamajjhaṃ gacchantā dantameva🔽goṇaṃ vā dantaṃ assājānīyaṃ vā yāne yojetvā nayanti. Rājāti tathārūpāneva ṭhānāni
analyzed: passati iti dakkhati oloketi cakkhunā rūpanti cakkhu viññāṇena rūpa ārammaṇam chanda rāgaḥ ti taṇhā chandaḥ  dantam nayanti uyyāna kīḷā maṇḍala ādīsu hi mahā jana majjham gacchantā dantam eva  goṇam vā dantam assājānīyam vā yāne yojetvā nayanti tathārūpān eva ṭhānāni
translated: ‘He sees’: he sees, he looks. ‘With the eye and visible objects’: with eye-consciousness and visible-object objects. ‘With desire as his horse’: with craving as his horse.🔽‘They lead the tamed one with a rein’: for when they go out to the pleasure park or to the arena, etc., they lead the tamed

original: gacchanto rājāpi dantameva abhiruhati. Manussesūti manussesupi catūhi ariyamaggehi🔽danto nibbisevanova seṭṭho. Yotivākyanti evarūpaṃ atikkammavacanaṃ punappunaṃ vuccamānampi
analyzed: gacchantaḥ rājā api dantam eva abhiruhati manussesu uti manussesu pi catūhi ariya maggehi  dantaḥ nibbisevanā uva seṭṭhaḥ evarūpam atikkamma vacanam punappunam vuccamānam pi
translated: elephant or the thoroughbred horse harnessed to the carriage with a rein. ‘The king’: when the king goes to such places, he mounts only a tamed elephant or horse. ‘Among men’: among men, too,

original: titikkhati nappatippharati na vihaññati, evarūpo danto seṭṭhoti attho.🔽Assatarāti vaḷavāya gadrabhena jātā. Ājānīyāti yaṃ assadammasārathi kāraṇaṃ kāreti,
analyzed: titikkhati na patippharati na vihaññati evarūpaḥ danto seṭṭhaḥ ti attho  vaḷavāya gadrabhena jātā ājānīyāti yam assa damma sārathi kāraṇam kāreti
translated: the tamed one, who abstains by the four noble paths, is the best. ‘The one who bears with what is said’: the meaning is that the tamed one is the best who bears with what is said, who endures it without getting angry, without being annoyed, without being resentful, even when such words are repeated again and again.

original: tassa khippaṃ jānanasamatthā. Sindhavāti sindhavaraṭṭhe jātā assā. Mahānāgāti kuñjarasaṅkhātā
analyzed: tassa khippam jānana samatthā sindhavā ti sindhava raṭṭhe jātā assā mahā nāgā ati kuñjara saṅkhātā
translated: ‘Mule’: a cross between a horse and a donkey. ‘Thoroughbred’: one that is capable of quickly learning the reasons for which a horse trainer trains. ‘Sindhu horse’: a horse born in the country of the Sindhus. ‘Great tusker’: an elephant called a ‘bull’.

original: mahāhatthino. Attadantoti ete assatarā vā sindhavā vā kuñjarā vā dantāva, na adantā.
analyzed: mahā hatthinaḥ atta dantā iti ete assatarāḥ vā sindhavāḥ vā kuñjarāḥ vā dantā ava na a dantā
translated: and the great elephants. Self-controlled with self : these horses, thoroughbreds, thoroughbred mares, and elephants are self-controlled with tusks, not with no tusks.

original: Yo pana catumaggasaṅkhātena attano dantatāya attadanto nibbisevano, ayaṃ tatopi varaṃ,
analyzed: yaḥ pana catu magga saṅkhātena attanaḥ danta tāya atta dantaḥ nibbisevanaḥ ayam tatas api varam
translated: But he who is self-controlled with self by means of the four paths, being free from craving, is better than they.

original: sabbehipi etehi uttaritaroti attho.🔽Na hi etehi yānehīti yāni etāni hatthiyānādīni uttamayānāni, etehi yānehi koci puggalo
analyzed: sabbehi pi etehi uttaritaraḥ ti attho  na hi etehi yānehi iti yāni etāni hatthi yāna ādīni uttama yānāni etehi yānehi koci puggalaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he is superior to all of them.

original: supinantenapi agatapubbattā “agata”nti saṅkhātaṃ nibbānadisaṃ tathā na gaccheyya.🔽Yathā pubbabhāge indriyadamena dantena, aparabhāge ariyamaggabhāvanāya sudantena
analyzed: supin antena api a gata pubba ttā a gata nti saṅkhātam nibbāna disam tathā na gaccheyya  yathā pubbabhāge indriya damena dantena aparabhāge ariya magga bhāvanāya su dantena
translated: By no vehicle : by these vehicles, namely, the elephant vehicle, etc., which are the best kinds of vehicles. By no vehicle can anyone go to the place called “unattained” because it has never been attained before, namely, Nibbāna.

original: danto nibbisevano sappañño puggalo taṃ agatapubbaṃ disaṃ gacchati, dantabhūmiṃ pāpuṇāti,
analyzed: dantaḥ nibbisevanaḥ sappaññaḥ puggalo tam agata pubbam disam gacchati danta bhūmim pāpuṇāti
translated: But the self-controlled man, who is wise, goes to that place that has never been gone to before, he reaches the plane of self-control,🔽by being self-controlled in the earlier stage with the self-control of the faculties and in the later stage with the self-control of the development of the noble paths.

original: tasmā attadamanameva varataranti attho.
analyzed: tasmai atta damanam eva varataranti
translated: The meaning is that self-control is better.

original: Vidhāsu na vikampantīti navavidhamānakoṭṭhāsesu na calanti na vedhenti. Vippamuttā
analyzed: vidhāsu na vikampanti iti navavidha māna koṭṭhāsesu na calanti na vedhenti vippamuttā
translated: Do not tremble in the face of views : they do not waver or vacillate in the face of the ninefold misapprehension of the bases. Being free from misapprehension,

original: punabbhavāti kammakilesato samucchedavimuttiyā suṭṭhu muttā. Dantabhūmiṃ anuppattāti
analyzed: punabbhavāti kamma kilesataḥ samuccheda vimuttiyā suṭṭhu muttā danta bhūmim anuppattā ti
translated: “They are freed from renewed existence” means that they are well freed from the freedom that is the cutting off of kamma and defilements. “They have reached the state of the tamed” means that they have reached the state of the tamed by the taming of the defilements.

original: arahattaphalaṃ pāpuṇitvā ṭhitā. Te loke vijitāvinoti te vuttappakārā khīṇāsavā sattaloke vijitavijayā nāma.🔽Yassindriyāni bhāvitānīti yassa khīṇāsavassa saddhādipañcindriyāni arahattaphalaṃ
analyzed: arahatta phalam pāpuṇitvā ṭhitā te loke vijitāvinaḥ ti te vutta ppakārā khīṇa āsavā satta loke vijitavijayā nāma  yassa indriyāni bhāvitāni iti yassa khīṇāsavassa saddhā ādi pañca indriyāni arahatta phalam
translated: “They are freed from future becoming” : they are well freed from future becoming by the freedom of the exhaustion of the defilements. “They have reached the state of peace” : they have reached and are established in the fruit of arahantship. “They are victors in the world” : those khīṇāsavas of the aforementioned description are called “victors” in the world of beings.

original: pāpetvā vaḍḍhitāni. Ajjhattañca bahiddhā cāti cakkhādiajjhattāyatanāni ca rūpādibahiddhāyatanāni🔽ca nibbisevanāni katāni. Sabbaloketi sakalatedhātuke loke ca. Nibbijjha imaṃ parañca
analyzed: pāpetvā vaḍḍhitāni ajjhattam ca bahiddhā ca ati cakkha ādi ajjhatta āyatanāni ca rūpa ādi bahiddha āyatanāni  ca nibbisevanāni katāni sabbaloke iti sakala tedhātuke loke ca nibbijjhe imam param ca
translated: “Whose faculties are developed” : whose faculties of faith, etc., have been developed by bringing about the fruit of arahantship. “Both internally and externally” : the internal sense bases beginning with the eye and the external sense bases beginning with visible forms.

original: lokanti imañca attabhāvaṃ paraloke ca attabhāvaṃ atikkamitvā ṭhito khīṇāsavo. Kālaṃ
analyzed: imam ca atta bhāvam para loke ca atta bhāvam atikkamitvā ṭhitaḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ kālam
translated: “They have abandoned” : they have abandoned the internal and external sense bases. “In the entire world” : in the entire world consisting of the three planes. “Having become disenchanted with this world and the next” : the khīṇāsava is established having gone beyond this present existence and the next existence.

original: kaṅkhati bhāvito sa dantoti so khīṇāsavo cakkhādito danto vaḍḍhitacitto maraṇakālaṃ pattheti.
analyzed: kaṅkhati bhāvito sa danto ti saḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ cakkhāditaḥ danto vaḍḍhita cittaḥ maraṇa kālam pattheti
translated: “He waits for the time, the tamed one, his faculties developed” : the khīṇāsava, the tamed one, his mind developed, waits for the time of death.

original: Yesaṃ dhammānaṃ ādito samudāgamanaṃ paññāyatīti yesaṃ khandhādidhammānaṃ uppatti
analyzed: yesam dhammānam āditas samudāgamanam paññāyati iti yesam khandha ādi dhammānam uppatti
translated: “Of those ideas whose arising is discerned”: of those ideas classed as aggregates, etc., whose arising is discerned.

original: paññāyati. Atthaṅgamato nirodhoti atthaṅgamanavasena tesaṃyeva abhāvo paññāyati.
analyzed: paññāyati atthaṅgamataḥ nirodho ti atthaṅgamana vasena tesam yeva abhāvo paññāyati
translated: “Cessation through their ending”: the non-existence of those same ideas is discerned through their ending.

original: Kammasannissito vipākoti kusalākusalakammanissito vipāko kammaṃ amuñcitvā pavattanato
analyzed: kamma sannissitaḥ vipāko ti kusala akusala kamma nissitaḥ vipāko kammaṃ a muñcitvā pavattanato
translated: “Result dependent on kamma”: the result is dependent on profitable and unprofitable kamma, since it occurs without abandoning the kamma.

original: vipākopi kammasannissitova nāma. Nāmasannissitaṃ rūpanti sabbarūpaṃ nāmaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: vipākaḥ api kamma sannissitaḥ va nāma nāma sannissitam rūpan ti sabba rūpam nāmam gahetvā
translated: “Form dependent on name”: all form is called “dependent on name” since it occurs by taking cognizance of name.

original: pavattanato nāmasannissitaṃ nāma jātaṃ. Jātiyā anugatanti sabbaṃ kammādikaṃ jātiyā🔽anupaviṭṭhaṃ. Jarāya anusaṭanti jarāya patthaṭaṃ. Byādhinā abhibhūtanti byādhidukkhena
analyzed: pavattanataḥ nāma sannissitam nāma jātam jātiyā anugatan ti sabbam kamma ādikam jātiyā  anupaviṭṭham jarāya jarāya patthaṭam byādhinā byādhi dukkhena
translated: “Followed by birth”: all kamma, etc., is “followed by birth” since it is accompanied by birth.🔽“Overtaken by ageing”: it is “overtaken by ageing” since it is struck by ageing.🔽“Overwhelmed by suffering”: it is “overwhelmed by suffering” since it is oppressed by the suffering of pain.

original: abhimadditaṃ. Maraṇena abbhāhatanti maccunā abhihaṭaṃ pahaṭaṃ. Atāṇanti puttādīhipi
analyzed: abhimadditam maraṇena maccunā abhihaṭam pahaṭam
translated: “Struck by death”: it is “struck by death” since it is struck down by death.🔽“No shelter”: it has no shelter since it has no protection in sons, etc., and it is no protection since it is no safe haven.

original: tāyanassa abhāvato atāyanaṃ anārakkhaṃ alabbhaṇeyyaṃ khemaṃ vā. Aleṇanti allīyituṃ
analyzed: tāyanassa abhāvataḥ atāyanam anārakkham alabbhaṇeyyam khemam vā a leṇanti allīyitum
translated: “No saviour”: it has no saviour since it has no protector in sons, etc., and it is no protection since it is no safe haven.

original: nissayituṃ anarahaṃ, allīnānampi na leṇakiccakaraṇaṃ. Asaraṇanti nissitānaṃ na bhayahārakaṃ,🔽na bhayavināsakaṃ. Asaraṇībhūtanti pure uppattiyā attano abhāveneva asaraṇaṃ, uppattisamakālameva
analyzed: nissayitum na leṇa kicca karaṇam na bhaya hārakam  na bhaya vināsakam a saraṇībhūtam ti pure uppattiyāḥ attanaḥ abhāvena iva asaraṇam uppatti sama kālam eva
translated: and it is not a refuge for those who have gone to it, nor does it do the work of a refuge for them. It is not a refuge for those who have gone to it: it does not remove the fear of those who have gone to it,🔽nor does it destroy the fear. It has become no refuge: it is no refuge because it has no existence of its own prior to the arising of those who have gone to it;

original: asaraṇabhūtanti attho.
analyzed: a saraṇa bhūtanti attho
translated: the meaning is that it has become no refuge at the very moment of the arising of those who have gone to it.

original: 19. Apucchasīti ettha a-iti padapūraṇamatte nipāto, pucchasitveva attho. Pavakkhāmi🔽yathā pajānanti yathā pajānanto ācikkhati, evaṃ ācikkhissāmi. Upadhinidānā pabhavanti🔽dukkhāti taṇhādiupadhinidānā jātiādidukkhavisesā pabhavanti.
analyzed: a pucchasi iti ettha aiti pada pūraṇa matte nipātaḥ pucchasi tvā iva atthaḥ pavakkhāmi  yathā pajānanti yathā pajānantaḥ ācikkhati evam ācikkhissāmi upadhi nidānā pabhavanti  dukkhā ti taṇhā ādi upadhi nidānā jāti ādi dukkha visesā pabhavanti
translated: You ask: here the prefix a- is merely a pleonastic particle; the meaning is “you ask.” I shall explain🔽as one who knows how to teach explains. Suffering originates from the underlying tendencies: the various kinds of suffering beginning with birth originate from the underlying tendencies beginning with craving.

original: Taṇhūpadhīti taṇhā eva taṇhūpadhi. Sassatucchedadiṭṭhi eva diṭṭhūpadhi. Rāgādikilesā
analyzed: taṇhu upadhi iti taṇhā eva taṇhu upadhi eva diṭṭhu upadhi rāga ādi kilesā
translated: Craving is the underlying tendency of craving: craving itself is the underlying tendency of craving. The view of eternalism and the view of annihilationism are the underlying tendency of views. The defilements beginning with lust are the underlying tendency of defilements.

original: eva kilesūpadhi. Puññādikammāni eva kammūpadhi. Tividhaduccaritāniyeva duccaritūpadhi.
analyzed: eva kilesūpadhi puñña ādi kammāni eva kammūpadhi tividha duccaritāni eva duccaritūpadhi
translated: Meritorious and other kinds of kamma are the underlying tendency of kamma. The three kinds of misconduct are the underlying tendency of misconduct.

original: Kabaḷīkārādayo āhārā eva āhārūpadhi. Dosapaṭigho eva paṭighūpadhi. Kammasamuṭṭhānā
analyzed: kabaḷīkāra ādayo āhārāḥ eva āhāra upadhi dosa paṭighaḥ eva paṭigha upadhi kamma samuṭṭhānā
translated: The kinds of nutriment beginning with physical food are the underlying tendency of nutriment. Hostility and resistance are the underlying tendency of resistance. Kamma-originated,

original: kammeneva gahitā pathavādayo catasso dhātuyova catasso upādinnadhātuyo upadhī. Cakkhādichaajjhattikāni
analyzed: kammena iva gahitā pathavā ādayo catasso dhātuyo ca catasso upādinna dhātuyo upadhī cakkhu ādi cha ajjhattikāni
translated: The four elements, earth, etc., which are included by the term “kamma” are the four appropriated elements. The six internal bases, eye, etc.,

original: āyatanāni eva cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni upadhī. Cakkhuviññāṇādichaviññāṇakāyāva
analyzed: āyatanāni eva cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni upadhī cakkhu viññāṇa ādi cha viññāṇa kāyā ava
translated: are the six internal bases. The six groups of consciousness, eye-consciousness, etc.,

original: cha viññāṇakāyā upadhī. Sabbampi dukkhaṃ dukkhamanaṭṭhenāti sabbatebhūmakaṃ dukkhaṃ🔽dussahanaṭṭhena upadhi.🔽20. Evaṃ upadhinidānato pabhavantesu dukkhesu – yo ve avidvāti gāthā. Tattha pajānanti
analyzed: cha viññāṇa kāyāḥ upadhī sabbam pi dukkham dukkham an aṭṭhena ati sabbatebhūmakam dukkham  dussahana ṭṭhena upadhi  evam upadhi nidānataḥ pabhavantesu dukkhesu yaḥ gāthāḥ tattha pajānanti
translated: are the six groups of consciousness. All suffering is a burden in the sense of being a nuisance.🔽Thus all suffering of the three planes of existence is a burden in the sense of being hard to bear.🔽Thus in regard to suffering that originates from the burden of clinging, the verse: “One who, not knowing, clings to the burden,

original: saṅkhāre aniccādivasena jānanto. Dukkhassa jātippabhavānupassīti vaṭṭadukkhassa jātikāraṇaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāre anicca ādi vasena jānantaḥ dukkhassa jāti ppabhava anupassī ti vaṭṭa dukkhassa jāti kāraṇam
translated: Herein, they know the formations by way of impermanence, etc. He contemplates the origin of suffering,

original: “upadhī”ti anupassanto. Imissā gāthāya niddese vattabbaṃ natthi.
analyzed: upadhi iti anupassanto imissā gāthāya niddese vattabbam na atthi
translated: contemplating the cause of the suffering of the round as “clinging.” There is nothing to be said in the exposition of this verse.

original: 21. Sokapariddavañcāti sokañca paridevañca. Tathā hi te vidito esa dhammoti yathā yathā sattā jānanti, tathā tathā ñāpanavasena vidito esa tayā dhammoti.
analyzed: soka pariddavañca ati sokañca paridevañca tathā hi te viditaḥ esa dhammo ti yathā yathā sattāḥ jānanti tathā tathā ñāpana vasena viditaḥ esa tayā dhammo ti
translated: Sorrow and lamentation: sorrow and lamentation. Thus, “This state is known to you” is stated in the sense of making known in whatever way beings know.

original: Tattha tarantīti paṭhamamaggena diṭṭhoghaṃ taranti. Uttarantīti dutiyamaggena kāmoghaṃ🔽tanukaraṇavasena uggantvā taranti. Patarantīti tameva niravasesappahānavasena tatiyamaggena
analyzed: tattha taranti iti paṭhama maggena diṭṭha ogham taranti uttaranti iti dutiya maggena kāma ogham  tanu karaṇa vasena uggantvā taranti pataranti iti tam eva niravasesa pahāna vasena tatiya maggena
translated: Herein, they cross over means they cross over the flood of views by means of the first path. They go beyond means they go beyond the flood of sensual desire by means of the second path,🔽having emerged by means of the attenuation of the defilements. They fare across means they fare across by means of the third path,

original: visesena taranti. Samatikkamantīti bhavoghaavijjoghappahānavasena catutthamaggena
analyzed: visesena taranti samatikkamanti iti bhava ogha avijja ogha ppahāna vasena catuttha maggena
translated: which is the crossing over by means of the complete abandoning of the flood of existence. They pass over means they pass over by means of the fourth path,

original: sammā atikkamanti. Vītivattantīti phalaṃ pāpuṇitvā tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: sammā atikkamanti vītivattanti iti phalam pāpuṇitvā tiṭṭhanti
translated: which is the right passing over by means of the abandoning of the flood of ignorance. They do so by reaching the fruition.

original: 22. Kittayissāmi te dhammanti nibbānadhammaṃ nibbānagāminipaṭipadādhammañca te desayissāmi.🔽Diṭṭhe dhammeti diṭṭheva dukkhādidhamme, imasmiṃyeva vā attabhāve. Anītihanti attapaccakkhaṃ.
analyzed: kittayissāmi te dhamman ti nibbāna dhammam nibbāna gāmini paṭipadā dhammam ca te desayissāmi  diṭṭhe dhamme iti diṭṭhā iva dukkha ādi dhamme imasmin yeva vā atta bhāve anīti hanti atta paccakkham
translated: I will proclaim to you the Dhamma, excellent in the beginning, excellent in the middle, excellent in the end, with its own intrinsic meaning, with its own intrinsic message.🔽In the Dhamma and Discipline made known by the Tathagata, you will live as an ascetic all your life, and we will provide you with robes, almsfood, resting place, and medicinal requisites.”

original: Yaṃ viditvāti yaṃ dhammaṃ “sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā”tiādinā nayena sammasanto viditvā.
analyzed: yam viditvā iti yam dhammam sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccā iti ādinā nayena sammasantaḥ viditvā
translated: Herein, in the Dhamma and Discipline made known by the Tathagata means in the Dhamma and Discipline taught by the Tathagata.

original: Tattha ādikalyāṇanti hitvāpi anuttaraṃ vivekasukhaṃ dhammaṃ tava kittayissāmi, tañca
analyzed: tattha ādi kalyāṇam ti hitvā api anuttaram viveka sukham dhammam tava kittayissāmi tam ca
translated: You will live as an ascetic all your life means you will live as an ascetic for as long as you live.

original: kho appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā kittayanto ādikalyāṇādippakārameva kittayissāmi. Ādimhi kalyāṇaṃ
analyzed: kho appam vā bahum vā kittayantaḥ ādi kalyāṇa ādi ppakāram eva kittayissāmi ādimhi kalyāṇam
translated: I shall extol it, whether little or much, as having good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and revealing the perfectly pure spiritual life wholly complete and purified.

original: bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva katvā kittayissāmi. Majjhepi. Pariyosānepi bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva🔽katvā kittayissāmīti vuttaṃ hoti. Yasmiñhi bhagavā ekagāthampi desesi, sā samantabhaddakattā
analyzed: bhaddakam anavajjam eva katvā kittayissāmi majjhe pi pariyosāne pi bhaddakam anavajjam eva  katvā kittayissāmi iti vuttam hoti yasmin hi bhagavā eka gātham pi desesi sā samanta bhadda kattā
translated: I shall extol it, making it good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and revealing the perfectly pure spiritual life wholly complete and purified.

original: dhammassa paṭhamapādena ādikalyāṇā, dutiyatatiyapādehi majjhekalyāṇā, pacchimapādena🔽pariyosānakalyāṇā. Ekānusandhikaṃ suttaṃ nidānena ādikalyāṇaṃ, nigamanena pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ,🔽sesena majjhekalyāṇaṃ. Nānānusandhikaṃ suttaṃ paṭhamānusandhinā ādikalyāṇaṃ, pacchimena
analyzed: dhammassa paṭhama pādena ādi kalyāṇā dutiya tatiya pādehi majjhe kalyāṇā pacchima pādena  pariyosāna kalyāṇāḥ eka anusandhikam suttam nidānena ādi kalyāṇam nigamanena pariyosāna kalyāṇam  sesena majjhe kalyāṇam nānā anusandhikam suttam paṭhama anusandhinā ādi kalyāṇam pacchimena
translated: For whatever verse the Exalted One taught, that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and reveals the perfectly pure spiritual life wholly complete and purified, because the Dhamma is entirely good.🔽A sutta with a single sequence is good in the beginning with the introduction, good in the end with the conclusion, and good in the middle with the rest.

original: pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ, sesehi majjhekalyāṇaṃ.
analyzed: pariyosāna kalyāṇam sesehi majjhe kalyāṇam
translated: A sutta with several sequences is good in the beginning with the first sequence, good in the end with the last sequence, and good in the middle with the rest.

original: Api ca sanidānauppattittā ādikalyāṇaṃ, veneyyānaṃ anurūpato atthassa aviparītatāya
analyzed: api ca sa nidāna auppatti ttā ādi kalyāṇam veneyyānam anurūpataḥ atthassa a viparīta tāya
translated: Moreover, it is good in the beginning because it has an introduction that tells how it came about. It is good in the middle because it is not contrary to the meaning. And it is good in the end because it is purified by the relinquishment of the defilements.

original: ca hetudāharaṇayuttato ca majjhekalyāṇaṃ, sotūnaṃ saddhāpaṭilābhajananena nigamanena🔽ca pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ.
analyzed: ca ca majjhe kalyāṇam sotūnam saddhā paṭilābha jananena nigamanena  ca pariyosāna kalyāṇam
translated: It is good in the end because it has a conclusion that inspires faith in the listeners.🔽For the whole of the Dispensation is good in the beginning with virtue, which is its benefit;

original: Sakalo hi sāsanadhammo attano atthabhūtena sīlena ādikalyāṇo, samathavipassanāmaggaphalehi
analyzed: sakalaḥ hi sāsana dhammaḥ attanaḥ attha bhūtena sīlena ādi kalyāṇaḥ samatha vipassanā magga phalehi
translated: it is good in the middle with serenity, insight, the path, and fruition;🔽it is good in the end with extinction. Or alternatively, it is good in the beginning with virtue and concentration;

original: majjhekalyāṇo, nibbānena pariyosānakalyāṇo. Sīlasamādhīhi vā ādikalyāṇo, vipassanāmaggehi
analyzed: majjhe kalyāṇaḥ nibbānena pariyosāna kalyāṇaḥ sīla samādhīhi vā ādi kalyāṇaḥ vipassanā maggehi
translated: it is good in the middle with insight and the path;

original: majjhekalyāṇo, phalanibbānehi pariyosānakalyāṇo. Buddhasubodhitāya vā ādikalyāṇo,
analyzed: majjhe kalyāṇaḥ phala nibbānehi pariyosāna kalyāṇaḥ buddha su bodhitāya vā ādi kalyāṇaḥ
translated: it is good in the end with fruition and extinction. Or alternatively, it is good in the beginning because it is well proclaimed by the Enlightened One;

original: dhammasudhammatāya majjhekalyāṇo, saṅghasuppaṭipattiyā pariyosānakalyāṇo. Taṃ sutvā🔽tathattāya paṭipannena adhigantabbāya abhisambodhiyā vā ādikalyāṇo, paccekabodhiyā
analyzed: dhamma su dhamma tāya majjhe kalyāṇaḥ saṅgha su paṭipattiyā pariyosāna kalyāṇaḥ tam sutvā  tathattāya paṭipannena adhigantabbāya abhisambodhiyā vā ādi kalyāṇo paccekabodhiyā
translated: it is good in the middle because it is well penetrated by the clansmen who are disciples;

original: majjhekalyāṇo, sāvakabodhiyā pariyosānakalyāṇo.
analyzed: majjhe kalyāṇaḥ sāvaka bodhiyā pariyosāna kalyāṇaḥ
translated: it is good in the end because it is well seen as liberation.

original: Suyyamāno cesa nīvaraṇavikkhambhanato bhavanenapi kalyāṇameva āvahatīti ādikalyāṇo,
analyzed: suyyamānaḥ ca isa nīvaraṇa vikkhambhanataḥ bhavanena api kalyāṇam eva āvahati iti ādi kalyāṇaḥ
translated: And when it is heard, it brings good only, even when merely listened to, since it causes the hindrances to be suppressed. So it is good in the beginning.🔽It brings good in the middle since it causes the development of the enlightenment factors to be reached. So it is good in the middle.

original: paṭipajjiyamāno samathavipassanāsukhāvahanato paṭipattiyāpi kalyāṇameva āvahatīti
analyzed: paṭipajjiyamānaḥ samatha vipassanā sukha āvahanataḥ paṭipattiyā api kalyāṇam eva āvahati iti
translated: It is good in the middle because it brings about what is good in the middle by bringing about the happiness of serenity and insight.

original: majjhekalyāṇo, tathāpaṭipanno ca paṭipattiphale niṭṭhite tādibhāvāvahanato paṭipattiphalenapi🔽kalyāṇameva āvahatīti pariyosānakalyāṇoti.
analyzed: majjhe kalyāṇo tathā paṭipanno ca paṭipatti phale niṭṭhite ta ādi bhāva āvahanato paṭipatti phalena api  kalyāṇam eva āvahati iti
translated: And it is good in the end because it brings about what is good in the end by bringing about the state of having such a nature as is proper to the fruit of the path for one who has thus gone in that way.

original: Yaṃ panesa bhagavā dhammaṃ desento sāsanabrahmacariyaṃ maggabrahmacariyañca pakāseti,🔽nānānayehi dīpeti. Taṃ yathānurūpaṃ atthasampattiyā sātthaṃ. Byañjanasampattiyā sabyañjanaṃ.
analyzed: yam pana isa bhagavā dhammaṃ desentaḥ sāsana brahmacariyam magga brahmacariyañca pakāseti  dīpeti tam yathānurūpam attha sampattiyā sa attham byañjana sampattiyā sa byañjanam
translated: But when the Blessed One teaches the True Idea, he reveals the spiritual life and the True Idea that is the way to the spiritual life.🔽He illuminates them with various methods. That is good in meaning and good in phrasing.🔽It is good in meaning in so far as it is endowed with the meaning that is the outcome of the four kinds of profundity, namely, that of phrasing, of teaching, of language, and of penetration.

original: Saṅkāsanapakāsanavivaraṇavibhajanauttānīkaraṇapaññattiatthapadasamāyogato sātthaṃ.🔽Akkharapadabyañjanākāraniruttiniddesasampattiyā sabyañjanaṃ. Atthagambhīratāpaṭivedhagambhīratāhi
analyzed: saṅkāsana pakāsana vivaraṇa vibhajana auttānīkaraṇa paññatti attha pada samāyogataḥ sa attham  akkhara pada byañjana ākāra nirutti niddesa sampattiyā sa byañjanam attha gambhīra tā paṭivedha gambhīra tāhi
translated: It is good in phrasing in so far as it is endowed with the phrasing that is the outcome of the four kinds of profundity, namely, that of syllables, of words, of letters, and of expression.🔽It is good in meaning in so far as it is endowed with the meaning that is the outcome of the four kinds of profundity, namely, that of phrasing, of teaching, of language, and of penetration.🔽It is good in phrasing in so far as it is endowed with the phrasing that is the outcome of the four kinds of profundity, namely, that of syllables, of words, of letters, and of expression.

original: sātthaṃ. Dhammagambhīratādesanāgambhīratāhi sabyañjanaṃ. Atthapaṭibhānapaṭisambhidāvisayato
analyzed: sa attham dhamma gambhīra tā desanā gambhīra tāhi sa byañjanam attha paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā visayato
translated: It is good in meaning in so far as it is endowed with the meaning that is the outcome of the four kinds of profundity, namely, that of phrasing, of teaching, of language, and of penetration.🔽It is good in phrasing in so far as it is endowed with the phrasing that is the outcome of the four kinds of profundity, namely, that of syllables, of words, of letters, and of expression.

original: sātthaṃ. Dhammaniruttipaṭisambhidāvisayato sabyañjanaṃ. Paṇḍitavedanīyato sarikkhakajanappasādakanti🔽sātthaṃ. Saddheyyato lokiyajanappasādakanti sabyañjanaṃ. Gambhīrādhippāyato sātthaṃ.
analyzed: sa attham dhamma nirutti paṭisambhidā visayato sa byañjanam paṇḍita vedanīyato sa rikkhaka jana ppasādakam ti  sāttham saddheyyataḥ lokiya jana ppasādakanti sa byañjanam gambhīra adhippāyataḥ sāttham
translated: It is meaningful because it is the province of the discrimination of language and of the discrimination of perspicuity. It is perspicuous because it is intelligible to the wise.🔽It is meaningful because it inspires confidence in those who are like oneself. It is perspicuous because it inspires confidence in the world.

original: Uttānapadato sabyañjanaṃ. Upanetabbassa abhāvato sakalaparipuṇṇabhāvena kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: uttāna padataḥ sa byañjanam upanetabbassa abhāvataḥ sakala paripuṇṇa bhāvena kevala paripuṇṇam
translated: It is meaningful because it has a profound purport. It is perspicuous because its words are clear. It is fulfilled in the sense of being complete in all its parts because there is nothing to be added to it.

original: Apanetabbassa abhāvato niddosabhāvena parisuddhaṃ.
analyzed: apanetabbassa abhāvataḥ niddosa bhāvena parisuddham
translated: It is purified in the sense of being free from blemishes because there is nothing to be subtracted from it.

original: Api ca – paṭipattiyā adhigamabyattito sātthaṃ. Pariyattiyā āgamabyattito sabyañjanaṃ.🔽Sīlādipañcadhammakkhandhayuttato kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ. Nirupakkilesato nittharaṇatthāya
analyzed: api ca paṭipattiyāḥ adhigama byattitaḥ sa attham pariyattiyāḥ āgama byattitaḥ sa byañjanam  kevala paripuṇṇam nirupakkilesataḥ nittharaṇa tthāya
translated: Moreover, it is meaningful because of the abundance of realization through practice. It is perspicuous because of the abundance of learning through study.

original: pavattito lokāmisanirapekkhato ca parisuddhaṃ. Sikkhattayapariggahitattā brahmabhūtehi
analyzed: pavattitaḥ loka āmisa nirapekkhato ca parisuddham sikkhattaya pariggahita ttā brahma bhūtehi
translated: It is fulfilled in the sense of being complete in itself because it is endowed with the five aggregates of Dhamma beginning with virtue. It is purified in the sense of being free from defilements because it is the means for crossing over the flood .

original: seṭṭhehi caritabbato, tesañca cariyabhāvato brahmacariyaṃ.
analyzed: seṭṭhehi caritabbato tesam ca cariya bhāvataḥ brahmacariyam
translated: It is the life of purity because it is to be practised by the holy ones, the best of beings, and because it is the practice of those holy ones.

original: Evaṃ pariyattidhammaṃ dassetvā idāni lokuttaradhammaṃ dassetuṃ “cattāro satipaṭṭhāne”ti
analyzed: evam pariyatti dhammam dassetvā idāni lokuttara dhammam dassetum cattāro sati paṭṭhāne ti
translated: Having thus shown the Dhamma as text, he now said “The four foundations of mindfulness”

original: āha. Sattatiṃsabodhipakkhiyadhamme dassetvā nibbattitalokuttaraṃ dassetuṃ “nibbānañcā”ti
analyzed: āha sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhamme dassetvā nibbattita lokuttaram dassetum nibbānam ca iti
translated: in order to show the supramundane Dhamma. Having shown the seventy-three states that are factors of enlightenment, he said “And also Nibbana”

original: āha. Nibbānagāminiñca paṭipadanti pubbabhāgasīlasamādhivipassanādhammañca kittayissāmi.
analyzed: āha nibbāna gāminim ca paṭipadanti pubbabhāga sīla samādhi vipassanā dhammam ca kittayissāmi
translated: in order to show the supramundane state that occurs in the process of rebirth. The way that leads to Nibbana: I shall proclaim the Dhamma of virtue, concentration, and wisdom in the preliminary stage.

original: Dukkhe diṭṭheti dukkhasacce sarasalakkhaṇena diṭṭhe dukkhasaccaṃ pakāsessāmi. Samudayādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: dukkhe diṭṭhā iti dukkha sacce sa rasa lakkhaṇena diṭṭhe dukkha saccam pakāsessāmi samudaya ādīsu pi esa eva nayaḥ
translated: Having seen in suffering: having seen the truth of suffering by way of its characteristic of being an unpleasant thing. The same method applies to the origin, etc.

original: 23. Tañcāhaṃ abhinandāmīti taṃ vuttappakāradhammajotakaṃ tava vacanaṃ ahaṃ patthayāmi. Dhammamuttamanti tañca dhammamuttamaṃ abhinandāmi.🔽Tattha mahato tamokāyassa padālananti mahato avijjārāsissa chedanaṃ. Aniccalakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: tat ca aham abhinandāmi iti tam vutta ppakāra dhamma jotakam tava vacanam aham patthayāmi dhammam uttaman ti tat ca dhammam uttamam abhinandāmi  tattha mahataḥ tamokāyassa padālanam ti mahataḥ avijjā rāsissa chedanam anicca lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: I rejoice in that: I long for your words that reveal the Dhamma of the kind stated above. The supreme Dhamma: I rejoice in that supreme Dhamma.🔽Herein, the crushing of the great mass of darkness: the cutting off of the great mass of ignorance. The search by way of the characteristic of impermanence,

original: esī. Dukkhalakkhaṇavasena gavesī. Anattalakkhaṇavasena samantato pariyesī. Mahato
analyzed: esī dukkha lakkhaṇa vasena gavesī anatta lakkhaṇa vasena samantataḥ pariyesī mahataḥ
translated: the seeking by way of the characteristic of suffering, the thorough search by way of the characteristic of non-self. The great

original: vipallāsassa pabhedananti mahantassa asubhe subhantiādidvādasavidhassa vipallāsassa
analyzed: vipallāsassa mahantassa asubhe subha anti ādi dvādasavidhassa vipallāsassa
translated: ‘The breaking up of the perversions’: the breaking up of the great twelvefold perversion, namely, ‘The foul is the beautiful’ and so on.

original: bhedanaṃ. Mahato taṇhāsallassa abbahananti mahantassa antotudanaṭṭhena taṇhākaṇṭakassa🔽luñcanaṃ. Diṭṭhisaṅghāṭassa viniveṭhananti diṭṭhiyeva abbocchinnappavattito saṅghaṭitaṭṭhena
analyzed: bhedanam mahataḥ taṇhā sallassa mahantassa antotudanaṭṭhena taṇhākaṇṭakassa  luñcanam diṭṭhi saṅghāṭassa viniveṭhanan ti diṭṭhiyā iva abbocchinna ppavattitaḥ saṅghaṭita ṭṭhena
translated: ‘The drawing out of the great dart of craving’: the plucking out of the great dart of craving, which pierces the inside and is called ‘thirst.’🔽‘The turning back of the mass of views’: the mass of views is a mass in the sense of being a compact mass, since it occurs without interruption. The turning back of that mass of views.

original: saṅghāṭo, tassa diṭṭhisaṅghāṭassa nivattanaṃ. Mānadhajassa pātananti ussitaṭṭhena
analyzed: saṅghāṭaḥ tassa diṭṭhi saṅghāṭassa nivattanam māna dhajassa pātanam ti ussita ṭṭhena
translated: ‘The felling of the banner of conceit’: the felling of the banner of conceit, which is characterized by haughtiness and is raised high.🔽‘The allaying of the formations’: the allaying of the formations of merit, etc.

original: unnatilakkhaṇassa mānaddhajassa pātanaṃ. Abhisaṅkhārassa vūpasamanti puññādiabhisaṅkhārassa🔽upasamanaṃ. Oghassa nittharaṇanti vaṭṭe osīdāpanassa kāmoghādioghassa nittharaṇaṃ🔽nikkhamanaṃ. Bhārassa nikkhepananti rūpādipañcakkhandhabhārassa khipanaṃ chaḍḍanaṃ.
analyzed: unnati lakkhaṇassa mānaddha jassa pātanam abhisaṅkhārassa vūpasamanti puñña ādi abhisaṅkhārassa  upasamanam oghassa nittharaṇanti vaṭṭe osīdāpanassa kāma ogha ādi oghassa nittharaṇam  nikkhamanam bhārassa nikkhepanam ti rūpa ādi pañca kkhandha bhārassa khipanam chaḍḍanam
translated: ‘The crossing of the flood’: the crossing of the flood of sense desires, etc., which is the sinking of the wheel .🔽‘The laying down of the burden’: the casting off of the burden consisting of the five aggregates of clinging.

original: Saṃsāravaṭṭassa upacchedanti khandhādipaṭipāṭisaṃsāravaṭṭassa hetunassanena ucchijjanaṃ.
analyzed: saṃsāra vaṭṭassa khandha ādi paṭipāṭi saṃsāra vaṭṭassa ucchijjanam
translated: ‘The breaking of the round’: the breaking of the round of the aggregates, etc., by the destruction of the cause.

original: Santāpassa nibbāpananti kilesasantāpassa nibbutiṃ. Pariḷāhassa paṭipassaddhanti kilesapariḷāhassa🔽vūpasamaṃ paṭipassambhanaṃ. Dhammadhajassa ussāpananti navavidhalokuttaradhammassa🔽ussāpetvā ṭhapanaṃ. Paramatthaṃ amataṃ nibbānanti uttamaṭṭhena paramatthaṃ. Natthi🔽etassa maraṇasaṅkhātaṃ matanti amataṃ. Kilesavisapaṭipakkhattā agadantipi amataṃ.🔽Saṃsāradukkhapaṭipakkhabhūtattā nibbutanti nibbānaṃ. Natthettha taṇhāsaṅkhātaṃ vānantipi nibbānaṃ.🔽Mahesakkhehi sattehīti mahānubhāvehi sakkādīhi sattehi. Pariyesitoti pariyiṭṭho. Kahaṃ devadevoti devānaṃ atidevo kuhiṃ. Kahaṃ narāsabhoti uttamapuriso.
analyzed: santāpassa nibbāpananti kilesa santāpassa nibbutim pariḷāhassa paṭipassaddhanti kilesa pariḷāhassa  vūpasamam paṭipassambhanam dhamma dhajassa ussāpananti navavidha lokuttara dhammassa  ussāpetvā ṭhapanam paramattham amatam nibbānam ti uttamaṭṭhena paramattham natthi  etassa maraṇa saṅkhātam matanti amatam kilesa visa paṭipakkha ttā agadanti pi amatam  saṃsāra dukkha paṭipakkha bhūta ttā nibbutanti nibbānam nattha ittha taṇhā saṅkhātam vānanti api nibbānam  mahesakkhehi sattehi iti mahā anubhāvehi sakka ādīhi sattehi pariyesitaḥ iti pariyiṭṭhaḥ kaham devadevaḥ iti devānam atidevaḥ kuhim kaham narāsabhaḥ iti uttama purisaḥ
translated: “The quenching of the fever” is the quenching of the defilement-fever. “The allaying of the fever” is the allaying, the subsiding, of the fever of defilement. “The hoisting of the banner of the True Idea” is the hoisting and setting up of the nine-factored Supramundane True Idea. “The supreme state of deathlessness” is the state of deathlessness in the sense of being supreme. “It has no death” is deathlessness in the sense of there being no death called “death” in it. It is also deathless in the sense of being an antidote to the poison of defilement. “It is extinction” is extinction in the sense of extinction of the suffering of the round of rebirths. “It has no craving” is extinction in the sense of there being no craving called “craving” in it.🔽“By the great beings” is by the beings of great potency, Sakka and so on. “Is sought” is is sought out. “Where, O God, is the God of gods?” is where is the God above the gods? “Where is the bull among men?” is where is the supreme man?🔽

original: 24. Uddhaṃ adho tiriyañcāpi majjheti ettha uddhanti anāgataddhā vuccati. Adhoti atītaddhā.
analyzed: uddham adhas tiriyam ca api majjhe iti ettha uddhan ti anāgata ddhā vuccati adhas ti atīta ddhā
translated: “The quenching of the fever” is the quenching of the defilement fever. “The allaying of the fever” is the allaying, the subsiding, of the defilement fever. “The hoisting of the banner of the True Idea” is the hoisting and setting up of the nine-factored Supramundane True Idea. “The supreme state of deathlessness” is the state of deathlessness in the sense of being supreme. “It has no death” is the state of deathlessness in the sense of there being no death in it. “It is the antidote” is the state of deathlessness in the sense of being the antidote to the poison of defilement. “It is extinction” is the state of deathlessness in the sense of being the extinction of the suffering of the round of rebirths. “It has no in-breath and out-breath” is the state of deathlessness in the sense of there being no in-breath and out-breath in it. “The gods with great powers” are the gods Sakka and so on. “Searched for” is sought. “Where is the god of gods?” is “Where is the god above the gods?” “Where is the bull of men?” is “Where is the best of men?” “Above, below, around, and in the middle” : here “above” is said to be the future direction, “below” is the past direction,

original: Tiriyañcāpi majjheti paccuppannaddhā. Etesu nandiñca nivesanañca, panujja viññāṇanti
analyzed: tiriyam ca api majjhe ti etesu nandiñca nivesanañca panujja viññāṇanti
translated: and the present as “the middle.” “Having abandoned delight and settled views, consciousness”:

original: etesu uddhādīsu taṇhañca diṭṭhinivesanañca abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇañca panudehi. Panuditvā
analyzed: etesu uddha ādīsu taṇham ca diṭṭhi nivesanañca abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇañca panudehi panuditvā
translated: Abandon craving, settled views, and the consciousness that is a formation in regard to the up-going, etc. Having abandoned them,

original: ca bhave na tiṭṭheti evaṃ sante duvidhepi bhave na tiṭṭheyya. Evaṃ tāva panujjasaddassa
analyzed: ca bhave na tiṭṭheti evam sante duvidhe api bhave na tiṭṭheyya evam tāva panujja saddassa
translated: he does not stand in becoming: if it is so, he does not stand in the two kinds of becoming. This, firstly, is the construction of the meaning in the expression “having abandoned” .

original: panudehīti imasmiṃ atthavikappe sambandho. Panuditvāti etasmiṃ pana atthavikappe🔽bhave na tiṭṭheti ayameva sambandho. Etāni nandīnivesanaviññāṇāni panuditvā duvidhepi
analyzed: panudehi iti imasmin attha vikappe sambandhaḥ panuditvā iti etasmin pana attha vikappe  bhave na tiṭṭha iti ayam eva sambandhaḥ etāni nandī nivesana viññāṇāni panuditvā duvidhe pi
translated: But in the construction of the meaning in the expression “having abandoned,”

original: bhave na tiṭṭheyyāti.
analyzed: bhave na tiṭṭheyya ati
translated: the construction is simply “he does not stand in becoming.” The meaning is that he does not stand in the two kinds of becoming having abandoned the delight, settled views, and consciousness.

original: Sahokāsavasena devaloko uddhaṃ. Apāyaloko adho. Manussaloko majjhe. Tattha kusalā🔽dhammāti apāyaṃ muñcitvā upari paṭisandhidānato kusalā dhammā uddhanti vuccanti.
analyzed: sahokāsa vasena deva lokaḥ uddham apāya lokaḥ adhas manussa lokaḥ majjhe tattha kusalā  dhammā ti apāyam muñcitvā upari paṭisandhi dānato kusalāḥ dhammāḥ uddhanti vuccanti
translated: The deva world is “up” because it is the opposite of the underworld. The underworld is “down.” The human world is “the middle.” Therein, the profitable dhammas🔽are called “up-going” because they go up by giving rebirth-linking above, having freed from the underworld.

original: Akusalā dhammā apāyesu paṭisandhidānato adhoti. Tadubhayavimuttattā abyākatā dhammā
analyzed: akusalāḥ dhammāḥ apāyesu paṭisandhi dānataḥ adho ti tad ubhaya vimutta ttā abyākatāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: The unprofitable dhammas are called “down-going” because they go down by giving rebirth-linking in the underworld. The indeterminate dhammas are called “neither-down-going-nor-up-going”🔽because they are free from both.

original: tiriyañcāpi majjheti vuccanti. Sabboparivasena arūpadhātu uddhaṃ. Sabbaadhovasena
analyzed: tiriyam ca api majjhā iti vuccanti sabba upari vasena arūpadhātu uddham sabba adhas vasena
translated: and the immaterial world is called “above” because it is above all the worlds.🔽The sense-desire world is called “below” because it is below all the worlds.🔽The material world is called “in between” because it is in between the two.

original: kāmadhātu adho. Tadubhayantaravasena rūpadhātu majjhe. Kāyacittābādhakhananavasena
analyzed: kāmadhātu adho tad ubhaya antara vasena rūpadhātu majjhe kāya citta ābādha khanana vasena
translated: Pleasant feeling is called “above” because it is the opposite of bodily and mental affliction.🔽Painful feeling is called “below” because it is the opposite of pleasure.

original: sukhā vedanā uddhaṃ. Dukkhamanavasena dukkhā vedanā adho. Adukkhamasukhā vedanā majjhe.
analyzed: sukhāḥ vedanāḥ uddham dukkham anavasena dukkhāḥ vedanāḥ adhas adukkham asukhāḥ vedanāḥ majjhe
translated: Neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is called “in between” because it is in between the two.

original: Attabhāvavasena paricchedaṃ dassento “uddhanti uddhaṃ pādatalā”tiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: atta bhāva vasena paricchedam dassentaḥ uddhan ti uddham pāda tala ati ādim āha tattha
translated: Showing the delimitation by means of the individual essence, he said, “Above, from the soles of the feet upwards,” etc. Herein,🔽above, from the soles of the feet: above the soles of the feet.🔽Below, from the tips of the hair downwards: below the tips of the hair.

original: uddhaṃ pādatalāti pādatalato upari. Adho kesamatthakāti kesamatthakato adho. Majjheti dvinnaṃ antaraṃ.🔽Puññābhisaṅkhārasahagataṃ viññāṇanti terasavidhapuññābhisaṅkhārasampayuttaṃ kammaviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: uddham pāda talā ati pāda talataḥ upari adhas kesamatthakā ati kesamatthakataḥ adhas majjhā iti dvinnam antaram  puñña abhisaṅkhāra sahagatam viññāṇanti terasavidha puñña abhisaṅkhāra sampayuttam kamma viññāṇam
translated: In between: the space between the two.🔽Consciousness associated with the formation of merit: kamma-consciousness associated with the thirteen kinds of formation of merit.

original: Apuññābhisaṅkhārasahagataṃ viññāṇanti dvādasavidhaapuññābhisaṅkhārasampayuttaṃ kammaviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: apuñña abhisaṅkhāra sahagatam viññāṇanti dvādasavidha apuñña abhisaṅkhāra sampayuttam kamma viññāṇam
translated: Consciousness associated with the formation of demerit: kamma-consciousness associated with the twelve kinds of formation of demerit.

original: Āneñjābhisaṅkhārasahagataṃ viññāṇanti catubbidhaṃ āneñjābhisaṅkhārasahagataṃ kammaviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: āneñja abhisaṅkhāra sahagatam viññāṇanti catubbidham āneñja abhisaṅkhāra sahagatam kamma viññāṇam
translated: “Consciousness accompanied by the imperturbable” is the fourfold consciousness accompanied by the imperturbable, which is kamma-result.

original: Nujjāti khipa. Panujjāti atīva khipa. Nudāti luñca. Panudāti atīva luñca. Pajahāti
analyzed: nujjāti khipa panujjāti atīva khipa nudāti luñca panudāti atīva luñca pajahāti
translated: “Throw off” means “quickly get rid of.” “Throw off completely” means “get rid of very quickly.” “Shake off” means “shake out.” “Shake off completely” means “shake out very quickly.” “Throw away” means

original: chaḍḍehi. Vinodehīti dūraṃ karohi.
analyzed: chaḍḍehi vinodehi iti dūram karohi
translated: “abandon.” “Remove” means “make far away.”

original: Kammabhavañcāti puññābhisaṅkhāracetanāva. Paṭisandhikañca punabbhavanti paṭisandhiyā
analyzed: kamma bhavam ca ati puñña abhisaṅkhāra cetanā ava paṭisandhikam ca punar bhavanti paṭisandhiyā
translated: “Kamma-process becoming” is the volition of the formation of merit, etc. “Re-becoming” is the re-becoming of form, etc., that is, rebirth-linking.

original: rūpādipunabbhavañca. Pajahanto paṭhamamaggena, vinodento dutiyamaggena, byantī karonto
analyzed: rūpa ādi punabbhavam ca pajahantaḥ paṭhama maggena vinodentaḥ dutiya maggena byantī karontaḥ
translated: By “throwing off,” “removing,” “making to cease,” and “making to finish,” he shows the four paths respectively.

original: tatiyamaggena, anabhāvaṃ gamento catutthamaggena. Kammabhave na tiṭṭheyyāti puññādiabhisaṅkhāre na tiṭṭheyya.
analyzed: tatiya maggena anabhāvam gamento catuttha maggena kamma bhave na tiṭṭheyya ati puñña ādi abhisaṅkhāre na tiṭṭheyya
translated: By “not standing in kamma-process becoming” he shows that he does not stand in the formations of merit, etc.

original: 25. Etāni vinodetvā bhave atiṭṭhanto eso – evaṃ vihārīti gāthā. Tattha idhevāti imasmiṃyeva sāsane, imasmiṃyeva vā attabhāve. Imissā gāthāya niddeso uttānatthova.
analyzed: etāni vinodetvā bhave atiṭṭhantaḥ esaḥ evam vihārī iti gāthā tattha idha iva ati imasmiṃ yeva sāsane imasmiṃ yeva vā attabhāve imissā gāthāya niddesaḥ uttāna atthaḥ uva
translated: “Here itself” is in this dispensation or in this very individual existence. The commentary on this verse is clear in meaning.

original: 26. Sukittitaṃ gotamanūpadhīkanti ettha anūpadhīkanti nibbānaṃ, taṃ sandhāya bhagavantaṃ ālapanto āha – “sukittitaṃ gotamanūpadhīka”nti.
analyzed: su kittitam gotama anūpadhīkanti ettha anūpadhīkanti nibbānam tam sandhāya bhagavantam ālapantaḥ āha su kittitam gotama anūpadhīkanti
translated: “Well-proclaimed is the state of peace by the Gotama” : here the state of peace is Nibbna, and referring to that he said: “Well-proclaimed is the state of peace by the Gotama.”

original: Niddese kilesā cāti upatāpanaṭṭhena rāgādayo kilesā ca rāsaṭṭhena vipākabhūtā pañcakkhandhā
analyzed: niddese kilesā ca ati upatāpana ṭhena rāga ādayo kilesā ca rāsa ṭhena vipāka bhūtā pañca kkhandhā
translated: In the Niddesa, defilements are called “upadhi” in the sense of afflicting, and the five aggregates which are the result of past action are called “upadhi” in the sense of a heap.

original: ca kusalādiabhisaṅkhārā cetanā ca “upadhī”ti vuccanti kathīyanti. Upadhippahānaṃ
analyzed: ca kusala ādi abhisaṅkhārā cetanā ca upadhi iti vuccanti kathīyanti upadhi ppahānam
translated: The volitions of the wholesome, etc., are called “cetana” . The abandoning of upadhi is by the abandoning of its conditions.

original: tadaṅgappahānena, upadhivūpasamaṃ vikkhambhanappahānena, upadhipaṭinissaggaṃ samucchedappahānena
analyzed: tad aṅga ppahānena upadhi vūpasamam vikkhambhana ppahānena upadhi paṭinissaggam samuccheda ppahānena
translated: The stilling of upadhi is by the abandoning of suppression. The relinquishing of upadhi is by the abandoning of cutting off.

original: upadhipaṭipassaddhaṃ phalenāti.
analyzed: upadhi paṭipassaddham phalena ati
translated: The subsiding of upadhi is by the abandoning of the fruit.

original: 27. Na kevalaṃ dukkhameva pahāsi – te cāpīti gāthā. Tattha aṭṭhitanti sakkaccaṃ,
analyzed: na kevalam dukkham eva pahāsi te ca api iti gāthā tattha aṭṭhitam ti sakkaccam
translated: Not only does he abandon suffering, but also those other things as well. The verse: “I pay homage to him who has abandoned the two” .🔽Herein, “steadfastly” means with devotion,

original: sadā vā. Taṃ taṃ namassāmīti tasmā taṃ namassāmi. Sameccāti upagantvā. Nāgāti bhagavantaṃ ālapanto āha.
analyzed: sadā vā tam tam namassāmi iti tasmai tam namassāmi upagantvā nāgā iti bhagavantam ālapantaḥ āha
translated: or always. “I pay homage to him” : for that reason I pay homage to him. “I have come” : having approached. “The Naga” : he said, referring to the Blessed One.

original: Niddese sameccāti jānitvā, ekato hutvā vā. Abhisameccāti paṭivijjhitvā. Samāgantvāti
analyzed: niddese samet ca ati jānitvā ekatas hutvā vā abhisamet ca ati paṭivijjhitvā samāgantvā ati
translated: In the Niddesa, sameccā ti jānitvā, ekato hutvā vā. Abhisameccā ti paṭivijjhitvā. Samāgantvā ti

original: sammukhā hutvā. Abhisamāgantvāti samīpaṃ gantvā. Sammukhāti sammukhe. Āguṃ na karotīti pāpaṃ na karoti.
analyzed: sammukhāḥ hutvā abhisamāgantvā ati samīpam gantvā sammukhā ati sammukhe āgum na karoti iti pāpam na karoti
translated: sammukhā hutvā. Abhisamāgantvā ti samīpaṃ gantvā. Sammukhā ti sammukhe. Āguṃ na karotī ti pāpaṃ na karoti.

original: 28. Idāni naṃ bhagavā “addhā hi bhagavā pahāsi dukkha”nti evaṃ tena brāhmaṇena viditopi
analyzed: idāni nam bhagavā addhā hi bhagavā pahāsi dukkhanti evam tena brāhmaṇena viditaḥ api
translated: . Now, although the Blessed One was known by that brāhmaṇa thus: “Surely, the Blessed One has abandoned suffering,”

original: attānaṃ anupanetvāva pahīnadukkhena puggalena ovadanto “yaṃ brāhmaṇa”nti gāthamāha.
analyzed: attānam an upanetvā ava pahīna dukkhena puggalena ovadantaḥ yam gātham āha
translated: the Blessed One, without introducing himself, spoke the stanza beginning with “Yaṃ brāhmaṇa,” advising the person who had abandoned suffering.

original: Tassattho – yaṃ taṃ abhijānanto “ayaṃ bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇo, vedehi gatattā vedagū,
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yam tam abhijānantaḥ ayam bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇaḥ vedehi gatattā vedagū
translated: The meaning is: “You should know, you should understand, that this brāhmaṇa who has expelled evil is a knower of the Vedas because he has gone to the Vedas,

original: kiñcanābhāvā akiñcano, kāmesu ca bhavesu ca asattattā kāmabhave asatto”ti jaññā jāneyyāsi.
analyzed: kiñcana abhāvā akiñcano kāmesu ca bhavesu ca asatta ttā kāma bhave asatto ti jaññā jāneyyāsi
translated: is a poor man because he has no possessions, and is not attached to sense-pleasures and to existence because he is not attached to sense-pleasures and to existence.”

original: Addhā hi so oghamimaṃ atāri, tiṇṇo ca pāraṃ akhilo akaṅkho.
analyzed: addhā hi saḥ ogham imam atāri ca pāram akhilaḥ
translated: Surely, he has crossed this flood, and he has crossed over to the other shore, free from defilements, free from doubt.

original: Niddese rāgakiñcananti rāgapalibodhaṃ. Dosakiñcanantiādipi eseva nayo. Kāmoghaṃ tiṇṇo
analyzed: niddese rāga kiñcananti rāga palibodham esa iva nayo kā mogham
translated: In the Niddesa, rāgakiñcanaṃ means the hindrance of lust. Dosakiñcanaṃ means the hindrance of hatred. Kāmoghaṃ tiṇṇo means he has crossed the flood of sense-pleasures.

original: anāgāmimaggena. Bhavoghaṃ tiṇṇo arahattamaggena. Diṭṭhoghaṃ tiṇṇo sotāpattimaggena.
analyzed: anāgāmi maggena bhava ogham tiṇṇaḥ arahatta maggena diṭṭha ogham sotāpatti maggena
translated: with the Non-Return Path. He has crossed the flood of being with the Arahant Path. He has crossed the flood of views with the Stream Entry Path.

original: Avijjoghaṃ tiṇṇo arahattamaggena. Saṃsārapathaṃ tiṇṇo kusalākusalakammappabhedenāti.🔽Uttiṇṇo paṭhamamaggena. Nittiṇṇo dutiyamaggena. Atikkanto tatiyamaggena. Samatikkanto
analyzed: avijja ogham tiṇṇaḥ arahatta maggena saṃsāra patham tiṇṇaḥ kusala akusala kamma ppabhedena ati  uttiṇṇaḥ paṭhama maggena nittiṇṇaḥ dutiya maggena atikkanto tatiya maggena samatikkanto
translated: He has crossed the flood of ignorance with the Arahant Path. He has crossed the path of the round of rebirths with the distinction of profitable and unprofitable action.

original: catutthamaggena.Vītivatto phalena.
analyzed: phalena
translated: He has crossed over with the first Path. He has gone beyond with the second Path. He has gone beyond with the third Path. He has gone beyond with the fourth Path. He has gone beyond with the fruition.

original: 29. Kiñca bhiyyo – vidvā ca yoti gāthā. Tattha idhāti imasmiṃ sāsane, attabhāve vā. Visajjāti vosajjitvā.
analyzed: kiñca bhiyyas vidvā ca gāthā tattha idha ati imasmin sāsane atta bhāve vā visajjāti vosajjitvā
translated: And what is more, the verse “The wise one who” . Herein, here in this Dispensation, or in his own person. He has let go of : he has let go of, has relinquished.

original: Niddese sajjanti muñcanaṃ. Visajjanti vosajjanaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva. Evaṃ🔽bhagavā idampi suttaṃ arahattanikūṭeneva desesi. Desanāpariyosāne ca vuttasadiso
analyzed: niddese sajjanti muñcanam visajjanti vosajjanam sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva evam  bhagavā idam pi suttam arahatta nikūṭena iva desesi desanā pariyosāne ca vutta sadisaḥ
translated: In the Niddesa the word sajjati is explained as meaning “to let go” , and visajjati is explained as meaning “to let go of” . The rest is clear throughout.

original: eva dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: eva dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: Thus the Blessed One taught this Thread too with the peak of Arahantship. And at the end of the teaching the kind of comprehension of the True Idea that occurred was of the kind already stated.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the Minor Commentary on the First Fifty Discourses of the Middle Length

original: Mettagūmāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mettagūmāṇava sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Metta-Guna-Mallaputta Sutta is finished.

original: 5. Dhotakamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: 5. The commentary on the Dhotakamāṇava Sutta

original: 30. Pañcame dhotakasutte – vācābhikaṅkhāmīti vācaṃ abhikaṅkhāmi. Sikkhe nibbānamattanoti attano rāgādīnaṃ nibbānatthāya adhisīlādīni sikkheyya. Niddese apubbaṃ natthi.
analyzed: pañcame dhotaka sutte vācā abhikaṅkhāmi iti vācam abhikaṅkhāmi sikkhe nibbānam attano ti attanaḥ rāga ādīnam nibbāna atthāya adhi sīla ādīni sikkheyya niddese apubbam natthi
translated: In the fifth sutta in the Dhotakavagga, the Dhotakasutta, the words are: “I long for speech” means I long for speech. “Train for the quenching of your own self” means you should train in the higher virtue, etc., for the quenching of your own lust, etc. There is nothing in the Niddesa not already dealt with.

original: Itoti mama mukhato.🔽Niddese ātappanti kilesatāpanaṃ. Ussāhanti asaṅkocaṃ. Ussoḷhīnti balavavīriyaṃ. Thāmanti
analyzed: itas iti mama mukhataḥ  niddese ātappanti kilesa tāpanam ussāhanti asaṅkocam ussoḷhīnti balava vīriyam thāmanti
translated: “From here” means from my mouth.

original: asithilaṃ. Dhitinti dhāraṇaṃ. Vīriyaṃ karohīti parakkamaṃ karohi. Chandaṃ janehīti ruciṃ uppādehi.
analyzed: asithilam dhitinti dhāraṇam vīriyam karohi iti parakkamam karohi chandam janehi iti rucim uppādehi
translated: In the Niddesa, “heat” is the burning of defilements. “Exertion” is the absence of timidity. “Exertion” is strong energy. “Steadfastness” is the absence of slackness. “Perseverance” is the bearing up. “Make an effort” means make an effort. “Arouse zeal” means arouse a liking.

original: 32. Evaṃ vutte attamano dhotako bhagavantaṃ abhitthavamāno kathaṃkathāpamokkhaṃ yācanto
analyzed: evam vutte atta manaḥ dhotakaḥ bhagavantam abhitthavamāno kathaṃkathā apamokkham yācantaḥ
translated: When this was said, the Dhotaka, pleased with the Blessed One, praising him, and asking for the removal of his doubts,

original: “passāmaha”nti gāthamāha. Tattha passāmahaṃ devamanussaloketi passāmi ahaṃ devamanussaloke.
analyzed: passāmahanti gātham āha tattha passāmaham deva manussa loke iti passāmi aham deva manussa loke
translated: said the verse: “I see.” Herein, I see the world of gods and men.

original: Taṃ taṃ namassāmīti taṃ evarūpaṃ taṃ namassāmi. Pamuñcāti pamocehi.
analyzed: tam tam namassāmi iti tam evarūpam tam namassāmi pamuñca ati pamocehi
translated: I pay homage to him, I pay homage to him of such a kind. “Release” means release.

original: Niddese paccekabuddhāti taṃ taṃ ārammaṇaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ catusaccaṃ sayameva buddhā paṭivedhappattāti
analyzed: niddese paccekabuddhā ati tam tam ārammaṇam pāṭiyekkam catu saccam sayam eva buddhā paṭivedha ppattā ati
translated: In the description, “Paccekabuddha” : they are Paccekabuddhas because they have themselves individually awakened to the four Truths with regard to this or that object.🔽“Sīhasīha” : he is a lion among lions because he is fearless.

original: paccekabuddhā. Sīhasīhoti achambhitaṭṭhena sīhānaṃ atisīho. Nāganāgoti nikkilesaṭṭhena,
analyzed: paccekabuddhā sīha sīhaḥ oti a chambhita ṭṭhena sīhānam ati sīhaḥ nāga nāgaḥ iti nikkilesa ṭṭhena
translated: “Nāganāga” : he is a nāga among nāgas because he is free from defilements,🔽or because he is great.

original: mahantaṭṭhena vā nāgānaṃ atināgo. Gaṇigaṇīti gaṇavantānaṃ atīva gaṇavā. Munimunīti
analyzed: mahanta ṭṭhena vā nāgānam ati nāgaḥ gaṇi gaṇī iti gaṇavantānam atīva gaṇavā muni muni iti
translated: “Gaṇigaṇī” : he is a gaṇī among gaṇīs because he is a gaṇī in the highest degree.🔽“Munimuni” : he is a muni among munis because he is a muni in the highest degree.🔽“Rājarājā” : he is the supreme king.

original: ñāṇavantānaṃ atīva ñāṇavā. Rājarājāti uttamarājā. Muñca manti mocehi maṃ. Pamuñca
analyzed: atīva ñāṇavā rāja rājā ati uttama rājā muñca manti mocehi mam pamuñca
translated: “Muñca maṃ” : release me.🔽“Pamuñca maṃ” : release me in various ways.🔽“Mocehi maṃ” : loosen me.

original: manti nānāvidhena muñcehi maṃ. Mocehi manti sithilaṃ karohi maṃ. Pamocehi manti atīva🔽sithilaṃ karohi maṃ. Uddhara manti maṃ saṃsārapaṅkā uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpehi.
analyzed: nānāvidhena muñcehi mam mocehi manti sithilam karohi mam atīva  sithilam karohi mam uddhara manti mam saṃsāra paṅkāḥ uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpehi
translated: “Pamocehi maṃ” : loosen me very much.🔽“Uddhara maṃ” : lift me up, lift me out of the mud of saṃsāra and establish me on dry land.🔽“Samuddhara maṃ” : lift me up properly, lift me out of the mud of saṃsāra and establish me on dry land.

original: Samuddhara manti sammā uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpehi maṃ. Vuṭṭhāpehīti vicikicchāsallato🔽apanetvā visuṃ karaṇavasena uṭṭhāpehi.
analyzed: samuddhara manti uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpehi mam vuṭṭhāpehi iti vicikicchā sallataḥ 🔽apanetvā visum karaṇa vasena uṭṭhāpehi
translated: “Vuṭṭhāpehī” : lift me up by removing me from the dart of doubt and making me stand alone.

original: 33. Athassa bhagavā attādhīnameva kathaṃkathāpamokkhaṃ oghataraṇamukhena dassento
analyzed: atha assa bhagavā attā adhīnam eva kathaṃkathā apamokkham ogha taraṇa mukhena dassentaḥ
translated: Then the Blessed One, showing him the escape from the round of questions by means of the crossing of the flood, which is dependent on oneself,

original: “nāha”nti gāthamāha. Tattha nāhaṃ sahissāmīti ahaṃ na sahissāmi na sakkomi. Na vāyamissāmīti
analyzed: na aham ti gātham āha tattha na aham sahissāmi iti aham na sahissāmi na sakkomi na vā āyamissāmi iti
translated: said the verse: “I will not bear it” . Herein, I will not bear it : I will not bear it, I cannot bear it. I will not strive :

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Pamocanāyāti pamocetuṃ. Kathaṃkathinti sakaṅkhaṃ. Taresīti tareyyāsi.🔽Niddese na īhāmīti payogaṃ na karomi. Na samīhāmīti atīva payogaṃ na karomi. Assaddhe
analyzed: vuttam hoti pamocanāya ati pamocetum kathaṃkathinti sa kaṅkham taresi iti tareyyāsi  niddese na īhāmi iti payogam na karomi na samīhāmi iti atīva payogam na karomi assaddhe
translated: what is meant is, I will not make an effort. For the sake of deliverance : for the purpose of deliverance. From the round of questions : from the round of doubt. You will cross : you will cross over.

original: puggaleti ratanattaye saddhāvirahite puggale. Acchandiketi maggaphalatthaṃ rucivirahite.
analyzed: puggala iti rata nattaye saddhā virahite puggale acchandikā iti magga phala attham ruci virahite
translated: In the commentary on the meaning I will not strive : I will not make an effort. I will not strive hard : I will not make a great effort. In a person without faith : in a person devoid of faith in the Triple Gem. Without keenness : devoid of keenness for the path and fruit.

original: Kusīteti samādhivirahite. Hīnavīriyeti nibbīriye. Appaṭipajjamāneti paṭipattiyā na paṭipajjamāne.🔽34. Evaṃ vutte attamanataro dhotako bhagavantaṃ abhitthavamāno anusāsaniṃ yācanto
analyzed: kusītā iti samādhi virahite hīna vīriye iti nibbīriye appaṭipajjamāne iti paṭipattiyāḥ na paṭipajjamāne  evam vutte attamanataraḥ dhotakaḥ bhagavantam abhitthavamānaḥ anusāsanim yācantaḥ
translated: Lazy : devoid of concentration. Of little energy : lacking in energy. Not practising : not practising the practice.

original: “anusāsa brahme”ti gāthamāha. Tattha brahmeti seṭṭhavacanametaṃ. Tena bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: anusāsa brahma iti gātham āha tattha brahmā iti seṭṭha vacanam etam tena bhagavantam
translated: When this was said, the Dhotaka became more confident still. And, in order to get the Blessed One to give him further instruction, he said the verse: “Instruct me, O Brahmā” . Herein, O Brahmā is a term of respect. By it he said: “Venerable Sir, I am not satisfied with the Blessed One’s answer to my question. So please instruct me further.”

original: āmantayamāno āha “anusāsa brahme”ti. Vivekadhammanti sabbasaṅkhāravivekaṃ nibbānadhammaṃ.
analyzed: āmantayamānaḥ āha anusāsa brahma iti viveka dhammam ti sabba saṅkhāra vivekam nibbāna dhammam
translated: The state of seclusion: the state of Nibbāna, which is the seclusion from all formations.🔽Not invading: not invading in various ways.🔽Being right here: being just here.

original: Abyāpajjamānoti nānappakārakaṃ anāpajjamāno. Idheva santoti idheva samāno. Asitoti anissito.
analyzed: a byāpajjamānaḥ ti nānappakārakam an āpajjamānaḥ idhā iva santo ti idhā iva samānaḥ asitaḥ ti anissitaḥ
translated: Not clinging: not clinging to anything.🔽The next two stanzas are in the same way as in the Metta Sutta.

original: 35-7. Ito parā dve gāthā mettagūsutte vuttanayā eva. Kevalañhi tattha dhammaṃ, idha
analyzed: itas parā dve gāthāḥ mettagū sutte vutta nayāḥ eva kevalam hi tattha dhammam idha
translated: The only difference is that there the word is dhamma, here it is santanti .🔽In the third stanza, the first half is in the same way as there.

original: santinti ayaṃ viseso. Tatiyagāthāyapi pubbaḍḍhaṃ tattha vuttanayameva. Aparaḍḍhe
analyzed: ayam visesaḥ tatiya gāthāya api pubbaḍḍham tattha vutta nayam eva aparaḍḍhe
translated: In the second half,🔽saṅgo means a place of attachment, a place of clinging.

original: saṅgoti sajjanaṭṭhānaṃ, laggananti vuttaṃ hoti. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva.
analyzed: saṅgo ti sajjana ṭṭhānam laggananti vuttam hoti sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva
translated: The rest is clear everywhere.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā idampi suttaṃ arahattanikūṭeneva desesi, desanāpariyosāne ca vuttasadiso eva dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: evam bhagavā idam pi suttam arahatta nikūṭena iva desesi desanā pariyosāne ca vutta sadisaḥ eva dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: Thus the Blessed One taught this sutta too with the peak of arahantship. And at the conclusion of the teaching, the penetration of the Dhamma was of a kind similar to that already described.🔽The commentary on the brief explanation in the Niddesa,

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya
translated: the illumination of the true Dhamma,🔽is finished.🔽The commentary on the brief explanation in the Niddesa,🔽the illumination of the true Dhamma,

original: Dhotakamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽6. Upasīvamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dhotakamāṇavasutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽upasīvamāṇava sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: is finished.

original: 38. Chaṭṭhe upasīvasutte – mahantamoghanti mahantaṃ oghaṃ. Anissitoti puggalaṃ vā🔽dhammaṃ vā anallīno. No visahāmīti na sakkomi. Ārammaṇanti nissayaṃ. Yaṃ nissitoti
analyzed: chaṭṭhe upasīva sutte mahantam ogham ti mahantam ogham anissito ti puggalam vā  dhammam vā an allīnaḥ no visahāmi iti na sakkomi ārammaṇam ti nissayam yam nissito ti
translated: 38. In the Chaṭṭha-Upasīva Sutta , “Great flood” is a great stream. “Not fixed” is not attached to a person or a thing. “I cannot” is I am not able. “Support” is a reliance.

original: yaṃ dhammaṃ vā puggalaṃ vā nissito.🔽Niddese kāmoghanti anāgāmimaggena kāmoghaṃ. Arahattamaggena bhavoghaṃ. Sotāpattimaggena🔽diṭṭhoghaṃ. Arahattamaggena avijjoghaṃ tareyyaṃ. Sakyakulā pabbajitoti bhagavato
analyzed: yam dhammam vā puggalam vā nissitaḥ  niddese kāmogham ti anāgāmi maggena kāmogham arahatta maggena bhavogham sa utāpatti maggena  diṭṭha ogham arahatta maggena avijja ogham tareyyam sakya kulā pabbajitaḥ ti bhagavataḥ
