translated: In the sixth, the Upasīva Sutta , the great flood is the great flood of craving. “Not supported” : not cleaving to a person or a doctrine. “I cannot cross” : I am not able to cross. “Support” : reliance. “What I am supported by” : what doctrine or person I am supported by.

original: uccākulaparidīpanavasena vuttaṃ. Ālambaṇanti avattharitvā ṭhānaṃ. Nissayanti allīyanaṃ.
analyzed: ucca ākula paridīpana vasena vuttam ālambaṇam nti avattharitvā ṭhānam nissayanti allīyanam
translated: In the description, the flood of sensual desire is crossed by the non-return path, the flood of becoming by the path of arahantship, the flood of views by the path of stream-entry, and the flood of ignorance by the path of arahantship. “One gone forth from the Sakyan clan” : this is said to show the Exalted One’s high birth. “Support” : a place to stand on. “Reliance” : cleaving.

original: Upanissayanti apassayanaṃ.
analyzed: upanissayanti apassayanam
translated: “Underlying tendency” : attachment.

original: 39. Idāni yasmā brāhmaṇo ākiñcaññāyatanalābhī tañca santampi nissayaṃ na jānāti.
analyzed: idāni yasmai brāhmaṇaḥ ākiñcaññāyatana lābhī tam ca santam pi nissayam na jānāti
translated: Now, since the brahmin had attained the base of nothingness, he did not know that support.

original: Tenassa bhagavā tañca nissayaṃ uttariñca niyyānapathaṃ dassento “ākiñcañña”nti gāthamāha.
analyzed: tena assa bhagavā tañca nissayam uttariñca niyyāna patham dassentaḥ ākiñcaññam ti gātham āha
translated: Therefore the Exalted One, showing him that support and the path of escape beyond it, spoke the verse, “The base of nothingness.”

original: Tattha pekkhamānoti taṃ ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpattiṃ sato samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā ca
analyzed: tattha pekkhamāno ti tam ākiñcaññāyatana samāpattim sataḥ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhahitvā ca
translated: Herein, looking is the bhikkhu who, having attained the base consisting of nothingness, emerges and then sees it as impermanent, etc.,

original: aniccādivasena passamāno. Natthīti nissāyāti taṃ “natthi kiñcī”ti pavattaṃ samāpattiṃ🔽ārammaṇaṃ katvā. Tarassu oghanti tato pabhuti pavattāya vipassanāya yathānurūpaṃ
analyzed: anicca ādi vasena passamāno natthi iti nissāya ati tat natthi kiñci iti pavattam samāpattim  ārammaṇam katvā tarassu tato pabhuti pavattāya vipassanāya yathānurūpam
translated: depending on is the attainment that occurs with the words “There is nothing” as its object.🔽Cross the flood is the fourfold flood that occurs from then on.

original: catubbidhampi oghaṃ tarassu. Kathāhīti kathaṃkathāhi. Taṇhakkhayaṃ nattamahābhipassāti
analyzed: catubbidham pi ogham tarassu kathāhi iti kathaṃkathāhi taṇha khayam
translated: How? is the question. The great ocean of craving’s end is the Nibbāna element.

original: rattindivaṃ nibbānaṃ vibhūtaṃ katvā passa. Etenassa diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṃ kathesi.
analyzed: rattindivam nibbānam vibhūtam katvā passa etena assa diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāram kathesi
translated: Look is the exhortation to look at Nibbāna all day and all night, making it evident. By this he exhorts him to abide in bliss here and now.

original: Niddese taññeva viññāṇaṃ abhāvetīti ākāsālambaṇaṃ katvā pavattamahaggataviññāṇaṃ
analyzed: niddese tañca eva viññāṇam abhāveti iti ākāsa ālambaṇam katvā pavatta mahaggata viññāṇam
translated: In the description, he does not bring that kind of consciousness to presence: he does not bring to presence the exalted consciousness that occurs making space its object.

original: abhāveti abhāvaṃ gameti. Vibhāvetīti vividhā abhāvaṃ gameti. Antaradhāpetīti adassanaṃ
analyzed: abhāva iti abhāvam gama iti vibhāva iti iti vividhā abhāvam gama iti antaradhāpa iti iti adassanam
translated: He makes it absent: he makes it go to absence. He makes it disappear: he makes it go to non-appearance.

original: gameti. Natthi kiñcīti passatīti antamaso bhaṅgamattampissa natthīti passati.
analyzed: gameti natthi kiñci iti passati iti antamasaḥ bhaṅga mattam pissa natthi iti passati
translated: He sees that there is nothing: he sees that there is not even the mere fact of its dissolution.

original: 40. Idāni “kāme pahāyā”ti sutvā vikkhambhanavasena attanā pahīne kāme sampassamāno
analyzed: idāni kāme pahāya ati sutvā vikkhambhana vasena attanā pahīne kāme sampassamānaḥ
translated: Now, having heard the words “having abandoned sense desires” , he saw that he himself had abandoned sense desires by way of suppression.

original: “sabbesū”ti gāthamāha. Tattha hitvā maññanti aññaṃ tato heṭṭhā chabbidhampi samāpattiṃ
analyzed: sabbesu iti gātham āha tattha hitvā maññanti aññam tatas heṭṭhā chabbidham pi samāpattim
translated: So he spoke the verse, “All” . Herein, they think they have abandoned by way of the other six kinds of attainment, too, beginning with the first jhana.🔽They think they have abandoned by way of the seven kinds of perceptional-sphere deliverance, too, beginning with the first perceptional-sphere deliverance.

original: hitvā. Saññāvimokkhe parameti sattasu saññāvimokkhesu uttame ākiñcaññāyatane. Tiṭṭhe🔽nu so tattha anānuyāyīti so puggalo tattha ākiñcaññāyatanabrahmaloke avigacchamāno
analyzed: hitvā saññā vimokkhe paramā iti sattasu saññā vimokkhesu uttame ākiñcaññāyatane tiṭṭhe  nu so tattha an ānuyāyī iti so puggalo tattha ākiñcaññāyatana brahma loke a vigacchamāno
translated: In the supreme perceptional-sphere deliverance, namely, the base consisting of nothingness,🔽would he stand there without being subject to it?

original: tiṭṭheyya nūti pucchati.
analyzed: tiṭṭheyya nu uti pucchati
translated: He asks whether that person would stand there in the Brahma-world of the base consisting of nothingness without departing from it.

original: Niddese aviccamānoti aviyujjamāno. Avigacchamānoti viyogaṃ anāpajjamāno. Anantaradhāyamānoti antaradhānaṃ anāpajjamāno. Aparihāyamānoti anantarā parihānaṃ anāpajjamāno.
analyzed: niddese a viccamānaḥ ti a viyujjamānaḥ a vigacchamānaḥ iti viyogam an āpajjamānaḥ anantaradhāyamānaḥ iti antaradhānam an āpajjamānaḥ aparihāyamānaḥ iti anantarā parihānam an āpajjamānaḥ
translated: In the Niddesa the words aviccamāno and avigacchamāno are synonymous. Aparihāyamāno is the same as anantarā parihānaṃ anāpajjamāno .

original: 41-2. Athassa bhagavā saṭṭhikappasahassamattakaṃyeva ṭhānaṃ anujānanto catutthaṃ
analyzed: atha assa bhagavā saṭṭhi kappa sahassa mattakam yeva ṭhānam anujānantaḥ catuttham
translated: Then the Blessed One allowed him a place of standing of only sixty-four steps, speaking the fourth

original: gāthamāha. Evaṃ tassa tattha ṭhānaṃ sutvā idānissa sassatucchedabhāvaṃ pucchanto
analyzed: gātham āha evam tassa tattha ṭhānam sutvā idānissa sassatu cheda bhāvam pucchanto
translated: verse. Having heard that he had a place of standing there, he now asked whether he was eternal or subject to annihilation.

original: “tiṭṭhe ce”ti gāthamāha. Tattha pūgampi vassānanti anekasaṅkhyampi vassānaṃ, gaṇanarāsinti
analyzed: tiṭṭhe ca iti gātham āha tattha pūgam pi vassānam ti aneka saṅkhyam pi vassānam gaṇana rāsim ti
translated: “If he should stand” , he said the verse. Herein, if he should stand for many years means if he should stand for many years reckoned by number and by heap.

original: attho. “Pūgampi vassānī”tipi pāṭho. Tattha vibhattibyattayena sāmivacanassa paccattavacanaṃ
analyzed: pūgam pi vassāni iti pi tattha vibhatti byattayena sāmi vacanassa paccatta vacanam
translated: He spoke the verse, “If he were to stand … ” . Herein, even for many years means even for many years reckoned by number. The meaning is: a heap of reckoning. There is also the reading pūgampi vassānī . Herein, the locative case is to be construed with the possessive case by the rule of the locative-possessive compound .

original: kātabbaṃ, pūganti vā etassa bahūnīti attho vattabbo. “Pūgānī”ti vāpi paṭhanti, purimapāṭhoyeva🔽sabbasundaro. Tattheva so sīti siyā vimuttoti so puggalo tatthevākiñcaññāyatane nānādukkhehi
analyzed: kātabbam pūganti vā etassa bahūni iti atthaḥ vattabbaḥ pūgāni iti vā api paṭhanti purima pāṭhaḥ yā iva  sabba sundaro tattha iva so si iti siyā vimutto ti so puggalo tattha iva ākiñcaññāyatane nānā dukkhehi
translated: Or else the meaning of many is to be construed as the meaning of pūgā . Or else they read pūgānī . The former reading is the most beautiful.

original: vimutto sītibhāvappatto bhaveyya, nibbānappatto sassato hutvā tiṭṭheyyāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: vimuttaḥ sīti bhāva ppatto bhaveyya nibbāna ppatto sassataḥ hutvā tiṭṭheyya ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: There he would be freed: that person would reach the state of being , that is, he would reach extinction, and he would stand being eternal.

original: Cavetha viññāṇaṃ tathāvidhassāti “udāhu tathāvidhassa viññāṇaṃ anupādāya parinibbāyeyyā”ti
analyzed: cavetha viññāṇam tathāvidhassa ati udāhu tathāvidhassa viññāṇam an upādāya parinibbāyeyya ati
translated: But consciousness of such a kind: he asks about annihilation, “Or would consciousness of such a kind go to a rebirth-linking? ”

original: ucchedaṃ pucchati, “paṭisandhiggahaṇatthaṃ vāpi bhaveyyā”ti paṭisandhimpi tassa pucchati.
analyzed: ucchedam pucchati paṭisandhi ggahaṇa attham vā api bhaveyya ati paṭisandhim pi tassa pucchati
translated: Or else he asks about rebirth-linking, “Or would it be for the purpose of taking up a rebirth-linking? ”

original: Tassa viññāṇaṃ caveyyāti tassa ākiñcaññāyatane uppannassa viññāṇaṃ cutiṃ pāpuṇeyya.
analyzed: tassa viññāṇam caveyya ati tassa ākiñcaññāyatane uppannassa viññāṇam cutim pāpuṇeyya
translated: His consciousness would be cut off: his consciousness would reach the state of death.

original: Ucchijjeyyāti ucchedaṃ bhaveyya. Vinasseyyāti vināsaṃ pāpuṇeyya. Na bhaveyyāti abhāvaṃ
analyzed: ucchijjeyya ati ucchedam bhaveyya vinasseyya ati vināsam pāpuṇeyya na bhaveyya ati abhāvam
translated: It would be destroyed: it would be destroyed. It would vanish: it would reach the state of vanishing. It would not be: it would go to non-existence.

original: gameyya. Upapannassāti paṭisandhivasena upapannassa.🔽43. Athassa bhagavā ucchedasassataṃ anupagamma tatthupapannassa ariyasāvakassa anupādāya
analyzed: gameyya upapannassa ati paṭisandhi vasena upapannassa  atha assa bhagavā uccheda sassatam an upagamma tattha upapannassa ariya sāvakassa an upādāya
translated: Of one who has been reborn: of one who has been reborn by way of rebirth-linking.

original: parinibbānaṃ dassento “accī yathā”ti gāthamāha. Tattha atthaṃ paletīti atthaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: parinibbānam dassento accī yathā iti gātham āha tattha attham paleti iti attham gacchati
translated: Then the Blessed One, not taking up the annihilationist or eternalist view, showed the extinction by non-clinging of the noble disciple reborn there, saying, “As a flame,” and so on. Herein, it goes to its end: it goes to its destruction.

original: Na upeti saṅkhanti “asukaṃ nāma disaṃ gato”ti vohāraṃ na gacchati. Evaṃ munī nāmakāyā
analyzed: na upa iti asukam nāma disam gatā iti vohāram na gacchati evam munī nāmakāyā
translated: It does not go the way of talk: it does not go the way of expression, “It has gone to such and such a place.” So the sage,🔽freed from the body’s bonds,

original: vimuttoti evaṃ tattha uppanno sekkhamuni pakatiyā pubbeva rūpakāyā vimutto, tattha
analyzed: vimutto ti evam tattha uppanno sekkha muni pakatiyā pubbā iva rūpa kāyā vimutto tattha
translated: So the trainee sage reborn there is already freed from the bonds of the body, which is natural to him,

original: catutthamaggaṃ nibbattetvā dhammakāyassa pariññātattā puna nāmakāyāpi vimutto ubhatobhāgavimutto
analyzed: catuttha maggam nibbattetvā dhammakāyassa pariññāta ttā puna nāmakāya api vimuttaḥ ubhatobhāga vimutto
translated: and by arousing the fourth path he is freed from the bonds of the name, which is the discovery of the Dhamma. Freed from both bonds he is🔽freed in both instances.

original: khīṇāsavo hutvā anupādānibbānasaṅkhātaṃ atthaṃ paleti na upeti saṅkhaṃ “khattiyo
analyzed: khīṇāsavaḥ hutvā an upādā nibbāna saṅkhātam attham paleti na upeti saṅkham khattiyaḥ
translated: and having become one whose cankers are destroyed, he passes away to the end of suffering called Nibbāna, and does not come to existence again.

original: vā brāhmaṇo vā”ti evamādikaṃ.
analyzed: vā brāhmaṇaḥ vāti evamādikam
translated: and having become one whose cankers are destroyed, he passes away to the state of extinction called “without residue of attachment” and does not come to be reckoned as “a warrior-noble” or “a brahmin” or “a merchant” or “a worker.”

original: Niddese khittāti calitā. Ukkhittāti aticalitā. Nunnāti papphoṭiyā. Paṇunnāti dūrīkatā. Khambhitāti paṭikkamāpitā. Vikkhambhitāti na santike katā.
analyzed: niddese khittā ati calitā ukkhittā ati aticalitā nunnā ati papphoṭiyā paṇunnā ati dūrīkatā khambhitā ati paṭikkamāpitā vikkhambhitā ati na santike katā
translated: In the description, “thrown down” means shaken. “Thrown out” means shaken out. “Thrown away” means thrown off. “Thrown aside” means thrown off at a distance. “Thrown out of” means thrown out from. “Thrown off” means not made near.

original: 44. Idāni “atthaṃ paletī”ti sutvā tassa yoniso atthamasallakkhento “atthaṅgato so”ti
analyzed: idāni attham paleti iti sutvā tassa yonisas attham a saṃlakkhento atthaṅgataḥ so ti
translated: Now, having heard “passes away to the state of extinction,” he, discerning the meaning of that, said the second stanza, “Has he gone to extinction or not?

original: gāthamāha. Tassattho – so atthaṅgato udāhu natthi, udāhu ve sassatiyā sassatabhāvena
analyzed: gātham āha tassa atthaḥ saḥ atthaṅgataḥ udāhu natthi udāhu ve sassatiyā sassata bhāvena
translated: ” The meaning is: has he gone to extinction or not? Or is he, by his eternalness, his eternal state,

original: arogo avipariṇāmadhammo soti evaṃ taṃ me munī sādhu byākarohi. Kiṃkāraṇā? Tathā hi
analyzed: arogaḥ a vipariṇāma dhammo saḥ ti evam tam me munī sādhu byākarohi kiṃkāraṇā tathā hi
translated: free from disease, not subject to change? Please explain that to me, Sage. Why? Because

original: te vidito esa dhammoti.
analyzed: te viditaḥ esa dhammo ti
translated: this state is known to you.

original: Niddese niruddhoti nirodhaṃ patto. Ucchinnoti ucchinnasantāno. Vinaṭṭhoti vināsaṃ patto.
analyzed: niddese niruddho ti nirodham patto ucchinno ti ucchinna santānaḥ vinaṭṭho ti vināsam patto
translated: In the description, “ceased” means reached cessation. “Cut off” means cut off continuity. “Destroyed” means reached destruction.

original: 45. Athassa bhagavā tathā avattabbataṃ dassento “atthaṅgatassā”ti gāthamāha. Tattha🔽atthaṅgatassāti anupādāparinibbutassa. Na pamāṇamatthīti rūpādipamāṇaṃ natthi. Yena
analyzed: athassa bhagavā tathā avattabba tam dassentaḥ atthaṅgatassa iti gātham āha tattha  atthaṅgatassa ati anupādā parinibbutassa na pamāṇam atthi iti rūpa ādi pamāṇam na atthi yena
translated: Then the Blessed One, showing how it should be spoken of, spoke this stanza:

original: naṃ vajjunti yena rāgādinā naṃ vadeyyuṃ. Sabbesu dhammesūti sabbesu khandhādidhammesu.🔽Niddese adhivacanāni cāti sirivaḍḍhako dhanavaḍḍhakotiādayo hi vacanamattaṃyeva adhikāraṃ🔽katvā pavattā adhivacanā nāma. Adhivacanānaṃ pathā adhivacanapathā nāma. “Abhisaṅkharontīti🔽kho, bhikkhave, tasmā saṅkhārā”ti evaṃ niddhāritvā sahetukaṃ katvā vuccamānā abhilāpā
analyzed: nam vajjum ti yena rāga ādinā nam vadeyyum sabbesu dhammesu iti sabbesu khandha ādi dhammesu  niddese adhivacanāni ca ati sirivaḍḍhakaḥ dhanavaḍḍhaka uti ādayaḥ hi adhikāram  katvā pavattāḥ adhivacanāḥ nāma adhivacanānam pathā adhivacana pathāḥ nāma abhisaṅkharonti iti  kho bhikkhave tasmai saṅkhārā ati evam niddhāritvā sa hetukam katvā vuccamānāḥ abhilāpāḥ
translated: Atthaṅgatassā ti, of one who has attained Nibbāna by not grasping. Na pamāṇam atthi ti, there is no measure of form, etc. Yena naṃ vajju ti, by which they might blame him for lust, etc. Sabbesu dhammesu ti, in all the ideas of the categories of form, etc.

original: nirutti nāma. Niruttīnaṃ pathā niruttipathā nāma. “Takko vitakko saṅkappo”ti evaṃ
analyzed: nirutti nāma niruttīnam pathā nirutti pathā nāma takkaḥ vitakkaḥ saṅkappo ti evam
translated: In the description, the terms are called “terms” because they occur with the mere word as their province, such as “wealth-increasing” and “prosperity-increasing” . The “paths of terms” are the paths of the terms. “They form , bhikkhus, that is why they are called ‘formations’ ” . The expressions thus stated with cause are called “designations” . The “paths of designations” are the paths of the designations. “Thinking, thinking-seeks, thinking-done” .

original: tena tena pakārena paññāpanato paññatti nāma. Paññattīnaṃ pathā paññattipathā nāma.
analyzed: tena tena pakārena paññāpanataḥ paññatti nāma paññattīnam pathā paññatti pathā nāma
translated: The “informing” is called “intimation” because it is intimated in such and such a way. The “paths of intimation” are the paths of the intimation.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva
translated: The rest is clear in all its details.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā idampi suttaṃ arahattanikūṭeneva desesi, desanāpariyosāne ca vuttasadisova dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: evam bhagavā idam pi suttam arahatta nikūṭena iva desesi desanā pariyosāne ca vutta sadisaḥ iva dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: Thus the Exalted One taught this sutta too by the peak of arahantship. And at the conclusion of the teaching, the penetration of the Dhamma by the assembly was similar to what has been related above.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Cūḷaniddesa, the illumination of the true Dhamma,

original: Upasīvamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽7. Nandamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upasīvamāṇava sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.🔽The commentary on the Nandamāṇava Sutta

original: 46. Sattame nandasutte – paṭhamagāthāyattho – loke khattiyādayojanā ājīvakanigaṇṭhādike🔽sandhāya “santi loke munayo”ti vadanti. Tayidaṃ kathaṃsūti kiṃ nu kho te samāpattiñāṇādinā
analyzed: sattame nanda sutte loke ājīvaka nigaṇṭha ādike  sandhāya santi loke munayaḥ iti vadanti kim nu khalu te samāpatti ñāṇa ādinā
translated: In the seventh sutta, the Nandamāṇava Sutta, the meaning of the first stanza is this: In the world, people like the khattiyas, etc.,

original: ñāṇena upapannattā ñāṇūpapannaṃ muni no vadanti, evaṃvidhaṃ nu vadanti, udāhu ve
analyzed: ñāṇena ñāṇūpapannam muni naḥ vadanti evaṃvidham nu vadanti udāhu ve
translated: referring to the Ājīvakas, Niganthas, etc., say: “There are sages in the world.” How is this? Do they say that a sage is one who has arisen through knowledge, i.e., one who has arisen by means of knowledge such as the knowledge of spiritual attainments, etc.? Or do they say that a sage is one who has arisen by means of a life

original: nānappakārakena lūkhajīvitasaṅkhātena jīvitenūpapannanti.
analyzed: nānappakārakena lūkha jīvita saṅkhātena jīvitena upapannanti
translated: of hardship, i.e., by means of a life of hardship of various kinds?

original: Niddese aṭṭhasamāpattiñāṇena vāti paṭhamajjhānādiaṭṭhasamāpattisampayuttañāṇena vā. Pañcābhiññāñāṇena vāti pubbenivāsādijānanañāṇena vā.
analyzed: niddese aṭṭha samāpatti ñāṇena vā ti paṭhamajjhāna ādi aṭṭha samāpatti sampayutta ñāṇena vā pañca abhiññā ñāṇena vā ti pubbenivāsa ādi jānana ñāṇena vā
translated: In the niddesa, “with the knowledge of the eight attainments” means with the knowledge associated with the eight attainments beginning with the first jhāna. “With the knowledge of the five higher knowledges” means with the knowledge of the five higher knowledges beginning with the knowledge of the recollection of past lives.

original: 47. Athassa bhagavā tadubhayampi paṭikkhipitvā muniṃ dassento “na diṭṭhiyā”ti gāthamāha.
analyzed: athassa bhagavā tat ubhayam pi paṭikkhipitvā munim dassentaḥ na diṭṭhiyā iti gātham āha
translated: Then the Blessed One, having rejected both of those, spoke the verse “Not by views” in order to show the sage.

original: 48. Idāni “diṭṭhādīhi suddhī”ti vadantānaṃ vāde kaṅkhāpahānatthaṃ “ye kecime”ti pucchati.
analyzed: idāni diṭṭha ādīhi suddhi iti vadantānam vāde kaṅkhā apahāna attham ye pucchati
translated: Now, in order to remove doubt in the doctrine of those who say “Purification is by views, etc.,” he asks, “Who are these?”

original: Tattha anekarūpenāti kotūhalamaṅgalādināpi. Tattha yatā carantāti tattha sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā guttā viharantā.
analyzed: tattha aneka rūpena ati kotūhala maṅgala ādinā api tattha yatā carantā iti tattha sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā guttā viharantā
translated: Herein, by many a form means by the auspicious sign of the crow, etc. Therein, they who live means they who live guarded by the view of self in the body.

original: 49. Athassa tathā suddhiabhāvaṃ dīpento bhagavā catutthaṃ gāthamāha.
analyzed: atha assa tathā suddhi abhāvam dīpentaḥ bhagavā catuttham gātham āha
translated: Then the Blessed One, in order to illuminate the fact that there is no purification in that way, spoke the fourth verse.

original: 50. Evaṃ “nātariṃsū”ti sutvā idāni yo atari, taṃ sotukāmo “ye kecime”ti pucchati. Athassa bhagavā oghatiṇṇamukhena jātijarātiṇṇe dassento chaṭṭhaṃ gāthamāha.
analyzed: evam na atariṃsu iti sutvā idāni yaḥ atari tam sotu kāmaḥ ye kecid iti pucchati athassa bhagavā ogha tiṇṇa mukhena jāti jarā tiṇṇe dassentaḥ chaṭṭham gātham āha
translated: Thus, having heard “They did not cross over,” now, desiring to hear who did cross over, he asks, “Who are these?” Then the Blessed One, showing those who have crossed over birth and aging by the example of those who have crossed over the flood, spoke the sixth verse.

original: 51. Tattha nivutāti ovuṭā pariyonaddhā. Ye sīdhāti ye su idha, ettha ca su-iti nipātamattaṃ.
analyzed: tattha nivutā ati ovuṭā pariyonaddhā ye ye ettha ca su iti nipāta mattam
translated: Herein, covered means covered over, concealed. Those who are good here means those who are good in this matter. Herein, su is merely a particle.

original: Taṇhaṃ pariññāyāti tīhi pariññāhi taṇhaṃ parijānitvā. Sesaṃ sabbattha pubbe vuttanayattā pākaṭameva.
analyzed: taṇham pariññāya ti tīhi pariññāhi taṇham parijānitvā sesam sabbattha pubbe vutta naya ttā pākaṭam eva
translated: Having fully understood craving means having fully understood craving by means of the three kinds of full understanding. The rest is clear in all its details since the method of explanation is the same as before.

original: 52. Evaṃ bhagavā arahattanikūṭeneva desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesi, desanāpariyosāne pana nando🔽bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandamāno etābhinandāmīti gāthamāha. Idhāpi ca pubbe vuttasadiso
analyzed: evam bhagavā arahatta nikūṭena iva desanam niṭṭhāpesi desanā pariyosāne pana nando  bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandamānaḥ etā abhinandāmi iti gātham āha idha api ca pubbe vutta sadisaḥ
translated: Thus the Blessed One concluded the teaching with the peak of arahatship. At the conclusion of the teaching, Nanda🔽rejoiced in the Blessed One’s speech, saying, “I rejoice in this.” And here too,

original: eva dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: eva dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti

translated: The commentary on the explanation of the sutta for the disciple Nanda,

translated: the ninth sutta in the Middle Length Discourses, is finished.🔽The commentary on the explanation of the sutta for the disciple Hemaka,🔽the eighth sutta in the Middle Length Discourses, is finished.

translated: as a general heading. Now, in order to show sensual-desire-thought, etc., in their individual essences, he showed the nine kinds of thought beginning with “the increase of sensual-desire-thought” .

analyzed: taṇhā nigghātanam ti taṇhā vināsanam
translated: The destruction of craving: the destruction of craving.

analyzed: athassa bhagavā tam dhammaṃ ācikkhantaḥ idha iti gāthā dvayam āha tattha etad aññāya
translated: Then, in explaining that Dhamma to him, the Blessed One uttered the two stanzas beginning with “Here.” Herein, having understood this,

analyzed: anupubbena jānitvā ye kāya anupassanā sati ādīhi satā diṭṭhadhamma abhinibbutā ati vidita dhamma ttā  diṭṭhadhammā ca rāga ādi nibbānena ca abhinibbutā sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva

analyzed: navame todeyya sutte vimokkho tassa kīdiso ti tassa kīdisaḥ vimokkho icchitabbo ti pucchati
translated: “Those who know” : those who know by insight in the way beginning, “All formations are impermanent” .🔽“

original: 58. Idānissa aññavimokkhābhāvaṃ dassento bhagavā dutiyaṃ gāthamāha. Tattha vimokkho tassa nāparoti tassa añño vimokkho natthi.🔽59. Evaṃ “taṇhakkhayo eva vimokkho”ti vuttepi tamatthaṃ asallakkhento “nirāsaso so
analyzed: idāni issa añña vimokkha abhāvam dassentaḥ bhagavā dutiyam gātham āha tattha vimokkho tassa na aparaḥ ti tassa aññaḥ vimokkho natthi  evam taṇhā khayaḥ eva vimokkhaḥ ti vutte api tam attham asat lakkhentaḥ so
translated: Now, showing that he has no other liberation, the Blessed One uttered the second stanza. Herein, there is no other liberation for him means there is no other liberation for him.

original: uda āsasāno”ti puna pucchati. Tattha uda paññakappīti udāhu samāpattiñāṇādinā ñāṇena
analyzed: uda āsasānaḥ ti puna pucchati tattha uda paññakappī iti udāhu samāpatti ñāṇa ādinā ñāṇena
translated: Although it was said thus, “The destruction of craving is liberation,” still, not understanding the meaning, he asked the question again, “Is he without longing, or is he longing?” Herein, is he a schemer? means is he a schemer by the knowledge of attainment, etc.,

original: taṇhākappaṃ vā diṭṭhikappaṃ vā kappayati.
analyzed: taṇhā kappam vā diṭṭhi kappam vā kappayati
translated: or does he scheme craving or views?

original: 60. Athassa bhagavā taṃ ācikkhanto catutthaṃ gāthamāha. Tattha kāmabhaveti kāme ca bhave ca.
analyzed: athassa bhagavā tam ācikkhantaḥ catuttham gātham āha tattha kāma bhava iti kāme ca bhave ca
translated: Then the Blessed One, explaining that, uttered the fourth stanza. Herein, in the realm of sensual desires means in sensual desires and in the realm of sensual desires.

original: Rūpe nāsīsatīti catusamuṭṭhānike rūpārammaṇe chandarāgavasena na pattheti. Saddhādīsupi🔽eseva nayo. Palibodhaṭṭhena rāgo eva kiñcanaṃ rāgakiñcanaṃ madanaṭṭhena vā. Dosakiñcanādīsupi
analyzed: rūpe na āsīsati iti catu samuṭṭhānike rūpa ārammaṇe chanda rāga vasena na pattheti saddhā ādīsu pi  esa iva palibodha ṭṭhena rāgaḥ eva kiñcanam rāga kiñcanam madana ṭṭhena vā dosa kiñcana ādīsu pi
translated: He does not hanker after form means he does not long for the four-originated materiality as object by means of desire and lust. The same method applies in the case of faith, etc.

original: eseva nayo. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva
translated: Lust itself is a something in the sense of obstruction, thus it is lust-something. The same method applies in the case of hate-something, etc. The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā idampi suttaṃ arahattanikūṭeneva desesi, desanāpariyosāne ca pubbasadiso eva dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: evam bhagavā idam pi suttam arahatta nikūṭena iva desesi desanā pariyosāne ca pubba sadisaḥ eva dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: So the Exalted One taught this sutta too by way of the peak of arahantship. And at the conclusion of the teaching, the penetration of the Dhamma by the assembly was similar to the previous case.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Cullaniddesa, a lamp for the true Dhamma,

original: Todeyyamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: todeyyamāṇava sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is finished.

original: 10. Kappamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽61. Dasame kappasuttaniddese – majjhe sarasminti purimapacchimakoṭipaññāṇābhāvato
analyzed: dasame kappa sutta niddese majjhe sarasmin ti purima pacchima koṭi paññāṇa abhāvato
translated: The commentary on the tenth sutta, the Kappasutta, in the Cullaniddesa is finished.

original: majjhabhūte saṃsāreti vuttaṃ hoti. Tiṭṭhatanti tiṭṭhamānānaṃ. Yathāyidaṃ nāparaṃ
analyzed: majjha bhūte saṃsāre iti vuttam hoti tiṭṭhatanti tiṭṭhamānānam yathāyidam na aparam
translated: In the Kappasutta: “In the middle of the clear expanse” means in the middle of the round of rebirths, since the beginning and end are not known.

original: siyāti yathā idaṃ dukkhaṃ puna na bhaveyya.
analyzed: siyāti yathā idam dukkham puna na bhaveyya
translated: “Standing” means standing in the present. “So that this may not be” means so that this suffering may not be again.

original: Āgamananti pubbantato idhāgamanaṃ. Gamananti ito paralokagamanaṃ. Gamanāgamananti🔽tadubhayavasena vuttaṃ. Kālanti maraṇakālaṃ. Gatīti nibbatti. Bhavābhavoti bhavato
analyzed: āgamananti pubbantataḥ idha āgamanam gamananti itas para loka gamanam gamana āgamananti  tad ubhaya vasena vuttam kālanti maraṇa kālam gatī iti nibbatti bhava abhavoti bhavato
translated: “Coming” means coming from the past to the present. “Going” means going from the present to the future. “Coming and going”🔽means both. “The end of life” means the time of death. “The end of the round” means rebirth. “From existence to existence” means from one existence to another.

original: bhavo. Cuti cāti bhavato cavanañca. Upapatti cāti cutassa upapatti ca. Nibbatti cāti
analyzed: bhavaḥ cuti ca ati bhavato cavanam ca upapatti ca ati cutassa upapatti ca nibbatti ca ati
translated: “Death and rebirth” means death from one existence and rebirth in another. “Rebirth” means

original: pātubhāvo ca. Bhedo cāti khandhabhedo ca. Jāti cāti jananañca. Jarā cāti hāni ca.
analyzed: pātubhāvaḥ ca bhedaḥ ca ati khandha bhedaḥ ca jāti ca ati jananañca jarā ca ati hāni ca
translated: and manifestation. And dissolution: the dissolution of the aggregates. And birth: the being born. And ageing: the wasting away.

original: Maraṇañcāti jīvitindriyassa cāgo ca. Purimāpi koṭi na paññāyatīti pubbāpi koṭi natthi
analyzed: maraṇam ca ati jīvitindriyassa cāgo ca purimā api koṭi na paññāyati iti pubbā api koṭi natthi
translated: And death: the giving up of the life faculty. The past limit is not known: there is no past limit.

original: na saṃvijjati. Tathā pacchimāpi koṭi.
analyzed: na saṃvijjati tathā pacchimā api
translated: Nor is the future limit:

original: Ettakā jātiyoti etaparamā jātiyo. Vaṭṭaṃ vattīti saṃsārapavatti. Tato paraṃ na vattatīti
analyzed: ettakāḥ jātiyaḥ ti eta paramāḥ jātiyaḥ vaṭṭam vatti iti saṃsāra pavatti tato param na vattati iti
translated: So many births: there is this much birth. The round goes on: the round of existence goes on. Beyond that it does not go on:

original: tato uddhaṃ nappavattati. Hevaṃ natthīti evaṃ natthi na saṃvijjati. Hi-iti nipāto.
analyzed: tatas uddham nappavattati ha ivam natthi iti evam natthi na saṃvijjati hi iti nipātaḥ
translated: beyond that it does not go on. It is not: it is not so, it does not exist. Hi is a particle.

original: Anamataggoyanti ayaṃ saṃsāro aviditaggo.
analyzed: ayam saṃsāraḥ a viditaggaḥ
translated: Without known beginning: this round of existence has no known beginning.

original: Avijjānīvaraṇānanti avijjāya āvaritānaṃ. Taṇhāsaṃyojanānanti kāmarāgasaṅkhātataṇhābandhanabaddhānaṃ.
analyzed: avijjā nīvaraṇānam avijjāya āvaritānam taṇhā saṃyojanānam anti kāma rāga saṅkhāta taṇhā bandhana baddhānam
translated: With ignorance as veil: with ignorance as obstruction. With craving as bond: bound by craving called greed for sensual desires.

original: Sandhāvatanti kāmadhātuyā punappunaṃ dhāvantānaṃ. Saṃsaratanti rūpārūpadhātuyā saṃsarantānaṃ.
analyzed: sandhāvatanti kāmadhātuyā punappunam dhāvantānam saṃsaratanti rūpa arūpadhātuyā saṃsarantānam
translated: Running: running again and again in the sense-desire element. Transmigrating: transmigrating in the form and formless elements.

original: Dukkhaṃ paccanubhūtanti kāyikacetasikadukkhaṃ anubhūtaṃ vinditaṃ. Tibbanti bahalaṃ.
analyzed: dukkham paccanubhūtanti kāyika cetasika dukkham anubhūtam vinditam tibbanti bahalam
translated: Experiencing suffering: experiencing, finding, bodily and mental suffering. Thickly: densely.

original: Byasananti avaḍḍhi vināso. Kaṭasī vaḍḍhitāti susānavaḍḍhitaṃ. Alamevāti yuttameva.🔽Sabbasaṅkhāresūti tebhūmakasaṅkhāresu. Nibbinditunti ukkaṇṭhituṃ. Virajjitunti virāgaṃ
analyzed: alam eva ati yuttam eva  sabba saṅkhāresu iti tebhūmaka saṅkhāresu nibbinditum ti ukkaṇṭhitum virajjitum ti virāgam
translated: Byasanam = misfortune, loss. Katasi vaḍḍhitam = increased by corpses. Alameva = it is enough.

original: uppādetuṃ. Vimuccitunti mocetuṃ. Vaṭṭaṃ vattissatīti saṃsārapavattaṃ tebhūmakavaṭṭaṃ
analyzed: uppādetum vimuccitum ti mocetum vaṭṭam vattissati iti saṃsāra pavattam tebhūmaka vaṭṭam
translated: Sabbasankhāresu = in the formations of the three planes. Nibbinditum = to be disgusted. Virajjitum = to arouse dispassion. Vimuccitum = to be liberated. Vattam vattissati = the round of existence will revolve.

original: anāgate pavattissati. Tato paraṃ na vattissatīti tato uddhaṃ anāgate saṃsārapavattaṃ
analyzed: anāgate pavattissati tato param na vattissati iti tatas uddham anāgate saṃsāra pavattam
translated: The round of existence of the three planes will revolve in the future. Tato param na vattissati = after that it will not revolve.

original: nappavattissati. Jātibhayeti jātiṃ paṭicca uppajjanakabhaye. Jarābhayādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: na ppavatti sati jāti bhaye iti jātim paṭicca uppajjanaka bhaye jarā bhaya ādīsu pi esa eva nayaḥ
translated: The round of existence will not revolve in the future. Jatibhaye = in the fear arising from birth. The same method applies to the fear of old age, etc.

original: 62-3. Athassa bhagavā tamatthaṃ byākaronto uparūparigāthāyo abhāsi. Dutiyagāthā vuttatthāyeva.🔽Tatiyagāthāya akiñcananti kiñcanapaṭipakkhaṃ. Anādānanti ādānapaṭipakkhaṃ, kiñcanādānavūpasamanti
analyzed: atha assa bhagavā tam attham byākarontaḥ upari upari gāthāyaḥ abhāsi dutiya gāthāḥ vutta tthāya eva  tatiya gāthāya akiñcananti kiñcana paṭipakkham anādānanti ādāna paṭipakkham kiñcana ādāna vūpasamanti
translated: -. Then the Blessed One, explaining the meaning of this, spoke the following verses. The meaning of the second verse is clear.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Anāparanti aparapaṭibhāgadīpavirahitaṃ, seṭṭhanti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: vuttam hoti anāparam ti apara paṭibhāga dīpa virahitam seṭṭham ti vuttam hoti
translated: In the third verse, akiñcanam = the opposite of kiñcana. Anādāna = the opposite of ādāna. Anāparam = without a further side. Seṭṭham = the best.

original: 64. Catutthagāthāya na te mārassa paddhagūti te mārassa paddhacarā paricārikā sissā na honti.🔽Mahājanaṃ pāse niyojetvā māretīti māro. Akusalakamme niyuttattā kaṇho. Chasu devalokesu🔽adhipatittā adhipati. Akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ antaṃ gatattā antagū. Pāpajanaṃ na muñcatīti
analyzed: catuttha gāthāya na te mārassa paddhagū ti te mārassa paddhacarā paricārikā sissāḥ na honti  mahājanam pāse niyojetvā māreti iti māraḥ akusala kamme niyuttattā kaṇhaḥ chasu deva lokesu  adhipati ttā adhipati akusalānam dhammānam antam gata ttā antagū pāpa janam na muñcati iti
translated: In the fourth stanza, “They are not Mara’s foot-soldiers” : they are not Mara’s foot-soldiers, his attendants, his disciples.

original: namuci. Sativippavāsappamattapuggalānaṃ ñātakoti pamattabandhu. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva.
analyzed: namuci sati vippavāsa ppamatta puggalānam ñātako ti pamatta bandhu sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva
translated: He kills by binding a great multitude in bondage, thus he is Mara . He is black because he is bound to unwholesome action. He is a lord because he is a lord over the six divine worlds. He is a foot-soldier because he has gone to the end of unwholesome states. He does not release the wicked, thus he is Namuci . He is a friend of the heedless because he is a relative of persons who are heedless through the mere loss of mindfulness. The rest is clear in all its aspects.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā idampi suttaṃ arahattanikūṭeneva desesi, desanāpariyosāne ca pubbasadisova dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: evam bhagavā idam pi suttam arahatta nikūṭena iva desesi desanā pariyosāne ca pubba sadisaḥ va dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: Thus the Exalted One taught this sutta too by the peak of arahantship. And at the conclusion of the teaching, the penetration of the Dhamma by the bhikkhu was similar to the previous case.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the commentary to the Minor Readings, a light on the true Dhamma,

original: Kappamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽11. Jatukaṇṇimāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kappamāṇava sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the Kappamāṇava Sutta is finished.🔽. The Jatukaṇṇi Māṇava Sutta

original: 65. Ekādasame jatukaṇṇisutte – sutvānahaṃ vīra akāmakāminti ahaṃ “itipi so bhagavā”tiādinā
analyzed: ekādasame jatukaṇṇi sutte sutvān aham vīra a kāma kāmin ti aham saḥ bhagavān ati ādinā
translated: In the eleventh sutta, on Jatukaṇṇi, the words “Having heard, O hero, I who am unwilling to desire” refer to the passage beginning “Thus indeed that Exalted One” .

original: nayena vīra kāmānaṃ akāmanato akāmakāmiṃ buddhaṃ sutvā. Akāmamāgamanti nikkāmaṃ bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: nayena vīra kāmānam a kāmanataḥ a kāma kāmim buddham sutvā akāmam āgamanti nikkāmam bhagavantam
translated: I have come to ask the Blessed One, who has no desires,

original: pucchituṃ āgatomhi. Sahajanettāti sahajātasabbaññutaññāṇacakkhu. Yathātacchanti yathātathaṃ.
analyzed: pucchitum āgataḥ amhi sahaja nettā ati sahajāta sabbaññuta ññāṇa cakkhu yathātacchanti yathātatham
translated: who has come without desire.” “The eye of knowledge that is innate” is the eye of knowledge of omniscience that is innate. “The way things are” is the way things are.

original: Brūhi meti puna yācanto bhaṇati. Yācanto hi sahassakkhattumpi bhaṇeyya, ko pana vādo dvikkhattuṃ.
analyzed: brūhi mā iti puna yācantaḥ bhaṇati yācantaḥ hi sahassa kkhattum pi bhaṇeyya kaḥ pana vādaḥ dvi khattum
translated: “Tell me” is said by one who is asking again. For one who is asking would say it even a thousand times, let alone twice.

original: Itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddhoti imesaṃ padānaṃ attho heṭṭhā vuttova. Vijjāhi
analyzed: iti pi saḥ bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ ti imesam padānam atthaḥ heṭṭhā vuttaḥ iva vijjāhi
translated: The meaning of the terms “The Blessed One is … accomplished and fully enlightened” has been given above.

original: pana caraṇena ca sampannattā vijjācaraṇasampanno. Tattha vijjāti tissopi vijjā aṭṭhapi
analyzed: pana caraṇena ca sampanna ttā vijjā caraṇa sampanno tattha vijjā ti tissaḥ api vijjā aṭṭha api
translated: But he is “endowed with knowledge and conduct” because he is endowed with knowledge and conduct. Herein, “knowledge” is the three knowledges or the eight knowledges.

original: vijjā. Tisso vijjā bhayabheravasutte vuttanayena veditabbā, aṭṭha ambaṭṭhasutte.
analyzed: vijjā tissaḥ vijjāḥ bhayabheravasutte vutta nayena veditabbāḥ aṭṭha ambaṭṭha sutte
translated: The three knowledges should be understood in the way stated in the Bhayabherava Sutta, and the eight in the Ambattha Sutta.

original: Tattha hi vipassanāñāṇena manomayiddhiyā ca saha cha abhiññā pariggahetvā aṭṭha vijjā
analyzed: tattha hi vipassanā ñāṇena manaḥ maya iddhiyā ca saha cha abhiññā pariggahetvā aṭṭha vijjā
translated: For in the latter, after including the six kinds of direct knowledge together with the supernormal power of the mind-made body, he said: “The knowledge and vision arose in me: ‘My deliverance is unshakeable; this is my last birth; now there is no renewal of being’” .

original: vuttā. Caraṇanti sīlasaṃvaro indriyesu guttadvāratā bhojane mattaññutā jāgariyānuyogo
analyzed: vuttā sīla saṃvaraḥ indriyesu gutta dvāra tā bhojane mattaññu tā jāgariya anuyogo
translated: and “conduct” .

original: satta saddhammā cattāri rūpāvacarajjhānānīti ime pannarasa dhammā veditabbā. Imeyeva
analyzed: satta saddhammā cattāri rūpāvacara jhānāni iti ime pannarasa dhammāḥ veditabbāḥ
translated: These fifteen ideas should be understood as follows: the seven good states, the four jhana of the fine-material sphere, and the four paths and four fruitions of the supramundane.🔽For it is by means of these fifteen ideas that the Noble Disciple goes to the deathless,

original: hi pannarasa dhammā yasmā etehi carati ariyasāvako gacchati amataṃ disaṃ, tasmā “caraṇa”nti
analyzed: hi pannarasa dhammāḥ yasmai etehi carati ariya sāvakaḥ gacchati amatam disam tasmai
translated: to the direction of deathlessness, and so they are called “conduct” .

original: vuttā. Yathāha – “idha, mahānāma, ariyasāvako sīlavā hotī”ti sabbaṃ majjhimapaṇṇāsake
analyzed: vuttā yathā āha mahānāma ariya sāvako sīlavā hoti iti sabbam majjhima paṇṇāsake
translated: As it is said: “Here, Mahanama, a Noble Disciple is virtuous” , all of which should be understood in the way given in the Majjhima Nikaya in the Mahanama Sutta .

original: vuttanayena veditabbaṃ. Bhagavā imāhi vijjāhi iminā ca caraṇena samannāgato, tena
analyzed: vutta nayena veditabbam bhagavā imāhi vijjāhi iminā ca caraṇena samannāgataḥ tena
translated: The Blessed One is possessed of this knowledge and this conduct,🔽and so he is called “possessed of knowledge and conduct” .

original: vuccati vijjācaraṇasampannoti. Tattha vijjāsampadā bhagavato sabbaññutaṃ pūretvā
analyzed: vuccati vijjā caraṇa sampannaḥ ti tattha vijjā sampadā bhagavato sabbaññu tam pūretvā
translated: Herein, the Blessed One’s perfection of knowledge is established in the fulfilment of omniscience,

original: ṭhitā, caraṇasampadā mahākāruṇikataṃ. So sabbaññutāya sabbasattānaṃ atthānatthaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitā caraṇa sampadā mahā kāruṇika tam saḥ sabbaññu tāya sabba sattānam attha anattham
translated: and his perfection of conduct in the fulfilment of great compassion. Having known by omniscience what is good and bad for all creatures,

original: ñatvā mahākāruṇikatāya anatthaṃ parivajjetvā atthe niyojeti, yathā taṃ vijjācaraṇasampanno.
analyzed: ñatvā mahā kāruṇika tāya anattham parivajjetvā atthe niyojeti yathā tam vijjā caraṇa sampannaḥ
translated: he avoids what is bad and recommends what is good by his great compassion, as one “possessed of knowledge and conduct” does.

original: Tenassa sāvakā suppaṭipannā honti, no duppaṭipannā, vijjācaraṇavipannānañhi sāvakā attantapādayo viya.🔽Sobhanagamanattā sundaraṃ ṭhānaṃ gatattā sammā gatattā sammā ca gadattā sugato. Gamanampi
analyzed: tena assa sāvakā suppaṭipannāḥ honti no duppaṭipannāḥ vijjā caraṇa vipannānam hi sāvakā attantapa ādayaḥ viya  sundaram ṭhānam gatattā sammā gatattā sammā ca sugataḥ gamanampi
translated: For his disciples are well-behaved, not badly behaved. For disciples of those whose knowledge and conduct are defective are like the disciples of the self-immolators.🔽He is “well gone” because of his beautiful going, because of his going to a beautiful place, because of his going rightly, and because of his rightly proclaimed going. For going is called “gone” .

original: hi gatanti vuccati. Tañca bhagavato sobhanaṃ parisuddhamanavajjaṃ. Kiṃ pana tanti?🔽Ariyamaggo. Tena hesa gamanena khemaṃ disaṃ asajjamāno gatoti sobhanagamanattā sugato.
analyzed: hi gata nti vuccati tat ca bhagavato sobhanam parisuddham anavajjam kim pana tat ti  ariya maggo tena ha isa gamanena khemam disam a sajjamānaḥ gataḥ iti sobhana gamana ttā sugato
translated: And that of the Blessed One is beautiful, purified, and blameless. But what is it?🔽It is the noble path. For he has gone to the secure place without impediment by that going. Therefore he is “well gone” because of his beautiful going.

original: Sundarañcesa ṭhānaṃ gato amataṃ nibbānanti sundaraṃ ṭhānaṃ gatattāpi sugato. Sammā
analyzed: sundaram ca isa ṭhānam gataḥ amatam nibbānam ti sundaram ṭhānam gata ttā api sugataḥ sammā
translated: He is “well gone” also because he has gone to a beautiful place, to the deathless Nibbāna.

original: ca gato tena tena maggena pahīne kilese puna apaccāgacchanto. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: ca gataḥ tena tena maggena pahīne kilese puna apaccāgacchantaḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: And he has gone rightly by that path, for he has gone without again returning to the defilements abandoned by each path. For this is said:

original: “Sotāpattimaggena ye kilesā pahīnā, te kilese na puneti na pacceti na paccāgacchatīti
analyzed: sotāpatti maggena ye kilesā pahīnā te kilese na puneti na pacceti na paccāgacchati iti
translated: “The defilements abandoned by the path of stream-entry he does not again enter upon, does not again touch, does not again come to” .

original: sugato…pe… arahattamaggena ye kilesā pahīnā, te kilese na puneti na pacceti na paccāgacchatīti sugato”ti.
analyzed: sugata upe arahatta maggena ye kilesā pahīnā te kilese na puneti na pacceti na paccāgacchati iti sugata uti
translated: He is well-gone because he does not again and again return to and come back to the defilements that have been abandoned by the path of arahatship.

original: Sammā vā gato dīpaṅkarapādamūlato pabhuti yāva bodhimaṇḍā tāva samatiṃsapāramīpūrikāya🔽sammā paṭipattiyā sabbalokassa hitasukhameva karonto sassataṃ ucchedaṃ kāmasukhaṃ
analyzed: sammā vā gataḥ dīpaṅkara pāda mūlataḥ yāva bodhimaṇḍā tāva sama tiṃsa pāramī pūrikāya  sammā paṭipattiyā sabba lokassa hita sukham eva karontaḥ sassatam ucchedam kāma sukham
translated: He is well-gone because he has gone well, that is, because he has gone to the end of the path by fulfilling the thirty perfections from the time of the Buddha Dipankara until he reached the seat of enlightenment.

original: attakilamathanti ime ca ante anupagacchanto gatoti sammā gatattāpi sugato. Sammā
analyzed: attakilamathanti ime ca ante an upagacchantaḥ gataḥ ti sammā gata ttā api sugataḥ sammā
translated: He is well-gone because he has gone to the end of the path by practicing the right way, which is the way that brings welfare and happiness to all the world, and by not falling into either extreme of eternalism or annihilationism, of sensual indulgence or self-mortification.

original: cesa gadati yuttaṭṭhānesu yuttameva vācaṃ bhāsatīti sammā gadattāpi sugato.
analyzed: ca isa gadati yutta ṭṭhānesu yuttam eva vācam bhāsati iti sammā sugataḥ
translated: He is well-gone because he speaks well, that is, because he speaks only what should be spoken and speaks it at the proper time.

original: Tatridaṃ sādhakasuttaṃ –🔽“Yaṃ tathāgato vācaṃ jānāti abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sā ca paresaṃ appiyā
analyzed: tatra idam sādhaka suttam  yam tathāgataḥ vācam jānāti a bhūtam a taccham anattha saṃhitam sā ca paresam appiyā
translated: Here is a sutta that illustrates this:🔽“There may be speech that the Tathagata knows to be untrue, incorrect, and unbeneficial, and which is also unloved and unwelcome to others.

original: amanāpā, na taṃ tathāgato vācaṃ bhāsati. Yampi tathāgato vācaṃ jānāti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ
analyzed: amanāpā na tam tathāgataḥ vācam bhāsati yam api tathāgataḥ vācam jānāti bhūtam tat śam
translated: The Tathagata would not utter such speech. There may be speech that the Tathagata knows to be true, correct, and unbeneficial, and which is also unloved and unwelcome to others.

original: anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sā ca paresaṃ appiyā amanāpā, tampi tathāgato vācaṃ na bhāsati.
analyzed: anattha saṃhitam sā ca paresam appiyā amanāpā tam pi tathāgataḥ vācam na bhāsati
translated: and it is unbeneficial and agreeable to others, the Realised One does not speak that speech.

original: Yañca kho tathāgato vācaṃ jānāti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ, sā ca paresaṃ appiyā
analyzed: yat ca kho tathāgataḥ vācam jānāti bhūtam tat śam attha saṃhitam sā ca paresam appiyā
translated: But that speech which the Realised One knows to be true, correct, and beneficial, and it is unbeneficial and disagreeable to others,

original: amanāpā, tatra kālaññū tathāgato hoti tassā vācāya veyyākaraṇāya. Yaṃ tathāgato vācaṃ🔽jānāti abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ. Sā ca paresaṃ piyā manāpā, na taṃ tathāgato🔽vācaṃ bhāsati. Yampi tathāgato vācaṃ jānāti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ, sā ca
analyzed: amanāpā tatra kālaññū tathāgataḥ hoti tassāḥ vācāya veyyākaraṇāya yam tathāgataḥ vācam  jānāti abhūtam ataccham anattha saṃhitam sā ca paresam piyā manāpā na tam tathāgataḥ  vācam bhāsati yam pi tathāgataḥ vācam jānāti bhūtam tat śam anattha saṃhitam sā ca
translated: the Realised One is one who knows the time for that speech. That speech which the Realised One knows to be untrue, incorrect, and unbeneficial,🔽and it is agreeable and pleasing to others, the Realised One does not speak that speech. But that speech which the Realised One knows to be true, correct, and unbeneficial,

original: paresaṃ piyā manāpā, tampi tathāgato vācaṃ na bhāsati. Yañca kho tathāgato vācaṃ🔽jānāti bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ, sā ca paresaṃ piyā manāpā, tatra kālaññū tathāgato
analyzed: paresam piyā manāpā tam pi tathāgataḥ vācam na bhāsati yat ca kho tathāgataḥ vācam  jānāti bhūtam taccham attha saṃhitam sā ca paresam piyā manāpā tatra kālaññū tathāgataḥ
translated: and it is agreeable and pleasing to others, the Realised One does not speak that speech. But that speech which the Realised One knows to be true, correct, and beneficial,

original: hoti tassā vācāya veyyākaraṇāyā”ti.
analyzed: hoti tassāḥ vācāya veyyākaraṇāya ati
translated: and it is agreeable and pleasing to others, the Realised One is one who knows the time for that speech.”

original: Evaṃ sammā gadattāpi sugatoti veditabbo.
analyzed: evam sammā gadattā api sugataḥ iti veditabbo
translated: Thus it should be understood that the Realised One is well-gone because of speaking correctly.

original: Sabbathā viditalokattā pana lokavidū. So hi bhagavā sabhāvato samudayato nirodhato nirodhūpāyatoti sabbathā lokaṃ avedi aññāsi paṭivijjhi. Yathāha –
analyzed: sabbathā vidita loka ttā pana loka vidū so hi bhagavā sabhāvataḥ samudayataḥ nirodhataḥ nirodha upāyataḥ ti sabbathā lokam avedi aññāsi paṭivijjhi yathā āha
translated: But because He has understood the world in all ways, He is the “world-knower.” For the Blessed One has understood, known, and penetrated the world in all ways, as regards its nature, its origin, its cessation, and the way leading to its cessation. As it is said:

original: “Yattha kho, āvuso, na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati, nāhaṃ🔽taṃ gamanena lokassa antaṃ ñāteyyaṃ daṭṭheyyaṃ patteyyanti vadāmi. Na cāhaṃ, āvuso,🔽appatvāva lokassa antaṃ dukkhassa antakiriyaṃ vadāmi. Api cāhaṃ, āvuso, imasmiṃyeva
analyzed: yattha kho āvuso na jāyati na jīyati na mīyati na cavati na upapajjati na aham  tam gamanena lokassa antam ñāteyyam daṭṭheyyam patteyyam ti vadāmi na ca aham āvuso  a patvā ava lokassa antam dukkhassa anta kiriyam vadāmi api ca aham āvuso imasmin yeva
translated: “Friend, I do not say that the end of the world can be known, seen, or reached by travelling.🔽But, friend, I do not say that the end of suffering can be reached without reaching the end of the world.

original: byāmamatte kaḷevare sasaññimhi samanake lokañca paññapemi lokasamudayañca lokanirodhañca🔽lokanirodhagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ.
analyzed: byāma matte kaḷevare sa saññimhi samanake lokañca paññapemi loka samudayañca loka nirodhañca  loka nirodha gāminiṃ ca paṭipadam
translated: Friend, I declare this world to be with its self, with its passion, with its bondage, and I declare the world beyond, which is different from the former, to be without self, without passion, without bondage.

original: “Gamanena na pattabbo, lokassanto kudācanaṃ;
analyzed: gamanena na pattabbaḥ lokaḥ santaḥ kudācanam
translated: “The end of the world cannot be reached by travelling.

original: Na ca appatvā lokantaṃ, dukkhā atthi pamocanaṃ.
analyzed: na ca a patvā lokantam dukkhā atthi pamocanam
translated: And without reaching the end of the world, suffering cannot be ended.

original: “Tasmā have lokavidū sumedho, lokantagū vusitabrahmacariyo;
analyzed: tasmai have loka vidū sumedhaḥ lokantagū
translated: “Therefore, the world-knower, the wise one, has lived the holy life

original: Lokassa antaṃ samitāvi ñatvā, nāsīsatī lokamimaṃ parañcā”ti. ;🔽Api ca – tayo lokā saṅkhāraloko sattaloko okāsalokoti. Tattha “eko loko sabbe sattā🔽āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti āgataṭṭhāne saṅkhāraloko veditabbo. “Sassato lokoti vā asassato
analyzed: lokassa antam samitā avi ñatvā lokam imam parañca ati  api ca tayaḥ lokā saṅkhāra loko satta lokaḥ okāsa loko ti tattha ekaḥ loko sabbe sattā  āhāra ṭṭhitikā ti āgata ṭṭhāne saṅkhāra loko veditabbo sassataḥ loko ti vā a sassataḥ
translated: The knower of the world’s end, having known the world’s end, does not lead the world to the world again.”🔽Moreover, there are three worlds: the world of formations , the world of beings , and the world of location . Herein, the world of formations should be understood as the world stated thus: “One world, monks, I declare, all beings

original: lokoti vā”ti āgataṭṭhāne sattaloko.
analyzed: loko ti vā ti āgata ṭṭhāne satta loko
translated: live on.” The world of beings is stated thus: “The world is eternal, or the world is not eternal” .

original: “Yāvatā candimasūriyā pariharanti, disā bhanti virocamānā;
analyzed: yāvatā candima sūriyā pariharanti disā bhanti virocamānā
translated: The world of location is stated thus: “As far as the moon and sun revolve, shining,

original: Tāva sahassadhā loko, ettha te vattatī vaso”ti. –
analyzed: tāva sahassadhā lokaḥ ettha te vattatī
translated: so much is this world, so much is what is born, become, and produced. Herein, your power extends.”

original: Āgataṭṭhāne okāsaloko. Tampi bhagavā sabbathā avedi. Tathā hissa “eko loko sabbe
analyzed: āgata ṭṭhāne okāsa loko tam pi bhagavā sabbathā avedi tathā hi ssa ekaḥ loko sabbe
translated: The Blessed One knew all these worlds in all aspects. For he knew the world of formations thus: “One world, monks, I declare, all beings

original: sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā. Dve lokā nāmañca rūpañca. Tayo lokā tisso vedanā. Cattāro lokā
analyzed: sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā dve lokā nāmañca rūpañca tayaḥ lokā tisso vedanā cattāro lokā
translated: live on. Two worlds: name and form. Three worlds: the three kinds of feeling. Four worlds:

original: cattāro āhārā. Pañca lokā pañcupādānakkhandhā. Cha lokā cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni.
analyzed: cattāro āhārā pañca lokā pañca upādānakkhandhā cha lokā cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni
translated: the four kinds of nutriment. Five worlds: the five aggregates as objects of clinging. Six worlds: the six internal bases.

original: Satta lokā satta viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo. Aṭṭha lokā aṭṭha lokadhammā. Nava lokā nava sattāvāsā.
analyzed: satta lokā satta viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ aṭṭha lokāḥ aṭṭha loka dhammā nava lokāḥ nava sattāvāsā
translated: the seven worlds, the seven stations of consciousness, the eight worlds, the eight worldly ideas, the nine worlds, the nine abodes of beings,

original: Dasa lokā dasāyatanāni. Dvādasa lokā dvādasāyatanāni. Aṭṭhārasalokā aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo”ti
analyzed: dasa lokāḥ dasa āyatanāni dvādasa lokāḥ dvādasa āyatanāni aṭṭhārasa lokāḥ aṭṭhārasa
translated: the ten worlds, the ten bases, the twelve worlds, the twelve bases, the eighteen worlds, the eighteen elements.

original: ayaṃ saṅkhāralokopi sabbathā vidito.
analyzed: ayam saṅkhāra lokaḥ api sabbathā vidito
translated: So this world of formations is known in all ways.

original: Yasmā panesa sabbesampi sattānaṃ āsayaṃ jānāti, anusayaṃ jānāti, caritaṃ jānāti,
analyzed: yasmā pana esa sabbesam pi sattānam āsayam jānāti anusayam jānāti caritam jānāti

analyzed: atha vā anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathī iti ekam eva idam attha padam bhagavā hi tathā purisa damme  sāra iti yathā eka pallaṅkena iva nisinnāḥ aṭṭha disā a sajjamānāḥ dhāvanti tasmai anuttaraḥ  purisa damma sārathī iti vuccati hatthi damakena bhikkhave hatthi dammo sāritaḥ ekam yeva

analyzed: tādi nibbikāratāya pavuccate tathattā ati tathārūpaḥ vīriyavā ati pavuccati  te kāma kāmino ti ete rūpa ādi vatthu kāme icchantā rāga rāgino ti rāgena rañjitā saññā saññino ti  rāga saññāya saññinaḥ na kāme kāmeti iti rūpa ādi vatthu kāme na pattheti akāmo ti kāmehi

original: virahito. Nikkāmoti nikkantakāmo.🔽Sabbaññutaññāṇanti tiyaddhagataṃ sabbaneyyapathaṃ jānātīti sabbaññū, tassa bhāvo

translated: “They do not desire sense desires” do not seek sense desires having form, etc. as their object. “They who are not desirous” are devoid of sense desires. “They who are free from desire” are free from sense desires.

original: sabbaññutā, sabbaññutā eva ñāṇaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, sabbaññutaññāṇasaṅkhātaṃ nettañca
analyzed: sabbaññu tā sabbaññu tā eva ñāṇam sabbaññu tad ñāṇam sabbaññu tad ñāṇa saṅkhātam nettam ca
translated: “The knowledge of omniscience” : he is “omniscient” because he knows the entire range of what should be known in the three times. His state is “omniscience” . Omniscience itself is knowledge, i.e., the knowledge of omniscience. The guide consisting in the knowledge of omniscience

original: vāsanāya saha kilese parājetvā jitattā jinabhāvo ca apubbaṃ acarimaṃ apure apacchā
analyzed: vāsanāya saha kilese parājetvā jita ttā jina bhāvaḥ ca apubbam acarimam a pure apacchā
translated: and the state of victory, i.e., the fact that he has conquered by vanquishing the defilements together with their residues, are unprecedented and without a second.

original: ekasmiṃ khaṇe ekasmiṃ kāle uppanno pubbantato uddhaṃ pannoti uppanno.
analyzed: ekasmin khaṇe ekasmin kāle uppannaḥ pubbantataḥ uddham panno ti uppannaḥ
translated: In one moment, in one instant, arisen: arisen from the past.

original: 66. Tejī tejasāti tejena samannāgato tejasā abhibhuyya. Yamahaṃ vijaññaṃ jātijarāya idha vippahānanti yaṃ ahaṃ jātijarāya pahānabhūtaṃ dhammaṃ idheva jāneyyaṃ.
analyzed: tejī tejasā ati tejena samannāgato tejasā abhibhuyya yam aham vijaññam jāti jarāya idha vippahānan ti yam aham jāti jarāya pahāna bhūtam dhammam idha iva jāneyyam
translated: Tejī tejas: endowed with heat, having overcome with heat. Yamahaṃ vijaññaṃ jātijarāya idha vippahānanti: I would know here and now the Dhamma that is the state of abandoning birth and aging.

original: Jagatīti pathavī. Sabbaṃ ākāsagatanti sakalaṃ ākāse pavattaṃ patthaṭaṃ. Tamagatanti🔽tamameva tamagataṃ andhakāraṃ yathā gūthagataṃ muttagatanti. Abhivihaccāti nāsetvā.
analyzed: jagatī iti pathavī sabbam ākāsa gatam ti sakalam ākāse pavattam patthaṭam  tamam eva tama gatam andhakāram yathā gūtha gatam mutta gatanti
translated: Jagatī: the earth. Sabbaṃ ākāsagataṃ: all that is spread out in the sky. Tamagataṃ:🔽darkness. Abhivihacca: having destroyed.

original: Andhakāraṃ vidhamitvāti cakkhuviññāṇuppattinivārakaṃ andhakāraṃ palāpetvā. Ālokaṃ
analyzed: andhakāram vidhamitvā ti cakkhu viññāṇa uppatti nivārakam andhakāram palāpetvā ālokam
translated: Andhakāraṃ vidhamitvā: having dispelled the darkness that prevents the arising of eye-consciousness. Ālokaṃ

original: dassayitvāti sūriyālokaṃ dassayitvā. Ākāseti ajaṭākāse. Antalikkheti antaradhātusamatthatucchokāse.
analyzed: dassayitvā iti sūriya ālokam dassayitvā ākāsā iti ajaṭa ākāse antalikkhā iti antara dhātu samattha tuccha ukāse
translated: dassayitvā: having shown the light of the sun. Ākāse: in the sky without clouds. Antalikkhe: in the sky with clouds.

original: Gaganapatheti devatānaṃ gamanamagge gacchati. Sabbaṃ abhisaṅkhārasamudayanti sakalaṃ
analyzed: gagana pathā iti devatānam gamana magge gacchati sabbam sakalam
translated: Gaganapathe: going along the path of the gods. Sabbaṃ abhisaṅkhārasamudayanti: all that is the arising of formations.

original: kammaṃ samudayaṃ uppādaṃ, taṇhanti attho. Kilesatamaṃ avijjandhakāraṃ vidhamitvāti
analyzed: kammam samudayam uppādam taṇhanti attho kilesatamam avijja andhakāram vidhamitvā ati
translated: and kamma is its origination, its arising, its source is craving. Having dispelled the darkness of ignorance, the gloom,🔽having removed, having destroyed, the unknowing called the darkness of defilements, the gloom of ignorance,

original: kilesatamasaṅkhātaṃ aññāṇaṃ avijjandhakāraṃ nīharitvā nāsetvā. Ñāṇālokaṃ paññālokaṃ
analyzed: kilesa tama saṅkhātam aññāṇam avijja andhakāram nīharitvā nāsetvā ñāṇa ālokam paññā ālokam
translated: having shown the light of knowledge, the light of wisdom,

original: dassayitvā. Vatthukāme parijānitvāti rūpādivatthukāme ñātatīraṇapariññāya jānitvā.
analyzed: dassayitvā vatthu kāme parijānitvā ati rūpa ādi vatthu kāme ñāta tīraṇa pariññāya jānitvā
translated: having fully understood sensual desires as objects, having known sensual desires as objects consisting in visible forms, etc., by the full-understanding of their knownness,

original: Kilesakāme pahāyāti upatāpanasaṅkhāte kilesakāme pahānapariññāya pajahitvā.
analyzed: kilesa kāme pahāya ati upatāpana saṅkhāte kilesa kāme pahāna pariññāya pajahitvā
translated: having abandoned sensual desires as defilements, having given them up by the full-understanding of their abandonment,

original: 67. Athassa bhagavā taṃ dhammaṃ ācikkhanto uparūparigāthāyo abhāsi. Tattha nekkhammaṃ🔽daṭṭhu khematoti nibbānañca nibbānagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ “khema”nti disvā. Uggahitanti
analyzed: athassa bhagavā tam dhammaṃ ācikkhantaḥ upari upari gāthāyaḥ abhāsi tattha nekkhammam  daṭṭhu khemato ti nibbānam ca nibbāna gāminim ca paṭipadam khemanti disvā uggahitanti
translated: Then the Blessed One, teaching him that Dhamma, spoke these further verses. Herein, having seen security in renunciation🔽he should give up what is taken: having seen Nibbāna and the way leading to Nibbāna as “security,”🔽he should give up what is taken by craving and by views.

original: taṇhāvasena diṭṭhivasena gahitaṃ. Nirattaṃ vāti nirassitabbaṃ vā, muñcitabbanti vuttaṃ
analyzed: taṇhā vasena diṭṭhi vasena gahitam nirattam vā ati nirassitabbam vā muñcitabbanti vuttam
translated: What is meant is that he should give up what is taken by craving and by views.

original: hoti. Mā te vijjitthāti mā te ahosi. Kiñcananti rāgādikiñcanaṃ, tampi te mā vijjittha.
analyzed: hoti mā te vijjittha ati mā te ahosi kiñcanam ti rāga ādi kiñcanam tam pi te mā vijjittha
translated: Let there be no more “I am” for you: let there be no more “I am” in regard to the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: Muñcitabbanti muñcitvā na puna gahetabbaṃ. Vijahitabbanti cajitabbaṃ. Vinodetabbanti
analyzed: muñcitabbanti muñcitvā na puna gahetabbanti vijahitabbanti cajitabbam vinodetabbanti
translated: “Should be given up”: having given it up, it should not be taken up again. “Should be relinquished”: should be discarded. “Should be abandoned”:

original: khipitabbaṃ. Byantīkātabbanti vigatantaṃ kātabbaṃ. Anabhāvaṃ gametabbanti anu anu abhāvaṃ gametabbaṃ.
analyzed: khipitabbam byantīkātabbanti vigata antam kātabbam anabhāvam gametabbanti anu anu abhāvam gametabbam
translated: Should be given up: having given up, they should not be taken up again. Should be abandoned: they should be discarded. Should be got rid of: they should be thrown away. Should be done away with: they should be made free from doing. Should be brought to an end: they should be brought to an end again and again.

original: 68-9. Pubbeti atīte saṅkhāre ārabbha uppannakilesā. Brāhmaṇāti bhagavā jatukaṇṇiṃ ālapati. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva.
analyzed: pubba iti atīte saṅkhāre ārabbha uppanna kilesāḥ brāhmaṇa iti bhagavā jatukaṇṇim ālapati sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva
translated: . In the past: defilements that have arisen in regard to past formations. Brahmin: the Blessed One is addressing Jatukaṇṇi. The rest is clear in all its aspects.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā idampi suttaṃ arahattanikūṭeneva desesi, desanāpariyosāne ca pubbasadiso eva dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.

translated: Thus the Blessed One taught this Thread too by the peak of arahantship, and at the end of the teaching the penetration of the True Idea was the same as before.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the Minor Commentary on the First Fifty Discourses of the Middle Length Collection
