With the fourth, that is, with the fourth jhāna, he meditates with unification of mind that is equanimous and possesses mindfulness and is neither blissful nor suffering. With the jhāna that possesses applied thought and sustained thought, that is, with the first jhāna in the fourfold reckoning and with the first and second jhānas in the fivefold reckoning, he meditates with applied thought and sustained thought. With that which possesses only sustained thought and is without applied thought, that is, with the second jhāna in the fivefold reckoning. With that which is without applied thought and without sustained thought, that is, with the remaining jhānas beginning with the third. With that which possesses happiness, that is, with the jhāna that possesses happiness in the three- factored reckoning. With that which is without happiness, that is, with the remaining jhāna that is without happiness. With that which possesses bliss, that is, with the jhāna that possesses bliss in the four- factored and five- factored reckonings. With that which possesses equanimity, that is, with the fourth jhāna in the four- factored reckoning and with the fifth jhāna in the five- factored reckoning. With the void, that is, with the void attainment. With the desireless, that is, with the desireless attainment. With the signless, that is, with the signless attainment. With the desire for the destruction of lust, that is, with the desire for the destruction of lust in the sense of the path. With the desire for the destruction of hatred, that is, with the desire for the destruction of hatred in the sense of the path. With the desire for the destruction of delusion, that is, with the desire for the destruction of delusion in the sense of the path.

original: jhānena jhāyatīti jhāyī. Appaṇihitenapīti maggāgamanavasena paṇidhiṃ sodhetvā pariyādiyitvā
analyzed: jhānena jhāyati iti jhāyī appaṇihitena api iti magga āgamana vasena paṇidhim sodhetvā
translated: “He is a meditator” : he meditates with jhāna, thus he is a meditator. “With the desireless” : he is also one who has purified and surmounted the desire for the attainment of the path by means of the desireless fourth jhāna.

original: phalasamāpattivasena appaṇihitenapi. Lokiyenapīti lokiyena paṭhamadutiyatatiyacatutthena.
analyzed: phala samāpatti vasena appaṇihitena api lokiyena api iti lokiyena paṭhama dutiya tatiya catutthena
translated: “With the mundane” : with the mundane first, second, third, and fourth jhānas.

original: Lokuttarenapīti teneva lokuttarasampayuttena. Jhānaratoti jhānesu abhirato. Ekattamanuyuttoti🔽ekattaṃ ekībhāvaṃ anuyutto payutto. Sadatthagarukoti sakatthagaruko, ka-kārassāyaṃ🔽da-kāro kato. Sadatthoti ca arahattaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tañhi attūpanibaddhaṭṭhena attānaṃ
analyzed: lokuttarena api iti tena iva lokuttara sampayuttena jhāna rataḥ ti jhānesu abhirataḥ ekattam anuyuttaḥ ti  ekattam ekībhāvam anuyuttaḥ payuttaḥ sadattha garuko ti sakattha garukaḥ kakārassa ayam  dakāraḥ kataḥ sat atthaḥ ti ca arahattam veditabbam tat hi attu upanibaddha ṭṭhena attānam
translated: “With the supramundane” : with the supramundane jhāna associated with the path. “Delights in jhāna” : he delights in jhāna. “Intent on unity” : intent on oneness, on unity.🔽“Cherishing his own good” : cherishing his own good, his own welfare. The letter da in the Pali word for “cherishing” , namely, garukatta,🔽is a retroflex consonant. “His own good” should be understood as arahatship. For that is called one’s own good because it is bound up with oneself in the sense of being one’s own, because it is not abandoned by oneself, and because it is the highest good for oneself.

original: avijahanaṭṭhena attano paramatthaṭṭhena ca attano atthattā sakatthoti vuccati. Phalasamāpattisamāpajjanavasena
analyzed: avijahana ṭhena attano paramattha ṭṭhena ca attano atthattā sakattho ti vuccati phala samāpatti samāpajjana vasena
translated: Cherishing his own good by means of the attainment of the fruition,

original: sakatthagaruko, “nibbānagaruko”ti eke. Arajoti nikkileso. Virajoti vigatakileso.
analyzed: sakatthagarukaḥ nibbāna garukaḥ ti eke arajaḥ ati nikkilesaḥ virajaḥ ati vigata kilesaḥ
translated: some say, “he cherishes Nibbāna.” “Free from passion” : free from defilements. “Stainless” : free from defilements.

original: Nirajoti apanītakileso, “vitarajo”tipi pāṭho, soyevattho. Rajāpagatoti kilesehi dūrībhūto.
analyzed: nirajaḥ ti apanīta kilesaḥ pāṭhaḥ raja apagataḥ ti kilesehi dūrībhūtaḥ
translated: “Dust-free” : rid of defilements. The reading “vitaraja” has the same meaning. “Gone beyond dust” : become remote from defilements.🔽“Given up dust” : given up defilements. “Freed from dust” : freed from defilements.

original: Rajavippahīnoti kilesappahīno. Rajavippayuttoti kilesehi mutto.🔽Pāsāṇake cetiyeti pāsāṇapiṭṭhe pārāyanasuttantadesitaṭṭhāne. Sabbossukkapaṭippassaddhattāti sabbesaṃ kilesaussukkānaṃ paṭippassaddhattā, nāsitattā āsīno.🔽Kiccākiccanti “idaṃ kattabbaṃ, idaṃ na kattabba”nti evaṃ manasā cintetabbaṃ. Karaṇīyākaraṇīyanti🔽kāyadvārena avassaṃ idaṃ karaṇīyaṃ, idaṃ na karaṇīyanti evaṃ karaṇīyākaraṇīyaṃ. Pahīnanti
analyzed: raja vippahīno ti kilesa ppahīnaḥ raja vippayuttaḥ ti kilesehi muttaḥ  pāsāṇake cetiyā iti pāsāṇa piṭṭhe pārāyana suttanta desita ṭṭhāne sabba ussukka paṭippassaddhattā ati sabbesam kilesa ussukkānam paṭippassaddhattā na āsita ttā āsīnaḥ  kicca akiccanti idam kattabbam idam na kattabbanti evam manasā cintetabbam karaṇīya a karaṇīyam iti  kāya dvārena idam karaṇīyam idam na karaṇīyanti evam karaṇīya akaraṇīyam pahīnam ti
translated: “Seated on the rocky slab” : seated on the rocky slab at the place where the Parayana Suttanta was taught. “Because of the complete cessation of all that is unwholesome” : because of the destruction of all the unwholesomeness of defilements.

original: vissaṭṭhaṃ. Vasippattoti paguṇabhāvappatto.🔽75. Atha bhagavā yasmā udayo catutthajjhānalābhī, tasmāssa paṭiladdhajhānavasena
analyzed: vissaṭṭham vasi patto ti paguṇa bhāva ppatto 🔽atha bhagavā yasmai udayaḥ catuttha jhāna lābhī tasmai sa paṭiladdha jhāna vasena
translated: “Worthy of being done and unworthy of being done” : what should be done and what should not be done by thinking with the mind thus: “This should be done, this should not be done.” “Worthy of being done and unworthy of being done by action” : what should be done and what should not be done by action through the door of the body thus: “This should be done by action, this should not be done by action.” “Worthy of being done and unworthy of being done by speech” : what should be done and what should not be done by speech thus: “This should be done by speech, this should not be done by speech.” “Worthy of being done and unworthy of being done by mind” : what should be done and what should not be done by mind thus: “This should be done by mind, this should not be done by mind.” “Worthy of being done and unworthy of being done by body, speech, and mind” : what should be done and what should not be done by body, speech, and mind thus: “This should be done by body, speech, and mind, this should not be done by body, speech, and mind.” “Worthy of being done and unworthy of being done in the world” : what should be done and what should not be done in the world thus: “This should be done in the world, this should not be done in the world.” “Worthy of being done and unworthy of being done in the Dispensation” : what should be done and what should not be done in the Dispensation thus: “This should be done in the Dispensation, this should not be done in the Dispensation.” “Worthy of being done and unworthy of being done by a recluse” : what should be done and what should not be done by a recluse thus: “This should be done by a recluse, this should

original: nānappakārato aññāvimokkhaṃ dassento uparūparigāthamāha. Tattha pahānaṃ kāmacchandānanti
analyzed: nānā ppakārataḥ aññā vimokkham dassentaḥ upari upari gātham āha tattha pahānam kāmacchandānam ti
translated: showing the other kinds of deliverance in various ways, he uttered the following verse. Herein, abandoning of sensual desire

original: yadidaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ nibbattentassa kāmacchandapahānaṃ, tampi aññāvimokkhanti
analyzed: yat idam paṭhamam jhānam nibbattentassa kāmacchanda pahānam tat pi
translated: Showing the other kinds of deliverance by way of the various kinds of defilements, he uttered the following stanza. Herein, abandoning of lust for sensual desires is the abandoning of lust for sensual desires that occurs in one who generates the first jhāna. That too is a deliverance by way of knowledge.

original: pabrūmi. Evaṃ sabbapadāni yojetabbāni.🔽Yā cittassa akalyatāti cittassa gilānabhāvo. Gilāno hi akallakoti vuccati. Vinayepi
analyzed: evam sabba padāni yojetabbāni  yā cittassa cittassa gilāna bhāvaḥ gilānaḥ hi akallakaḥ ti vuccati vinaye pi
translated: So too with all the terms.

original: vuttaṃ – “nāhaṃ, bhante, akallako”ti. Akammaññatāti cittagelaññasaṅkhātova akammaññatākāro.🔽Olīyanāti olīyanākāro. Iriyāpathikacittañhi iriyāpathaṃ sandhāretuṃ asakkontaṃ rukkhe
analyzed: vuttam na aham bhante a kallakaḥ ti akammañña tā ati citta gelañña saṅkhātaḥ va akammañña tā ākāraḥ  olīyanā ati olīyana ākāraḥ iriyāpathika cittam hi iriyāpatham sandhāretum a sakkontam rukkhe
translated: The unfitness of cognizance is the sickliness of cognizance. For one who is sick is called “unfit” . In the Vinaya too it is said: “I am not unfit, venerable sir” . Unfitness of cognizance is the aspect of unfitness due to the sickliness of cognizance.

original: vagguli viya khīle laggitaphāṇitavārako viya ca olīyati, tassa taṃ ākāraṃ sandhāya
analyzed: vagguli viya khīle laggita phāṇita vārakaḥ viya ca olīyati tassa tam ākāram sandhāya
translated: Sagging is the aspect of sagging. For when the cognizance that is the basis for deportment is unable to support the deportment, it sags like a creeper on a tree or like a rope of fibers on a post. With reference to that aspect,

original: “olīyanā”ti vuttaṃ. Dutiyapadaṃ upasaggavasena vaḍḍhitaṃ. Līnāti avipphārikatāya
analyzed: olīyanā ti vuttam dutiya padam upasagga vasena vaḍḍhitam līnā ti a vipphārika tāya
translated: “sagging” is said. The second term is the first with the prefix u added. Slackened is the aspect of slackened cognizance due to its lack of expansion.

original: paṭikuṭitaṃ. Itare dve ākārabhāvaniddesā. Thinanti sappipiṇḍo viya avipphārikatāya
analyzed: paṭikuṭitam itare dve ākāra bhāva niddesā sappi piṇḍaḥ viya a vipphārika tāya
translated: The other two are descriptions of the development of the mode. “Slack” is like a lump of fat that has no spread.

original: ghanabhāvena ṭhitaṃ. Thiyanāti ākāraniddeso. Thiyitabhāvo thiyitattaṃ, avipphāravaseneva thaddhatāti attho.
analyzed: ghana bhāvena ṭhitam ākāra niddeso thiyita bhāvaḥ thiyitattam a vipphāra vasena iva attho
translated: The other two are descriptions of the mode. Stiff: not spreading out like a lump of fat, it is stiff through being compact. Stiffness: this is a description of the mode. The state of being stiff is stiffness. The meaning is: unbending through lack of spreading out.

original: 76. Upekkhāsatisaṃsuddhanti catutthajjhānaupekkhāsatīhi saṃsuddhaṃ. Dhammatakkapurejavanti
analyzed: upekkhā sati saṃsuddham ti catuttha jhāna aupekkhā satīhi saṃsuddham dhamma takka purejavanti
translated: Pure in equanimity and mindfulness: purified by the equanimity and mindfulness of the fourth jhāna. Preceded by the act of defining:

original: iminā tasmiṃ catutthajjhānavimokkhe ṭhatvā jhānaṅgāni vipassitvā adhigataṃ arahattavimokkhaṃ
analyzed: iminā tasmin catuttha jhāna vimokkhe ṭhatvā jhāna aṅgāni vipassitvā adhigatam arahatta vimokkhaṃ
translated: by this he shows that he is speaking of the deliverance of Arahantship which he has reached by standing in that fourth-jhana deliverance of mind and by insight into the jhāna factors.

original: vadati. Arahattavimokkhassa hi maggasampayuttasammāsaṅkappādibhedo dhammatakko purejavo🔽hoti. Tenāha “dhammatakkapurejava”nti. Avijjāya pabhedananti etameva ca aññāvimokkhaṃ
analyzed: vadati arahatta vimokkhassa hi magga sampayutta sammāsaṅkappa ādi bhedaḥ dhamma takkaḥ purejavaḥ  hoti tena āha dhamma takka purejavanti avijjāya pabhedananti etam eva ca aññā vimokkham
translated: For the act of defining, which is the right thought, etc., associated with the path, is the forerunner of the deliverance of Arahantship.🔽Hence he said: “Preceded by the act of defining.” The breaking up of ignorance:

original: avijjāpabhedanasaṅkhātaṃ nibbānaṃ nissāya jātattā kāraṇopacārena “avijjāya pabhedana”nti brūmīti.
analyzed: avijjā pabhedana saṅkhātam nibbānam nissāya jāta ttā kāraṇa upacārena avijjāya pabhedananti brūmi iti
translated: we say that this deliverance of the Arahant is “the breaking up of ignorance” figuratively, since it is born with Nibbāna, the “breaking up of ignorance,” as its support.

original: Yā catutthe jhāne upekkhāti ettha upapattito ikkhatīti upekkhā, samaṃ passati apakkhapatitā
analyzed: yā catutthe jhāne upekkhā ati ettha upapattito ikkhati iti upekkhā samam passati a pakkha pati tā
translated: “Equanimity” is equanimity in the fourth jhāna. Herein, it is looked at , thus it is equanimity ; it is looked at evenly, without partiality,

original: hutvā passatīti attho. Upekkhanāti ākāraniddeso. Ajjhupekkhanāti upasaggavasena padaṃ
analyzed: hutvā passati iti attho upekkhanā ati ākāra niddesaḥ ajjhupekkhanā ti upasagga vasena padam
translated: without leaning to one side. The meaning is that it is looked at after making it even. Equanimity is a description of the mode. Equanimity about means the word is compounded with the prefix upa in the sense of proximity.

original: vaḍḍhitaṃ. Cittasamatāti cittassekaggabhāvo. Cittappassaddhatāti cittassa ūnātirittavajjitabhāvo.
analyzed: vaḍḍhitam citta sama tā ati cittassa ikagga bhāvo citta ppassaddha tā ati cittassa ūna atiritta vajjita bhāvo
translated: The mind’s composure is the mind’s unification. The mind’s confidence is the mind’s being free from the fault of being low or over-exerted.

original: Majjhattatāti cittassa majjhe ṭhitabhāvo.
analyzed: majjhatta tā ati cittassa majjhe ṭhita bhāvaḥ
translated: The mind’s steadiness is the mind’s steadiness in the middle.

original: 77. Evaṃ avijjāpabhedavacanena vuttaṃ nibbānaṃ sutvā “taṃ kissa vippahānena vuccatī”ti
analyzed: evam avijjā apabheda vacanena vuttam nibbānam sutvā tat kissa vippahānena vuccati iti
translated: Having heard it said that Nibbāna is described as the abandoning of ignorance, he asks, “What is it that is fettered? ”🔽inquiring into the meaning of the words, “What is it that is fettered? ”🔽What is the cause of the inquiry?

original: pucchanto “kiṃsu saṃyojano”ti gāthamāha. Tattha kiṃsu saṃyojanoti kiṃsaṃyojano. Vicāraṇanti🔽vicāraṇakāraṇaṃ. Kissassa vippahānenāti kiṃnāmakassa assa dhammassa vippahānena.
analyzed: pucchantaḥ gātham āha tattha kiṃsu saṃyojanaḥ iti kiṃsaṃyojanaḥ vicāraṇanti  vicāraṇa kāraṇam kissassa vippahānena ati kiṃnāmakassa assa dhammassa vippahānena
translated: By the abandoning of what?

original: 78. Athassa bhagavā tamatthaṃ byākaronto “nandisaṃyojano”ti gāthamāha. Tattha vitakkassāti kāmavitakkādiko vitakko assa.
analyzed: athassa bhagavā tam attham byākarontaḥ nandisaṃyojanaḥ ti gātham āha tattha vitakkassa ati kāma vitakka ādikaḥ vitakkaḥ assa
translated: Then the Blessed One, explaining the meaning of that, uttered the third stanza, “By the abandoning of lust, O Bhikkhu, one is not fettered” . Herein, his is his, that is, the bhikkhu’s.

original: 79. Idāni tassa nibbānassa maggaṃ pucchanto “kathaṃ satassā”ti gāthamāha. Tattha viññāṇanti abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: idāni tassa nibbānassa maggam pucchantaḥ katham satassa ati gātham āha tattha viññāṇam ti abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇam
translated: Now, asking the path to that Nibbāna, he asked the question beginning, “How does one who is mindful?” Herein, consciousness is the consciousness that is a formation.

original: Athassa maggaṃ kathento bhagavā “ajjhattañcā”ti gāthamāha. Tattha evaṃ satassāti evaṃ satassa sampajānassa. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva.
analyzed: athassa maggam kathentaḥ bhagavā ajjhattam ca iti gātham āha tattha evam satassa ati evam satassa sampajānassa sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva
translated: Then the Blessed One, telling him the path, uttered the stanza beginning “Internally and externally too.” Herein, thus mindful thus is thus mindful, possessed of full awareness. The rest is plain in all instances.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā idampi suttaṃ arahattanikūṭeneva desesi, desanāpariyosāne ca pubbasadisova dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: evam bhagavā idam pi suttam arahatta nikūṭena iva desesi desanā pariyosāne ca pubba sadisaḥ va dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: So the Blessed One taught this sutta too by the peak of the arahant path. And at the end of the teaching the penetration of the Dhamma was the same as before.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the brief exposition in the Niddesa, the light of the true Dhamma,🔽is finished.

original: Udayamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽14. Posālamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: udayamāṇava sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the brief exposition of the sutta about Udayamanavita is finished.

original: 81. Cuddasame posālasutte – yo atītaṃ ādisatīti yo bhagavā attano ca paresañca “ekampi jāti”ntiādibhedaṃ atītaṃ ādisati.
analyzed: cuddasame posāla sutte yaḥ atītam ādisati iti yaḥ bhagavā attano ca paresam ca ekam pi atītam ādisati
translated: In the fourteenth sutta, the Posāla sutta, the verse “He who declares what is past” means that the Blessed One declares what is past, beginning with “One birth, two births … ten births” , both of himself and others.

original: Ekampi jātinti ekampi paṭisandhimūlakaṃ cutipariyosānaṃ ekabhavapariyāpannaṃ khandhasantānaṃ.
analyzed: ekam pi ekam pi paṭisandhi mūlakam cuti pariyosānam eka bhava pariyāpannam khandha santānam
translated: One birth: one continuity of aggregates included in one becoming, having one rebirth-linking as its root and death as its end.

original: Esa nayo dvepi jātiyotiādīsu. Anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappetiādīsu pana parihāyamāno kappo
analyzed: esa nayaḥ dve pi jātiyo ti ādīsu aneke pi saṃvaṭṭa kappa iti ādīsu pana parihāyamānaḥ kappo
translated: In the case of many aeons of world-contraction, etc., an aeon of contraction is an aeon of contraction and of stasis,

original: saṃvaṭṭakappo, tadā sabbesaṃ brahmaloke sannipatanato. Vaḍḍhamāno kappo vivaṭṭakappo,
analyzed: saṃvaṭṭa kappaḥ tadā sabbesam brahmaloke sannipatanataḥ vaḍḍhamāno kappaḥ vivaṭṭa kappaḥ
translated: because all beings are included in the Brahmā-world at that time. An aeon of expansion is an aeon of expansion and of stasis,

original: tadā brahmalokato sattānaṃ vivaṭṭanato. Tattha saṃvaṭṭena saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyī gahito hoti🔽taṃmūlakattā, vivaṭṭena ca vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyī. Evañhi sati yāni tāni “cattārimāni, bhikkhave,
analyzed: tadā brahmalokato sattānam vivaṭṭanato tattha saṃvaṭṭena saṃvaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī gahitaḥ hoti  tad mūlaka ttā vivaṭṭena ca vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī evam hi sati yāni tāni cattārimāni bhikkhave
translated: because beings expand out of the Brahmā-world at that time. Herein, the aeon of contraction is included in the aeon of contraction and of stasis,

original: kappassa asaṅkhyeyyāni. Katamāni cattāri? Saṃvaṭṭo saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyī vivaṭṭo vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyī”ti🔽vuttāni, tāni pariggahitāni honti. Saṃvaṭṭakappe vivaṭṭakappeti ca kappassa addhaṃ
analyzed: kappassa asaṅkhyeyyāni katamāni cattāri saṃvaṭṭaḥ saṃvaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī vivaṭṭaḥ vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī iti  vuttāni tāni pariggahitāni honti saṃvaṭṭa kappe vivaṭṭa kappe iti ca kappassa addham
translated: because the latter has the former as its root. And the aeon of expansion is included in the aeon of expansion and of stasis. For when it is put thus, the four kinds of aeon mentioned in the passage, “Bhikkhus, there are four incalculables. What are the four? The aeon of contraction, the aeon of stasis after contraction, the aeon of expansion, the aeon of stasis after expansion” ,🔽are included. And the half of the aeon consisting of the aeon of contraction and the aeon of expansion is called “the aeon of contraction and expansion.” The whole aeon consisting of the aeon of contraction and the aeon of expansion is called “the aeon of contraction and expansion.”

original: gahetvā vuttaṃ. Saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappeti sakalaṃ kappaṃ gahetvā vuttaṃ. Kathaṃ anussaratīti
analyzed: gahetvā vuttam saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappe iti sakalam kappam gahetvā vuttam katham anussarati iti
translated: How does he recollect?

original: ce? Amutrāsintiādinā nayena. Tattha amutrāsinti amumhi saṃvaṭṭakappe ahaṃ amumhi
analyzed: ce amutra asin ti ādinā nayena tattha amutra āsin ti amumhi saṃvaṭṭa kappe aham amumhi
translated: By means of the method beginning, “There I was so and so … . ” Herein, there I was so and so means I was so named, so classed, in that aeon of contraction.

original: bhave vā yoniyā vā gatiyā vā viññāṇaṭṭhitiyā vā sattāvāse vā sattanikāye vā āsiṃ.
analyzed: bhave vā yoniyā vā gatiyā vā viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyā vā sattā vāse vā satta nikāye vā āsim
translated: or in a realm of existence, or in a destiny, or in a station of consciousness, or in a place of suffering, or in a class of beings.

original: Evaṃnāmoti tisso vā phusso vā. Evaṃgottoti kaccāno vā kassapo vā. Idamassa atītabhave
analyzed: evaṃnāmo ti tissaḥ vā phussaḥ vā evaṃgotto ti kaccānaḥ vā kassapaḥ vā idam assa atīta bhave
translated: Such was my name: Tissa or Phussa. Such was my family: Kaccana or Kassapa. This is said with reference to his own name and family in his past existence.

original: attano nāmagottānussaraṇavasena vuttaṃ. Sace pana tasmiṃ kāle attano vaṇṇasampattiṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ nāma gotta anussaraṇa vasena vuttam sace pana tasmin kāle attanaḥ vaṇṇa sampattim
translated: But if at that time he wishes to recollect his own perfection of beauty,

original: vā lūkhapaṇītajīvitabhāvaṃ vā sukhadukkhabahulataṃ vā appāyukadīghāyukabhāvaṃ vā
analyzed: vā lūkha paṇīta jīvita bhāvam vā sukha dukkha bahula tam vā appāyuka dīghāyuka bhāvam vā
translated: or his state of having a life that was either coarse or refined, or his having much happiness or much suffering, or his having a short life-span or a long life-span,

original: anussaritukāmo, tampi anussaratiyeva. Tenāha – “evaṃvaṇṇo evamāyupariyanto”ti. Tattha
analyzed: anussaritu kāmaḥ tam pi tena āha evaṃvaṇṇaḥ evam āyu pariyantaḥ ti tattha
translated: then he recollects that too. Hence it is said: “I was possessed of such form, such was my life-term” . Herein,

original: evaṃvaṇṇoti odāto vā sāmo vā. Evamāhāroti sālimaṃsodanāhāro vā pavattaphalabhojano🔽vā. Evaṃ sukhadukkhapaṭisaṃvedīti anekappakārena kāyikacetasikānaṃ sāmisanirāmisādippabhedānaṃ
analyzed: evaṃvaṇṇaḥ iti odātaḥ vā sāmaḥ vā evamāhāraḥ iti sāli maṃsodana āhāraḥ vā pavatta phala bhojano  vā evam sukha dukkha paṭisaṃvedī iti aneka ppakārena kāyika cetasikānam sa āmisa nirāmisa ādi ppabhedānam
translated: possessed of such form means either white or dark. Such was my life-term means that he had a life-term of rice and curry to eat or of forest fruits to eat.🔽Such was my happiness and suffering means that he experienced bodily and mental happiness and suffering of various kinds,

original: vā sukhadukkhānaṃ paṭisaṃvedī. Evamāyupariyantoti evaṃ vassasataparamāyupariyanto
analyzed: vā sukha dukkhānam paṭisaṃvedī evam āyu pariyantaḥ ti evam vassa sata parama āyu pariyantaḥ
translated: or that he experienced happiness and suffering that were either mundane or supramundane, etc. Such was the end of my life-span means that his life-span ended after a hundred years,

original: vā caturāsīti kappasahassaparamāyupariyanto vā.
analyzed: vā catur āsīti kappa sahassa parama āyu pariyantaḥ vā
translated: or a life-span of eighty-four thousand eons.

original: So tato cuto amutra udapādinti so ahaṃ tato bhavato yonito gatito viññāṇaṭṭhitito
analyzed: saḥ tatas cutaḥ amutra udapādinti saḥ aham tatas bhavataḥ yonitaḥ gatitaḥ viññāṇa ṭṭhititaḥ
translated: So I, having passed away from there, arose there: so I, having passed away from that state of existence, from that destiny, from that realm of beings, from that station of consciousness,

original: sattāvāsato sattanikāyato vā cuto puna amukasmiṃ nāma bhave yoniyā gatiyā viññāṇaṭṭhitiyā🔽sattāvāse sattanikāye vā udapādiṃ. Tatrāpāsinti atha tatrāpi bhave yoniyā gatiyā
analyzed: satta āvāsataḥ satta nikāyataḥ vā cutaḥ puna amukasmin nāma bhave yoniyā gatiyā viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyā  sattā vāse satta nikāye vā udapādim tatra apāsinti atha tatra api bhave yoniyā gatiyā
translated: from that class of beings, arose again in a certain state of existence, in a certain destiny, in a certain realm of beings, in a certain station of consciousness,🔽in a certain class of beings. There also I was: then also in that state of existence, in that destiny, in that realm of beings, in that station of consciousness,

original: viññāṇaṭṭhitiyā sattāvāse sattanikāye vā puna ahosiṃ. Evaṃnāmotiādivuttanayameva.
analyzed: viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyā satta āvāse satta nikāye vā puna ahosim evaṃnāmā iti ādi vutta nayam eva
translated: in that class of beings, I was again. So named: in the way already stated.

original: Api ca – yasmā amutrāsinti idaṃ anupubbena ārohantassa yāvadicchakaṃ anussaraṇaṃ.🔽So tato cutoti paṭinivattantassa paccavekkhaṇaṃ. Tasmā idhūpapannoti imissā idhūpapattiyā
analyzed: api ca yasmai amutra asinti idam anupubbena ārohantassa yāvadicchakam anussaraṇam  so tatas cutaḥ ti paṭinivattantassa paccavekkhaṇam tasmai idha upapannaḥ ti imissā idha upapattiyā
translated: Besides, “I was there” is the recollection of one who has ascended in order, as far as he wishes.🔽“So I, having passed away from there” is the reviewing of one who has descended in order. “So I arose here” is the arising in this state of existence.

original: anantaramevassa upapattiṭṭhānaṃ sandhāya amutra udapādinti idaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: anantaram eva assa upapatti ṭṭhānam sandhāya amutra udapādin ti idam vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: Therefore it should be understood that “So I, having passed away from there, arose there” is said with reference to the place of rebirth immediately next to this one.

original: Tatrāpāsinti evamādi panassa tatrā imissā upapattiyā antare upapattiṭṭhāne nāmagottādīnaṃ🔽anussaraṇadassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. So tato cuto idhūpapannoti svāhaṃ tato anantarūpapattiṭṭhānato
analyzed: tatra apāsin ti evamādi panassa tatra imissā upapattiyāḥ antare upapatti ṭṭhāne nāma gotta ādīnam  anussaraṇa dassana attham vuttam saḥ tatas cutaḥ idhū upapanno ti svāham tatas anantarūpapattiṭṭhānato
translated: “There I had such and such a name” and so on is said for the purpose of showing his recollection of the name, clan, etc.,🔽in the place of rebirth in the interval between the two existences. “Having passed away from there, I arose here” means:🔽from that place of rebirth immediately before this one.

original: cuto idha asukasmiṃ nāma khattiyakule vā brāhmaṇakule vā nibbatto.
analyzed: cutaḥ idha asukasmin nāma khattiya kule vā brāhmaṇa kule vā nibbattaḥ
translated: “There I had such and such a name” and so on is said in order to show the remembering of the name, clan, etc., in the place of rebirth in the interval between the two existences. “I passed away from there and was reborn here” means: I passed away from that place of rebirth immediately following this existence and was reborn here in such and such a clan of nobles, brahmans, or householders.

original: Ititi evaṃ. Sākāraṃ sauddesanti nāmagottavasena sauddesaṃ, vaṇṇādivasena sākāraṃ.
analyzed: iti ti evam sa ākāram sa auddesanti nāma gotta vasena sa auddesam vaṇṇa ādi vasena sa ākāram
translated: “Thus” means in this way. “With its aspects and particulars” means with its particulars of name and clan, and with its aspects of color, etc.

original: Nāmagottena hi satto “tisso kassapo”ti uddisiyati, vaṇṇādīhi “odāto sāmo”ti nānattato
analyzed: nāma gottena hi sattaḥ tissaḥ kassapo ti uddisiyati vaṇṇa ādīhi odātaḥ sāmaḥ ti nānattataḥ
translated: For a being is particularized by name and clan as “Kassapa of the Thullananda” clan, and is known by color, etc., as “fair,” “dark,” etc.

original: paññāyati. Tasmā nāmagottaṃ uddeso, itare ākārāti. Pubbenivāsanti pubbe atītajātīsu🔽nivuṭṭhakkhandhā pubbenivāso. Nivuṭṭhāti ajjhāvuṭṭhā anubhūtā attano santāne uppajjitvā
analyzed: paññāyati tasmai nāma gottam uddesaḥ itare  nivuṭṭha kkhandhā pubbenivāsaḥ nivuṭṭhā ati ajjhāvuṭṭhā anubhūtā attano santāne uppajjitvā
translated: Therefore name and clan are the particulars, and the others are the aspects.🔽“Recollection of past lives” means the aggregates that occurred in past births.🔽“That occurred” means that which was experienced, which arose and ceased in one’s own continuum, or which was experienced as a past state.

original: niruddhā, nivuṭṭhadhammā vā. Nivuṭṭhāti gocaranivāsena nivuṭṭhā, attano viññāṇena
analyzed: niruddhā nivuṭṭha dhammā vā nivuṭṭhā ati gocara nivāsena nivuṭṭhā attanaḥ viññāṇena
translated: “That occurred” also means that which occurred by dwelling in the domain, which was experienced by one’s own consciousness.

original: viññātā paricchinnā, paraviññāṇena viññātāpi vā chinnavaṭumakānussaraṇādīsu. Te buddhānaṃyeva🔽labbhanti. Taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ ādisati katheti. Paresaṃ atītanti aññesaṃ parapuggalānaṃ
analyzed: viññātā paricchinnā para viññāṇena viññātā api vā chinna vaṭumaka anussaraṇa ādīsu te buddhānam yeva  labbhanti tam pubbenivāsam ādisati kathā iti paresam atītam ti aññesam para puggalānam
translated: and known, defined, by another’s consciousness, or remembered by the knowledge of the past life of another, and so on. These are only possible for Buddhas.

original: pubbenivāsaṃ ekampi jātintiādinā nayena ādisati.🔽Mahāpadāniyasuttantanti mahāpurisānaṃ apadānaniyuttaṃ mahāpadānasuttaṃ. Mahāsudassaniyasuttantanti🔽mahāsudassanassa sampattiyuttaṃ mahāsudassanasuttaṃ. Mahāgovindiyasuttantanti mahāgovindabrāhmaṇassa
analyzed: pubbenivāsam ekam pi jātiṃ ti ādinā nayena ādisati  mahāpadāniya suttantanti mahāpurisānam apadāna niyuttam mahā padāna suttam mahāsudassaniya suttantanti  mahāsudassanassa sampatti yuttam mahāsudassana suttam mahāgovindiya suttantanti mahāgovinda brāhmaṇassa
translated: He describes the former habitation, he talks about it. The past of others: he describes the former habitation of others, of other persons, in the way beginning, “So-and-so in the past … was … ”

original: apadānaniyuttaṃ mahāgovindasuttaṃ. Māghadeviyasuttantanti maghadevarañño apadānaniyuttaṃ
analyzed: apadāna niyuttam mahāgovindasuttam māghadeviya suttantanti maghadeva raññaḥ apadāna niyuttam
translated: The Great Discourse on the Lineages: the Great Discourse on the Lineages of Great Men . The Great Discourse on the Auspicious: the Great Discourse on the Auspicious, which deals with the Greatly Auspicious One’s excellence. The Great Discourse on Govinda: the Great Discourse on Govinda, which deals with the lineage of the Great Brahmin Govinda. The Discourse on Maghadevi: the Discourse on Maghadevi, which deals with the lineage of the Great God Magha.

original: maghadevasuttaṃ. Satānusāriññāṇaṃ hotīti pubbenivāsānussatisampayuttañāṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: maghadeva suttam sata anusāri ñāṇam hoti iti pubbenivāsa anussati sampayutta ñāṇam hoti
translated: The knowledge of the one who follows the hundred: the knowledge that is associated with the recollection of past lives.

original: Yāvatakaṃ ākaṅkhatīti yattakaṃ ñātuṃ icchati, tattakaṃ jānissāmīti ñāṇaṃ peseti.
analyzed: yāvatakam ākaṅkhati iti yattakam ñātum icchati tattakam jānissāmi iti ñāṇam peseti
translated: As far as he wishes: he sends forth the knowledge, “I shall know as much as I want to know.”

original: Athassa dubbalapattapuṭe pakkhandanārādho viya appaṭihataṃ anivāritaṃ ñāṇaṃ gacchati.🔽Tena yāvatakaṃ ākaṅkhati, tāvatakaṃ anussarati. Bodhijanti bodhiyā mūle jātaṃ. Ñāṇaṃ
analyzed: athassa dubbala patta puṭe pakkhandana ārādhaḥ viya appaṭihatam anivāritam ñāṇam gacchati  tena yāvatakam ākaṅkhati tāvatakam anussarati bodhi janti bodhiyāḥ mūle jātam ñāṇam
translated: His knowledge goes unobstructed and unhindered, like a strong man alighting from a weak man’s shoulders.

original: uppajjatīti catumaggañāṇaṃ uppajjati. Ayamantimā jātīti tena ñāṇena jātimūlassa pahīnattā
analyzed: uppajjati iti catu magga ñāṇam uppajjati ayam antimā jātī iti tena ñāṇena jāti mūlassa pahīna ttā
translated: He recollects as far back as he wishes. “Enlightened” : born at the foot of the enlightenment tree. “Knowledge” : the knowledge of the four paths arises. “This is my last birth” : by means of that knowledge, since the root of birth has been eradicated,

original: puna “ayamantimā jāti, natthidāni punabbhavo”ti aparampi ñāṇaṃ uppajjati. Indriyaparopariyattañāṇanti
analyzed: puna ayam antimā jāti natthi idāni punabbhavaḥ ti aparam pi ñāṇam uppajjati indriya para upari yatta ñāṇam ti

original: ettha upari “sattāna”nti padaṃ idheva āharitvā sattānaṃ indriyaparopariyattañāṇanti🔽yojetabbaṃ. Parāni ca aparāni ca “parāparānī”ti vattabbe sandhivasena ro-kāraṃ katvā
analyzed: ettha upari sattānanti padam idhā iva āharitvā sattānam  yojetabbam parāni ca aparāni ca para aparāni iti vattabbe sandhi vasena ra okāram katvā
translated: here the word “beings” should be brought in here itself and the compound should be resolved as follows: “the knowledge of the diversity of the faculties of beings.”

original: “paroparānī”ti vuccati. Paroparānaṃ bhāvo paropariyaṃ, paropariyameva paropariyattaṃ,
analyzed: paroparāni iti vuccati bhāvo paropariyam paropariyam eva
translated: “Superior” and “inferior” : the word “superior” should be analyzed as follows: “parāni ca aparāni ca parāparāni.” But because of the sandhi rule, the ro is made ra and it is said “paroparāni.” The state of being superior and inferior is paropariyattam.

original: veneyyasattānaṃ saddhādīnaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ paropariyattaṃ indriyaparopariyattaṃ,
analyzed: veneyya sattānam saddhā ādīnam pañcannam indriyānam indriya paropariyattam
translated: The superiority and inferiority of the faculties of faith, etc., of beings to be trained is called “the superiority and inferiority of faculties.”

original: indriyaparopariyattassa ñāṇaṃ indriyaparopariyattañāṇaṃ, indriyānaṃ uttamānuttamabhāvañāṇanti🔽attho. “Indriyavarovariyattañāṇa”ntipi pāṭho, varāni ca avarāni ca varovariyāni,

translated: The knowledge of the superiority and inferiority of faculties is called “knowledge of the superiority and inferiority of faculties,” or else the knowledge of the high and low state of the faculties.🔽The reading “knowledge of the high and low state of faculties” is also allowable. The high and low are the high and low states.🔽The meaning is that they are high and low. Or alternatively, the high and low are the high and low states.🔽The meaning is that they are high and low. Or alternatively, the high and low are the high and low states.

Or alternatively, the high and low are the high and low states.🔽The meaning is that they are high and low. Or alternatively, the high and low are the high and low states.

analyzed: gatā tathā gatassa tathāgata balan ti aññehi asādhāraṇam tathāgatassa iva balam yathā

analyzed: vā pubba buddhānam balam puññussaya sampattiyā āgatam tathā āgata balam ti pi atthaḥ

original: Tattha duvidhaṃ tathāgatassa balaṃ kāyabalañca ñāṇabalañca. Tesu kāyabalaṃ hatthikulānusārena
analyzed: tattha duvidham tathāgatassa balam kāya balañca ñāṇa balañca tesu kāya balam hatthi kula anusārena
translated: Herein, a Buddha’s power is twofold, that is to say, physical power and knowledge power. Herein, his physical power can be understood from the description of the elephant family.

original: veditabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ porāṇehi –
analyzed: veditabbam vuttam ha etam porāṇehi

original: pañcagatiparicchedakañāṇaṃ saṃyuttake āgatāni tesattati ñāṇāni sattasattati ñāṇānīti
analyzed: pañca gati paricchedaka ñāṇam saṃyuttake āgatāni tesattati ñāṇāni sattasattati ñāṇāni iti
translated: Knowledge of the delimitation of the five destinies, and the seventy-three kinds of knowledge given in the Saṃyutta Nikāya , and the seventy-seven kinds of knowledge given in the Saṃyutta Nikāya ,

original: evaṃ aññānipi anekāni ñāṇasahassāni, etaṃ ñāṇabalaṃ nāma. Idhāpi ñāṇabalameva adhippetaṃ,
analyzed: evam aññāni api anekāni ñāṇa sahassāni etam ñāṇa balam nāma idha api ñāṇa balam eva adhippetam
translated: and so on—there are many thousands of kinds of knowledge. This is what is called the power of knowledge. Here too it is knowledge as power that is intended.

original: ñāṇañhi akampiyaṭṭhena upathambhakaṭṭhena ca balanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ñāṇam hi akampiya ṭṭhena upathambhaka ṭṭhena ca balan ti vuttam
translated: For knowledge is called “power” in the sense of being unshakable and in the sense of being unsuppressable.

original: Sattānaṃ āsayānusaye ñāṇanti ettha rūpādīsu khandhesu chandarāgena sattā visattāti sattā. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –🔽“Rūpe kho, rādha, yo chando yo rāgo yā nandī yā taṇhā, tatra satto tatra visatto,
analyzed: sattānam āsaya anusaye ettha rūpa ādīsu khandhesu chanda rāgena sattā visattā ati sattā vuttam ha etam bhagavatā  rūpe kho chandaḥ yaḥ rāgaḥ yā nandī yā taṇhā tatra satto tatra visatto
translated: Knowledge of the dispositions and latent tendencies of beings: here beings are so called because they are scattered in the various destinies owing to desire and lust for the aggregates beginning with form. For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: tasmā ‘satto’ti vuccati. Vedanāya… saññāya… saṅkhāresu… viññāṇe yo chando yo rāgo
analyzed: tasmā satto ti vuccati vedanāya saññāya saṅkhāresu viññāṇe yaḥ chandaḥ yaḥ rāgaḥ
translated: “Rādha, whatever desire and lust there is with regard to form, whatever desire and lust there is with regard to feeling, whatever desire and lust there is with regard to perception, whatever desire and lust there is with regard to the mental formations, whatever desire and lust there is with regard to consciousness,

original: yā nandī yā taṇhā, tatra satto tatra visatto, tasmā ‘satto’ti vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: yā nandī yā taṇhā tatra satto tatra visatto tasmā satto ti vuccati iti
translated: that is the internal being, that is the internal scatterer, and that is why ‘being’ and ‘scattered being’ are said” .🔽But those who merely think about the meaning of the words without investigating it claim that “it is only a mere name” .

original: Akkharacintakā pana atthaṃ avicāretvā “nāmamattameta”nti icchanti. Yepi atthaṃ vicārenti,
analyzed: akkhara cintakā pana attham a vicāretvā nāmam attam etat ti icchanti ye pi attham vicārenti
translated: And those who investigate the meaning of the words

original: te satvayogena sattāti icchanti. Tesaṃ sattānaṃ āsayanti nissayanti etthāti āsayo,
analyzed: te sattva yogena sattā ati icchanti tesam sattānam āsayanti nissayanti ettha ati āsayaḥ
translated: They are “satvas” because they are the “satvas” of beings, because they are the “satvas” of those beings.

original: micchādiṭṭhiyā sammādiṭṭhiyā vā kāmādīhi nekkhammādīhi vā paribhāvitassa cittasantānassetaṃ
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhiyā sammādiṭṭhiyā vā kāma ādīhi nekkhamma ādīhi vā paribhāvitassa citta santānassa etam
translated: It is a term for the mental continuum that is imbued with wrong view or right view, with sense desire or renunciation, etc.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Sattasantāne anusenti anupavattantīti anusayā, thāmagatānaṃ kāmarāgādīnaṃ🔽etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Āsayo ca anusayo ca āsayānusayo. Jātiggahaṇena ca dvandasamāsavasena
analyzed: adhivacanam satta santāne anusenti anupavattanti iti anusayāḥ thāma gatānam kāma rāga ādīnam  etam adhivacanam āsayo ca anusayo ca āsaya anusayaḥ jāti ggahaṇena ca dvanda samāsa vasena
translated: They are “satvas” because they “satva” in the being’s continuum, because they occur in continuity. It is a term for the sense desires, etc., that have become habitual.🔽The “satva” is the “satva” and the “satva” is the “anusaya,” thus it is the “satva-anusaya.”🔽And the singular number should be understood as in the expression “jāti-gahaṇa” and as a dvanda compound.

original: ca ekavacanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Yasmā caritādhimuttiyo āsayānusayasaṅgahitā, tasmā uddese
analyzed: ca ekavacanam veditabbam yasmai carita adhimuttiyaḥ āsaya anusaya saṅgahitā tasmai uddese
translated: Since the “character” and “predominance” are included in the “satva” and “anusaya,” in the exposition

original: caritādhimuttīsu ñāṇāni āsayānusayañāṇeneva saṅgahetvā “āsayānusaye ñāṇa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: carita adhimuttīsu ñāṇāni āsaya anusaya ñāṇena iva saṅgahetvā āsaya anusaye ñāṇam ti vuttam
translated: the knowledge of the “character” and “predominance” is included in the knowledge of the “satva” and “anusaya” and is called “knowledge of the satva-anusaya.”

original: Yamakapāṭihīre ñāṇanti ettha aggikkhandhaudakadhārādīnaṃ apubbaṃ acarimaṃ sakiṃyeva
analyzed: yamaka pāṭihīre ettha aggi kkhandha odaka dhārā ādīnam apubbam a carimam
translated: Knowledge of the twin miracle: here, the twin miracle is so called because of the simultaneous occurrence of the flame-basket, the water-stream, etc., without prior or subsequent order.

original: pavattito yamakaṃ, assaddhiyādīnaṃ paṭipakkhadhammānaṃ haraṇato pāṭihīraṃ, yamakañca
analyzed: pavattitaḥ yamakam assaddhi ādīnam paṭipakkha dhammānam haraṇataḥ pāṭihīram yamakam ca
translated: It is a “miracle” because of the removal of the opposing states such as lack of faith, etc.

original: taṃ pāṭihīrañcāti yamakapāṭihīraṃ.
analyzed: tam pāṭihīram ca ati yamakapāṭihīram
translated: and the miracle: the Twin Miracle.

original: Mahākaruṇāsamāpattiyā ñāṇanti ettha paradukkhe sati sādhūnaṃ hadayakampanaṃ karotīti
analyzed: mahākaruṇā samāpattiyāḥ ettha para dukkhe sati sādhūnam hadaya kampanam karoti iti
translated: Knowledge of the attainment of great compassion: compassion is so called because it is a shaking of the heart at the sight of others’ suffering.

original: karuṇā, kināti vā paradukkhaṃ hiṃsati vināsetīti karuṇā, kirīyati vā dukkhitesu pharaṇavasena
analyzed: karuṇā vā para dukkham hiṃsati vināseti iti karuṇā vā dukkhitesu pharaṇa vasena
translated: Or alternatively, it is the destruction of others’ suffering, thus it is compassion ; or it is extended by pervasion over those who are suffering, thus it is compassion .

original: pasārīyatīti karuṇā, pharaṇakammavasena kammaguṇavasena ca mahatī karuṇā mahākaruṇā,
analyzed: pasārīyati iti karuṇā pharaṇa kamma vasena kamma guṇa vasena ca mahatī karuṇā mahākaruṇā
translated: Great compassion is either great because it is extended by pervasion or great because it is a quality of great beings.

original: samāpajjanti etaṃ mahākāruṇikāti samāpatti, mahākaruṇā ca sā samāpatti cāti mahākaruṇāsamāpatti,
analyzed: samāpajjanti etam mahā kāruṇikā ati samāpatti mahā karuṇā ca sā samāpatti ca ati mahā karuṇā samāpatti
translated: It is an attainment because of the attainment of it by the Greatly Compassionate One. It is both great compassion and an attainment, thus it is the attainment of great compassion.

original: tassaṃ mahākaruṇāsamāpattiyaṃ. Taṃ sampayuttaṃ vā ñāṇaṃ.🔽Sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ anāvaraṇañāṇanti ettha pañcaneyyapathappabhedaṃ sabbaṃ aññāsīti
analyzed: mahā karuṇā samāpattiyam tam sampayuttam vā ñāṇam  sabbaññuta ññāṇam anāvaraṇa ñāṇan ti ettha pañcaneyya patha pabhedam sabbam aññāsi iti
translated: It is the knowledge associated with that attainment of great compassion.

original: sabbaññū, sabbaññussa bhāvo sabbaññutā, sabbaññutā eva ñāṇaṃ sabbaññutāñāṇanti vattabbe
analyzed: sabbaññū sabbaññussa bhāvaḥ sabbaññu tā sabbaññu tā eva ñāṇam sabbaññu tā ñāṇam ti vattabbe
translated: Knowledge of omniscience, knowledge free of obstruction: he knows all that is divided into the five constituent groups, thus he is omniscient ; the state of the omniscient one is omniscience . Knowledge of omniscience should be said to be knowledge of omniscience.

original: sabbaññutaññāṇanti vuttaṃ. Saṅkhatāsaṅkhatādibhedā sabbadhammā hi saṅkhāro vikāro
analyzed: sabbaññuta ññāṇanti vuttam saṅkhata asaṅkhata ādi bhedā sabba dhammāḥ hi saṅkhāraḥ vikāraḥ
translated: and it is called “knowledge of omniscience.”

original: lakkhaṇaṃ nibbānaṃ paññattīti pañceva neyyapathā honti. Āvajjanapaṭibaddhattā eva
analyzed: lakkhaṇam nibbānam paññatti iti pañca iva neyya pathāḥ honti āvajjana paṭibaddha ttā eva
translated: All states are classified into five categories, namely, formations, change-of-state, characteristic, Nibbāna, and designation.

original: hi natthi tassa āvaraṇanti tadeva anāvaraṇañāṇanti vuccati.
analyzed: hi natthi tassa āvaraṇanti tat eva anāvaraṇa ñāṇanti vuccati
translated: For it is because of the adverting that it is said, “There is no obstruction to it.”🔽It is called “knowledge of non-obstruction” because it is unobstructed.

original: Sabbattha asaṅgamappaṭihatamanāvaraṇañāṇanti ettha atītānāgatapaccuppannesu asaṅgaṃ saṅgavirahitaṃ appaṭihataṃ paṭipakkhavirahitaṃ hutvā pavattaṃ āvaraṇavirahitaṃ ñāṇaṃ.
analyzed: sabbattha asaṅgam appaṭihatam anāvaraṇa ñāṇam ti ettha atīta anāgata paccuppannesu asaṅgam saṅga virahitam appaṭihatam paṭipakkha virahitam hutvā pavattam āvaraṇa virahitam ñāṇam
translated: “Knowledge unobstructed as to all things” is knowledge that occurs without obstruction, without hindrance, without resistance, as to all things in the past, future, and present.

original: Anāgatampi ādisatīti –
analyzed: anāgatam pi ādisati iti
translated: “It knows the future as present”:

original: “Imasmiṃ bhaddake kappe, tayo āsiṃsu nāyakā;
analyzed: imasmin bhaddake kappe tayaḥ āsiṃsu nāyakā
translated: “In this auspicious aeon Three Buddhas have appeared,

original: Ahametarahi sambuddho, metteyyo cāpi hessatī”ti. ca –
analyzed: aham etarahi sambuddhaḥ metteyyaḥ ca api hessati iti ca
translated: And I am now the Enlightened One, And Metteyya will be the next” ;

original: “Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu metteyyo nāma bhagavā loke uppajjissati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno”ti ca –
analyzed: asīti vassa sahassa āyukesu bhikkhave manussesu metteyyaḥ nāma bhagavā loke uppajjissati araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampannaḥ ti ca
translated: “Bhikkhus, when human life has a duration of eighty thousand years, the Blessed One named Metteyya will appear in the world, an Arahant, a Perfectly Enlightened One, endowed with wisdom and conduct, a Happy One, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed trainer of those who are to be tamed, a teacher of gods and humans, an Enlightened One, a Blessed One” .

original: “Atha kho, bhikkhave, saṅkho nāma rājā yo so yūpo raññā mahāpanādena kārāpito, taṃ🔽yūpaṃ ussāpetvā ajjhāvasitvā taṃ datvā vissajjitvā samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānaṃ🔽dānaṃ datvā metteyyassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa santike kesamassuṃ ohāretvā
analyzed: atha kho bhikkhave saṅkhaḥ nāma rājā yaḥ saḥ yūpaḥ raññā mahāpanādena kārāpito tam  yūpam ussāpetvā ajjhāvasitvā tam datvā vissajjitvā samaṇa brāhmaṇaka paṇaddhika vaṇibbaka yācakānam  dānam datvā metteyyassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa santike kesa massuṃ ohāretvā
translated: “Then King Saṅkha, having had the sacrificial post erected by King Mahāpanāda🔽cut down, will dwell in the midst of the sacrificial enclosure, give it away, and set it free. Having given gifts to ascetics, brahmins, paupers, tramps,

original: kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissatī”ti ca –
analyzed: kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasmaā anagāriyam pabbajissati iti ca
translated: and beggars, he will shave off his hair and beard, put on the yellow robe, and go forth from the home life into homelessness in the presence of the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One Metteyya.”

original: “Anāgate aṭṭhissaro nāma paccekasambuddho bhavissatī”ti ca, “sumanissaro nāma paccekasambuddho bhavissatī”ti ca –
analyzed: anāgate aṭṭhissaraḥ nāma paccekasambuddhaḥ bhavissati iti ca sumanissaraḥ nāma paccekasambuddhaḥ bhavissati iti ca
translated: “In the future there will be a Paccekabuddha named Aṭṭhissara,” and “In the future there will be a Paccekabuddha named Sumanissara,”

original: Ādinā nayena devadattādīnaṃ anāgataṃ ācikkhati. Paccuppannampi ādisatīti idaṃ pākaṭameva.🔽82. Vibhūtarūpasaññissāti samatikkantarūpasaññissa. Sabbakāyappahāyinoti tadaṅgavikkhambhanavasena
analyzed: ādinā nayena devadatta ādīnam anāgatam ācikkhati paccuppannam api ādisati iti idam pākaṭam eva 🔽vibhūta rūpa saññissa āti samatikkanta rūpa saññissa sabba kāya ppahāyinaḥ ti tad aṅga vikkhambhana vasena
translated: and so on. He predicted the future of Devadatta and others. And that he can also reveal the present is obvious.

original: sabbarūpakāyapahāyino, pahīnarūpabhavapaṭisandhikassāti adhippāyo. Natthi kiñcīti
analyzed: sabba rūpa kāya pahāyinaḥ pahīna rūpa bhava paṭisandhikassa ati adhippāyaḥ natthi kiñci iti
translated: the intention is that of one who has abandoned the entire material form body and has abandoned the material-form-aggregate rebirth-linking.🔽‘Seeing that there is nothing at all’:

original: passatoti viññāṇābhāvadassanena “natthi kiñcī”ti passato, ākiñcaññāyatanalābhinoti
analyzed: passatoti viññāṇa abhāva dassanena na atthi kiñci iti passato ākiñcaññāyatana lābhino ti
translated: ‘seeing’ means seeing the non-existence of consciousness. ‘There is nothing at all’ means that there is nothing at all that is not included in the four immaterial aggregates.🔽‘I ask the Blessed One for knowledge’: he said this addressing the Blessed One as ‘Blessed One’.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Ñāṇaṃ sakkānupucchāmīti sakkāti bhagavantaṃ ālapanto āha. Tassa puggalassa
analyzed: vuttam hoti ñāṇam sakka anupucchāmi iti sakkā ati bhagavantam ālapantaḥ āha tassa puggalassa
translated: ‘I ask the Blessed One for knowledge of that person’s🔽knowledge, for what kind of knowledge is to be desired?’

original: ñāṇaṃ pucchāmi, kīdisaṃ icchitabbanti. Kathaṃ neyyāti kathañca so netabbo, kathamassa🔽uttariñāṇaṃ uppādetabbanti.
analyzed: ñāṇam pucchāmi kīdisam icchitabbanti katham neyya iti katham ca saḥ netabbaḥ katham assa  uttari ñāṇam uppādetabbanti
translated: ‘How should he be led?’ means ‘How should he be led on, how should his higher knowledge be aroused?’

original: Katamā rūpasaññāti ettha rūpasaññāti saññāsīsena vuttarūpāvacarajhānañceva tadārammaṇañca.🔽Rūpāvacarajhānampi hi rūpanti vuccati “rūpī rūpāni passatī”tiādīsu. Tassa ārammaṇampi
analyzed: katamā rūpa saññā ti ettha rūpa saññā ti saññā sīsena vutta rūpāvacara jhānañca iva tad ārammaṇañca  rūpāvacara jhānam pi hi rūpanti vuccati rūpī rūpāni passati itiādīsu tassa ārammaṇam pi
translated: ‘What is material-form perception?’ Herein, ‘material-form perception’ is the fine-material-sphere jhāna stated under the heading of perception, and also its object.🔽For the fine-material-sphere jhāna is called ‘material form’ in such passages as ‘Possessed of material form, he sees material forms’ .🔽And its object is called ‘material form’ in such passages as ‘He sees material forms externally, beautiful and ugly’ .

original: “bahiddhā rūpāni passati suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”tiādīsu. Tasmā idha rūpe saññā rūpasaññāti
analyzed: bahiddhā rūpāni passati suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni itiādīsu tasmai idha rūpe saññā rūpa saññā ati
translated: So here ‘material-form perception’ is perception of material form.

original: evaṃ saññāsīsena rūpāvacarajhānassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Rūpaṃ saññā assāti rūpasaññā,
analyzed: evam saññā sīsena rūpāvacara jhānassa itam adhivacanam rūpam saññā assa ati rūpa saññā
translated: So this is a term for the fine-material-sphere jhāna with perception as its head. “Perceptions of materiality” is perception of materiality,

original: rūpamassa nāmanti vuttaṃ hoti. Evaṃ pathavīkasiṇādibhedassa tadārammaṇassa cetaṃ🔽adhivacananti veditabbaṃ. Idha pana kusalavipākakiriyavasena pañcadasajhānasaṅkhātā
analyzed: rūpam assa nāman ti vuttam hoti evam pathavī kasiṇa ādi bhedassa tad ārammaṇassa ca itaṃ  adhivacanam ti veditabbam idha pana kusala vipāka kiriya vasena pañcadasa jhāna saṅkhātā
translated: which is to say, materiality is its name. So this should be understood as a term for the kasiṇa of earth, etc., and for the object of that kasiṇa.

original: rūpasaññā eva adhippetā. Rūpāvacarasamāpattiṃ samāpannassa vāti rūpāvacarakusalajjhānasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: rūpa saññā eva adhippetā rūpāvacara samāpattim samāpannassa vāti rūpāvacara kusala jhāna samāpattim
translated: But here the “perceptions of materiality” intended are the fifteen kinds of jhāna called “perceptions of materiality” because they occur with materiality as their object, that is to say, the profitable, resultant and functional jhānas.🔽“One who has attained the immaterial jhānas”: one who has attained the immaterial-sphere profitable jhānas.

original: samāpannassa. Upapannassa vāti vipākajjhānavasena tasmiṃ bhave upapannassa. Diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārissa
analyzed: samāpannassa upapannassa vāti vipāka jjhāna vasena tasmin bhave upapannassa diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārissa
translated: “One who has been reborn there”: one who has been reborn in that becoming by means of resultant jhāna.

original: vāti imasmiṃyeva attabhāve kiriyājhānaṃ samāpajjitvā sukhaṃ uppādetvā viharantassa.
analyzed: vāti imasmin yeva atta bhāve kiriyā jhānam samāpajjitvā sukham uppādetvā viharantassa
translated: “One who abides in ease here and now”: one who, having entered upon functional jhāna in this very existence, generates bliss by experiencing that bliss.🔽“The immaterial attainments”: the base consisting of boundless space, and so on.

original: Arūpasamāpattiyoti ākāsānañcāyatanādīni. Paṭiladdhassāti uppādetvā ṭhitassa. Rūpasaññā
analyzed: arūpa samāpattiyaḥ ti ākāsa anañcāyatana ādīni paṭiladdhassa ati uppādetvā ṭhitassa rūpa saññā
translated: “Has attained”: has produced and is possessing.

original: vibhūtā hontīti rūpasaññā apagatā honti. Vigatāti vināsitā. “Abhāvitā”tipi pāṭho, sundaro.🔽Tadaṅgasamatikkamāti tadaṅgappahānavasena atikkamena. Vikkhambhanappahānena pahīnoti
analyzed: vibhūtāḥ honti iti rūpa saññāḥ apagatāḥ honti vigatā ati vināsitāḥ pāṭhaḥ sundaraḥ  tad aṅga samatikkamā ati tad aṅga ppahāna vasena atikkamena vikkhambhana ppahānena pahīnaḥ ti
translated: They are ‘vanished’ because the perception of materiality has gone. ‘Gone’ is a synonym for ‘vanished.’ ‘Not developed’ is a reading, but it is not good.🔽‘Surmounting the fine-material sphere’ means by surmounting it through abandoning the fine-material jhānas. ‘Abandoned by suppression’ means abandoned by the suppression of the jhāna.

original: arūpajjhānapaṭilābhena vikkhambhanena pahīno. Tassa rūpakāyoti tassa arūpasamāpattipaṭilābhino
analyzed: arūpa jhāna paṭilābhena vikkhambhanena pahīnaḥ tassa rūpa kāyaḥ ti tassa arūpa samāpatti paṭilābhinaḥ
translated: ‘By obtaining the immaterial jhāna’ means by obtaining the immaterial jhāna.

original: arūpapuggalassa rūpāvacarakāyo.🔽Ākiñcaññāyatananti ettha nāssa kiñcananti akiñcanaṃ, antamaso saṅgamattampi assa
analyzed: arūpa puggalassa rūpāvacara kāyo  ākiñcaññāyatananti ettha na assa kiñcananti akiñcanam antamasaḥ saṅga mattam pi assa
translated: ‘His material body’ means the material body of the person who has obtained the immaterial jhāna.

original: avasiṭṭhaṃ natthīti vuttaṃ hoti. Akiñcanassa bhāvo ākiñcaññaṃ, ākāsānañcāyatanaviññāṇāpagamassetaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ, taṃ ākiñcaññaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena imissā saññāya āyatananti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: avasiṭṭham na atthi iti vuttam hoti akiñcanassa bhāvaḥ ākiñcaññam ākāsa ānañca āyatana viññāṇa apagamassa etam  adhivacanam tam ākiñcaññam adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena imissā saññāyaḥ āyatanan ti ākiñcaññāyatanam
translated: ‘The base consisting of nothingness’: there is nothing there, thus it is nothingness . What is meant is that there is nothing there left over, not even as much as an atom. The state of nothingness is the nothingness base . This is a term for the disappearance of consciousness in the base consisting of boundless space.🔽The meaning is that it is the jhāna that has that as its object. ‘The base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception’ is the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: ākāse pavattitaviññāṇāpagamārammaṇassa jhānassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Viññāṇañcāyatanasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: ākāse pavattita viññāṇa apagama ārammaṇassa jhānassa etam adhivacanam viññāṇaṃ ca āyatana samāpattim
translated: ‘The attainment of the base consisting of boundless consciousness’ is the attainment of the base consisting of boundless consciousness.

original: sato samāpajjitvāti taṃ viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ satokārī hutvā samāpajjitvā. Tato vuṭṭhahitvāti
analyzed: sataḥ samāpajjitvā ti tam viññāṇam ca āyatanam satokārī hutvā samāpajjitvā tatas vuṭṭhahitvā ati
translated: Having attained and emerged mindfully: having attained that base of infinite consciousness and emerged mindfully.🔽Having emerged from that attainment: having emerged from that attainment mindfully.

original: satokārī hutvā tāya samāpattiyā vuṭṭhāya. Taññeva viññāṇanti taṃ ākāse pavattitaṃ
analyzed: satokārī hutvā tāya samāpattiyā vuṭṭhāya tañca eva viññāṇanti tam ākāse pavattitam
translated: That very consciousness: that exalted consciousness occurring in the base of infinite space.

original: mahaggataviññāṇaṃ. Abhāvetīti vināseti. Vibhāvetīti vividhā nāseti. Antaradhāpetīti adassanaṃ gameti.
analyzed: mahaggata viññāṇam abhāveti iti vināseti vibhāveti iti vividhā nāseti antaradhāpeti iti adassanam gameti
translated: He annihilates: he destroys. He annihilates by differentiation: he destroys by various means. He causes to disappear: he causes to vanish.🔽How should he be known? How should that person be known?

original: Kathaṃ so netabboti so puggalo kenappakārena jānitabbo. Vinetabboti nānāvidhena jānitabbo. Anunetabboti punappunaṃ cittena kathaṃ gamayitabbo.
analyzed: katham saḥ netabbaḥ iti saḥ puggalo kena pakārena jānitabbaḥ vinetabbaḥ iti nānāvidhena jānitabbaḥ anunetabbaḥ iti punappunam cittena katham gamayitabbaḥ
translated: How should he be guided? How should he be known in various ways? How should he be led? How should he be led by the mind again and again?🔽Then the Blessed One, having shown that he has unobstructed knowledge with regard to such a person,

original: Athassa bhagavā tādise puggale attano appaṭihatañāṇataṃ pakāsetvā taṃ ñāṇaṃ byākātuṃ🔽gāthamāha. Tattha viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo sabbā, abhijānaṃ tathāgatoti abhisaṅkhāravasena
analyzed: athassa bhagavā tādise puggale attanaḥ appaṭihata ñāṇa tam pakāsetvā tam ñāṇam byākātum  gātham āha tattha viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ sabbāḥ abhijānam tathāgataḥ ti abhisaṅkhāra vasena
translated: recited this verse in order to explain that knowledge.🔽Herein, all the stations of consciousness: the Tathāgata knows all the stations of consciousness, that is to say, the four by way of the formations and the seven by way of rebirth-linking.

original: catasso paṭisandhivasena sattāti evaṃ sabbā viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo abhijānanto tathāgato.
analyzed: catasso paṭisandhi vasena sattā ti evam sabbāḥ viññāṇa ṭhitiyaḥ abhijānanto tathāgato
translated: He who knows thus is the Tathāgata.

original: Tiṭṭhantamenaṃ jānātīti kammābhisaṅkhāravasena tiṭṭhametaṃ puggalaṃ jānāti – “āyatiṃ
analyzed: tiṭṭhantam enam jānāti iti kamma abhisaṅkhāra vasena tiṭṭham etam puggalam jānāti āyatim
translated: He knows him as standing : he knows that this person, standing as he is in the formation of kamma, will go to such and such a destination in the future.🔽Bent on that : bent on the base consisting of nothingness, etc.

original: ayaṃ evaṃgatiko bhavissatī”ti. Dhimuttanti ākiñcaññāyatanādīsu adhimuttaṃ. Tapparāyaṇanti tammayaṃ.
analyzed: ayam evaṃgatikaḥ bhavissati iti dhimuttam ti ākiñcaññāyatana ādīsu adhimuttam tad parāyaṇam ti tammayam
translated: That is his resort : he is made up of that.

original: Viññāṇaṭṭhitiyoti paṭisandhiviññāṇassa ṭhānāni saviññāṇakā khandhā eva. Tattha seyyathāpīti🔽nidassanatthe nipāto yathā manussāti attho. Aparimāṇesupi hi cakkavāḷesu aparimāṇānaṃ🔽manussānaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena dvepi ekasadisā natthi. Yepi hi katthaci yamakabhātaro
analyzed: viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ ti paṭisandhi viññāṇassa ṭhānāni sa viññāṇakā khandhāḥ eva tattha seyyathā api iti  nidassana atthe nipātaḥ yathā manussā iti atthaḥ aparimāṇesu pi hi cakkavāḷesu aparimāṇānam  manussānam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādi vasena dve pi eka sadisāḥ natthi ye pi hi katthaci yamaka bhātaro
translated: Stations of consciousness : the aggregates with consciousness are the stations for the consciousness of rebirth-linking.🔽As if in a great mass of timber : the particle seyyotha is in the sense of “as if” . The meaning is: as if in a great mass of human beings.🔽For in the innumerable world systems there are innumerable human beings, and there are none alike in colour, shape, etc.

original: vaṇṇena vā saṇṭhānena vā sadisā honti. Tepi ālokitavilokitādīhi visadisāva honti.
analyzed: vaṇṇena vā saṇṭhānena vā sadisāḥ honti te pi ālokita vilokita ādīhi visadisāḥ ava honti
translated: Even twins are not alike in the way they look, the way they move, etc.

original: Tasmā “nānattakāyā”ti vuttā. Paṭisandhisaññā pana nesaṃ tihetukāpi duhetukāpi ahetukāpi
analyzed: tasmā nānattakāya ati vuttā paṭisandhi saññā pana nesam ti hetukā api du hetukā api ahetukā api
translated: Therefore they are said to be “of various bodies.” But their rebirth-linking perceptions are of three kinds, namely, with three roots, with two roots, and rootless.

original: hoti. Tasmā “nānattasaññino”ti vuttā. Ekacce ca devāti cha kāmāvacaradevā. Tesu hi
analyzed: hoti tasmā nānatta saññinaḥ ti vuttāḥ ekacce ca devā ti cha kāmāvacara devā tesu hi
translated: Some gods: six kinds of sense-sphere gods.

original: kesañci kāyo nīlo hoti, kesañci pītakādivaṇṇo. Saññā pana nesaṃ tihetukāpi duhetukāpi🔽hoti, ahetukā na hoti. Ekacce ca vinipātikāti catuapāyavinimuttā punabbasumātā yakkhinī
analyzed: kesañci kāyaḥ nīlaḥ hoti kesañci pītaka ādi vaṇṇo saññā pana nesam ti hetukā api du hetukā api  hoti ahetukā na hoti ekacce ca vinipātikā ati catu apāya vinimuttā punabbasu mātā yakkhinī
translated: For some of them the body is blue, some are yellow, and so on. But their perception is of the triple- and double-rooted kinds;🔽it is not rootless.

original: piyaṅkaramātā phussamittā dhammaguttāti evamādayo aññe ca vemānikā petā. Etesañhi
analyzed: piyaṅkara mātā phussa mittā dhamma guttā ti evamādayo aññe ca vemānikā petā etesam hi
translated: Some ghosts: the ghosts other than the four bad destinations, such as the ghost Punabbasu’s mother, the ghost Piyaṅkara’s mother, Phussamittā, Dhammaguttā, and other such ghosts.🔽For their bodies are various

original: odātakāḷamaṅguracchavisāmavaṇṇādivasena ceva kisathūlarassadīghavasena ca kāyo nānā🔽hoti, manussānaṃ viya tihetukaduhetukāhetukavasena saññāpi. Te pana devā viya na
analyzed: odāta kāḷamaṅgura chavi sāma vaṇṇa ādi vasena ca iva kisa thūla rassa dīgha vasena ca kāyaḥ nānā  hoti manussānam viya ti hetuka duhetuka ahetuka vasena saññā api te pana devāḥ viya na
translated: in colour as white, black, red, smooth, rough, and so on, and in shape as short, fat, tall, and so on,

original: mahesakkhā, kapaṇamanussā viya appesakkhā dullabhaghāsacchādanā dukkhapīḷitā viharanti.
analyzed: mahesakkhāḥ kapaṇa manussāḥ viya appesakkhāḥ dullabha ghāsa chādanāḥ dukkha pīḍitāḥ viharanti
translated: and their perception is of the triple- and double-rooted and rootless kinds like that of human beings. But they are not powerful like the gods; they are powerless like poor human beings, and they live in suffering, oppressed by hunger and thirst and lacking clothing.

original: Ekacce kāḷapakkhe dukkhitā juṇhapakkhe sukhitā honti, tasmā sukhasamussayato vinipatitattā
analyzed: ekacce kāḷapakkhe dukkhitāḥ juṇhapakkhe sukhitāḥ honti tasmā sukha samussayataḥ vinipatita ttā
translated: Some are miserable in the dark fortnight but happy in the bright fortnight. So they are called “ghosts fallen from happiness” .

original: vinipātikāti vuttā. Ye panettha tihetukā, tesaṃ dhammābhisamayopi hoti piyaṅkaramātādīnaṃ viya.
analyzed: vinipātikā ati vuttā ye pana ittha ti hetukā tesam dhamma abhisamayaḥ api hoti piyaṅkara mātā ādīnam viya
translated: But those of them who are of triple-root type have also the penetration of ideas, like Piyaṅkaramātā and others.

original: Brahmakāyikāti brahmapārisajjabrahmapurohitamahābrahmāno. Paṭhamābhinibbattāti te
analyzed: brahmakāyikā ati brahma pārisajja brahmapurohita mahābrahmāno paṭhama abhinibbattā ati te
translated: “Brahma-order beings” are the Brahmā’s Retinue, the Ministers of Brahmā, and the Great Brahmās.🔽“First-arisen” :

original: sabbepi paṭhamajjhānena nibbattā. Brahmapārisajjā pana parittena, brahmapurohitā
analyzed: sabbe api paṭhama jhānena nibbattāḥ brahmapārisajjā pana parittena brahmapurohitā
translated: all of them are arisen by means of the first jhāna. But the Brahmā’s Retinue are of limited extent, the Ministers of Brahmā🔽are of medium extent, and the Great Brahmās’ bodies are of still greater extent.

original: majjhimena, kāyova nesaṃ vipphārikataro hoti. Mahābrahmāno paṇītena, kāyo pana nesaṃ🔽ativipphārikataro hoti. Iti te kāyassa nānattā, paṭhamajjhānavasena saññāya ekattā
analyzed: majjhimena kāyo uva nesam vipphārikataraḥ hoti mahābrahmāno paṇītena kāyo pana nesam  ativipphārikataraḥ hoti iti te kāyassa nānattā paṭhamajjhāna vasena saññāya ekattā
translated: The Great Brahmās are of refined extent, but their bodies🔽are of still greater extent. So they are called “having different bodies and the same perception” because of the difference in their bodies and the sameness in their perception by means of the first jhāna.

original: nānattakāyā ekattasaññinoti vuttā. Yathā ca te, evaṃ catūsu apāyesu sattā. Nirayesu🔽hi kesañci gāvutaṃ, kesañci aḍḍhayojanaṃ, kesañci tigāvutaṃ attabhāvo hoti, devadattassa
analyzed: nānatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññinaḥ ti vuttāḥ yathā ca te evam catūsu apāyesu sattāḥ nirayesu  hi kesañci gāvutam kesañci aḍḍha yojanam kesañci tigāvutam atta bhāvaḥ hoti devadattassa
translated: And just as they are, so are the beings in the four lower worlds.🔽For in the hells some have the size of a gāvuta , some a half-yojana, and some three gāvutas, but Devadatta’s was a yojana in size.🔽And among animals some are small and some are big. And among ghosts

original: pana yojanasatiko jāto. Tiracchānesupi keci khuddakā honti, keci mahantā. Pettivisayesupi
analyzed: pana yojana satikaḥ jātaḥ tiracchānesu pi keci khuddakāḥ honti keci mahantā petti visayesu pi
translated: some

original: keci saṭṭhihatthā, keci asītihatthā honti, keci suvaṇṇā, keci dubbaṇṇā. Tathā kālakañcikā
analyzed: keci saṭṭhi hatthā keci asīti hatthā honti keci suvaṇṇā keci dubbaṇṇā tathā kālakañcikā
translated: Some are sixty leagues tall, some eighty. Some are beautiful, some ugly. So too are the asuras.

original: asurā. Api cettha dīghapiṭṭhikapetā nāma saṭṭhiyojanikāpi honti. Saññā pana sabbesampi
analyzed: asurāḥ api ca ittha dīghapiṭṭhika petāḥ nāma saṭṭhi yojanikā api honti saññā pana sabbesam pi
translated: And here the long-backed demons are sixty leagues long. But the perception of all

original: akusalavipākāhetukāva hoti. Iti āpāyikāpi nānattakāyā ekattasaññinoti saṅkhaṃ gacchanti.
analyzed: akusala vipākā ahetukā ava hoti iti āpāyikā api nānatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññinaḥ ti saṅkham gacchanti
translated: is non-causally arisen unprofitable perception only. So they are classed as “having different bodies and the same perception. ”

original: Ābhassarāti daṇḍaukkāya acci viya etesaṃ sarīrato ābhā chijjitvā chijjitvā patantī🔽viya sarati visaratīti ābhassarā. Tesu pañcakanaye dutiyatatiyajjhānadvayaṃ parittaṃ🔽bhāvetvā upapannā parittābhā nāma honti. Majjhimaṃ bhāvetvā upapannā appamāṇābhā
analyzed: daṇḍaukkāya etesam sarīrataḥ ābhā chijjitvā chijjitvā patantī  sarati visarati iti ābhassarā tesu pañcaka naye dutiya tatiya jhāna dvayam parittam  bhāvetvā upapannā paritta ābhā nāma honti majjhimam bhāvetvā upapannā appamāṇa ābhā
translated: “Ābhassarans”: light goes forth from their bodies as they move about, as if it were the flame of a burning oil-lamp.

original: nāma honti. Paṇītaṃ bhāvetvā upapannā ābhassarā nāma honti. Idha pana ukkaṭṭhaparicchedavasena
analyzed: nāma honti paṇītam bhāvetvā upapannāḥ ābhassarāḥ nāma honti idha pana ukkaṭṭha pariccheda vasena
translated: So they are called “Ābhassarans” . Among them, those reborn by developing the second and third jhānas of the fivefold system to a limited extent are called “Parittābhās” . Those reborn by developing them to an extensive extent are called “Appamāṇābhās” . Those reborn by developing them to the highest extent are called “Ābhassarans” . But here all are included by the words “Ābhassarans” in the sense of the highest extent.

original: sabbe gahitā. Sabbesañhi tesaṃ kāyo ekavipphārova hoti, saññā pana avitakkavicāramattā
analyzed: sabbe gahitā sabbesam hi tesam kāyaḥ eka vipphāraḥ va hoti saññā pana a vitakka vicāra mattā
translated: For all of them the body is of the same extent, but the perception is only of the first jhāna.

original: ca avitakkaavicārā cāti nānā.
analyzed: ca a vitakka a vicārā ca ati nānā
translated: and the third is without applied thought and sustained thought. So they are different.

original: Subhakiṇhāti subhena vokiṇṇā, subhena sarīrappabhāvaṇṇena ekagghanāti attho. Etesañhi
analyzed: subhakiṇhā ati subhena vokiṇṇā subhena sarīra pabhā vaṇṇena ekagghanā ati attho etesam hi
translated: “Mixed with light” : mixed with light, that is, with the colour of the radiance of the bodies. The meaning is that they are of the same value.

original: na ābhassarānaṃ viya chijjitvā chijjitvā pabhā gacchatīti. Catukkanaye tatiyassa🔽pañcakanaye catukkassa parittamajjhimapaṇītassa jhānassa vasena parittasubhaappamāṇasubhasubhakiṇhā
analyzed: na viya chijjitvā chijjitvā pabhā gacchati iti catukka naye tatiyassa  pañcaka naye catukkassa paritta majjhima paṇītassa jhānassa vasena paritta subha appamāṇa subha subha kiṇhā
translated: For their radiance does not go forth in separate jets like that of the Ābhassara Brahmās.🔽In the fourfold reckoning they are called “limited-beauty Brahmās,” “measureless-beauty Brahmās,” “beautiful Brahmās,” and “mixed-beauty Brahmās” respectively according to whether their jhāna is limited, measureless, and so on, as in the case of the Ābhassara Brahmās.

original: nāma hutvā nibbattanti. Iti sabbepi te ekattakāyā ceva catutthajjhānasaññāya ekattasaññino
analyzed: nāma hutvā nibbattanti iti sabbe pi te ekatta kāyā ca iva catuttha jhāna saññāya ekatta saññinaḥ
translated: So all of them are of the same body and of the same perception owing to the fourth jhāna.

original: cāti veditabbā. Vehapphalāpi catutthaviññāṇaṭṭhitimeva bhajanti. Asaññasattā viññāṇābhāvā
analyzed: ca ati veditabbā vehapphalā api catuttha viññāṇa ṭṭhitim eva bhajanti asañña sattā viññāṇa abhāvā
translated: The Vehapphala gods belong to the fourth kind of rebirth as consciousness. The non-percipient beings are not included here because of the absence of consciousness.

original: ettha saṅgahaṃ na gacchanti, sattāvāsesu gacchanti.🔽Suddhāvāsā vivaṭṭapakkhe ṭhitā, na sabbakālikā, kappasatasahassampi asaṅkhyeyyampi
analyzed: ettha saṅgaham na gacchanti sattā vāsesu gacchanti  suddhāvāsā vivaṭṭa pakkhe ṭhitā na sabba kālikā kappa sata sahassam pi asaṅkhyeyyam pi
translated: They are included among the stations of beings.🔽The Suddhāvāsa gods are not included here because they are not included in the round of rebirths, and they do not exist all the time. They do not arise in a world devoid of a Buddha for a hundred thousand aeons or for an incalculable age.

original: buddhasuññe loke na uppajjanti. Soḷasakappasahassabbhantare buddhesu uppannesuyeva
analyzed: buddha suññe loke na uppajjanti soḷasa kappa sahassa abbhantare buddhesu uppannesu yeva
translated: They arise only when sixteen thousand aeons are occupied by Buddhas.

original: uppajjanti. Dhammacakkapavattissa bhagavato khandhāvārasadisā honti. Tasmā neva viññāṇaṭṭhitiṃ,🔽na ca sattāvāsaṃ bhajanti. Mahāsīvatthero pana “na kho pana so, sāriputta, āvāso
analyzed: uppajjanti dhamma cakka pavattissa bhagavato khandhāvāra sadisāḥ honti tasmā na iva viññāṇa ṭṭhitim  na ca satta āvāsam bhajanti mahāsīva theraḥ pana na kho pana saḥ sāriputta āvāsaḥ
translated: That is why they do not belong to any station for consciousness or abode of beings.

original: sulabharūpo, yo mayā anāvuṭṭhapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā aññatra suddhāvāsehi devehīti
analyzed: sulabha rūpaḥ yaḥ mayā an āvuṭṭha pubbaḥ iminā dīghena addhunā aññatra suddha āvāsehi devehi iti
translated: But the Elder Maha-Siva said: “Sariputta, it is not easy to find a place where I have not been before in the course of a long time except in the case of the gods in the Pure Abodes” .

original: iminā suttena suddhāvāsāpi catutthaviññāṇaṭṭhitiṃ catutthasattāvāsañca bhajantī”ti
analyzed: iminā suttena suddhāvāsā api catuttha viññāṇa ṭṭhitim catuttha sattāvāsam ca bhajanti iti
translated: He said this because the Pure Abodes belong to the fourth station for consciousness and the fourth abode of beings according to the sutta passage, “The gods of the base of infinite space are the fourth station for consciousness” , etc.

original: vadati, taṃ appaṭibāhitattā suttassa anuññātaṃ.🔽Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamāti ettha sabbasoti sabbākārena, sabbāsaṃ vā anavasesānanti🔽attho. Rūpasaññānanti saññāsīsena vuttarūpāvacarajjhānānañceva tadārammaṇānañca.
analyzed: vadati tam a paṭibāhita ttā suttassa anuññātam  sabbasas rūpa saññānam samatikkama ati ettha sabbasas ti sabba ākārena sabbāsam vā anavasesānam ti  atthaḥ rūpa saññānan ti saññā sīsena vutta rūpāvacara jhānānam ca iva tad ārammaṇānam ca
translated: But that is not contradicted by the sutta, since it is allowed.🔽As to the words “having completely surmounted the perception of physical matter” , etc., here the word “completely” is in all ways, or without exception.🔽The “perception of physical matter” is the fine-material jhānas stated under the heading of perception.

original: Rūpāvacarajjhānampi hi rūpanti vuccati “rūpī rūpāni passatī”tiādīsu, tassa ārammaṇampi
analyzed: rūpāvacara jhānam pi hi rūpanti vuccati rūpī rūpāni passati itiādīsu tassa ārammaṇam pi
translated: And the fine-material jhāna itself is called “physical matter” in such passages as “Possessed of physical matter, he sees … ” .

original: “bahiddhā rūpāni passati suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”tiādīsu. Tasmā idha “rūpe saññā rūpasaññā”ti🔽evaṃ saññāsīsena vuttarūpāvacarajjhānassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Rūpaṃ saññā assāti rūpasaññā,
analyzed: bahiddhā rūpāni passati suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni itiādīsu tasmai idha rūpe saññā rūpa saññā ati  evam saññā sīsena vutta rūpāvacara jhānassa etam adhivacanam rūpam saññā assa ati rūpa saññā

original: jhānassa pasaṃsāvasena etāsaṃ ettha vacanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Atha vā – kiñcāpi tā rūpāvacaraṃ

translated: Therefore it is proper to say that they are abandoned here. original: ca vuttā – “āḷāro ca kālāmo arūpaṃ samāpanno pañcamattāni sakaṭasatāni nissāya nissāya🔽atikkantāni neva addasa, na pana saddaṃ assosī”ti.

translated: And it is because they are abandoned here that the imperturbability of the immaterial attainments and the state of their being peaceful emancipations are mentioned: “Āḷāra Kālāma attained the immaterial attainments and passed away without ever seeing or hearing the five hundred carts that went past right near him” .

analyzed: asadisā tasmā nānatta saññā iti vuttā tāsam sabbasas nānatta saññānam amanasikārā

analyzed: vadati kaḥ nu kho etāya nibbattitāya atthaḥ kaḥ ānisaṃsaḥ ti te evam vattum mā labhantu uti  imehi ākārehi samāpattiyāḥ vaṇṇam kathesi tat hi na esam sutvā evam bhavissati evam
