analyzed: santā kira ayam samāpatti evam paṇītāḥ nibbattessāma nanti atha assāḥ nibbattana tthāya  ussāham karissanti iti  palobhana ttham ca api tesam etissā vaṇṇam kathesi visakaṇṭaka vāṇijo viya visakaṇṭaka vāṇijo  nāma guḷa vāṇijaḥ vuccati saḥ kira guḷa phāṇita khaṇḍa sakkara ādīni sakaṭena ādāya paccanta gāmam
translated: For when they hear this, they will think thus: “So it seems this attainment is so excellent; we shall attain it.” Then they will make an effort to attain it.

original: gantvā “visakaṇṭakaṃ gaṇhatha, visakaṇṭakaṃ gaṇhathā”ti ugghosesi. Taṃ sutvā gāmikā
analyzed: gantvā visa kaṇṭakam gaṇhatha visa kaṇṭakam gaṇhatha ati ugghosesi tam sutvā gāmikā
translated: And he extols it in this way in order to tempt them, like a hawker who extols his wares. A hawker of sugar is what is meant. He is said to have gone to a village in the border country with sugar, sugar-cane, sugar- confectionery, treacle, etc., in a carrying pole. He called out, “Take some sugar, take some sugar.” When the villagers heard that,

original: “visaṃ nāma kakkhaḷaṃ, yo naṃ khādati, so marati, kaṇṭakopi vijjhitvā māreti, ubhopete
analyzed: visam nāma kakkhaḷam yaḥ nam khādati saḥ marati kaṇṭakaḥ api vijjhitvā māreti ubhā upete
translated: they said, “Sugar is bitter. Whoever eats it dies. A thorn pierces and kills. Both are the same.

original: kakkhaḷā, ko ettha ānisaṃso”ti gehadvārāni thakesuṃ, dārake ca palāpesuṃ. Taṃ disvā
analyzed: kakkhaḷā kaḥ ettha ānisaṃsaḥ ti geha dvārāni thakesum dārake ca tam disvā
translated: and they closed their doors and drove away their children.

original: vāṇijo “avohārakusalā ime gāmikā, handa ne upāyena gaṇhāpemī”ti “atimadhuraṃ gaṇhatha,🔽atisāduṃ gaṇhatha, guḷaṃ phāṇitaṃ sakkaraṃ samagghaṃ labbhati, kūṭamāsakakūṭakahāpaṇādīhipi
analyzed: vāṇijaḥ avohāra kusalāḥ ime gāmikāḥ handa ne upāyena ati madhuram gaṇhatha  atisādum gaṇhatha guḷam phāṇitam sakkaram samaggham labbhati kūṭa māsaka kūṭaka hāpaṇa ādīhi pi
translated: Seeing this, the trader thought, “These villagers are clever at haggling. Well, I’ll get them to buy by a trick.” He announced, “Buy something very sweet,🔽buy something very sour. You can get sugar, molasses, granulated sugar, and honey. You can get them for a counterfeit māsaka, a counterfeit kahāpaṇa, and so on.”

original: labbhatī”ti ugghosesi. Taṃ sutvā gāmikā haṭṭhapahaṭṭhā nikkhantā bahumpi mūlaṃ datvā gahesuṃ.
analyzed: labbhati iti ugghosesi tam sutvā gāmikāḥ haṭṭha pahaṭṭhāḥ nikkhantāḥ bahum pi mūlam da tvā gahesuṃ
translated: Hearing this, the villagers were delighted. They came out and bought a lot, paying a high price.

original: Tattha vāṇijassa “visakaṇṭakaṃ gaṇhathā”ti ugghosanaṃ viya bhagavato “ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: tattha vāṇijassa visa kaṇṭakam gaṇhatha ati ugghosanam viya bhagavataḥ ākāsa anañca āyatana samāpattim
translated: Here the trader’s announcement, “Buy something with a bitter stalk,” is like the Blessed One’s statement, “Develop the base of the infinity of space.”

original: nibbattethā”ti vacanaṃ. “Ubhopete kakkhaḷā, ko ettha ānisaṃso”ti gāmikānaṃ cintanaṃ
analyzed: nibbattetha iti vacanam ubhopete kakkhaḷā kaḥ ettha ānisaṃsaḥ ti gāmikānam cintanam
translated: The villagers’ thought, “Both are bitter. What’s the advantage?”

original: viya “bhagavā ‘ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ nibbattethā’ti āha, ko nu kho ettha ānisaṃso, nāssa
analyzed: viya bhagavā ākāsānañcāyatanam nibbattetha ati āha kaḥ nu kho ettha ānisaṃsaḥ na assa
translated: is like the thought of the bhikkhus, “The Blessed One says, ‘Develop the base of the infinity of space.’ But what’s the advantage?”

original: guṇaṃ jānāmā”ti sotūnaṃ cintanaṃ. Athassa vāṇijassa “atimadhuraṃ gaṇhathā”tiādivacanaṃ🔽viya bhagavato rūpasaññāsamatikkamanādikaṃ ānisaṃsappakāsanaṃ. Idañhi sutvā te bahumpi🔽mūlaṃ datvā gāmikā viya guḷaṃ “iminā ānisaṃsena palobhitacittā mahantampi ussāhaṃ
analyzed: guṇam jānāma ati sotūnam cintanam athassa vāṇijassa ati madhuram gaṇhatha ati ādi vacanam  viya bhagavataḥ rūpa saññā samatikkamana ādikam ānisaṃsa pakāsanam idam hi sutvā te  mūlam da tvā gāmikā viya guḷam iminā ānisaṃsena palobhita cittā mahantam pi ussāham
translated: The thought of the listeners is like the thought of the merchants: “We will know the quality.” The statement of the Blessed One is like the statement of the merchant: “Take it very sweet.”🔽The teaching of the benefits beginning with the surmounting of perception of visible objects, etc., is like the statement: “Take it very sweet.” For having heard this, they, like the villagers who having given much money for the sugar,🔽take it with the thought: “We will know the quality,” with their minds attracted by the benefits, will make great effort to surmount the perception of visible objects, etc.🔽

original: katvā imaṃ samāpattiṃ nibbattessantī”ti ussāhajananatthaṃ palobhanatthañca kathesi.🔽Ākāsānañcāyatanūpagāti ettha nāssa antoti anantaṃ, ākāsaṃ anantaṃ ākāsānantaṃ, ākāsānantaṃ🔽eva ākāsānañcaṃ, taṃ ākāsānañcaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena āyatanamassa sasampayuttadhammassa
analyzed: katvā imam samāpattim nibbattessanti iti ussāha janana attham palobhana attham ca kathesi  ākāsa anañca āyatana upagā ti ettha na assa anto ti anantam ākāsam anantam ākāsa anantam ākāsa anantam  eva ākāsānañcam tam ākāsānañcam adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena āyatanam assa sa sampayutta dhammassa
translated: “We know the quality” is the thought of the listeners. Then the Blessed One’s teaching of the benefits beginning with the surmounting of perception of visible objects is like the trader’s words “Take it very sweet” and so on. For this was spoken in order to generate enthusiasm and to inspire confidence, as the trader’s words were, in order to generate enthusiasm in the listeners and to inspire confidence by showing the benefits. For when they hear this they will be inspired with confidence and will generate enthusiasm and strive much to reach that attainment, as the villagers did when they heard about the benefits of the sugar.

original: jhānassa devānaṃ devāyatanamivāti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ. Kasiṇugghāṭimākāsassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: jhānassa devānam devāyatanam iva ati ākāsa anañca āyatanam adhivacanam
translated: The base consisting of boundless space: here it is boundless since there is no end to it, thus it is boundless . Space is boundless , thus it is the boundless of space . That boundless of space is the base in the sense of foundation for the jhāna whose nature it is to be associated with it, as the “deities’ base” is for deities, thus it is the “base consisting of boundless space” . This is a term for the space kasiṇa that has reached absorption.

original: Tattha jhānaṃ nibbattetvā paṭisandhivasena ākāsānañcāyatanabhavaṃ upagatā ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
analyzed: tattha jhānam nibbattetvā paṭisandhi vasena ākāsa anañca āyatana bhavam upagatā ākāsa anañca āyatana upagā
translated: Herein, those who have attained the base consisting of boundless space by rebirth- linking after producing the jhāna are called “bound for the base consisting of boundless space.”

original: Ito paresu visesamattameva vaṇṇayissāma.
analyzed: itas paresu visesa mattam eva vaṇṇayissāma
translated: We shall comment on the difference in each instance.

original: Ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkammāti ettha tāva pubbe vuttanayena ākāsānañcaṃ āyatanamassa
analyzed: ākāsānañca āyatanam samatikkamma ati ettha tāva pubbe vutta nayena ākāsānañcam āyatanam assa
translated: Having thus completely surmounted the base consisting of boundless space: here firstly, the base consisting of boundless space is his, thus he is a possessor of the base consisting of boundless space.🔽The jhāna is the base consisting of boundless space too in the sense of being its footing.

original: adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhenāti jhānampi ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ, vuttanayeneva ārammaṇampi. Evametaṃ🔽jhānañca ārammaṇañcāti ubhayampi appavattikaraṇena ca amanasikaraṇena ca samatikkamitvāva
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena ati jhānam pi ākāsa ānañca āyatanam vutta nayena iva ārammaṇam pi evam etam  jhānam ca ārammaṇam ca ati ubhayam pi appavatti karaṇena ca amanasikaraṇena ca samatikkamitvā ava
translated: The object is the base consisting of boundless space in the way already stated.🔽So both the jhāna and the object are the base consisting of boundless space.

original: yasmā idaṃ viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharitabbaṃ, tasmā ubhayampetaṃ ekajjhaṃ
analyzed: yasmai idam viññāṇañca āyatanam upasampajja viharitabbam tasmai ubhayam petam ekajjham
translated: And it is by completely surmounting the jhāna and the object in this way, that is, by not attending to them, that he enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of boundless consciousness.

original: katvā “ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkammā”ti idaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: katvā ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma ati idam vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: Since this is so, it must be understood that both the jhāna and the object are included in the words, “Having thus completely surmounted the base consisting of boundless space.”🔽Bound for the base consisting of boundless consciousness: here the meaning should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Viññāṇañcāyatanūpagāti ettha pana “ananta”nti manasikātabbavasena nāssa antoti anantaṃ,
analyzed: viññāṇañcāyatana upagā ti ettha pana anantam ti manasikātabba vasena na assa antaḥ ti anantam
translated: But “it has no end” is the same as “it is endless” .

original: anantameva ānañcaṃ, viññāṇaṃ ānañcaṃ “viññāṇānañca”nti avatvā “viññāṇañca”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: anantam eva ānañcam viññāṇam ānañcam viññāṇānañcanti avatvā viññāṇañcanti vuttam
translated: The base consisting of boundless consciousness is simply boundless consciousness, and it is called the base consisting of boundless consciousness because it is the base of boundless consciousness.🔽The word “base” here is in the sense of foundation.

original: Ayañhettha ruḷhīsaddo. Tadeva viññāṇañcaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena āyatananti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: ayam ha ittha ruḷhī saddo tat eva viññāṇañcam adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena āyatanan ti viññāṇañcāyatanam
translated: That same base consisting of boundless consciousness is the base consisting of boundless consciousness as the “sphere” in the sense of domain.

original: Tattha jhānaṃ nibbattetvā viññāṇañcāyatanabhavaṃ upagatā viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
analyzed: tattha jhānam nibbattetvā viññāṇañcāyatana bhavam upagatā viññāṇañcāyatana upagā
translated: Those who have arisen in the existence of the base consisting of boundless consciousness after developing jhāna there are “those who have arisen in the base consisting of boundless consciousness” .

original: Viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkammāti etthapi pubbe vuttanayeneva viññāṇañcaṃ āyatanamassa🔽adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhenāti jhānampi viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ, vuttanayeneva ca ārammaṇampi. Evametaṃ
analyzed: viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma ti ettha api pubbe vutta nayena iva āyatanam assa  adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena ati jhānam pi viññāṇañca āyatanam vutta nayena iva ca ārammaṇam pi evam etam
translated: The words “surpassing the base consisting of boundless consciousness” should be understood in the same way as the words “surpassing the base consisting of boundless space” in the preceding case.🔽That jhāna too is the base consisting of boundless consciousness in the sense of domain, and the object too is the base consisting of boundless consciousness in the same sense.🔽So both jhāna and its object are the base consisting of boundless consciousness.

original: jhānañca ārammaṇañcāti ubhayampi appavattikaraṇena ca amanasikaraṇena ca samatikkamitvāva
analyzed: jhānam ca ārammaṇam ca ati ubhayam pi appavatti karaṇena ca amanasikaraṇena ca samatikkamitvā ava
translated: And it is by making that same jhāna and its object in the first of all the immaterial states the foundation for insight that he “surpasses the base consisting of boundless consciousness” by making it subside in the way already described and by giving attention to the coarseness of that jhāna and its object.

original: yasmā idaṃ ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharitabbaṃ, tasmā ubhayampetaṃ ekajjhaṃ🔽katvā “viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkammā”ti idaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: yasmai idam ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharitabbam tasmai ubhayam petam ekajjham 🔽katvā viññāṇam ca āyatanam samatikkamma ati idam vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: And it is by giving attention to the peaceful in this way that he “enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of nothingness.”🔽Here too, “the base consisting of nothingness” is the name for a kind of jhāna, and it is also the name for the fine-material sphere of existence consisting of beings who are of that kind.

original: Ākiñcaññāyatanūpagāti ettha pana nāssa kiñcananti akiñcanaṃ, antamaso bhaṅgamattampi🔽assa avasiṭṭhaṃ natthīti vuttaṃ hoti. Akiñcanassa bhāvo ākiñcaññaṃ, ākāsānañcāyatanaviññāṇāpagamassetaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ. Taṃ ākiñcaññaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena āyatananti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatana upagā ti ettha pana na assa kiñcanan ti akiñcanam antamasaḥ bhaṅga mattam pi  assa avasiṭṭham natthi iti vuttam hoti akiñcanassa bhāvaḥ ākiñcaññam ākāsa ānañca āyatana viññāṇa apagamassa etam  adhivacanam tam ākiñcaññam adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena āyatanam ti ākiñcaññāyatanam tattha
translated: Herein, there is nothing for him, thus it is nothing ; what is meant is that there is not even a mere remnant left in him, not even a state of having been . The state of being nothing is nothingness ; this is a term for the passing away of consciousness that occurred in the base of infinite space. That nothingness is a base in the sense of foundation , thus it is the base of nothingness . Herein,

original: jhānaṃ nibbattetvā ākiñcaññāyatanabhavaṃ upagatā ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā. Ayaṃ sattamaviññāṇaṭṭhitīti🔽imaṃ sattamaṃ paṭisandhiviññāṇassa ṭhānaṃ jānāti. Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ yatheva
analyzed: jhānam nibbattetvā ākiñcaññāyatana bhavam upagatā ākiñcaññāyatana upagā ayam sattama viññāṇa ṭṭhitī iti  imam sattamam paṭisandhi viññāṇassa ṭhānam jānāti nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam yathā iva
translated: “The sphere of nothingness” : here there is nothing of his, thus it is nothingness . What is meant is that there is not even a mere remnant of it left, not even so much as would make up the smallest particle. The state of being nothingness is the sphere of nothingness . This is a designation for the passing away of consciousness in the base of infinite space. That sphere of nothingness is the sphere of nothingness in the sense of basis . Those who have produced the jhāna there and have been reborn in the plane of existence of the sphere of nothingness are “gone to the sphere of nothingness” . This is the seventh station of consciousness.🔽He knows: “This is the seventh rebirth-linking of consciousness.”

original: saññāya, evaṃ viññāṇassāpi sukhumattā neva viññāṇaṃ nāviññāṇaṃ, tasmā viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu na vuttaṃ.
analyzed: saññāyaḥ evam viññāṇassa api sukhuma ttā na iva viññāṇam na aviññāṇam tasmā viññāṇa ṭhitīsu na vuttam
translated: The base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is not mentioned among the stations of consciousness because consciousness is still more refined there than in the base of nothingness, and so it is neither perception nor non-perception .

original: Abhūtanti abhūtatthaṃ “rūpaṃ attā”tiādivacanaṃ. Taṃ vipallāsabhāvato atacchaṃ. Diṭṭhinissayato
analyzed: abhūtanti abhūtattham rūpam attā ati ādi vacanam tam vipallāsa bhāvataḥ ataccham diṭṭhi nissayato
translated: “Unreal” : the statement “Form is self” , etc., is unreal in the sense of being a perversion . It is not true because it is a support for wrong view.

original: anatthasañhitaṃ. Atha vā abhūtanti asantaṃ avijjamānaṃ. Acorasseva “idaṃ te corikāya🔽ābhataṃ, na idaṃ tuyhaṃ ghare dhana”ntiādivacanaṃ. Atacchanti atathākāraṃ aññathā🔽santaṃ. Anatthasañhitanti na idhalokatthaṃ vā paralokatthaṃ vā nissitaṃ. Na taṃ tathāgato🔽byākarotīti taṃ aniyyānikakathaṃ tathāgato na katheti. Bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ anatthasañhitanti
analyzed: anattha sañhitam atha vā a bhūta nti asantam a vijjamānam a corassa iva idam te corikāya  naḥ idam ghare a tathākāram aññathā  santam anattha sañhitanti na idha loka ttham vā para loka ttham vā nissitam na tam tathāgataḥ  byākaroti iti tam aniyyānika katham tathāgataḥ na kathā iti bhūtam taccham anattha sañhitan ti
translated: Or else, “unreal” means “non-existent,” “non-apprehensible.” It is like the words of a thief who says: “This was stolen by you, it is not your property.” “Untrue” means “of a different nature,” “existing in a different way.” “Unbeneficial” means “not based on the welfare of this world or the next.” “The Tathāgata does not declare” means that the Tathāgata does not speak of that which is not conducive to emancipation. “Real, true, and beneficial” means

original: rājakathāditiracchānakathaṃ. Bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasañhitanti ariyasaccasannissitaṃ.🔽Tatra kālaññū tathāgato hotīti tasmiṃ tatiyabyākaraṇe tassa pañhassa byākaraṇatthāya🔽tathāgato kālaññū hoti. Mahājanassa ādānakālaṃ gahaṇakālaṃ jānitvā sahetukaṃ sakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: rājakathāditiracchānakatham bhūtam taccham attha sañhitam ti ariya sacca sannissitam  tatra kālaññū tathāgataḥ hoti iti tasmim tatiya byākaraṇe tassa pañhassa byākaraṇa atthāya  tathāgato kālaññū hoti mahā janassa ādāna kālam gahaṇa kālam jānitvā sa hetukam sa kāraṇam
translated: Or else, “not happened” means “non-existent, not to be found.” “Not stolen” is a statement such as “This was not stolen by you, it is not your property” to a thief. “Not taken” means “not of that kind, not as it is.” “Not connected with welfare” means “not based on the welfare of this world or the next.” “The Tathāgata does not declare” means “the Tathāgata does not speak” that kind of talk which is not conducive to the goal. “What is happened, true, and connected with welfare” means “royal talk” and “animal talk.” “What is happened, true, and connected with welfare” means “talk based on the noble truths.”

original: katvā yuttapattakāleyeva byākarotīti attho.
analyzed: katvā byākaroti iti
translated: “In that, the Tathāgata is one who knows the time” means that in that third declaration, the Tathāgata knows the time to answer that question. The meaning is that he knows the time for the people to receive it and grasp it, and he answers at the appropriate time, giving reasons and causes.

original: Yuttapattakāle vadatīti kālavādī. Bhūtaṃ sabhāvaṃ vadatīti bhūtavādī. Paramatthaṃ
analyzed: yutta patta kāle vadati iti kāla vādī bhūtam sabhāvam vadati iti bhūta vādī paramattham
translated: He speaks at the right time: he is a timely speaker. He speaks what is true: he is a truthful speaker. He speaks what is beneficial: he is a beneficial speaker.

original: nibbānaṃ vadatīti atthavādī. Maggaphaladhammaṃ vadatīti dhammavādī. Saṃvarādivinayaṃ🔽vadatīti vinayavādī. Tattha diṭṭhanti aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ
analyzed: nibbānam vadati iti attha vādī magga phala dhammam vadati iti dhamma vādī saṃvara ādi vinayam  vadati iti vinaya vādī tattha aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānam sattānam
translated: He speaks at the proper time: he speaks when the time is appropriate for doing so. He speaks what is true: he speaks what is really so. He speaks in accordance with the goal: he speaks the goal which is Nibbāna. He speaks in accordance with the Dhamma: he speaks the Dhamma of the path and the fruits . He speaks in accordance with the discipline: he speaks the discipline of restraint, etc.

original: cakkhudvāresu āpāthaṃ āgacchantaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ nāma atthi, taṃ sabbākārato jānāti🔽passati. Evaṃ jānatā passatā ca tena taṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhādivasena vā diṭṭhasutamutaviññātesu🔽labbhamānakapadavasena vā “katamaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ? Yaṃ rūpaṃ catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu dvāresu āpātham āgacchantam rūpa ārammaṇam nāma atthi tam sabba ākārataḥ jānāti  passati evam jānatā passatā ca tena tam iṭṭha aniṭṭha ādi vasena vā diṭṭha suta muta viññātesu  labbhamānaka pada vasena vā katamam tam rūpam rūpa āyatanam yam rūpam catunnam mahābhūtānam
translated: Herein, visible : there is a visible-data object called “visible form” that comes into focus in the eye-door of beings in the countless world systems. He knows and sees it in all its aspects.

original: upādāya vaṇṇanibhā sanidassanaṃ sappaṭighaṃ nīlaṃ pītaka”ntiādinā nayena anekehi
analyzed: upādāya vaṇṇa nibhā sa nidassanam sa paṭigham nīlam pīta kanti ādinā nayena anekehi
translated: And knowing and seeing it thus, he knows and sees it as “visible” in the sense of being either agreeable or disagreeable, etc., or in the sense of being the visible-data base among the bases described thus, “What is the visible-data base? It is visible form cognizable by the eye” , or in the sense of being the visible form that is classified by the many names and the thirteen modes beginning thus: “What is the visible-data base? It is the blue, the yellow” .

original: nāmehi terasahi vārehi dvipaññāsāya nayehi vibhajjamānaṃ tathameva hoti vitathaṃ
analyzed: nāmehi terasahi vārehi dvipaññāsāya nayehi vibhajjamānam tatham eva hoti vitatham

analyzed: natthi esa nayo sota dvāra ādīsu pi āpātham āgacchantesu sadda ādīsu tesam vividham dassetum
translated: There is none. So too with the ear door, etc.

original: “diṭṭhaṃ suta”nti āha. Tattha diṭṭhanti rūpāyatanaṃ. Sutanti saddāyatanaṃ. Mutanti

original: patvā gahetabbato gandhāyatanaṃ rasāyatanaṃ phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ. Viññātanti sukhadukkhādidhammārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: patvā gahetabbataḥ gandha āyatanam rasa āyatanam phoṭṭhabba āyatanam viññātanti sukha dukkha ādi dhamma ārammaṇam

original: Pattanti pariyesitvā vā apariyesitvā vā pattaṃ. Pariyesitanti pattaṃ vā apattaṃ vā
analyzed: pattanti pariyesitvā vā a pariyesitvā vā pattam pariyesitanti pattam vā a pattam vā
translated: Obtained is what is obtained by searching for it or what is obtained without searching for it. Sought is what is sought by searching for it.🔽Considered by the mind is what is considered by the mind.

original: pariyesitaṃ. Anuvicaritaṃ manasāti cittena anusañcaritaṃ.🔽Tathāgatena abhisambuddhanti iminā etaṃ dasseti – yañhi aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu imassa
analyzed: pariyesitam anuvicaritam manasā ati cittena anusañcaritam  tathāgatena abhisambuddhanti iminā etam dasseti yat hi aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu imassa
translated: Discerned by wisdom is what is discerned by wisdom.🔽Well seen is what is well seen by the eye.🔽Well heard is what is well heard by the ear.🔽Well sensed is what is well sensed by the nose, tongue, and body.🔽Well cognized is what is well cognized by the mind.🔽The words “well seen” and so on are said in order to show that the seeing, etc., is not confused.🔽The words “well seen by the eye” are said in order to show that the seeing is not confused.

original: sadevakassa lokassa nīlaṃ pītakantiādi rūpārammaṇaṃ cakkhudvāre āpāthaṃ āgacchati,

translated: The words “well heard by the ear” are said in order to show that the hearing is not confused.🔽The words “well sensed by the nose, tongue, and body” are said in order to show that the sensing is not confused.

analyzed: vā jātaḥ iti sabbam tam tathāgatassa evam abhisambuddham tathā yam aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu  imassa sa devakassa lokassa bheri saddaḥ mudiṅga saddaḥ ti ādi sadda ārammaṇam sota dvāre āpātham

analyzed: āgacchati mūla gandho taca gandho iti ādi gandha ārammaṇam ghāna dvāre āpātham āgacchati  mūla rasaḥ khandha rasaḥ tiādi rasa ārammaṇam jivhā dvāre āpātham āgacchati kakkhaḷam mudukam tiādi

analyzed: pathavī dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu bhedam phoṭṭhabba ārammaṇam kāya dvāre āpātham āgacchati  ayam satto imasmin khaṇe imam nāma phoṭṭhabba ārammaṇam phusitvā sumanaḥ vā dummanaḥ  vā majjhattaḥ vā jātaḥ iti sabbam tam tathāgatassa evam abhisambuddham tathā yam aparimāṇāsu

translated: All this is fully understood by the Tathāgata.🔽There is nothing that he has to find out by inference through reasoning.🔽For there is nothing that has been seen, heard, or sensed by these beings that has not been seen, heard, or sensed by the Tathāgata.

translated: And there are things that have been found out by these beings that have also been found out by the Tathāgata, and there are things that have not been found out by these beings that have not been found out by the Tathāgata.🔽But there is nothing that has not been found out by the Tathāgata through direct knowledge.

analyzed: sabbam tam eka muddikāya lañchitam viya eka nāḷiyā mitam viya eka tulāya tulitam viya  ca tatham eva hoti vitatham na atthi tena āha yat ca cunda rattim tathāgata upe sabbam
translated: It is as if it were all stamped with the one seal. It is as if it were all measured with the one rule. It is as if it were all weighed with the one scale.

translated: It is just so. There is nothing false in it. For the word gata here has the meaning of ‘gone’ .

original: Api ca – āgadanaṃ āgado, vacananti attho. Tatho aviparīto āgado assāti da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā gatoti evametasmiṃ atthe padasiddhi veditabbā.

translated: Moreover, āgado is a non-erroneous utterance, that is the meaning. He has gone, making the da into a ta, in that way, thus the derivation of the word should be understood in this sense.

analyzed: yathāvādī cundape vuccati iti ettha bhagavataḥ vācāya kāyaḥ anulomā iti kāyassa api
translated: ‘And whatever the Tathagata says, Cunda, after he has known it with his wisdom thus: “This is the true idea here, this is the true goal here, this is the true doctrine here,” all that is just so, not otherwise. analyzed: vācā tasmai bhagavā yathāvādī tathākārī yathākārī tathāvādī ca hoti evaṃbhūtassa  cassa yathā vācā kāyaḥ api tathā gato pavatto ti atthaḥ yathā ca kāyaḥ vācā api tathā
translated: Therefore the Blessed One is one who acts as he speaks and speaks as he acts. analyzed: gatā pavattā ati tathāgato ti evam ettha pada siddhi veditabbā  upari bha vaggam heṭṭhā avīci pariyantam aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu  sabba satte abhibhavati sīlena api samādhinā api paññāya api vimuttiyā api na tassa tulā vā
translated: has become the same kind, has become similar, has become of the same quality, is said. Thus the derivation of the word should be understood here.

original: pamāṇaṃ vā atthi. Atulo appameyyo anuttaro rājarājā devadevo sakkānaṃ atisakko brahmānaṃ
analyzed: pamāṇam vai atthi atulaḥ appameyyaḥ anuttaraḥ rājarājā devadevaḥ sakkānam atisakkaḥ brahmānam
translated: He is the conqueror, the unvanquished: he conquers the highest pinnacle of existence below and Avīci hell above, and in the infinite world systems he conquers all beings by his virtue, concentration, wisdom, and liberation. original: atibrahmā. Aññadatthūti ekaṃsatthe nipāto. Dakkhatīti daso. Vasaṃ vattetīti vasavattī.
analyzed: atibrahmā ekaṃsatthe nipātaḥ dakkhati iti dasaḥ vasam vatteti iti vasavattī
translated: Aññadatthu is a particle in the sense of “one-sidedly.” Dakkhati is daso. Vasam vatteti is vasavatti.

original: Tatrāyaṃ padasiddhi veditabbā – agado viya agado, ko panesa? Desanāvilāso ceva puññussayo
analyzed: tatra ayam veditabbā agadaḥ viya agadaḥ kaḥ pana isa desanā vilāsaḥ ca iva puññussayo
translated: Herein, the derivation should be understood as follows. Agado is like a medicine. But what is it? It is the radiance of the teaching and the basis for merit.

original: ca. Tena hesa mahānubhāvo bhisakko dibbāgadena sappe viya sabbaparappavādino sadevakañca
analyzed: ca tena ha isa mahā anubhāvaḥ bhisakkaḥ dibbāgadena sappe viya sabba para ppavādinaḥ sa devakam ca

analyzed: lokam abhibhavati iti sabba loka abhibhavane aviparītaḥ desanā vilāsa mayaḥ ca iva
translated: Thus the opportunity for the display of the unerring teaching in the overcoming of the whole world,

analyzed: ca a ga daḥ assa ati dakārassa takāram katvā tathāgataḥ iti veditabbaḥ
translated: and the medicine of merit, is the meaning of the syllable ta in the word tathāgata, which is derived from the syllable da in the word dāyako .

analyzed: idhatthaññeva jānāti kamma abhisaṅkhāra vasena ati apuñña abhisaṅkhāra vasena idhatthaññeva
translated: Here and now he knows what is for his harm, by the performance of unprofitable kamma: here and now he knows what is for his harm by the performance of unprofitable kamma.

translated: With the breakup of the body, after death: with the breakup of the appropriated aggregates, after death.🔽The lower realms: the lower realms are so called because of the absence of growth , which is a kind of happiness and advantage. The hell: the hell is so called because of the absence of delight and because of the absence of protection .

translated: He will be reborn in that lower realm … in hell: he will be reborn by way of rebirth-linking in that lower realm … in hell. The animal generation:

original: tiriyaṃ añcantīti tiracchānā, tesaṃ yoni tiracchānayoni, taṃ tiracchānayoniṃ. Pettivisayanti🔽paccabhāvaṃ pattānaṃ visayoti pettivisayo, taṃ pettivisayaṃ. Manaso ussannatāya manussā,
analyzed: tiriyam añcanti iti tiracchānā tesam yoni tiracchāna yoni tam tiracchāna yonim pettivisayanti  paccabhāvam pattānam tam petti visayam manasaḥ ussanna tāya manussā
translated: “The animal birth” is the birth of animals. “The animal destiny” is the destiny of animals. “The ghost realm” is the realm of ghosts.🔽“Human beings” are those who are elevated in mind.🔽“Among human beings” means among those who are elevated in mind.

original: tesu manussesu. Ito paraṃ kammābhisaṅkhāravasenāti ettha puññābhisaṅkhāravasena attho gahetabbo.
analyzed: tesu manussesu itas param kamma abhisaṅkhāra vasena ati ettha puñña abhisaṅkhāra vasena atthaḥ gahetabbo
translated: From here on, the meaning should be understood in terms of the formation of merit.

original: Āsavānaṃ khayāti āsavānaṃ vināsena. Anāsavaṃ cetovimuttinti āsavavirahitaṃ arahattaphalasamādhiṃ.
analyzed: āsavānam khayā ati āsavānam vināsena anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim ti āsava virahitam arahatta phala samādhim
translated: “The destruction of the taints” is the destruction of the taints by means of the destruction of the taints. “The mind-deliverance that is taintless” is the concentration of the fruit of arahantship free from taints.

original: Paññāvimuttinti arahattaphalapaññaṃ. Arahattaphalasamādhi rāgavirāgā cetovimutti,
analyzed: paññā vimutti ti arahatta phala paññam arahatta phala samādhi rāga virāgā cetaḥ vimutti
translated: “The wisdom-deliverance” is the wisdom of the fruit of arahantship. The concentration of the fruit of arahantship is the mind-deliverance that is due to fading of lust.

original: arahattaphalapaññā avijjāvirāgā paññāvimuttīti veditabbā. Taṇhācaritena vā appanājhānabalena
analyzed: arahatta phala paññā avijjā virāgā paññā vimutti iti veditabbā taṇhā caritena vā appanā jhāna balena
translated: The wisdom of the fruit of arahantship is the wisdom-deliverance that is due to fading of ignorance.

original: kilese vikkhambhetvā adhigataṃ arahattaphalaṃ rāgavirāgā cetovimutti, diṭṭhicaritena
analyzed: kilese vikkhambhetvā adhigatam arahatta phalam rāga virāgā cetaḥ vimutti diṭṭhi caritena
translated: Or alternatively, the fruit of arahantship attained by suppressing the defilements through the strength of the jhāna of the fine-material sphere, which is the basis for the attainment of cessation, is the mind-deliverance that is due to fading of lust.🔽The fruit of arahantship attained by suppressing the defilements through the strength of the path of insight is the wisdom-deliverance that is due to fading of ignorance.

original: upacārajjhānamattaṃ nibbattetvā vipassitvā adhigataṃ arahattaphalaṃ avijjāvirāgā
analyzed: upacāra jhāna mattam nibbattetvā vipassitvā adhigatam arahatta phalam avijjā virāgā
translated: and he reached Arahantship by developing the jhāna only as far as the neighbourhood, and then by insight.🔽The knowledge of his Arahantship is deliverance by understanding through fading of ignorance.

original: paññāvimutti. Anāgāmiphalaṃ vā kāmarāgaṃ sandhāya rāgavirāgā cetovimutti, arahattaphalaṃ
analyzed: paññā vimutti anāgāmi phalam vā kāma rāgam sandhāya rāga virāgā cetaḥ vimutti arahatta phalam
translated: Or the knowledge of his non-return is deliverance by mind through fading of lust, and his Arahantship is deliverance by understanding through fading of ignorance.

original: sabbappakārato avijjāvirāgā paññāvimutti.🔽Ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ dhimuttanti vimokkhenāti kenaṭṭhena vimokkho veditabboti? Adhimuccanaṭṭhena.
analyzed: sabba ppakārataḥ avijjā virāgā paññā vimutti  ākiñcaññāyatanam dhimuttanti vimokkhena ati kenaṭṭhena vimokkhaḥ veditabbo ti adhimuccana ṭṭhena
translated: The base consisting of nothingness is the deliverance by means of which he is delivered.🔽In what sense is it a deliverance? It is a deliverance in the sense of a freeing.

original: Ko ayaṃ adhimuccanaṭṭho nāma? Paccanīkadhammehi ca suṭṭhu vimuccanaṭṭho, ārammaṇe
analyzed: kaḥ ayam adhimuccana ṭṭhaḥ nāma paccanīka dhammehi ca suṭṭhu vimuccana ṭṭhaḥ ārammaṇe
translated: What is the sense of a freeing? It is the sense of a freeing from opposing states, and it is the sense of a freeing by surmounting the object,

original: ca abhirativasena suṭṭhu vimuccanaṭṭho, pitu aṅke vissaṭṭhaaṅgapaccaṅgassa dārakassa
analyzed: ca abhirati vasena suṭṭhu vimucca naṭṭhaḥ pitu aṅke vissaṭṭha aṅga paccaṅgassa dārakassa
translated: like a child’s lying in its mother’s lap.

original: sayanaṃ viya aniggahitabhāvena nirāsaṅkatāya ārammaṇe pavattīti vuttaṃ hoti. Evarūpena
analyzed: sayanam viya a niggahita bhāvena nirāsaṅka tāya ārammaṇe pavatti iti vuttam hoti evarūpena
translated: What is meant is that it occurs with respect to the object without being clung to because it is unfettered.🔽He is delivered by means of the deliverance of the base consisting of nothingness:

original: vimokkhena dhimuttanti. Viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ muñcitvā ākiñcaññāyatane nirāsaṅkavasena
analyzed: vimokkhena dhimuttanti viññāṇañca āyatanam muñcitvā ākiñcaññāyatane nirāsaṅka vasena
translated: having been delivered from the base consisting of boundless consciousness,

original: dhimuttaṃ allīnaṃ. Tatrādhimuttanti tasmiṃ samādhimhi allīnaṃ. Tadadhimuttanti tasmiṃ🔽jhāne adhimuttaṃ. Tadādhipateyyanti taṃ jhānaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ. Rūpādhimuttotiādīni pañca🔽kāmaguṇagarukavasena vuttāni. Kulādhimuttotiādīni tīṇi khattiyādikulagarukavasena🔽vuttāni. Lābhādhimuttotiādīni aṭṭha lokadhammavasena vuttāni. Dhīvarādhimuttotiādīni
analyzed: dhimuttam al līnam tatra adhimuttanti tasmin samādhimhi al līnam tat adhimuttanti tasmin  jhāne adhimuttam tat ādhipateyyanti tam jhānam jeṭṭhakam rūpa adhimutta uti ādīni pañca  kāma guṇa garuka vasena vuttāni kula adhimutta uti ādīni tīṇi khattiya ādi kula garuka vasena  vuttāni lābha adhimuttaḥ ti ādīni aṭṭha loka dhamma vasena vuttāni dhīvara adhimuttaḥ ti ādīni
translated: “Bent on” means bent on that concentration. “Bent on that” means bent on that jhāna. “With that as its sovereign” means with that jhāna as the chief. “Bent on form” and the rest are said with reference to the five cords of sense desire. “Bent on family” and the rest are said with reference to the families of nobles, brahmans, and householders. “Bent on gain” and the rest are said with reference to the eight worldly ideas. “Bent on learning” and the rest are said with reference to the four castes.

original: cattāri paccayavasena vuttāni. Suttantādhimuttotiādīni piṭakattayavasena vuttāni.🔽Āraññakaṅgādhimuttotiādīni dhutaṅgasamādānavasena vuttāni. Paṭhamajjhānādhimuttotiādīni
analyzed: cattāri paccaya vasena vuttāni suttanta adhimuttaḥ ti ādīni piṭaka ttaya vasena vuttāni  āraññaka ṅga adhimuttaḥ ti ādīni dhutaṅga samādāna vasena vuttāni paṭhamajjhāna adhimuttaḥ iti ādīni
translated: and “he is intent” means he is attached to that concentration. “He is intent on that” means he is intent on that jhāna. “He is intent on that as his essence” means he is intent on that jhāna as the most important thing. “He is intent on visible forms” and the rest are said with reference to the five cords of sense desire. “He is intent on his clan” and the rest are said with reference to the clans of nobles, brahmans, merchants, and workers. “He is intent on gain” and the rest are said with reference to the eight worldly ideas. “He is intent on his wisdom” and the rest are said with reference to the four kinds of condition. “He is intent on the discourses” and the rest are said with reference to the three Piṭakas.

original: paṭilābhavasena vuttāni.
analyzed: paṭilābha vasena vuttāni
translated: “He is intent on the forest-dweller’s practice” and the rest are said with reference to the undertaking of the ascetic practices. “He is intent on the first jhāna” and the rest are said with reference to acquisition.

original: Kammaparāyaṇanti abhisaṅkhāravasena. Vipākaparāyaṇanti pavattivasena. Kammagarukanti cetanāgarukaṃ. Paṭisandhigarukanti upapattigarukaṃ.
analyzed: kamma parāyaṇanti abhisaṅkhāra vasena vipāka parāyaṇanti pavatti vasena kamma garukanti cetanā garukanti paṭisandhi garukanti upapatti garukanti
translated: “He is intent on kamma” means he is intent on it as volition. “He is intent on result” means he is intent on it as occurrence. “He is intent on kamma” means he is intent on it as the respect due to kamma. “He is intent on rebirth” means he is intent on it as the respect due to rebirth.

original: 84. Ākiñcaññāsambhavaṃ ñatvāti ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpattito vuṭṭhahitvā ākiñcaññāyatanajanakakammābhisaṅkhāraṃ
analyzed: ākiñcaññā sambhavam ñatvā ti ākiñcaññāyatana samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhahitvā ākiñcaññāyatana janaka kamma abhisaṅkhāram
translated: having emerged from the attainment of the base of nothingness, he knows the formation of the kamma that generates the base of nothingness.

original: ñatvā “kinti palibodho aya”nti. Nandisaṃyojanaṃ itīti yā catutthaarūparāgasaṅkhātā🔽nandī tañca saṃyojanaṃ ñatvā. Tato tattha vipassatīti atha tattha ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpattito🔽vuṭṭhahitvā taṃ samāpattiṃ aniccādivasena vipassati. Etaṃ ñāṇaṃ tathaṃ tassāti etaṃ🔽tassa puggalassa evaṃ vipassato anukkamena uppannaṃ arahattañāṇaṃ aviparītaṃ. Vusīmatoti
analyzed: ñatvā kinti nandi saṃyojanam iti iti yā catuttha arūpa rāga saṅkhātā  nandī tat ca saṃyojanam ñatvā tatas tattha vipassati iti atha tattha ākiñcaññāyatana samāpattito  vuṭṭhahitvā tam samāpattim anicca ādi vasena vipassati etam ñāṇam tatham tassa ati etam  tassa puggalassa evam vipassataḥ anukkamena uppannam arahatta ñāṇam aviparītam
translated: “What is the hindrance here?” He knows the delight called the fourth immaterial-sphere attachment🔽and the fetter. “Having known that, he sees there with insight”: then, having emerged from the attainment of the base of nothingness, he sees that attainment with insight as impermanent, etc. This knowledge of his is right

original: vusitavantassa. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva.🔽Evaṃ bhagavā idampi suttaṃ arahattanikūṭeneva desesi, desanāpariyosāne ca pubbasadiso eva dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: vusitavantassa sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva  evam bhagavā idam pi suttam arahatta nikūṭena iva desesi desanā pariyosāne ca pubba sadisaḥ eva dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: in that case: this knowledge of arahantship that arises in that person in this way by insight is unmistaken. “The one who is accomplished”: the one who has accomplished the accomplishment. The rest is clear in all its parts.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya
translated: Thus the Blessed One taught this sutta too by way of the peak of arahantship. And at the conclusion of the teaching, there was the same kind of penetration of the Dhamma by the venerable Nandaka as there was by the venerable Saṅgāmaji.

original: Posālamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: posāla māṇava sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Commentary to the Description of the Posāla Sutta finished.

original: 15. Mogharājamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽85. Pannarasame mogharājasutte – dvāhanti dve vāre ahaṃ. So hi pubbe ajitasuttassa🔽ca tissametteyyasuttassa ca avasāne dvikkhattuṃ bhagavantaṃ pucchi, bhagavā panassa
analyzed: pannarasame mogharājasutte dvāhanti dve vāre aham saḥ hi pubbe ajita suttassa  ca tissametteyya suttassa ca avasāne dvi kkhattum bhagavantam pucchi bhagavā pana ssa
translated: Commentary to the Description of the Mogharāja Sutta🔽In the fifteenth sutta, the Mogharāja Sutta, — twice: I asked Sakka twice. For he asked the Blessed One twice at the end of the Ajita Sutta and the Tissa Metteyya Sutta. But the Blessed One did not answer him, waiting for his faculties to mature. So he said, “I will ask Sakka.”

original: indriyaparipākaṃ āgamayamāno na byākāsi. Tenāha – “dvāhaṃ sakkaṃ apucchissa”nti.🔽Yāvatatiyañca devīsi, byākarotīti me sutanti yāvatatiyañca sahadhammikaṃ puṭṭho visuddhidevabhūto
analyzed: indriya paripākam āgamayamānaḥ na tena āha dvā aham sakkam apucchissanti  yāvatatiyam ca byākaroti iti me sutanti yāvatatiyam ca sahadhammikam puṭṭhaḥ visuddhideva bhūto
translated: And a third time, too, the Blessed One, when asked a proper question,

original: isi bhagavā sammāsambuddho byākarotīti evaṃ me sutaṃ. Godhāvarītīreyeva kira so evamassosi.🔽Tenāha – “byākarotīti me suta”nti. Imissā gāthāya niddese yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ
analyzed: isi bhagavā sammāsambuddhaḥ byākaroti iti evam me sutam godhāvarī tīre iva kira saḥ evam assosi  tena āha byākaroti iti me sutam ti imissā gāthāya niddese yat vattabbam siyā tat
translated: answered, I have heard. For a third time, too, the Blessed One, when asked a proper question, the Blessed One, the Perfect Sambuddha, the pure seer, answered, I have heard. He heard it, it seems, on the bank of the Godhāvarī River.

original: heṭṭhā vuttanayaṃ eva.
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: So he said, “I have heard the Blessed One answer.” In the description of this verse what is to be said has already been said below.

original: 86. Ayaṃ lokoti manussaloko. Paro lokoti taṃ ṭhapetvā avaseso. Sadevakoti brahmalokaṃ🔽ṭhapetvā avaseso upapattidevasammutidevayutto. “Brahmaloko sadevako”ti etaṃ vā “sadevako
analyzed: ayam loko ti manussa loko paraḥ loko ti tam ṭhapetvā avaseso sa devako ti brahma lokam  ṭhapetvā avasesaḥ upapatti deva sammuti deva yutto brahma loko etam vā sa devakaḥ
translated: ‘This world’ is the human world. ‘The other world’ is the rest of the worlds. ‘With its gods’ is the rest of the worlds except the Brahmā-world. ‘With its Brahmās’ is the rest of the worlds except the Brahmā-world.

original: loko”tiādinayanidassanamattaṃ. Tena sabbopi tathāvuttappakāraloko veditabbo.
analyzed: loka iti ādi naya nidassana mattam tena sabbaḥ api tathāvutta ppakāra lokaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: This world: the world of human beings. The other world: the rest, leaving aside the world of human beings. Together with gods: together with the gods of rebirth and the gods of divine approval, leaving aside the Brahma-world. Or else, “the Brahma-world together with gods” is a mere illustration by way of the phrase “the world together with gods.” Therefore all the world of the kind already stated should be understood.

original: 87. Evaṃ abhikkantadassāvinti evaṃ aggadassāviṃ, sadevakassa lokassa ajjhāsayādhimuttigatiparāyaṇādīni passituṃ samatthanti dasseti.🔽88. Suññato lokaṃ avekkhassūti avasiyapavattasallakkhaṇavasena vā tucchasaṅkhārasamanupassanāvasena
analyzed: evam abhikkanta dassāvin ti evam agga dassāvim sa devakassa lokassa ajjhāsaya adhimutti gati parāyaṇa ādīni passitum samatthanti dasseti  suññatas lokam avekkhassu iti avasiya pavatta sat lakkhaṇa vasena vā tuccha saṅkhāra samanupassanā vasena
translated: Thus, he who has seen the heights: he who has seen the highest, he who is able to see the inclinations, the proclivities, the tendencies, etc., of the world together with gods, is what is meant.

original: vāti dvīhākārehi suññato lokaṃ passa. Attānudiṭṭhiṃ ūhaccāti sakkāyadiṭṭhiṃ uddharitvā.
analyzed: vāti dvīhākārehi suññatas lokam passa attā anudiṭṭhim ūhati ca ati sakkāya diṭṭhim uddharitvā
translated: Look upon the world as void: look upon the world as void in two ways, by way of the discerning of the non-occurrence of the self and by way of the contemplation of the void formations.🔽Cross over the doubt that is in yourself: lift up the view of self in the five aggregates of clinging.

original: Lujjatīti bhijjati. Cakkhatīti cakkhu. Tadetaṃ sasambhāracakkhuno setamaṇḍalaparikkhittassa
analyzed: lujjati iti bhijjati cakkhati iti cakkhu tat etam sa sambhāra cakkhunaḥ seta maṇḍala parikkhittassa
translated: It breaks up: it is destroyed. Eye: the eye together with its accessories, surrounded by the white of the eye,

original: kaṇhamaṇḍalassa majjhe abhimukhe ṭhitānaṃ sarīrasaṇṭhānuppattidesabhūte diṭṭhamaṇḍale
analyzed: kaṇha maṇḍalassa majjhe abhimukhe ṭhitānam sarīra saṇṭhāna uppatti desa bhūte diṭṭha maṇḍale
translated: The visible-data base is the visible-data dimension that is the place of appearance of the shape of the body as it is to those who stand facing the middle of the dark circle.

original: cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ yathārahaṃ vatthudvārabhāvaṃ sādhayamānaṃ tiṭṭhati. Rūpayantīti
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam yathāraham vatthu dvāra bhāvam sādhayamānam tiṭṭhati rūpayanti iti
translated: It is present establishing the eye-consciousness, etc., in the function of physical basis and door respectively as appropriate. It is called visible data because it is visible,

original: rūpā, vaṇṇavikāramāpajjantā hadayaṅgatabhāvaṃ pakāsentīti attho. Cakkhuto pavattaṃ
analyzed: rūpāḥ vaṇṇa vikāram āpajjantāḥ hadayaṅgata bhāvam pakāsenti iti attho cakkhutaḥ pavattam
translated: because it assumes the appearance of colour, because it manifests the state of being in the heart.

original: viññāṇaṃ, cakkhussa vā cakkhusannissitaṃ vā viññāṇaṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Cakkhuto pavatto
analyzed: viññāṇam cakkhussa vā cakkhu sannissitam vā viññāṇam cakkhu viññāṇam cakkhutaḥ pavatto
translated: The consciousness that occurs from the eye, or the consciousness that is dependent on the eye, is eye-consciousness.

original: samphasso cakkhusamphasso. Cakkhusamphassapaccayāti cakkhuviññāṇasampayuttaphassapaccayā.🔽Vedayitanti vindanaṃ, vedanāti attho. Tadeva sukhayatīti sukhaṃ, yassa uppajjati,
analyzed: samphassaḥ cakkhu samphassaḥ cakkhu samphassa paccayā ti cakkhu viññāṇa sampayutta phassa paccayā  vedayitam ti vindanam vedanā ati attho tat eva sukhayati iti sukham yassa uppajjati
translated: The contact that occurs from the eye is eye-contact. With the condition of eye-contact as condition: with the condition of the contact associated with eye-consciousness as condition.

original: taṃ sukhitaṃ karotīti attho. Suṭṭhu vā khādati, khanati ca kāyacittābādhanti sukhaṃ.
analyzed: tam sukhitam karoti iti attho suṭṭhu vā khādati khanati ca kāya cittā ābādhanti sukham
translated: It is felt, thus it is feeling . The meaning is: it is experienced. It makes happy, thus it is pleasure . The meaning is: it makes that in which it arises happy. Or: it eats well, it digs into the body and mind, thus it is pleasure .

original: Dukkhayatīti dukkhaṃ. Yassa uppajjati, taṃ dukkhitaṃ karotīti attho. Na dukkhaṃ na
analyzed: dukkhayati iti dukkham yassa uppajjati tam dukkhitam karoti iti atthaḥ na dukkham na
translated: It makes unhappy, thus it is pain . The meaning is: it makes that in which it arises unhappy. It is neither pain nor

original: sukhanti adukkhamasukhaṃ. Ma-kāro sandhipadavasena vutto. So pana cakkhusamphasse🔽attanā sampayuttāya vedanāya sahajātaaññamaññanissayavipākaāhārasampayuttaatthiavigatavasena
analyzed: sukham ti adukkham asukham makāraḥ sandhi pada vasena vutto so pana cakkhu samphasse  attanā sampayuttāya vedanāya sahajāta aññamañña nissaya vipāka āhāra sampayutta atthi avigata vasena
translated: Pleasant means neither-painful-nor-pleasant. The letter Ma is stated as a connecting word. But that is in the case of the feeling associated with itself in eye-contact, by conascence, by con-joint-arising, by support, by kamma-result, by nutriment, by association, by presence, and by non-disappearance.

original: aṭṭhadhā paccayo hoti, sampaṭicchanasampayuttāya anantarasamanantarūpanissayanatthivigatavasena
analyzed: aṭṭhadhā paccayaḥ hoti sampaṭicchana sampayuttāya anantara samananta rūpa nissaya natthi vigata vasena
translated: and happiness is neither-painful-nor-pleasant. The letter Ma is stated as a compound word. But that is a condition in eight ways, as conascence, mutuality, support, result, nutriment, association, presence, and non-disappearance, for the feeling that is associated with itself in eye-contact.

original: pañcadhā, santīraṇādisampayuttānaṃ upanissayavaseneva paccayo hoti.🔽Suṇātīti sotaṃ, taṃ sasambhārasotabilassa anto tanutambalomācite aṅgulivedhakasaṇṭhāne🔽padese sotaviññāṇādīnaṃ yathārahaṃ vatthudvārabhāvaṃ sādhayamānaṃ tiṭṭhati. Saddīyantīti
analyzed: pañcadhā santīraṇa ādi sampayuttānam upanissaya vasena iva paccayaḥ hoti  suṇāti iti sotam tam sa sambhāra sota bilassa antar tanu tamba loma ācite aṅgulivedhaka saṇṭhāne  padese sota viññāṇa ādīnam yathāraham vatthu dvāra bhāvam sādhayamānam tiṭṭhati saddīyanti iti
translated: It is a condition in five ways, as proximity, contiguity, absence, disappearance, and support, for the receiving that is associated with itself. It is a condition in one way, as support, for the investigating, etc., that are associated with itself.🔽The ear is that which hears. It is situated in the place inside the ear-drum, which is in the region of the ear-hole, and which is covered with fine hairs. It is the physical basis and door for the ear-consciousness, etc., as appropriate.

original: saddā, udāharīyantīti attho. Ghāyatīti ghānaṃ, taṃ sasambhāraghānabilassa anto ajapadasaṇṭhāne
analyzed: saddāḥ udāharīyanti iti atthaḥ ghāyati iti ghānam tam sa sambhāra ghāna bilassa antaḥ aja pada saṇṭhāne
translated: Sounds are that which is sounded. The meaning is that they are uttered. The nose is that which smells. It is situated in the place inside the nostril, which is in the region of the nose, and which has the shape of the leaf of the ajapāla plant.

original: padese ghānaviññāṇādīnaṃ yathārahaṃ vatthudvārabhāvaṃ sādhayamānaṃ tiṭṭhati. Gandhiyantīti
analyzed: padese ghāna viññāṇa ādīnam yathāraham vatthu dvāra bhāvam sādhayamānam tiṭṭhati gandhiyanti iti
translated: It is in the place where the nose-consciousness, etc., are respectively located as the physical basis and the door.

original: gandhā, attano vatthuṃ sūciyantīti attho. Jīvitaṃ avhāyatīti jivhā, sāyanaṭṭhena🔽vā jivhā. Sā sasambhārajivhāya atiaggamūlapassāni vajjetvā uparimatalamajjhe bhinnauppaladalaggasaṇṭhāne
analyzed: gandhāḥ attanaḥ vatthum sūciyanti iti atthaḥ jīvitam avhāyati iti jivhā sa ayanaṭṭhena  vā jivhā sā sa sambhāra jivhāya ati agga mūla passāni vajjetvā uparima tala majjhe bhinna oppala da lagga saṇṭhāne
translated: Smelling is the meaning. The tongue is so called because it is what conveys the life faculty.

original: padese jivhāviññāṇādīnaṃ yathārahaṃ vatthudvārabhāvaṃ sādhayamānā tiṭṭhati. Rasanti
analyzed: padese jivhā viññāṇa ādīnam yathāraham vatthu dvāra bhāvam sādhayamānā tiṭṭhati rasanti
translated: Or the tongue is so called because it is what is stretched out. It is in the place where the tongue-consciousness, etc., are respectively located as the physical basis and the door.

original: te sattāti rasā, assādentīti attho.🔽Kucchitānaṃ āsavadhammānaṃ āyoti kāyo. Āyoti uppattideso. So yāvatā imasmiṃ kāye🔽upādinnapavatti nāma atthi, tattha yebhuyyena kāyappasādo kāyaviññāṇādīnaṃ yathārahaṃ
analyzed: te sattā ati rasāḥ assādenti iti attho  kucchitānam āsava dhammānam āyo ti kāyaḥ āyo ti uppatti deso saḥ yāvatā imasmin kāye  upādinnapavatti nāma atthi tattha yebhuyyena kāya ppasādo kāya viññāṇa ādīnam yathāraham
translated: Flavours are so called because they are what is savoured.🔽The body is so called because it is the arrival place of the foul and contaminated dhammas.🔽The body is the place of origin of the body-consciousness, etc. It is in the place where the body-consciousness, etc., are respectively located as the physical basis and the door.

original: vatthudvārabhāvaṃ sādhayamāno tiṭṭhati. Phusiyantīti phoṭṭhabbā. Manatīti mano, vijānātīti
analyzed: vatthu dvāra bhāvam sādhayamānaḥ tiṭṭhati phusiyanti iti phoṭṭhabbāḥ manati iti manaḥ vijānāti iti
translated: Touching is the meaning. The mind is so called because it is what thinks. It is what cognizes.

original: attho. Attano lakkhaṇaṃ dhārentīti dhammā. Manoti sahāvajjanabhavaṅgaṃ. Dhammāti
analyzed: atthaḥ attanaḥ lakkhaṇam dhārenti iti dhammā manaḥ uti sahāvajjana bhavaṅgam dhammā ati
translated: “Meaning” is the meaning of the word. “Ideas” are what bear their own characteristics. “Mind” is the mind with its associated states and its life-continuum. “Ideas” are the ideas of the three planes.

original: nibbānaṃ muñcitvā avasesā dhammārammaṇadhammā. Manoviññāṇanti javanamanoviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: nibbānam muñcitvā avasesāḥ dhamma ārammaṇa dhammāḥ manaḥ viññāṇanti javana manaḥ viññāṇam
translated: “Dhamma” is what bears its own intrinsic nature. “Mind” is the mind- element together with the associated states. “Dhamma” is the remaining dhammas with the exception of Nibbāna. “Mind-consciousness” is the impulsion mind-consciousness element.

original: Manosamphassoti taṃsampayutto phasso, so sampayuttāya vedanāya vipākapaccayavajjehi
analyzed: manaḥ samphassaḥ ti tad sampayutto phasso so sampayuttāya vedanāya vipāka paccaya vajjehi
translated: “Mind-contact” is the contact associated with that . That is a condition for the feeling associated with it by way of the result condition,

original: sesehi sattahi paccayehi paccayo hoti. Anantarāya teheva sesānaṃ upanissayeneva paccayo hoti.
analyzed: sesehi sattahi paccayehi paccayaḥ hoti anantarāya tehi iva sesānam upanissayena iva paccayaḥ hoti
translated: and for the remaining by way of the remaining seven conditions. It is a condition for the remaining by way of the decisive support condition only.

original: Avasiyapavattasallakkhaṇavasena vāti avaso hutvā pavattasaṅkhāre passanavasena olokanavasenāti🔽attho. Rūpe vaso na labbhatīti rūpasmiṃ vasavattibhāvo issarabhāvo na labbhati. Vedanādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: avasiya pavatta sat lakkhaṇa vasena vā ati avasas hutvā pavatta saṅkhāre passana vasena olokana vasena ati  atthaḥ rūpe vasaḥ na labbhati iti rūpasmim vasa vatti bhāvaḥ issara bhāvaḥ na labbhati vedanā ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: “By way of the observation of the characteristic of the occurrence of the dependent origination”: by way of the observation of the occurrence of the dependent origination after having made it one’s own.🔽“There is no mastery over form”: there is no mastery, no sovereignty, over form. The same method applies to feeling, etc.

original: Nāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kāyo tumhākanti attani sati attaniyaṃ nāma hoti, attāyeva ca natthi.
analyzed: na ayam bhikkhave kāyaḥ tumhākan ti attani sati attaniyam nāma hoti attāya iva ca natthi
translated: “This body, bhikkhus, is not yours, nor is it that of others. It is old kamma, it is to be felt here and now” . When there is a self, there would be what belongs to the self.

original: Tasmā “nāyaṃ, bhikkhave, kāyo tumhāka”nti āha. Nāpi aññesanti añño nāma paresaṃ attā.
analyzed: tasmā na ayam bhikkhave kāyaḥ tumhākan ti āha na api aññesan ti aññaḥ nāma paresam attā
translated: So he said, “This body is not yours, bhikkhus.”🔽Nor is it anyone else’s: there is no other self of anyone else.

original: Tasmiṃ sati aññesaṃ nāma siyā, sopi natthi. Tasmā “nāpi aññesa”nti āha. Purāṇamidaṃ,
analyzed: tasmin sati aññesam nāma siyā saḥ upi natthi tasmā na api aññesan ti āha purāṇam idam
translated: If there were, it might be someone else’s, but it is not. So he said, “Nor is it anyone else’s.”

original: bhikkhave, kammanti nayidaṃ purāṇakammameva, purāṇakammanibbatto panesa kāyo. Tasmā
analyzed: bhikkhave kammanti na yidam purāṇa kammam eva purāṇa kamma nibbattaḥ pana esa kāyaḥ tasmā
translated: This body is a product of former kamma: it is not only former kamma, but it is produced by former kamma.🔽So it is called in terms of the mode of expression appropriate to conditions.

original: paccayavohārena evaṃ vutto. Abhisaṅkhatantiādi kammavohārasseva vasena purimaliṅgasabhāvatāya🔽vuttaṃ. Ayaṃ panettha attho – abhisaṅkhatanti paccayehi katoti daṭṭhabbo. Abhisañcetayitanti
analyzed: paccaya vohārena evam vuttaḥ kamma vohārassa iva vasena purima liṅga sabhāva tāya  vuttam ayam pana ittha atthaḥ paccayehi kato ti daṭṭhabbaḥ abhisañcetayitanti
translated: It is willed, etc., is said in terms of the mode of expression appropriate to kamma.

original: cetanāvatthuko, cetanāmūlakoti daṭṭhabbo. Vedaniyanti vedanāya vatthūti daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: cetanā vatthuko cetanā mūlako ti daṭṭhabbo vedaniyanti vedanāya vatthū ti daṭṭhabbo
translated: The meaning here is this. It is willed, i.e., it should be regarded as made by conditions. It is resolved, i.e., it should be regarded as the basis for volition, as having volition as its root. It is to be felt, i.e., it should be regarded as the basis for feeling.

original: Rūpe sāro na labbhatīti rūpasmiṃ niccādisāro na labbhati. Vedanādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: rūpe sāraḥ na labbhati iti rūpasmim nicca ādi sāraḥ na labbhati vedanā ādīsu pi esa iva nayo
translated: No core is found in form: no core of permanence, etc., is found in form. The same method applies to feeling, and so on.

original: Rūpaṃ assāraṃ nissāranti rūpaṃ assāraṃ sāravirahitañca. Sārāpagatanti sārato apagataṃ.
analyzed: rūpam assāram nissāranti rūpam assāram sāra virahitam ca sāra apagatanti sārataḥ apagatam
translated: Form is without core, and it is in dependence on form that the core-less is sought: form is without core, and it is in dependence on form that the core-less is sought. It is devoid of core: it is devoid of a core of permanence, etc.

original: Niccasārasārena vāti bhaṅgaṃ atikkamitvā pavattamānena niccasārena vā. Kassaci niccasārassa🔽abhāvato niccasārena sāro natthi. Sukhasārasārena vāti ṭhitisukhaṃ atikkamitvā pavattamānassa🔽kassaci sukhasārassa abhāvato sukhasārasārena vā. Attasārasārena vāti attattaniyasārasārena🔽vā. Niccena vāti bhaṅgaṃ atikkamitvā pavattamānassa kassaci niccassa abhāvato niccena
analyzed: nicca sāra sārena vā ati bhaṅgam atikkamitvā pavattamānena nicca sārena vā kassaci nicca sārassa  abhāvataḥ nicca sārena sāraḥ natthi sukha sāra sārena vāti ṭhiti sukham atikkamitvā pavattamānassa  kassaci sukha sārassa abhāvataḥ sukha sāra sārena vā atta sāra sārena vā ati atta tta niya sāra sārena  vā niccena vā ati bhaṅgam atikkamitvā pavattamānassa kassaci niccassa abhāvataḥ niccena
translated: Or ‘with the essence of permanence’ means with the permanence that occurs transcending dissolution. In some it is because there is no essence of permanence. Or ‘with the essence of pleasure’ means with the pleasure that occurs transcending the pleasure of continued existence. In some it is because there is no essence of pleasure. Or ‘with the essence of self’ means with the essence of self as a self-master. Or ‘with the permanent’ means with the permanent in some that does not exist because there is no permanent.

original: vā. Dhuvena vāti vijjamānakālepi paccayāyattavuttitāya thirassa kassaci abhāvato🔽dhuvena vā. Sassatena vāti abbocchinnassa sabbakāle vijjamānassa kassaci abhāvato🔽sassatena vā. Avipariṇāmadhammena vāti jarābhaṅgavasena avipariṇāmapakatikassa kassaci🔽abhāvato avipariṇāmadhammena vā.
analyzed: vā dhuvena vāti vijjamāna kāle pi paccaya āyatta vutti tāya thirassa kassaci abhāvato 🔽dhuvena vā sassatena vā ati abbocchinnassa sabba kāle vijjamānassa kassaci abhāvato 🔽vā a vipariṇāma dhammena vā ati jarā bhaṅga vasena a vipariṇāma pakatikassa kassaci 🔽abhāvataḥ a vipariṇāma dhammena vā
translated: Or ‘with the essence of permanence’ means with the permanence that occurs transcending dissolution. Or ‘with the essence of permanence’ means with the essence of permanence in the sense that some permanent thing has no essence of permanence. Or ‘with the essence of pleasure’ means with the pleasure that occurs transcending the pleasure of continuance. Or ‘with the essence of pleasure’ means with the essence of pleasure in the sense that some pleasant thing has no essence of pleasure. Or ‘with the essence of self’ means with the essence of self that is the self’s own essence. Or ‘with the essence of self’ means with the essence of self in the sense that some self has no essence of self. Or ‘permanently’ means permanently in the sense that some permanent thing has no permanence. Or ‘permanently’ means permanently in the sense that some permanent thing has no permanence. Or ‘enduringly’ means enduringly in the sense that some enduring thing has no endurance. Or ‘enduringly’ means enduringly in the sense that some enduring thing has no endurance. Or ‘eternally’ means eternally in the sense that some eternal thing has no eternity. Or ‘eternally’ means eternally in the sense that some eternal thing has no eternity. Or ‘with an essence that is not subject to change’ means with an essence that is not subject to change in the sense that some thing that is not subject to change has no essence that is not subject to change. Or ‘with an essence that is not subject to change’ means with an essence that is not subject to change in the sense that some thing that is not subject to change has no essence that is not subject to change.

original: Cakkhu suññaṃ attena vā attaniyena vāti “kārako vedako sayaṃvasī”ti evaṃ parikappikena
analyzed: cakkhu suññam attena vā attaniyena vā ati kārakaḥ vedakaḥ sayaṃvasī iti evam parikappikena
translated: The eye is void of self or of the property of a self: it is void of the self that is imagined as follows: “The doer is the same as the experiencer, the self is the owner, the controller, the one who has power to dispose of itself.”

original: attanā vā attābhāvatoyeva attano santakena parikkhārena ca suññaṃ. Sabbaṃ cakkhādilokiyadhammajātaṃ
analyzed: attanā vā attā bhāvato yā iva attano santakena parikkhārena ca suññam sabbam cakkha ādi lokiya dhamma jātam
translated: Or it is void of a self that is its own, in the sense that it does not exist as such. All states beginning with the eye are void🔽because there is no self in them and no property of a self.

original: yasmā attā ca ettha natthi, attaniyañca ettha natthi, tasmā “suñña”nti vuccatīti
analyzed: yasmā attā ca ettha natthi attaniyañca ettha natthi tasmā suññanti vuccati iti
translated: The meaning is: they are called “void” .

original: attho. Lokuttarāpi dhammā attattaniyehi suññāyeva, suññātītadhammā natthīti vuttaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ lokuttarā api dhammā attattaniyehi suññāya iva suññā atīta dhammā natthi iti vuttam
translated: Supramundane states are also void of self and the property of a self. The words “void of what is not” mean that there is no non-existence of states.🔽The non-existence of a self and the property of a self in those states is stated.

original: hoti. Tasmiṃ dhamme attattaniyasārassa natthibhāvo vutto hoti. Loke ca “suññaṃ gharaṃ🔽suñño ghaṭo”ti vutto gharassa ghaṭassa ca natthibhāvo na hoti, tasmiṃ ghaṭe ca aññassa
analyzed: hoti tasmin dhamme atta tta niya sārassa natthi bhāvo vuttaḥ hoti loke ca suññam gharam  suññaḥ ghaṭaḥ ti vuttaḥ gharassa ghaṭassa ca natthi bhāvaḥ na hoti tasmin ghaṭe ca aññassa
translated: In the world, when it is said “The house is void” or “The pot is void,”🔽the non-existence of the house or the pot is not meant. The non-existence of something else in the house or the pot is meant.

original: natthibhāvo vutto hoti. Bhagavatā ca iti yampi koci tattha na hoti, tena taṃ suññaṃ.
analyzed: natthibhāvaḥ vuttaḥ hoti bhagavatā ca iti yam pi koci tattha na hoti tena tam suññam
translated: And the Exalted One has said: “Herein, what is void? Whatever is not found there, that is what is void there.

original: Yaṃ pana tattha avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti, taṃ santaṃ idamatthīti pajānātīti ayamevattho vutto.
analyzed: yam pana tattha avasiṭṭham hoti tam santam idam atthi iti pajānāti iti ayam eva atthaḥ vutto
translated: But what remains there, that is what is present there, that is what exists there” .

original: Tathā ñāyaganthe saddaganthe ca ayamevattho. Iti imasmiṃ sutte anattalakkhaṇameva🔽kathitaṃ. Anissariyatoti attano issariye avasavattanato. Akāmakāriyatoti attano akāmaṃ
analyzed: tathā ñāya ganthe sadda ganthe ca ayam eva atthaḥ iti imasmim sutte anatta lakkhaṇam eva  kathitam a nissariyato ti attanaḥ issariye a vasavattanataḥ a kāma kāriyato ti attanaḥ a kāmam
translated: So in this sutta only the characteristic of not-self is stated.🔽Not-self-owned: not self-owned in the sense of self-mastery.🔽Not self-willed: not self-willed in the sense of doing what is not desired.

original: arucikaraṇavasena. Apāpuṇiyatoti ṭhātuṃ patiṭṭhābhāvato. Avasavattanatoti attano
analyzed: aruci karaṇa vasena ṭhātum patiṭṭhā bhāvato
translated: Not self-controlled: not self-controlled in the sense of being a support.🔽Other: impermanent, existing in dependence on conditions.

original: vase avattanato. Paratoti aniccato paccayāyattavuttito. Vivittatoti nissarato.
analyzed: vase avattanato parato ti aniccato paccaya āyatta vuttitaḥ vivittato ti nissarato
translated: Isolated: detached.

original: Suddhanti kevalaṃ issarakālapakatīhi vinā kevalaṃ paccayāyattapavattivasena pavattamānaṃ
analyzed: suddhanti kevalam issara kālapakatīhi vinā kevalam paccaya āyatta pavatti vasena pavattamānam
translated: Pure: pure in the sense of existing only in dependence on conditions, without the presence of the creator and the like.

original: suddhaṃ nāma. Attaniyavirahito suddhadhammapuñjoti ca. Suddhaṃ dhammasamuppādaṃ,
analyzed: suddham nāma attaniya virahitaḥ suddha dhamma puñjo ti ca suddham dhamma samuppādam
translated: It is called pure because it is a pure mass of states devoid of a self.🔽Pure is the arising of states,

original: suddhaṃ saṅkhārasantatinti suddhaṃ passantassa jānantassa saṅkhārānaṃ santatiṃ abbocchinnasaṅkhārasantatiṃ.
analyzed: suddham saṅkhāra santatim ti suddham passantassa jānantassa saṅkhārānam santatim abbocchinna saṅkhāra santatim
translated: pure is the continuity of formations: pure is the continuity of formations that is unbroken.🔽So too, pure is the seeing of formations, etc.,

original: Tatheva suddhaṃ passantassa saṅkhārādīni, ekaṭṭhāni ādarena dvattikkhattuṃ vuttāni.
analyzed: tathā iva suddham passantassa saṅkhāra ādīni ekaṭṭhāni ādarena dvatti khattum vuttāni
translated: which are stated with emphasis twenty-two times.

original: Evaṃ passantassa maraṇamukhe bhayaṃ na hoti. Gāmaṇīti ālapanaṃ. Tiṇakaṭṭhasamaṃ lokanti
analyzed: evam passantassa maraṇa mukhe bhayam na hoti ālapanam tiṇa kaṭṭha samam
translated: When he sees thus, he has no fear at the moment of death. ‘Herdsman’ is an address. ‘The world is like grass and sticks’:

original: imaṃ upādinnakkhandhasaṅkhātaṃ lokaṃ. Yadā tiṇakaṭṭhasamaṃ paññāya passati. Yathā🔽araññe tiṇakaṭṭhādīsu gaṇhantesu attānaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā gaṇhātīti na hoti, tesu
analyzed: imam upādinna kkhandha saṅkhātam lokam yadā tiṇa kaṭṭha samam paññāya passati yathā  araññe tiṇa kaṭṭha ādīsu gaṇhantesu attānam vā attaniyam vā gaṇhāti iti na hoti tesu
translated: this world consisting of the five aggregates that have been assumed. When he sees it with understanding as being like grass and sticks,🔽just as when grass and sticks, etc., are being carried off in the forest, he does not think ‘They are carrying me off’ or ‘They are carrying what belongs to me,’

original: vā tiṇakaṭṭhādīsu sayameva nassantesupi vinassantesupi attā nassati, attaniyo nassatīti
analyzed: vā tiṇa kaṭṭha ādīsu sayam eva nassantesu pi vinassantesu attā nassati atta niyaḥ nassati iti
translated: or when they are being destroyed or burnt, he does not think ‘I am being destroyed’ or ‘What belongs to me is being destroyed,’

original: na hoti. Evaṃ imasmiṃ kāyepi nassante vā vinassante vā attā vā attaniyaṃ vā bhijjatīti
analyzed: na hoti evam imasmin kāye pi nassante vā vinassante vā attā vā attaniyam vā bhijjati iti
translated: so too, when this body is being destroyed or burnt, he does not see that ‘I am being destroyed’ or ‘What belongs to me is being destroyed.’

original: apassanto paññāya tiṇakaṭṭhasamaṃ passatīti vuccati. Nāññaṃ patthayate kiñci, aññatrappaṭisandhiyāti
analyzed: a passantaḥ paññāya tiṇa kaṭṭha samam passati iti vuccati na aññam patthayate kiñci aññatra paṭisandhiyā ti
translated: He is said to see with understanding as being like grass and sticks. ‘He does not wish for anything else’:

original: paṭisandhivirahitaṃ nibbānaṃ ṭhapetvā aññaṃ bhavaṃ vā attabhāvaṃ vā na pattheti.
analyzed: paṭisandhi virahitam nibbānam ṭhapetvā aññam bhavam vā atta bhāvam vā na pattheti
translated: except for Nibbāna, which is free from rebirth-linking, he does not wish for any other kind of becoming or any other kind of individual existence.

original: Rūpaṃ samannesatīti rūpassa sāraṃ pariyesati. Ahanti vāti diṭṭhivasena. Mamanti vāti
analyzed: rūpam samannesati iti rūpassa sāram pariyesati ahanti vā ati diṭṭhi vasena mamanti vā ati
translated: ‘He examines form’: he seeks the essence in form. ‘As “I” or “mine”’: as a view.

original: taṇhāvasena. Asmīti vāti mānavasena. Tampi tassa na hotīti taṃ tividhampi tassa puggalassa na hoti.
analyzed: taṇhā vasena asmi iti vāti māna vasena tam pi tassa na hoti iti tam tividham pi tassa puggalassa na hoti
translated: by way of craving. Asmīti vāti mānavasena. Tampi tassa na hotīti taṃ tividhampi tassa puggalassa na hoti.

original: Idhāti desāpadese nipāto, svāyaṃ katthaci lokaṃ upādāya vuccati. Yathāha – “idha
analyzed: idha ati desa apadese nipātaḥ svāyam katthaci lokam upādāya vuccati yathā āha idha
translated: Idhāti desāpadese nipāto, svāyaṃ katthaci lokaṃ upādāya vuccati. Yathāha – “idha

original: tathāgato loke uppajjatī”ti. Katthaci sāsanaṃ. Yathāha – “idheva, bhikkhave, samaṇo,
analyzed: tathāgataḥ loke uppajjati iti katthaci sāsanam yathā āha idha iva bhikkhave samaṇo
translated: tathāgato loke uppajjatī”ti. Katthaci sāsanaṃ. Yathāha – “idheva, bhikkhave, samaṇo,

translated: Herein, “Endowed with this restraint of the Pātimokkha, provided with it” is virtue as restraint. “He guards the eye faculty, enters upon restraint of the eye faculty” is virtue as mindfulness.

translated: I tell you; by wisdom they are stopped” .

translated: This is virtue as knowledge. “He is forbearing of cold and heat” is virtue as patience. “He does not consent to, does not acquiesce in, does not remain acquiescing in arisen thought of sensual desire” is virtue as energy. original: Evaṃ tāva saṃvaravinayo pañcadhā bhijjatīti veditabbo.
