translated: That is to say, the abandoning of personality view by defining of mentality-materiality;🔽of the view of holding to a doctrine of self by discerning conditions;

original: sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā, paccayapariggahena ahetuvisamahetudiṭṭhīnaṃ, tasseva aparabhāgena🔽kaṅkhāvitaraṇena kathaṃkathībhāvassa, kalāpasammasanena “ahaṃ mamā”ti gāhassa, maggāmaggavavatthānena🔽amagge maggasaññāya, udayadassanena ucchedadiṭṭhiyā, vayadassanena sassatadiṭṭhiyā,
analyzed: sakkāya diṭṭhiyā paccaya pariggahena ahetu visama hetu diṭṭhīnam tassa iva apara bhāgena  kaṅkhā vitaraṇena kathaṃkathībhāvassa kalāpa sammasanena aham mama ati gāhassa magga amagga vavatthānena  amagge magga saññāya udaya dassanena uccheda diṭṭhiyā vaya dassanena sassata diṭṭhiyā
translated: of the state of being a theorist by surmounting doubt;🔽of the view of becoming by seeing rise; of the view of annihilation by seeing fall;🔽of the view of fear by seeing danger; of the view of enjoyment by seeing danger;

original: bhayadassanena sabhaye abhayasaññāya, ādīnavadassanena assādasaññāya, nibbidānupassanāya
analyzed: bhaya dassanena sa bhaye abhaya saññāya ādīnava dassanena assāda saññāya nibbida anupassanāya
translated: of the state of being enamoured by contemplation of dispassion;

original: abhiratisaññāya, muñcitukamyatāñāṇena amuñcitukāmatāya, upekkhāñāṇena anupekkhāya,
analyzed: abhirati saññāya muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇena a muñcitu kāma tāya upekkhā ñāṇena an upekkhāya
translated: of the state of not desiring deliverance by knowledge of the desire for deliverance; of the state of not being equanimous by equanimity;

original: anulomena dhammaṭṭhitiyaṃ nibbāne ca paṭilomabhāvassa, gotrabhunā saṅkhāranimittaggāhassa
analyzed: anulomena dhamma ṭṭhitiyam nibbāne ca paṭiloma bhāvassa gotrabhunā saṅkhāra nimitta ggāhassa
translated: of the state of being averse to the persistence of formations in the case of the path and the unformed element by conformity;

original: pahānaṃ. Etaṃ tadaṅgappahānaṃ nāma.
analyzed: pahānam etam tadaṅgappahānam nāma
translated: of the state of grasping the sign of formations by change-of-lineage. This is called abandoning by discerning.

original: Yaṃ pana upacārappanābhedena samādhinā pavattibhāvanivāraṇato ghaṭappahāreneva udakapiṭṭhe
analyzed: yam pana upacāra ppanā bhedena samādhinā pavatti bhāva nivāraṇataḥ ghaṭa ppahārena iva udaka piṭṭhe
translated: But the development of concentration is the prevention of occurrence of defilements by means of concentration classed as access and absorption. It is like the surface of the water being prevented from occurrence by the pot.

original: sevālassa tesaṃ tesaṃ nīvaraṇādidhammānaṃ pahānaṃ, etaṃ vikkhambhanappahānaṃ nāma.🔽Yaṃ catunnaṃ ariyamaggānaṃ bhāvitattā taṃtaṃmaggavato attano attano santāne “diṭṭhigatānaṃ
analyzed: sevālassa tesam tesam nīvaraṇa ādi dhammānam pahānam etam vikkhambhana pahānam nāma  yam catunnam ariya maggānam bhāvita ttā taṃ taṃ maggavataḥ attanaḥ attanaḥ santāne diṭṭhi gatānam
translated: But the abandoning of the various states beginning with the hindrances by preventing their occurrence through development of concentration classed as access and absorption concentration, like the surface of water by a stroke from the pestle, is called “abandoning by suppression.”

original: pahānāyā”tiādinā nayena vuttassa samudayapakkhiyassa kilesagaṇassa accantaappavattibhāvena
analyzed: pahānāya ati ādinā nayena vuttassa samudaya pakkhiyassa kilesa gaṇassa accanta appavatti bhāvena
translated: But the abandoning of the various categories of defilements classed as the origin of the five aggregates by the occurrence of the four noble paths in the individual’s own mental continuity in the way stated thus, “For the abandoning of the kinds of view” , etc., is called “abandoning by cutting off.”

original: pahānaṃ, idaṃ samucchedappahānaṃ nāma. Yaṃ pana phalakkhaṇe paṭippassaddhattaṃ kilesānaṃ,🔽etaṃ paṭippassaddhippahānaṃ nāma. Yaṃ sabbasaṅkhatanissaṭattā pahīnasabbasaṅkhataṃ🔽nibbānaṃ, etaṃ nissaraṇappahānaṃ nāma. Sabbampi cetaṃ pahānaṃ yasmā cāgaṭṭhena pahānaṃ,
analyzed: pahānam idam samuccheda pahānam nāma yam pana phala kkhaṇe paṭippassaddhattam kilesānam  etam paṭippassaddhi ppahānam nāma yam sabba saṅkhata nissaṭa ttā pahīna sabba saṅkhatam  nibbānam etam nissaraṇa ppahānam nāma sabbam pi ca itam pahānam yasmā ca āgaṭṭhena pahānam
translated: And the disappearance of defilements at the moment of fruition is called “abandoning by tranquillization.”🔽And the Nibbāna element, which is the abandoning of all formations because of being free from all that is formed, is called “abandoning by escape.”

original: vinayanaṭṭhena vinayo, tasmā “pahānavinayo”ti vuccati. Taṃ taṃ pahānavato vā tassa
analyzed: vinayana ṭṭhena vinayo tasmā pahāna vinayo ti vuccati tam tam pahānavataḥ vā tassa
translated: And all this abandoning is called “the training in the disciplining of abandoning” because it is abandoning in the sense of relinquishing and because it is the training in the sense of taming.

original: tassa vinayassa sambhavatopetaṃ “pahānavinayo”ti vuccati. Evaṃ pahānavinayopi pañcadhā🔽bhijjatīti veditabbo.
analyzed: tassa vinayassa sambhava tā upetam pahāna vinayo ti vuccati evam pahāna vinayo api pañcadhā  bhijjati iti veditabbaḥ
translated: So the training in abandoning is also of five kinds.

original: Evamayaṃ saṅkhepato duvidho bhedato ca dasavidho vinayo bhinnasaṃvarattā, pahātabbassa
analyzed: evam ayam saṅkhepataḥ duvidhaḥ bhedataḥ ca dasavidhaḥ vinayaḥ bhinna saṃvara ttā pahātabbassa
translated: Thus this training, which is twofold as above and tenfold as to division,🔽is called “untrained” in the sense of non-existence,🔽because it does not exist in a foolish ordinary man who has not learned it,

original: ca appahīnattā yasmā etassa assutavato puthujjanassa natthi, tasmā abhāvato tassa🔽ayaṃ “avinīto”ti vuccatīti. Eseva nayo sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido,🔽sappurisadhamme avinītoti etthapi. Ninnānākaraṇañhi etamatthato. Yathāha – “yeva🔽te ariyā, teva te sappurisā. Yeva te sappurisā, teva te ariyā. Yo eva so ariyānaṃ
analyzed: ca appahīna ttā yasmai etassa a ssutavataḥ puthujjanassa na atthi tasmai abhāvato tassa  ayam avinītaḥ ti vuccati iti esa eva nayo sappurisānam a dassāvī sappurisa dhammassa a kovidaḥ  sappurisa dhamme avinītaḥ ti ettha api ninnānākaraṇam hi etam atthataḥ yathā āha  te ariyā teva te sappurisāḥ yeva te sappurisāḥ teva te ariyāḥ yaḥ eva saḥ
translated: because the abandoning that should be done has not been done by him.🔽So too in the case of “one destitute of perfect confidence in the ariyan Dhamma” and “one destitute of perfect confidence in good men” and “one destitute of the ariyan virtue” and “one destitute of the ariyan virtue of good men” and “one destitute of the ariyan Dhamma of good men.”

original: dhammo, so eva so sappurisānaṃ dhammo. Yo eva so sappurisānaṃ dhammo, so eva so ariyānaṃ
analyzed: dhammo saḥ eva saḥ sappurisānam dhammo yaḥ eva saḥ sappurisānam dhammo saḥ eva so ariyānam
translated: For the difference is only in the phrasing, as the following passage shows: “Those who are ariyans are also good men. Those who are good men are also ariyans. That which is the ariyan Dhamma is also the Dhamma of good men. That which is the Dhamma of good men is also the ariyan Dhamma.

original: dhammo. Yeva te ariyavinayā, teva te sappurisavinayā. Yeva te sappurisavinayā, teva🔽te ariyavinayā. Ariyeti vā, sappuriseti vā, ariyadhammeti vā, sappurisadhammeti vā,
analyzed: dhammo yeva te ariya vinayā teva te sappurisa vinayā yeva te sappurisa vinayā teva  te ariya vinayāḥ ariya iti vā sappurisa iti vā ariya dhamma iti vā sappurisa dhamma iti vā
translated: are the Noble One’s Discipline, are the Good Person’s Discipline.🔽are the Good Person’s Discipline, are the Noble One’s Discipline. Noble One, Good Person, Noble One’s Dhamma, Good Person’s Dhamma,

original: ariyavinayeti vā, sappurisavinayeti vā esese eke ekaṭṭhe same samabhāge tajjāte taññevāti.🔽Rūpaṃ attato samanupassatīti idhekacco rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, “yaṃ rūpaṃ, so🔽ahaṃ, yo ahaṃ, taṃ rūpa”nti rūpañca attānañca advayaṃ samanupassati. Seyyathāpi telappadīpassa
analyzed: ariya vinaye ti vā sappurisa vinaye ti vā esese eke ekaṭṭhe same sama bhāge tad jāte tañca eva ati  rūpam attataḥ samanupassati iti idha ekaccaḥ rūpam attataḥ samanupassati yam rūpam so  aham yaḥ aham tam rūpanti rūpan ca attānam ca advayam samanupassati seyyathā api telappadīpassa
translated: are the Noble Ones’ training, they are the training of the True Men. Those that are the training of the True Men, they are the Noble Ones’ training. Noble Ones, True Men, the Noble Ones’ True Dhamma, the training of the Noble Ones, the training of the True Men, the Noble Ones’ True Training, the training of the True Men, these are the same, they are not two or divided.

original: jhāyato “yā acci, so vaṇṇo. Yo vaṇṇo, sā accī”ti acciñca vaṇṇañca advayaṃ samanupassati,
analyzed: jhāyataḥ yā acci saḥ vaṇṇaḥ yaḥ vaṇṇaḥ sā accī iti acciñca vaṇṇam ca advayam samanupassati
translated: He regards material form as self: here someone regards material form as self, “What is material form, that is my self,” he regards both material form and self as non-dual. Just as with an oil-lamp burning in a windless place, “What is the flame, that is the colour, what is the colour, that is the flame,” he regards the flame and the colour as non-dual,

original: evameva idhekacco rūpaṃ attato…pe… samanupassatīti evaṃ rūpaṃ “attā”ti diṭṭhipassanāya
analyzed: evam eva idha ekaccaḥ rūpam atta tāpe samanupassati iti evam rūpam attā ati diṭṭhi passanāya
translated: so too someone regards material form as self… thus he sees by way of the view that material form is self.

original: passati. Rūpavantaṃ vā attānanti arūpaṃ “attā”ti gahetvā chāyāvantaṃ rukkhaṃ viya
analyzed: passati rūpavantam vā attā ananti arūpam attā ati gahetvā chāyāvantam rukkham viya
translated: Or he regards self as possessing material form: having grasped self as formless, he regards it as possessing a shadow, like a tree.

original: taṃ rūpavantaṃ “attā”ti samanupassati. Attani vā rūpanti arūpameva “attā”ti gahetvā
analyzed: tam rūpavantam attā ati samanupassati attani vā arūpam eva attā ati gahetvā
translated: He regards the visible-data-possessor as the self. Or else, taking the formless self to be in the visible data,

original: pupphasmiṃ gandhaṃ viya attani rūpaṃ samanupassati. Rūpasmiṃ vā attānanti arūpameva
analyzed: pupphasmim gandham viya attani rūpam samanupassati rūpasmim vā arūpam eva
translated: he regards the visible data as in the self, like a scent in a flower. Or else, taking the formless self to be the visible data,

original: “attā”ti gahetvā karaṇḍake maṇiṃ viya taṃ attānaṃ rūpasmiṃ samanupassati. Vedanādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: attā iti gahetvā karaṇḍake maṇim viya tam attānam rūpasmim samanupassati vedanā ādīsu pi esa iva nayo
translated: he regards the self as in the visible data, like a gem in a casket. The same method of explanation applies to feeling, and so on.

original: Tattha “rūpaṃ attato samanupassatī”ti suddharūpaṃyeva “attā”ti kathitaṃ. “Rūpavantaṃ
analyzed: tattha rūpam attataḥ samanupassati iti suddha rūpam yā eva attā iti kathitam rūpavantam
translated: Herein, “He regards materiality as the self” is said of one who holds the mere material form to be the self. “He regards the self as possessed of materiality,🔽or he regards materiality as in the self, or he regards the self as in materiality” are said of one who holds the formless self to be in the materiality,

original: vā attānaṃ, attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ. Vedanaṃ attato… saññaṃ… saṅkhāre…
analyzed: vā attānam attani vā rūpam rūpasmim vā attānam vedanam attataḥ saññam saṅkhāre
translated: or the materiality to be in the formless self, or the formless self to be in the materiality. “He regards feeling as the self” …

original: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassatī”ti imesu sattasu ṭhānesu arūpaṃ “attā”ti kathitaṃ,🔽“vedanāvantaṃ vā attānaṃ, attani vā vedanā, vedanāya vā attāna”nti evaṃ catūsu khandhesu
analyzed: viññāṇam attataḥ samanupassati iti imesu sattasu ṭhānesu arūpam attā iti kathitam  vedanāvantam vā attānam attani vā vedanā vedanāya vā attānanti evam catūsu khandhesu
translated: “He regards perception as the self” … “He regards formations as the self” … “He regards consciousness as the self” are said of one who holds the formless self to be the self.🔽“He regards the self as possessed of feeling, or he regards feeling as in the self, or he regards the self as in feeling” are said of one who holds the formless self to be in the feeling,

original: tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ vasena dvādasasu ṭhānesu rūpārūpamissako attā kathito. Tattha rūpaṃ
analyzed: tiṇṇam tiṇṇam vasena dvādasasu ṭhānesu rūpa arūpa missakaḥ attā kathito tattha rūpaṃ
translated: or the feeling to be in the formless self, or the formless self to be in the feeling. The same method of explanation applies to the remaining three aggregates. Thus the self is said to be mixed with the material and immaterial in twelve ways by means of the three ways in each of the four aggregates.🔽Herein, “He regards materiality as the self” is said of one who holds the mere material form to be the self.

original: attato samanupassati. Vedanaṃ… saññaṃ… saṅkhāre… viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassatīti
analyzed: attataḥ samanupassati vedanam saññam saṅkhāre viññāṇam attataḥ samanupassati iti
translated: he regards feeling, perception, the mental formations, and consciousness as the self.

original: pañcasu ṭhānesu ucchedadiṭṭhi kathitā. Avasesesu sassatadiṭṭhi. Evamettha pannarasa
analyzed: pañcasu ṭhānesu uccheda diṭṭhi kathitā avasesesu sassata diṭṭhi evam ettha pannarasa
translated: In the five places, the annihilationist view is stated. In the rest, the eternalist view. Thus here there are fifteen

original: bhavadiṭṭhiyo pañca vibhavadiṭṭhiyo honti. Tā sabbāpi maggāvaraṇā, na saggāvaraṇā,
analyzed: bhava diṭṭhiyaḥ pañca vibhava diṭṭhiyaḥ honti tā sabbā api magga āvaraṇā na sagga āvaraṇā
translated: views of becoming and five views of non-becoming. All these are hindrances to the path, not to heaven.

original: paṭhamamaggavajjhāti veditabbā.
analyzed: paṭhama magga vat jhā ati veditabbā
translated: They should be understood as abandoned by the first path.

original: Āraññikoti araññe nivāsaṃ. Pavaneti mahante gambhīravane. Caramānoti tahiṃ tahiṃ
analyzed: āraññikā uti araññe nivāsam pavaneti mahante gambhīra vane caramānaḥ iti tahim tahim
translated: “A forest-dweller”: one who lives in the forest. “In the jungle”: in a great, deep jungle. “Wandering”: wandering here and there.

original: vicaramāno. Vissattho gacchatīti nibbhayo nirāsaṅko carati. Anāpāthagato luddassāti🔽migaluddassa parammukhagato. Antamakāsi māranti kilesamāraṃ vā devaputtamāraṃ vā🔽antaṃ akāsi. Apadaṃ vadhitvāti kilesapadaṃ hantvā nāsetvā. Māracakkhuṃ adassanaṃ
analyzed: vicaramānaḥ vissatthaḥ gacchati iti nibbhayaḥ nirāsaṅkaḥ carati anāpātha gataḥ luddassa ati  miga luddassa parammukha gataḥ antam akāsi māranti kilesa māram vā devaputta māram vā  antam akāsi a padam vadhitvā ati kilesa padam hantvā nāsetvā māra cakkhum adassanam
translated: “Fearlessly goes”: he goes without fear, without anxiety. “Not within the range of the hunter”:🔽he is not within the range of the hunter who is facing him. “He has made an end”: he has made an end of the defilement-Mara or the son-of-god-Mara.

original: gatoti mārassa adassanavisayaṃ patto. Anāpāthagatoti mārassa parammukhaṃ patto. Sesaṃ
analyzed: gato ti mārassa a dassana visayam patto anāpātha gataḥ ti mārassa parammukham patto sesam
translated: “Having slain the foot”: having slain, having destroyed, the foot of the defilements. “He has gone beyond the range of Mara’s eye”: he has reached the sphere beyond the sight of Mara. “Not within the range”: he has reached the sphere beyond the face of Mara. The rest🔽is clear.

original: sabbattha pākaṭameva.
analyzed: sabbattha pākaṭam eva
translated: all of which is clear.

original: Evaṃ bhagavā idampi suttaṃ arahattanikūṭeneva desesi, desanāpariyosāne ca vuttasadisoyeva dhammābhisamayo ahosīti.
analyzed: evam bhagavā idam pi suttam arahatta nikūṭena iva desesi desanā pariyosāne ca vutta sadisaḥ yā iva dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi iti
translated: So the Blessed One taught this sutta too by way of the peak of arahantship. And at the conclusion of the teaching the penetration of the Dhamma by the venerable Ānanda and the venerable Bhaddiya was of the same type as before.

original: Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the brief exposition in the Niddesa, the illumination of the true Dhamma,🔽is finished.

original: Mogharājamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mogharājamāṇava sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the brief exposition of the sutta on the youth Mogharāja is finished.

original: 16. Piṅgiyamāṇavasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽89. Soḷasame piṅgiyasuttaniddese – jiṇṇohamasmi abalo vītavaṇṇoti so kira brāhmaṇo🔽jarābhibhūto vīsavassasatiko jātiyā, dubbalo ca “idha pādaṃ karissāmī”ti aññatreva
analyzed: soḷasame piṅgiya sutta niddese jiṇṇaḥ aham asmi abalaḥ vīta vaṇṇo ti saḥ kira brāhmaṇaḥ  jarā abhibhūtaḥ vīsa vassasatikaḥ jātiyāḥ dubbalaḥ ca idha pādam karissāmi iti aññatra eva
translated: The commentary on the brief exposition of the sutta on the youth Piṅgiya

original: karoti, vinaṭṭhapurimachavivaṇṇo ca. Tenāha – “jiṇṇohamasmi abalo vītavaṇṇo”ti. Māhaṃ
analyzed: karoti vinaṭṭha purima chavi vaṇṇaḥ ca tena āha jiṇṇaḥ aham asmi abalaḥ mā aham
translated: In the sixteenth sutta, the brief exposition on Piṅgiya, the brahmin Piṅgiya said: “I am old, feeble, and my complexion is poor” . It seems that he was overcome by old age, was sixty-two years old, and was weak. He would think, “I will put my foot here,” and he would put it somewhere else. His former complexion was destroyed. Therefore he said: “I am old, feeble, and my complexion is poor.”

original: nassaṃ momuho antarāvāti māhaṃ tuyhaṃ dhammaṃ asacchikatvā antarā eva avidvā hutvā
analyzed: nassam momuhaḥ antarā avāti mā aham tuyham dhammam a sacchikatvā antarā eva a vidvā hutvā
translated: “I will not die, deluded, in the middle,” he said. “I will not die without having realized your Dhamma, deluded, in the middle, without having become a knower.

original: anassiṃ. Jātijarāya idha vippahānanti idheva tava pādamūle pāsāṇake cetiye vā jātijarāya
analyzed: anassim jāti jarāya idha vippahānanti idha iva tava pāda mūle pāsāṇake cetiye vā jāti jarāya
translated: “Here, having abandoned birth and aging,” he said. “Here, at your feet, at the stone caitya, having abandoned birth and aging,

original: vippahānaṃ nibbānaṃ dhammarasaṃ ahaṃ vijaññaṃ, taṃ me ācikkha.
analyzed: vippahānam nibbānam dhamma rasam aham vijaññam tam me ācikkha
translated: I know that the abandoning of these is Nibbāna, the taste of the Dhamma. Please teach me that.”

original: Abaloti balavirahito. Dubbaloti dubbalabalo. Appabaloti parittabalo. Appathāmoti🔽parittavīriyo. Vītavaṇṇoti parivattitachavivaṇṇo. Vigatavaṇṇoti apagatachavivaṇṇo.
analyzed: abalaḥ ti bala virahitaḥ dubbalo ti dubbala balaḥ appabalo ti paritta balo appathāmo ti  paritta vīriyaḥ vīta vaṇṇaḥ ti parivattita chavi vaṇṇaḥ vigata vaṇṇaḥ ti apagata chavi vaṇṇaḥ
translated: “Weak” means devoid of strength. “Feeble” means having little strength. “Powerless” means having limited strength. “Lacking in energy” means🔽having limited energy. “Colourless” means having a changed skin colour. “Devoid of colour” means having a skin colour that has disappeared.

original: Vigacchitavaṇṇoti dūrībhūtachavivaṇṇo. Yā sā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhāti yā sā subhā🔽sundarā purimakāle sati, sā vaṇṇanibhā etarahi antarahitā vigatā. Ādīnavo pātubhūtoti
analyzed: vigacchita vaṇṇaḥ iti dūrībhūta chavi vaṇṇaḥ yā sā purimā subhā vaṇṇa nibhā ati yā sā subhā  sundarā purima kāle sati sā vaṇṇa nibhā etarahi antarahitā vigatā ādīnavaḥ pātubhūtā iti

translated: to fourteen koṭis of beings.”

original: Niṭṭhitāya pana dhammadesanāya tato tato āgatā manussā bhagavato ānubhāvena attano
analyzed: niṭṭhitāya pana dhamma desanāya tatas tatas āgatāḥ manussāḥ bhagavato ānubhāvena attano
translated: And when the teaching of the Dhamma was finished, the people who had come from here and there, by the Blessed One’s power,

original: attano gāmanigamādīsveva pāturahesuṃ. Bhagavāpi sāvatthimeva agamāsi paricārakasoḷasādīhi🔽anekehi bhikkhusahassehi parivuto. Tattha piṅgiyo bhagavantaṃ vanditvā āha – “gacchāmahaṃ,
analyzed: gāma nigama ādīsu eva bhagavā api sāvatthim eva agamāsi paricāraka soḷasa ādīhi  anekehi bhikkhu sahassehi parivutaḥ tattha piṅgiyaḥ bhagavantam vanditvā āha gacchāmaham aham
translated: and they came to their own villages and towns, etc. The Exalted One also came to Sāvatthi, surrounded by many thousands of bhikkhus, including the sixteen mendicants who had been his attendants.

original: bhante, bāvarissa buddhuppādaṃ ārocetuṃ, paṭissutañhi tasseva mayā”ti. Atha bhagavatā
analyzed: bhante bāvarissa buddhuppādam ārocetum paṭissutam hi tassa iva mayā ati atha bhagavatā
translated: There Piṅgiyānī saluted the Exalted One and said, “Venerable sir, I am going to announce the appearance of the Buddha to Bāvari, for I promised to do so.” Then, with the Exalted One’s permission,

original: anuññāto ñāṇagamaneneva godhāvarītīraṃ gantvā pādagamanena assamābhimukho agamāsi.
analyzed: anuññātaḥ ñāṇa gamanena iva godhāvarī tīram gantvā pāda gamanena assama abhimukhaḥ agamāsi
translated: he went by his psychic power to the bank of the Godhāvarī River and then on foot to the hermitage.

original: Tamenaṃ bāvarī brāhmaṇo maggaṃ olokento nisinno dūratova taṃ khārijaṭādivirahitaṃ
analyzed: tam enam bāvarī brāhmaṇaḥ maggam olokentaḥ nisinnaḥ dūratas va tam khāri jaṭā ādi virahitam
translated: Bāvari, the brahmin, was sitting watching the road. From afar he saw Piṅgiyānī coming, without the outer robe, etc.,

original: bhikkhuvesenāgacchantaṃ disvā “buddho loke uppanno”ti niṭṭhamagamāsi. Sampattañcāpi🔽naṃ pucchi – “kiṃ, piṅgiya, buddho loke uppanno”ti? “Āma, brāhmaṇa, uppanno, pāsāṇake
analyzed: bhikkhu vesena āgacchantam disvā buddhaḥ loke uppannaḥ ti niṭṭham agamāsi sampattam ca api  nam pucchi kim piṅgiya buddhaḥ loke uppannaḥ ti āma brāhmaṇaḥ uppannaḥ pāsāṇake
translated: and as he approached in the guise of a bhikkhu, he concluded, “The Buddha has appeared in the world.” When Piṅgiyānī arrived,

original: cetiye nisinno amhākaṃ dhammaṃ desesi, tamahaṃ tuyhaṃ desessāmī”ti. Tato bāvarī mahatā
analyzed: cetiye nisinnaḥ amhākam dhammam desesi tam aham tuyham desessāmi iti tatas bāvarī mahatā
translated: Bāvari asked him, “Piṅgiyānī, has the Buddha appeared in the world?” “Yes, brahmin, he has appeared. He was sitting at the Pāsāṇaka shrine and preached the Dhamma to us. I will teach it to you.”🔽Then Bāvari, with a great

original: sakkārena sapariso taṃ pūjetvā āsanaṃ paññāpesi. Tattha nisīditvā piṅgiyo “pārāyanamanugāyissa”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: sakkārena sa parisaḥ tam pūjetvā āsanam paññāpesi tattha nisīditvā piṅgiyaḥ pārāyanam anugāyissanti ādim āha
translated: and he worshipped him with the homage due to a Supreme Buddha, and prepared a seat. Sitting down, he said, “I will sing the Pārāyana.”

original: Tattha anugāyissanti bhagavato gītaṃ anugāyissaṃ. Yathāddakkhīti yathā sāmaṃ saccābhisambodhena🔽asādhāraṇañāṇena ca addakkhi. Nikkāmoti pahīnakāmo. “Nikkamo”tipi pāṭho, vīriyavāti
analyzed: tattha anugāyissanti bhagavataḥ gītam anugāyissam yathā addakkhi iti yathā sāmam sacca abhisambodhena  asādhāraṇa ñāṇena ca addakkhi nikkāmo ti pahīna kāmaḥ nikkamaḥ ti pi pāṭhaḥ vīriya vā ati
translated: Herein, I will sing the Pārāyana is what I will chant the Blessed One’s song. As he saw is as he saw for himself by the realization of the Truths

original: attho. Nikkhanto vā akusalapakkhā. Nibbanoti kilesavanavirahito, taṇhāvirahito eva
analyzed: atthaḥ nikkhantaḥ vā akusala pakkhā nibbano ti kilesa vana virahitaḥ taṇhā virahitaḥ eva
translated: with his own knowledge that is not held in common with others. He is free from lust is free from lust for lustful things. The reading is also nikkhāmo, in which case the meaning is “he is energetic” or “he has gone out” from the side of unprofitable things. He is the Unbinding is free from the defilements of the corruptions or free from craving.

original: vā. Kissa hetu musā bhaṇeti yehi kilesehi musā bhaṇeyya, ete tassa pahīnāti dasseti.
analyzed: vā kissa hetu musā bhaṇeti yehi kilesehi musā bhaṇeyya ete tassa pahīnā ati dasseti
translated: Why is it that he does not tell a lie? He shows that he has abandoned the defilements by which one might tell a lie.

original: Etena brāhmaṇassa savane ussāhaṃ janeti.
analyzed: etena brāhmaṇassa savane ussāham janeti
translated: By this he rouses the brahmin’s eagerness to listen.

original: Amaloti kilesamalavirahito. Vimaloti vigatakilesamalo. Nimmaloti kilesamalasuddho.
analyzed: kilesa mala virahitaḥ vimalo ti vigata kilesa malaḥ nimmalo ti kilesa mala suddho
translated: He is pure is free from the stain of defilement. He is spotless is free from the stain of defilement. He is stainless is purified from the stain of defilement.

original: Malāpagatoti kilesamalā dūrībhūto hutvā carati. Malavippahīnoti kilesamalappahīno.
analyzed: mala apagataḥ ti kilesa malāḥ dūrībhūtaḥ hutvā carati mala vippahīno ti kilesa mala ppahīno
translated: He has gone beyond the stain is one who goes having made the stain of defilement distant. He has abandoned the stain is one who has abandoned the stain of defilement.

original: Malavimuttoti kilesehi vimutto. Sabbamalavītivattoti vāsanādisabbakilesamalaṃ atikkanto.
analyzed: mala vimuttaḥ ti kilesehi vimuttaḥ sabba mala vītivattaḥ ti vāsanā ādi sabba kilesa malam atikkanto
translated: “Freed from the stain” : freed from defilements. “Gone beyond all stain” : gone beyond all stain of defilement, such as the latent tendency.

original: Te vanāti ete vuttappakārā kilesā.
analyzed: te ete vutta ppakārā kilesā
translated: “These” : these defilements of the kinds stated.

original: 103. Vaṇṇūpasaṃhitanti guṇūpasaṃhitaṃ.
analyzed: vaṇṇu upasaṃhitanti guṇu upasaṃhitam
translated: “Endowed with beauty” : endowed with the beauty of virtue.

original: 104. Saccavhayoti buddho hi sacceneva avhānena nāmena yutto. Brahmeti taṃ brāhmaṇaṃ ālapati.
analyzed: saccavhayā iti buddhaḥ hi saccena iva avhānena nāmena yuttaḥ brahmā iti tam brāhmaṇam ālapati
translated: “Truth-finder” : the Buddha is endowed with the name “Truth-finder” by means of the truth itself. “Brahma” : he addresses the brahmana.

original: Tattha lokoti lujjanaṭṭhena loko. Eko loko bhavalokoti tebhūmakavipāko. So hi bhavatīti🔽bhavo, bhavo eva loko bhavaloko. Bhavaloko ca sambhavaloko cāti ettha ekeko dve dve
analyzed: tattha loko ti ekaḥ lokaḥ bhava loko ti tebhūmaka vipāko saḥ hi bhavati iti  bhavaḥ bhavaḥ eva lokaḥ bhava lokaḥ bhava loko ca sambhava loko ca ati ettha ekekaḥ dve dve
translated: Herein, “world” is the world in the sense of that which is crushed . “One world” : the world of becoming, the kammic result of the three planes. For that is “becoming” ,

original: hoti. Bhavaloko hi sampattibhavavipattibhavavasena duvidho. Sambhavalokopi sampattisambhavavipattisambhavavasena
analyzed: bhava lokaḥ hi sampatti bhava vipatti bhava vasena sambhava lokaḥ api sampatti sambhava vipatti sambhava vasena
translated: and the world of becoming is the world of becoming. “World of becoming” and “world of birth” : here each has two meanings. For the world of becoming is twofold as the becoming of happiness and the becoming of misery. And the world of birth is also twofold as the birth of happiness and the birth of misery.

original: duvidho. Tattha sampattibhavalokoti sugatiloko. So hi iṭṭhaphalattā sundaro lokoti
analyzed: duvidho tattha sampatti bhava loko ti sugati loko so hi iṭṭha phala ttā sundaro
translated: Herein, the world of becoming of happiness is the world of good destinations. For that is a beautiful world because it is a desirable fruit.

original: sampatti, bhavatīti bhavo, sampatti eva bhavo sampattibhavo, so eva loko sampattibhavaloko.
analyzed: sampatti bhavati iti bhavaḥ sampatti eva bhavaḥ sampatti bhavaḥ saḥ eva lokaḥ sampatti bhava lokaḥ
translated: “Prosperity” is “becoming” (bhava), and “prosperity-becoming” (sampattibhavo) is just that. That itself is the “world” (loko), and so it is “prosperity-becoming-world” (sampattibhavaloko).

original: Sampattisambhavalokoti sugatūpagaṃ kammaṃ. Tañhi sambhavati etasmā phalanti sambhavo,
analyzed: sampatti sambhava loko ti sugata upagam kammam tat hi sambhavati etasmai phalanti sambhavaḥ
translated: “World of the origin of prosperity” (sampattisambhavaloko) is kamma that leads to a good destination. For that originates from it, and so it is “origin” (sambhavo).

original: sampattiyā sambhavo sampattisambhavo, sampattisambhavo eva loko sampattisambhavalokoti.🔽Vipattibhavalokoti apāyaloko. So hi aniṭṭhaphalattā virūpo lokoti vipatti, bhavatīti🔽bhavo, vipatti eva bhavo vipattibhavo, vipattibhavo eva loko vipattibhavaloko. Vipattisambhavalokoti
analyzed: sampattiyāḥ sambhavaḥ sampatti sambhavaḥ sampatti sambhavaḥ eva lokaḥ sampatti sambhava lokaḥ iti  vipatti bhava loko ti apāya loko so hi aniṭṭha phalattā virūpaḥ bhavati iti  bhavaḥ eva bhavaḥ vipatti bhavaḥ vipatti bhavaḥ eva lokaḥ vipatti bhava lokaḥ vipatti sambhava lokaḥ iti
translated: “Origin of prosperity” (sampattisambhavo) is just that, and that itself is the “world” (loko), and so it is “world of the origin of prosperity” (sampattisambhavaloko).🔽“World of adversity-becoming” (vipattibhavaloko) is the world of the unhappy destinations. For it is an undesirable fruit, and so it is “adversity” (vipatti). It “becomes,” and so it is “becoming” (bhavo).

original: apāyūpagaṃ kammaṃ. Tañhi sambhavati etasmā phalanti sambhavo, vipattiyā sambhavo
analyzed: apāyu upagam kammam tat hi sambhavati etasmai phalanti sambhavaḥ vipattiyā sambhavaḥ
translated: “Adversity-becoming” (vipattibhavo) is just that, and that itself is the “world” (loko), and so it is “world of adversity-becoming” (vipattibhavaloko). “World of the origin of adversity” (vipattisambhavaloko) is kamma that leads to an unhappy destination. For that originates from it, and so it is “origin” (sambhavo).

original: vipattisambhavo, vipattisambhavo eva loko vipattisambhavalokoti. Tisso vedanāti sukhā
analyzed: vipatti sambhavaḥ vipatti sambhavaḥ eva lokaḥ vipatti sambhava lokaḥ tissaḥ vedanā ati sukhā
translated: “Origin of adversity” (vipattisambhavo) is just that, and that itself is the “world” (loko), and so it is “world of the origin of adversity” (vipattisambhavaloko). “Three kinds of feeling” : pleasant,

original: vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā lokiyā eva. Āhārāti paccayā. Paccayā
analyzed: vedanā dukkhā vedanā adukkhamasukhā vedanā lokiyā eva āhārā ti paccayā paccayā
translated: Painful feeling, pleasant feeling, neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling are only mundane. Nutriment is a condition.🔽For nutriment is so called because it brings in its fruit, since conditions🔽bring in their own fruit. Nutriment is of four kinds as physical food,

original: hi attano phalaṃ āharantīti āhārā. Kabaḷīkārāhāro phassāhāro manosañcetanāhāro viññāṇāhāroti🔽cattāro. Vatthuvasena kabaḷīkattabbattā kabaḷīkāro, ajjhoharitabbattā āhāro, odanakummāsādivatthukāya
analyzed: hi attanaḥ phalam āharanti iti āhārā kabaḷīkāra āhāro phassa āhāro manaḥ sañcetanā āhāro viññāṇa āhāro ti  cattāro vatthu vasena kabaḷīkattabba ttā kabaḷīkāro ajjhoharitabba ttā āhāraḥ odana kummāsa ādi vatthukāya
translated: contact, mental volition, and consciousness.🔽It is called physical food because it can be made into morsels and eaten,

original: ojāyetaṃ nāmaṃ. Sā hi ojaṭṭhamakarūpāni āharatīti āhāro. Cakkhusamphassādiko chabbidho
analyzed: nāmam sā hi oja ṭṭha maka rūpāni āharati iti āhāraḥ cakkhu samphassa ādiko chabbidhaḥ
translated: because it is nutriment. It is the name for the nutritive essence that has as its basis rice, curry, etc.,🔽for that is nutriment since it brings in the eight kinds of physical nutriment.

original: phasso tisso vedanā āharatīti āhāro. Manaso sañcetanā na sattassāti manosañcetanā
analyzed: phassaḥ tissaḥ vedanāḥ āharati iti āhāraḥ manasaḥ sañcetanā na sattassa ati manaḥ sañcetanā
translated: Contact, which is of six kinds as eye-contact, etc., is nutriment since it brings in the three kinds of feeling.🔽Mental volition is what is associated with the mind.🔽Mental volition is so called because it is not volition of a living being, just as a “chariot of knowledge” is so called because it is yoked to the mind.

original: yathā cittekaggatā, manasā vā sampayuttā sañcetanā manosañcetanā yathā ājaññaratho,
analyzed: yathā citta ekagga tā manasā vā sampayuttā sañcetanā manaḥ sañcetanā yathā ājaññaratho
translated: It is volition associated with the mind, like a knowledge-chariot.

original: tebhūmakakusalākusalacetanā. Sā hi tayo bhave āharatīti āhāro. Viññāṇanti ekūnavīsatibhedaṃ
analyzed: tebhūmaka kusala akusala cetanā sā hi tayaḥ bhave āharati iti āhāraḥ viññāṇam ti ekūnavīsati bhedam
translated: It is the volition of the three planes, profitable and unprofitable. It is nutriment since it brings in the three kinds of becoming.🔽Consciousness is the nineteen kinds of rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: paṭisandhiviññāṇaṃ. Tañhi paṭisandhināmarūpaṃ āharatīti āhāro.
analyzed: paṭisandhi viññāṇam tat hi paṭisandhi nāma rūpam āharati iti āhāraḥ
translated: It is nutriment since it brings in rebirth-linking mentality-materiality.

original: Upādānakkhandhāti upādānagocarā khandhā upādānakkhandhā, majjhe padalopo daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: upādāna khandhā ti upādāna gocarāḥ khandhāḥ upādāna khandhāḥ majjhe pada lopaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: “Aggregates as acquisitions” : the aggregates that are the domain of acquisition are aggregates as acquisitions. The middle part of the compound should be taken as abbreviated.

original: Upādānasambhūtā vā khandhā upādānakkhandhā yathā tiṇaggi, thusaggi. Upādānavidheyyā
analyzed: upādāna sambhūtāḥ vā khandhāḥ upādāna kkhandhāḥ yathā tiṇaggi thusaggi upādāna vidheyyā
translated: Or the aggregates that are originated by acquisition are aggregates as acquisitions, like “grass-fire” and “straw-fire.”

original: vā khandhā upādānakkhandhā yathā rājapuriso. Upādānappabhavā vā khandhā upādānakkhandhā
analyzed: vā khandhāḥ upādāna kkhandhāḥ yathā rāja purisaḥ upādāna ppabhavāḥ vā khandhāḥ upādāna kkhandhāḥ
translated: Or the aggregates that are directed by acquisition are aggregates as acquisitions, like “king’s man.”

original: yathā puppharukkho, phalarukkho. Upādānāni pana kāmupādānaṃ diṭṭhupādānaṃ sīlabbatupādānaṃ
analyzed: yathā puppha rukkhaḥ phala rukkhaḥ upādānāni pana kāma upādānam diṭṭha upādānam sīla bbata upādānam
translated: Or the aggregates that are the outcome of acquisition are aggregates as acquisitions, like “flower tree” and “fruit tree.”

original: attavādupādānanti cattāri. Atthato pana bhusaṃ ādānanti upādānaṃ. Rūpupādānakkhandho,
analyzed: attavāt upādānanti cattāri atthato pana bhusam ādānam ti upādānam rūpa upādāna khandho
translated: But as to the acquisitions themselves, there are four: acquisition of sense pleasures, acquisition of views, acquisition of virtue and practice, and acquisition of self-theories.

original: vedanupādānakkhandho, saññupādānakkhandho, saṅkhārupādānakkhandho, viññāṇupādānakkhandhoti
analyzed: vedanā upādānakkhandho saññu pādānakkhandho saṅkhāru pādānakkhandho viññāṇu pādānakkhandhoti
translated: In meaning, however, acquisition is the seizing of what is not given. There are five aggregates as acquisitions: the form aggregate as acquisition, the feeling aggregate as acquisition, the perception aggregate as acquisition, the volitional formations aggregate as acquisition, and the consciousness aggregate as acquisition.

original: pañca. Cha ajjhattikāni āyatanānīti cakkhāyatanaṃ, sotāyatanaṃ, ghānāyatanaṃ, jivhāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: pañca cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni iti cakkhāyatanam sotāyatanam ghānāyatanam jivhāyatanam
translated: The six internal sense bases: the eye sense base, the ear sense base, the nose sense base, the tongue sense base, the body sense base, and the mind sense base.

original: kāyāyatanaṃ, manāyatanaṃ. Satta viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo vuttanayā eva. Tathā aṭṭha lokadhammā.🔽Api ca – lābho, alābho, yaso, ayaso, nindā, pasaṃsā, sukhaṃ, dukkhanti ime aṭṭha
analyzed: kāya āyatanam manāyatanam satta viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ vutta nayāḥ eva tathā aṭṭha loka dhammā  api ca lābhaḥ alābhaḥ yasaḥ ayasaḥ nindā pasaṃsā sukham dukkhanti ime aṭṭha
translated: The body base and the mind base. The seven stations of consciousness are as already stated. So too the eight worldly ideas.

original: lokappavattiyā sati anuparivattanadhammakattā lokassa dhammāti lokadhammā. Etehi
analyzed: loka ppavattiyā sati anuparivattana dhammaka ttā lokassa dhammā ati loka dhammāḥ etehi
translated: Besides, there are these eight: gain, loss, fame, disgrace,  disrepute, pleasure, and pain. These are called worldly ideas because they are ideas that occur in the world and that occur in conformity with the revolution of the world.

original: mutto satto nāma natthi, buddhānampi hontiyeva. Yathāha –
analyzed: muttaḥ satto nāma natthi buddhānam pi hontiyā iva yathā āha
translated: There is no being who is free from them, not even Buddhas. As it is said:

original: “Aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, lokadhammā lokaṃ anuparivattanti, loko ca aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattati.🔽Katame aṭṭha? Lābho ca alābho ca…pe… sukhañca dukkhañca. Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha
analyzed: aṭṭhime bhikkhave loka dhammā lokam anuparivattanti lokaḥ ca aṭṭha loka dhamme anuparivattati  katame aṭṭha lābho ca alābho ca pe sukhañca dukkhañca ime kho bhikkhave aṭṭha
translated: “Bhikkhus, these eight worldly ideas revolve around the world, and the world revolves around these eight worldly ideas.

original: lokadhammā lokaṃ anuparivattanti, loko ca ime aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattatī”ti.
analyzed: loka dhammā lokam anuparivattanti lokaḥ ca ime aṭṭha loka dhamme anuparivattati iti
translated: What eight? Gain and loss, fame and disgrace,  disrepute and pleasure, and pain. These eight worldly ideas revolve around the world, and the world revolves around these eight worldly ideas” .

original: Tattha anuparivattantīti anubandhanti nappajahanti, lokato na nivattantīti attho.
analyzed: tattha anuparivattanti iti anubandhanti na ppajahanti lokataḥ na nivattanti iti attho
translated: Herein, revolve around means follow, do not avoid; the meaning is that they do not turn away from the world.

original: Lābhoti pabbajitassa cīvarādi, gahaṭṭhassa dhanadhaññādilābho. Soyeva alabbhamāno🔽lābho alābho na lābho alābhoti vuccati, no ca attābhāvappattito pariññeyyo siyā.
analyzed: lābhaḥ ti pabbajitassa cīvara ādi gahaṭṭhassa dhana dhañña ādi lābho saḥ yeva alabbhamāno  lābhaḥ alābhaḥ na lābhaḥ alābhaḥ iti vuccati no ca attā abhāva ppattitaḥ pariññeyyaḥ siyā
translated: Gain is robe-material, etc., for the monk, and for the house- holder it is the gain of wealth, corn, etc. When that is not obtained,🔽it is called “non-gain,” not “what should be fully understood by seeing.”

original: Yasoti parivāro. Soyeva alabbhamāno yaso ayaso. Nindāti avaṇṇabhaṇanaṃ. Pasaṃsāti
analyzed: yasaḥ iti parivāraḥ a yā iva a labbhamānaḥ yasaḥ ayasaḥ nindāti avaṇṇa bhaṇanam
translated: Fame is a following. When that is not obtained, it is called “non- fame.” Dispraise is the speaking of dispraise. Praise is the speaking of praise.

original: vaṇṇabhaṇanaṃ. Sukhanti kāmāvacarakāyikacetasikaṃ. Dukkhanti puthujjanasotāpannasakadāgāmīnaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇa bhaṇanam sukhanti kāmāvacara kāyika cetasikam dukkhanti puthujjana sa utāpanna sakadāgāmīnam
translated: Pleasure is the mental pleasure of the sense sphere. Pain is the bodily and mental pain of ordinary men, of stream-enterers and once-returners,

original: kāyikacetasikaṃ, anāgāmiarahantānaṃ kāyikameva. Sattāvāsāti sattānaṃ āvāsā, vasanaṭṭhānānīti🔽attho. Tāni pana tathā pakāsitā khandhā eva. Sattasu viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu asaññasattena
analyzed: kāyika cetasikam anāgāmi arahantānam kāyikam eva satta āvāsā ati sattānam āvāsāḥ vasana ṭṭhānāni iti  atthaḥ tāni pana tathā pakāsitā khandhāḥ eva sattasu viññāṇa ṭṭhitīsu asaññasattena
translated: and the bodily pain of non-returners and Arahants. Abodes of beings are the abodes of beings, the places where they live.🔽But these are the aggregates themselves as described. There are nine abodes of beings, namely, the seven stations of consciousness and the non-percipient beings and the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: ca nevasaññānāsaññāyatanena ca saddhiṃ nava sattāvāsā. Dasāyatanānīti cakkhāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: ca nevasaññānāsaññāyatanena ca saddhim nava sattāvāsāḥ dasa āyatanāni iti cakkhāyatanam
translated: The ten bases are the eye base,

original: rūpāyatanaṃ, sotāyatanaṃ, saddāyatanaṃ, ghānāyatanaṃ, gandhāyatanaṃ, jivhāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: rūpa āyatanam sotāyatanam sadda āyatanam ghāna āyatanam gandha āyatanam jivhā āyatanam
translated: the form base, the ear base, the sound base, the nose base, the odour base, the tongue base, the flavour base, the body base, and the tangible-data base.

original: rasāyatanaṃ, kāyāyatanaṃ, phoṭṭhabbāyatananti evaṃ dasa. Dvādasāyatanānīti manāyatanadhammāyatanehi
analyzed: rasa āyatanam kāya āyatanam phoṭṭhabba āyatanam ti evam dasa dvādasa āyatanāni iti manāyatana dhammāyatanehi
translated: the tongue base, the body base, the tactile-object base. Thus ten. Twelve bases: the mind base, the idea base,

original: saddhiṃ evaṃ dvādasa. Aṭṭhārasa dhātuyoti cakkhudhātu, rūpadhātu, cakkhuviññāṇadhātu…pe…
analyzed: saddhim evam dvādasa aṭṭhārasa dhātuyaḥ ti cakkhu dhātu rūpa dhātu cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu pe
translated: together with the mind-consciousness base. Thus twelve. Eighteen elements: the eye element, the visible-data element, the eye-consciousness element …

original: manodhātu, dhammadhātu, manoviññāṇadhātūti ekekasmiṃ tīṇi tīṇi katvā aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo.
analyzed: manaḥ dhātu dhammadhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu uti ekekasmin tīṇi tīṇi katvā aṭṭhārasa dhātuyaḥ
translated: the mind element, the idea element, the mind-consciousness element. Thus eighteen by taking each in turn with three.

original: Sadisanāmoti tesaṃ sadisanāmo ekaguṇavaṇṇanāmo. Sadisavhayoti ekaguṇavaṇṇanāmena avhāyano. Saccasadisavhayoti avitathaekaguṇavaṇṇanāmena aviparītena avhāyano.
analyzed: sadisa nāmoti tesam sadisa nāmaḥ ekaguṇa vaṇṇa nāmo sadisavhayo ti ekaguṇa vaṇṇa nāmena avhāyano sacca sadisavhayaḥ iti avitatha ekaguṇa vaṇṇa nāmena aviparītena avhāyanaḥ
translated: Like-named: they have the same name for their one quality. Like-called: they are called by the same name for their one quality. Truth-like-called: they are called by the name for their undeluded one quality, by the name for their unperverted one quality.

original: Āsitoti upasaṅkamito. Upāsitoti upagantvā sevito. Payirupāsitoti bhattivasena atīva sevito.
analyzed: āsitaḥ iti upasaṅkamitaḥ upāsitaḥ iti upagantvā sevitaḥ payiḥ upāsitaḥ iti bhatti vasena atīva sevitaḥ
translated: Approached: approached, gone to. Worshipped: served. Revered: served with devotion.🔽A little grove: a small park. In a wood rich in fruits: in a wood

original: 105. Kubbanakanti parittavanaṃ. Bahupphalaṃ kānanamāvaseyyāti anekaphalādivikatibharitakānanaṃ
analyzed: kubbanakam ti paritta vanam bahu phalam kānanam āvaseyya ati aneka phala ādi vikati bharita kānanam
translated: rich in various fruits and so on.

original: āgamma vaseyya. Appadasseti bāvarippabhutike parittapaññe. Mahodadhinti anotattādiṃ
analyzed: āgamma vaseyya appadassa iti bāvari pabhutike paritta paññe mahā udadhinti anotatta ādiṃ
translated: and live there. Of little learning: of limited understanding, like the Bāvari. The great ocean: the ocean, the abode of Vāruṇa.

original: mahantaṃ udakarāsiṃ.🔽Appadassāti mandadassino. Parittadassāti atimandadassino. Thokadassāti parittatopi
analyzed: mahantam udaka rāsim  appa dassā ati manda dassinaḥ paritta dassā ati atimanda dassinaḥ thoka dassā ati parittataḥ pi
translated: “He should come and live with me.” “Of little learning”: of limited understanding, such as the Bāvarī brāhmaṇa. “The great ocean”: the great mass of water, such as the Anotatta lake, etc.

original: atiparittadassino. Omakadassāti heṭṭhimadassino. Lāmakadassāti appadhānadassino.🔽Chatukkadassāti na uttamadassino. Appamāṇadassanti pamāṇaṃ atikkamitvā appamāṇaṃ🔽nibbānadassaṃ. Aggadassanti “aggato ve pasannāna”ntiādinā nayena aggadhammadassaṃ.🔽Seṭṭhadassanti sambuddho dvipadaseṭṭhoti seṭṭhadassaṃ. Viseṭṭhadassantiādīni cattāri
analyzed: ati paritta dassinaḥ omaka dassā ati heṭṭhima dassinaḥ lāmaka dassā ati appadhāna dassinaḥ  chatukka dassā ti na uttama dassinaḥ appamāṇa dassanti pamāṇam atikkamitvā appamāṇam  nibbāna dassam agga dassanti aggataḥ ve pasannānan ti ādinā nayena agga dhamma dassam  seṭṭhadassanti sambuddhaḥ dvipada seṭṭhaḥ ti seṭṭhadassam viseṭṭhadassa nti ādīni cattāri
translated: “Of little vision”: of limited vision. “Of limited vision”: of very limited vision. “Of restricted vision”: even more restricted than limited vision. “Of inferior vision”: of lower vision. “Of poor vision”: of slow vision.🔽“Of fourfold vision”: not of the highest vision. “Of immeasurable vision”: having gone beyond measure, of immeasurable vision, of the vision of Nibbāna. “Of the highest vision”: of the vision of the highest Dhamma, in the way beginning, “The faithful one has confidence in the highest.”

original: upasaggena vaḍḍhitāni. Asamanti na samaṃ asamaṃ sabbaññuṃ. Asamasamanti asamehi atītabuddhehi
analyzed: upasaggena vaḍḍhitāni asamanti na samam asamam sabbaññum asamasamanti asamehi atīta buddhehi
translated: “Of the best vision”: of the vision of the Fully Enlightened One, the best of bipeds. “Of the most excellent vision,” etc., are four terms derived by adding a prefix. “Of the unequalled vision”: of the vision of the unequalled, the Omniscient One. “Of the vision that is equal to the unequalled”: of the vision that is equal to the unequalled Buddhas of the past.

original: samaṃ asamasamaṃ. Appaṭisamanti attano sadisavirahitaṃ. Appaṭibhāganti attano paṭibimbavirahitaṃ.
analyzed: samam asamasamam appaṭisamanti attano sadisa virahitam appaṭibhāganti attano paṭibimba virahitam
translated: Equal, unequalled, unequalled by an equal. Without a peer: without a peer in himself. Without a counterpart: without a counterpart in himself.

original: Appaṭipuggalanti paṭimallapuggalavirahitaṃ. Devātidevanti visuddhidevānampi atidevaṃ.
analyzed: paṭimalla puggala virahitam devātidevanti visuddhi devānam pi atidevam
translated: Without a rival: without a rival in himself. God of gods: a god above even the pure gods.

original: Abhimaṅgalasammataṭṭhena usabhaṃ. Achambhitaṭṭhena purisasīhaṃ. Niddosaṭṭhena purisanāgaṃ.🔽Uttamaṭṭhena purisājaññaṃ. Aṭṭhaparisapathaviṃ uppīḷetvā sadevake loke kenaci paccatthikena🔽paccāmittena akampiye acalaṭṭhāne tiṭṭhanaṭṭhena purisanisabhaṃ. Dhammadesanādhuravahanaṭṭhena purisadhorayhaṃ.
analyzed: abhimaṅgala sammata ṭṭhena usabham a chambhita ṭṭhena purisa sīham niddosa ṭṭhena purisa nāgam  uttamaṭṭhena purisājaññam aṭṭha parisa pathavim uppīḍetvā sa devake loke kenaci paccatthikena  pacca amittena akampiye acala ṭṭhāne tiṭṭhana ṭṭhena purisa nisabham dhamma desanā dhura vahana ṭṭhena purisa dhorayham
translated: Bull: in the sense of being accepted as the supreme good omen. Man-lion: in the sense of being fearless. Man-elephant: in the sense of being free from faults.

original: Mānasakaṃ vā saranti manasā cintetvā kataṃ pallaṃ vā nāmameva vā. Anotattaṃ vā dahanti🔽candimasūriyā dakkhiṇena vā uttarena vā gacchantā pabbatantarena taṃ obhāsenti, ujuṃ
analyzed: mānasakam vā saranti manasā cintetvā katam pallam vā nāmam eva vā anotattam vā dahanti 🔽candima sūriyā dakkhiṇena vā uttarena vā gacchantā pabbata antarena tam obhāsenti ujum

Man-leader: in the sense of being supreme. Man-leader: in the sense of being supreme.

original: gacchantā na obhāsenti, tenevassa “anotatta”nti saṅkhā udapādi. Evarūpaṃ anotattaṃ
analyzed: gacchantāḥ na obhāsenti tena iva assa anotattanti saṅkhā udapādi evarūpam anotattam
translated: Such an Anotatta lake,

original: vā dahaṃ. Akkhobhaṃ amitodakanti cāletuṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ aparimitaṃ udakajalarāsiṃ.
analyzed: vā daham akkhobham amita udakanti cāletum asakkuṇeyyam aparimitam udaka jala rāsim
translated: “unagitated, with infinite water,” which cannot be stirred up or moved, an infinite mass of water.

original: Evamevāti opammasaṃsandanaṃ, buddhaṃ bhagavantaṃ akkhobhaṃ āsabhaṃ ṭhānaṭṭhānena
analyzed: evam eva ati opammasaṃsandanam buddham bhagavantam akkhobham āsabham ṭhāna ṭhānena
translated: “Just so,” etc., is the application of the simile. The Buddha, the Blessed One, is “unagitated,” a leader, who cannot be stirred up or moved by anyone in any situation.

original: cāletuṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ. Amitatejanti aparimitañāṇatejaṃ. Pabhinnañāṇanti dasabalañāṇādivasena
analyzed: cāletum asakkuṇeyyam amita tejam ti aparimita ñāṇa tejam pabhinna ñāṇam ti dasa bala ñāṇa ādi vasena
translated: “Infinitely radiant” means having infinite knowledge-radiance. “Discerning” means having knowledge that has been analyzed into the ten powers of knowledge, etc.

original: pabhedagatañāṇaṃ. Vivaṭacakkhunti samantacakkhuṃ.
analyzed: pabheda gata ñāṇam vivaṭa cakkhunti samanta cakkhum
translated: “Open-eyed” means having all-seeing eyes.

original: Paññāpabhedakusalanti “yā paññā pajānanā vicayo pavicayo”tiādinā nayena paññāya pabhedajānane
analyzed: paññā pabheda kusalanti yā paññā pajānanā vicayo pavicayo ti ādinā nayena paññāya pabheda jānane
translated: “Skilled in the analysis of wisdom” means skilled in the analysis of wisdom by way of the statement: “Wisdom is the act of knowing, investigating, and fully investigating” (Vibh 1).

original: chekaṃ. Adhigatapaṭisambhidanti paṭiladdhacatupaṭisambhidaṃ. Catuvesārajjappattanti
analyzed: chekam adhigata paṭisambhidanti paṭiladdha catu paṭisambhidam catu vesārajja ppattam
translated: “Attained to discriminations” means having attained the four discriminations. “Having attained the four kinds of sure knowledge” means🔽having attained the four kinds of sure knowledge stated as follows:

original: “sammāsambuddhassa te paṭijānato ime dhammā anabhisambuddhā”tiādinā nayena vuttesu
analyzed: sammāsambuddhassa te paṭijānataḥ ime dhammā anabhisambuddhā ati ādinā nayena vuttesu
translated: “If anyone says: ‘You claim to be fully enlightened, but you have not fully awakened to these ideas,’ you would not react thus …

original: catūsu ṭhānesu visāradabhāvappattaṃ. Saddhādhimuttanti parisuddhe phalasamāpatticitte
analyzed: catūsu ṭhānesu visārada bhāva ppattam saddhā adhimuttam parisuddhe phala samāpatti citte
translated: He has attained confidence in the fourfold confidence. He is intent on faith: his mind is intent on the purified fruition attainment.

original: adhimuttaṃ, tattha paviṭṭhaṃ. Setapaccattanti vāsanāya vippahīnattā parisuddhaṃ āveṇikaattabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: adhimuttam tattha paviṭṭham seta paccatta nti vāsanāya vippahīna ttā parisuddham āveṇika atta bhāvam
translated: He has entered it. He has a pure white selfhood: his selfhood is pure, being devoid of the stain of defilements.

original: Advayabhāṇinti paricchinnavacanattā dvivacanavirahitaṃ. Tādinti tādisaṃ, iṭṭhāniṭṭhesu🔽akampanaṃ vā. Tathā paṭiññā assāti tathāpaṭiñño, taṃ. Aparittanti na khuddakaṃ. Mahantanti
analyzed: advaya bhāṇin ti paricchinna vacana ttā dvivacana virahitam tādin ti tādisam iṭṭha aniṭṭhesu  akampanam vā tathā paṭiññā assa ati tathāpaṭiññaḥ tam aparittam ti na khuddakam mahantam ti
translated: He is a non-dual speaker: his speech is free from the dualities, being non-discriminative. He is such: he is of such a kind, unshaken by what is agreeable and disagreeable.

original: tedhātuṃ atikkamitvā mahantappattaṃ.🔽Gambhīranti aññesaṃ duppavesaṃ. Appameyyanti atulaṭṭhena appameyyaṃ. Duppariyogāhanti🔽pariyogāhituṃ dukkhappavesaṃ. Pahūtaratananti saddhādiratanehi pahūtaratanaṃ. Sāgarasamanti
analyzed: tedhātum atikkamitvā mahantappattam  gambhīram ti aññesam duppavesam appameyyam ti atula ṭṭhena appameyyam duppariyogāhanti  pariyogāhitum dukkha ppavesam pahūta ratanam ti saddhā ādi ratanehi pahūta ratanam sāgara samam
translated: He is one who has such an assurance: he is one who has such an assurance in that. He is not small: he is not insignificant. He is great: he has attained greatness by transcending the three worlds.

original: ratanākarato samuddasadisaṃ. Chaḷaṅgupekkhāya samannāgatanti “cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā
analyzed: ratanākarato samudda sadisam chaḷaṅgu pekkhāya samannāgatanti cakkhunā rūpam disvā
translated: He is profound: he is hard to fathom for others. He is immeasurable: he is immeasurable in the sense of being incomparable. He is hard to fathom: he is hard to penetrate by fathoming. He is rich in jewels: he is rich in the jewels of faith, etc. He is like the ocean: he is like the ocean as a mine of jewels. He is endowed with the six kinds of equanimity: having seen a visible object with the eye,

original: neva sumano hoti na dummano”ti vuttanayena chaḷaṅgupekkhāya paripuṇṇaṃ. Atulanti
analyzed: na iva sumanaḥ hoti na dummanaḥ ti vutta nayena chaḷaṅgu pekkhāya paripuṇṇam atulanti
translated: and he is neither glad nor sad” .🔽Incomparable:🔽without comparison, incapable of being weighed.

original: tulavirahitaṃ, tulayituṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ. Vipulanti atimahantaṃ. Appameyyanti pametuṃ
analyzed: tula virahitam tulayitum a sakkuṇeyyam vipulanti atimahantam pametum
translated: Vast: very great.🔽Immeasurable: incapable of being measured.

original: asakkuṇeyyaṃ. Taṃ tādisanti taṃ bhagavantaṃ tādiguṇasampannaṃ. Pavadataṃ maggavādinanti
analyzed: a sakkuṇeyyam tam tādisanti tam bhagavantam tādi guṇa sampannam pavadatam magga vādinanti
translated: Such as he: such as that Blessed One, endowed with those special qualities.🔽Speaking:🔽speaking, saying, uttering the highest speech.

original: pavadantānaṃ kathentānaṃ uttamaṃ kathayantaṃ vadantaṃ adhigacchinti sambandho. Merumiva🔽nagānanti pabbatānaṃ antare sineruṃ viya. Garuḷamiva dijānanti pakkhijātānaṃ antare
analyzed: pavadantānam kathentānam uttamam kathayantam vadantam adhigacchinti sambandhaḥ merum iva  nagānam ti pabbatānam antare sinerum viya garuḷam iva dijānanti pakkhi jātānam antare
translated: I have attained: the connection is this.🔽Like Meru among the mountains: like Sineru among the mountains.🔽Like Garuda among the birds: like Supaṇṇa among the birds.

original: supaṇṇaṃ viya. Sīhamiva migānanti catuppadānamantare sīhaṃ viya. Udadhimiva aṇṇavānanti
analyzed: su paṇṇam viya sīham iva migānanti catuppadānam antare sīham viya udadhim iva aṇṇavānanti
translated: Like a lion among the beasts: like a lion among the quadrupeds.🔽Like the ocean among the reservoirs of water: like the ocean among the reservoirs of water.

original: vitthiṇṇaaṇṇavānaṃ antare samuddaṃ viya adhigacchiṃ. Jinapavaranti buddhuttamaṃ.
analyzed: antare samuddam viya adhigacchim jina pavaranti buddha uttamam
translated: The Victor, the Free: the supreme Buddha.

original: 106. Yeme pubbeti ye ime pubbe.
analyzed: ye ime pubbe iti ye ime pubbe
translated: Those who in the past: those who in the past.

original: 107. Tamonudāsīnoti tamonudo āsīno. Bhūripaññāṇoti ñāṇaddhajo. Bhūrimedhasoti vipulapañño.
analyzed: tamonuda āsīnaḥ ti tamonudaḥ āsīnaḥ bhūri paññāṇo iti ñāṇaddhajaḥ bhūrimedhaso ti vipula pañño
translated: 107. Tamonudāsīnoti tamonudo āsīno. Bhūripaññāṇoti ñāṇaddhajo. Bhūrimedhasoti vipulapañño.

original: Niddese pabhaṅkaroti tejaṃkaro. Ālokakaroti anandhakārakaro. Obhāsakaroti obhāsaṃ
analyzed: niddese pabhaṅkaroti tejaṃkaro āloka karoti an andhakāra karo obhāsa karoti obhāsaṃ
translated: Niddese pabhaṅkaroti tejaṃkaro. Ālokakaroti anandhakārakaro. Obhāsakaroti obhāsaṃ

original: jotiṃ karotīti obhāsakaro. Dīpasadisaṃ ālokaṃ karotīti dīpaṅkaro. Padīpasadisaṃ ālokaṃ
analyzed: jotim karoti iti obhāsakaraḥ dīpa sadisam ālokam karoti iti dīpaṅkaraḥ upadīpa sadisam ālokam
translated: jotiṃ karotīti obhāsakaro. Dīpasadisaṃ ālokaṃ karotīti dīpaṅkaro. Padīpasadisaṃ ālokaṃ

original: karotīti padīpakaro. Ujjotakaroti patāpakaro. Pajjotakaroti disāvidisā patāpakaro.
analyzed: karoti iti padīpa karo ujjota karoti patāpa karo pajjota karoti disāvidisā patāpa karo
translated: karotīti padīpakaro. Ujjotakaroti patāpakaro. Pajjotakaroti disāvidisā patāpakaro.

original: Bhūripaññāṇoti puthulañāṇo. Ñāṇapaññāṇoti ñāṇena pākaṭo. Paññādhajoti ussitaṭṭhena
analyzed: bhūri paññāṇo ti puthula ñāṇo ñāṇa paññāṇo ti ñāṇena pākaṭaḥ paññā dhajo ti ussita ṭṭhena
translated: Bhūripaññāṇoti puthulañāṇo. Ñāṇapaññāṇoti ñāṇena pākaṭo. Paññādhajoti ussitaṭṭhena

original: paññāva dhajo assāti paññādhajo, dhajo rathassa paññāṇantiādīsu viya. Vibhūtavihārīti pākaṭavihāro.
analyzed: dhajaḥ assa ati paññādhajaḥ dhajaḥ rathassa vibhūta vihārī iti pākaṭa vihāro
translated: paññāva dhajo assāti paññādhajo, dhajo rathassa paññāṇantiādīsu viya. Vibhūtavihārīti pākaṭavihāro.

original: 108. Sandiṭṭhikamakālikanti sāmaṃ passitabbaṃ phalaṃ, na ca kālantare pattabbaphalaṃ. Anītikanti kilesādiītivirahitaṃ.
analyzed: sandiṭṭhikam akālikam ti sāmam passitabbam phalam na ca kāla antare pattabba phalam anītikam ti kilesa ādi īti virahitam
translated: . Sandiṭṭhikamakālikanti sāmaṃ passitabbaṃ phalaṃ, na ca kālantare pattabbaphalaṃ. Anītikanti kilesādiītivirahitaṃ.

original: Sandiṭṭhikanti lokuttaradhammo yena adhigato hoti, tena parasaddhāya gantabbataṃ
analyzed: sandiṭṭhikam ti lokuttara dhammaḥ yena adhigataḥ hoti tena para saddhāya gantabbataṃ
translated: “To be seen here and now”: the supramundane state is to be seen by oneself through reviewing knowledge,

original: hitvā paccavekkhaṇañāṇena sayaṃ daṭṭhabboti sandiṭṭhiko, taṃ sandiṭṭhikaṃ. Attano🔽phalaṃdānaṃ sandhāya nāssa kāloti akālo, akāloyeva akāliko. Yo ettha ariyamaggadhammo,
analyzed: hitvā paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇena sayam daṭṭhabbaḥ ti sandiṭṭhiko tam sandiṭṭhikam attano  phalaṃdānam sandhāya na assa kālo ti akālaḥ akālo yeva akālikaḥ yaḥ ettha ariya magga dhammo
translated: without having to go elsewhere in dependence on the faith of others. That is why it is “to be seen here and now.”

original: so attano samanantarameva phalaṃ detīti attho, taṃ akālikaṃ. Ehi passa imaṃ dhammanti
analyzed: saḥ attanaḥ samanantaram eva phalam deti iti attho tam akālikam ehi passa imam dhamman ti
translated: “Not the wrong time”: it gives its fruit not at the wrong time but at the right time. The meaning is that the noble path here gives its fruit immediately. That is why it is “not the wrong time.”

original: evaṃ pavattaṃ ehipassavidhiṃ arahatīti ehipassiko, taṃ ehipassikaṃ. Ādittaṃ celaṃ
analyzed: evam pavattam ehipassa vidhim arahati iti ehipassikaḥ tam ehipassikam ādittam celam
translated: “Inviting of inspection”: it is worthy of being inspected thus: “Come and see this Dhamma.” That is why it is “inviting of inspection.”

original: vā sīsaṃ vā ajjhupekkhitvāpi attano citte upanayaṃ arahatīti opaneyyiko, taṃ opaneyyikaṃ.🔽Sabbehipi ugghaṭitaññūādīhi “bhāvito me maggo, adhigataṃ phalaṃ, sacchikato nirodho”ti
analyzed: vā sīsam vā ajjhupekkhitvā api attanaḥ citte upanayam arahati iti opaneyyikaḥ tam opaneyyikam  sabbehi pi ugghaṭita ññū ādīhi bhāvitaḥ me maggaḥ adhigatam phalam sacchikataḥ nirodhaḥ ti
translated: “To be realized by the wise for themselves”: it is to be realized by the wise in their own person, even though they are like a burning house or a burning head. That is why it is “to be realized by the wise for themselves.”

original: attani attani veditabbanti paccattaṃ veditabbaṃ viññūhi.
analyzed: attani attani veditabbanti paccattam veditabbam viññūhi
translated: “To be realized”: it is to be realized by all, by those of quick, medium, and low acumen, by those who are of the vehicle of the disciples, the vehicle of the paccekabuddhas, and the vehicle of the Buddhas. That is why it is “to be realized.”

original: 109. Atha naṃ bāvarī āha “kiṃ nu tamhā”ti dve gāthā.
analyzed: atha nam bāvarī āha kim nu tamhā iti dve gāthā
translated: Then Bāvari said to him, “Why leave it? ” in two verses.

original: Muhuttampīti thokampi. Khaṇampīti na bahukampi. Layampīti manampi. Vayampīti koṭṭhāsampi. Addhampīti divasampi.
analyzed: muhuttam pi iti thokam pi khaṇam pi iti na bahukam pi layam pi iti manam pi vayam pi iti koṭṭhāsam pi addham pi iti divasam pi
translated: Muhuttampi, for a moment, for a short time. Khaṇampi, for a moment, not for a long time. Layampi, for a moment, for a short time. Vayampi, for a moment, for a short time. Addhampi, for a day.

original: 111-113. Tato piṅgiyo bhagavato santikā avippavāsameva dīpento “nāhaṃ tamhā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tatas piṅgiyaḥ bhagavato santikā a vippavāsam eva dīpentaḥ na aham tamhā atiādim āha
translated: . Then Piṅgiya, showing that he had not been away from the Blessed One for even a moment, said, “I do not leave it” , etc.🔽Nāhaṃ tamhā, I do not leave it, I do not go away from it.

original: Nāhaṃ yo me…pe… passāmi naṃ manasā cakkhunāvāti taṃ buddhaṃ maṃsacakkhunā viya manasā
analyzed: na aham yaḥ mepe passāmi nam manasā cakkhunā avāti tam buddham maṃsa cakkhunā viya manasā
translated: Passāmi naṃ manasā cakkhunāvāti I see it with my mind as though with the physical eye.

original: passāmi. Namassamāno vivasemi rattinti namassamānova rattiṃ atināmemi.
analyzed: passāmi namassamānaḥ vivasemi rattin ti namassamānaḥ uva rattim atināmemi
translated: Namassamāno vivasemi rattinti I spend the night worshipping it.

original: 114. Tena teneva natoti yena yena disābhāgena buddho, tena tenevāhampi nato, tanninno tappoṇoti dasseti.
analyzed: tena tena iva nataḥ iti yena yena disā bhāgena buddhaḥ tena tena iva aham pi nataḥ tad ninno tad poṇaḥ ti dasseti
translated: . Tene teneva natoti I am bowed in that direction in which the Buddha is. I am inclined towards him, I am intent upon him.

original: 115. Dubbalathāmakassāti appathāmakassa. Atha vā dubbalassa dutthāmakassa ca, balavīriyahīnassāpīti
analyzed: dubbala thāmakassa ati appa thāmakassa atha vā dubbalassa dutthāmakassa ca bala vīriya hīnassa api iti
translated: . Dubbalathāmakassāti of one who is weak and feeble. Or else, of one who is weak and of bad character, of one who is deficient in strength and energy.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Teneva kāyo na paletīti teneva dubbalatthāmakattena kāyo na gacchati,
analyzed: vuttam hoti tena iva kāyaḥ na paleti iti tena iva dubbala tthāmaka ttena kāyaḥ na gacchati
translated: Teneva kāyo na paletīti because of that weakness and feebleness, the body does not go.

original: yena buddho, na tena gacchati. “Na paretī”tipi pāṭho, so evattho. Tatthāti buddhassa🔽santike. Saṅkappayantāyāti saṅkappagamanena. Tena yuttoti yena buddho, tena yutto
analyzed: yena buddhaḥ na tena gacchati na pareti iti pi pāṭhaḥ saḥ tattha ati buddhassa  santike saṅkappayantāya ati saṅkappa gamanena tena yuttaḥ iti yena buddhaḥ tena yuttaḥ
translated: “He does not go” is the reading in the Atthakathā. The meaning is the same.🔽“There” is in the vicinity of the Enlightened One.🔽“He does not go by way of thought” means by way of thought-process.

original: payutto anuyuttoti dasseti.
analyzed: payuttaḥ anuyuttaḥ iti dasseti
translated: “He is endowed with that” shows that he is furnished with, provided with, supplied with, that by which the Enlightened One is reached.

original: Yena buddhoti yena disābhāgena buddho upasaṅkamitabbo, tena disābhāgena na paleti.
analyzed: yena buddhaḥ iti yena disā bhāgena buddhaḥ upasaṅkamitabbo tena disā bhāgena na paleti
translated: “He does not go where the Enlightened One is” means that he does not go by the direction in which the Enlightened One is to be approached.

original: Atha vā bhummatthe karaṇavacanaṃ. Yattha buddho tattha na paleti na gacchati. Na
analyzed: atha vā bhumma atthe karaṇa vacanam yattha buddhaḥ tattha na na gacchati na
translated: Or else, the locative case is used in the sense of the ablative case. He does not go where the Enlightened One is.

original: vajatīti purato na yāti. Na gacchatīti nivattati. Nātikkamatīti na upasaṅkamati.
analyzed: vajati iti puratas na yāti na gacchati iti nivattati na atikkamati iti na upasaṅkamati
translated: “He does not go” means he does not go in front. “He does not go” means he does not turn back. “He does not pass beyond” means he does not approach.

original: 116. Paṅke sayānoti kāmakaddame sayamāno. Dīpā dīpaṃ upallavinti satthārādito satthārādiṃ
analyzed: paṅke sayānaḥ ti kāma kaddame sayamānaḥ dīpāḥ dīpam upallavinti satthārāditaḥ satthārādim
translated: “He lies in the mud” means he lies in the mud of sense desires. “From island to island” means from teacher to teacher.

original: adhigacchiṃ. Athaddasāsiṃ sambuddhanti sohaṃ evaṃ dudiṭṭhiṃ gahetvā anvāhiṇḍanto
analyzed: adhigacchim sambuddha nti saḥ ham evam dudiṭṭhim gahetvā anvāhiṇḍantaḥ
translated: “I have attained” means I have reached. “Then I saw the Enlightened One” means that after I had gone about holding such wrong views,

original: atha pāsāṇakacetiye buddhamaddakkhiṃ.
analyzed: atha pāsāṇaka cetiye buddha maddakkhim
translated: then I saw the Buddha at the Pāsāṇaka Shrine.

original: Tattha semānoti nisajjamāno. Sayamānoti seyyaṃ kappayamāno. Āvasamānoti vasamāno. Parivasamānoti niccaṃ vasamāno.
analyzed: tattha semāno ti nisajjamāno sayamāno iti seyyam kappayamāno āvasamāno iti vasamāno parivasamāno iti niccam vasamāno
translated: Herein, he is sitting means he is sitting down. He is lying means he is making a bed. He is staying means he is staying. He is living means he is living constantly.

original: Pallavinti uggamiṃ. Upallavinti uttariṃ, sampallavinti upasaggena padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ.
analyzed: pallavinti uggamim upallavinti uttarim sampallavinti upasaggena padam vaḍḍhitam
translated: He is growing means he is growing up. He is growing further means he is growing further still. He is growing still further means the word is extended by the prefix upa.

original: Addasanti niddesassa uddesapadaṃ. Addasanti passiṃ. Addakkhinti olokesiṃ. Apassinti
analyzed: addasanti niddesassa uddesa padam addasanti passim addakkhinti olokesim apassinti
translated: He is seeing means this is the name for the description. He is seeing means he is looking. He is looking means he is looking around. He is looking on means

original: esiṃ. Paṭivijjhinti vinivijjhiṃ.
analyzed: esim paṭivijjhinti vinivijjhim
translated: he is looking on. He is penetrating means he is penetrating.

original: 117. Imissā gāthāya avasāne piṅgiyassa ca bāvarissa ca indriyaparipākaṃ viditvā bhagavā
analyzed: imissā gāthāya avasāne piṅgiyassa ca bāvarissa ca indriya paripākam viditvā bhagavā
translated: At the end of this stanza, the Blessed One, having known the ripening of the faculties of Piṅgiya and Bāvari,

analyzed: sāvatthiyam suvaṇṇa ubhāsam piṅgiyaḥ bāvarissa buddha guṇe vaṇṇayantaḥ
translated: while staying at Sāvatthī, emitted a golden radiance. Piṅgiya, while extolling the Buddha’s qualities to Bāvari,

original: nisinno eva taṃ obhāsaṃ disvā “kiṃ ida”nti olokento bhagavantaṃ attano purato ṭhitaṃ
analyzed: nisinnaḥ eva tam obhāsam disvā kim idan ti olokentaḥ bhagavantam puratas ṭhitam
translated: while sitting down, having seen that radiance, asked “What is this?” and looking around, seeing the Blessed One as if standing in front of himself,

original: viya disvā bāvaribrāhmaṇassa “buddho āgato”ti ārocesi. Brāhmaṇo uṭṭhāyāsanā añjaliṃ
analyzed: viya disvā bāvari brāhmaṇassa buddhaḥ āgataḥ iti ārocesi brāhmaṇaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā añjalim
translated: he announced to the brāhmaṇa Bāvari “The Buddha has come.” The brāhmaṇa, having risen from his seat, with hands🔽joined in reverential salutation,

analyzed: sappāyam viditvā piṅgiyam eva ālapamānaḥ yathā imam gātham abhāsi
translated: Knowing that both were ready, he addressed only Piṅgiyānī, saying: “As was the Elder Vakkali, so be you, Vakkali.”

analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yathā vakkali ttheraḥ saddhā adhimuttaḥ ahosi saddhā dhurena iva arahattam pāpuṇi
translated: The meaning is this: As the Elder Vakkali was intent on faith, and by means of faith alone he reached Arahantship,

analyzed: yathā ca ekaḥ bhadrāvudhaḥ nāma yathā ca ca evam eva tvam pi
translated: and as he was one of the sixteen who were called “the good swords,” and as he was the chief of the Āḷavakas, so you too

analyzed: pamuñcassu saddham tatas saddhāya adhimuccantaḥ sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccā ati ādinā nayena
translated: should release your faith. Then, by means of faith, you should resolve thus: “All formations are impermanent,” etc.,

original: vipassanaṃ ārabhitvā maccudheyyassa pāraṃ nibbānaṃ gamissasīti arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ
analyzed: vipassanam ārabhitvā maccudheyyassa pāram nibbānam gamissasi iti arahatta nikūṭena desanam
translated: and beginning insight, you will go to the other side of the realm of Death, to Nibbāna. Thus he concluded his teaching with the peak of the Dhamma, Arahantship.

original: niṭṭhāpesi, desanāpariyosāne piṅgiyo arahatte, bāvarī anāgāmiphale patiṭṭhahi, bāvaribrāhmaṇassa
analyzed: niṭṭhāpesi desanā pariyosāne piṅgiyaḥ arahatte bāvarī anāgāmi phale patiṭṭhahi bāvari brāhmaṇassa
translated: At the conclusion of the teaching Piṅgiyānī was established in Arahantship, and Bāvari in the fruit of Non-Returner. Bāvari’s pupils,

analyzed: sissāḥ pana pañcasatā sotāpannāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: five hundred in number, were established in the fruit of Stream-Entry.

original: Niddese pārāyanikapañhānanti pārāyanikabrāhmaṇānaṃ pucchānaṃ. Avasānaṃ karotīti antakaro.
analyzed: niddese pārāyanika pañhānam ti pārāyanika brāhmaṇānam pucchānam avasānam karoti iti
translated: In the niddesa : “Pārāyanika-questions” : questions of the Pārāyanika Brahmins. “Makes an end” : he makes an end of it.

analyzed: koṭim karoti iti sīmam mariyādam karoti iti pariccheda karaḥ nigamam karoti iti
translated: “Makes a limit” : he makes a limit to it. “Makes a boundary” : he makes a boundary to it. “Makes a definition” :

analyzed: na kevalam pārāyanika brāhmaṇānam eva
translated: he makes a definition to it. “Sabhiya-questions” : not only the questions of the Pārāyanika Brahmins,

analyzed: rāga ādīhi asaṃhāriyam a saṅkuppanti a saṅkuppam a vipariṇāma dhammam
translated: “Unshakeable” : unshakeable by lust and so on. “Unstirred” : unstirred, unchangeable.
