translated: and letting go of it by means of faith, he revealed that faith-resolution to the Exalted One, saying: “Thus should you bear me in mind, with a resolved heart.” The meaning is: “Just as you have said, so should you bear me in mind, with a resolved heart.”

original: Na saṃhariyatīti gahetvā saṃharituṃ na sakkā. Niyogavacananti yuttavacanaṃ. Avatthāpanavacananti🔽sanniṭṭhānavacanaṃ. Imasmiṃ pārāyanavagge yaṃ antarantarā na vuttaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayena
analyzed: na saṃhariyati iti gahetvā saṃharitum na sakkā niyoga vacananti yutta vacanam avatthāpana vacananti  sanniṭṭhāna vacanam imasmin pārāyana vagge yam antar antarā na vuttam tam heṭṭhā vutta nayena
translated: “It cannot be gathered up”: having taken it, it cannot be gathered up again. “A statement of appointment”: a proper statement. “A statement of establishment”:

original: gahetabbaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha pākaṭameva.🔽Saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷaniddesa-aṭṭhakathāya🔽Pārāyanānugītigāthāniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Pārāyanavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Khaggavisāṇasuttaniddeso
analyzed: gahetabbam sesam sabbattha pākaṭam eva 🔽saddhammappajjotikāya cūḷa niddesa aṭṭhakathāya 🔽              🔽pārāyana vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽khaggavisāṇa sutta niddeso
translated: a statement of conclusion. What has not been stated in the middle of this chapter on the Pārāyanavagga should be understood by the method stated below. The rest is clear throughout.

original: Khaggavisāṇasuttaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: khaggavisāṇa sutta niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the Khaggavisāṇa Sutta

original: 1. Paṭhamavaggavaṇṇanā🔽121. Ito paraṃ khaggavisāṇasuttaniddesavaṇṇanāya okāso anuppatto. Tattha “sabbesu🔽bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍa”nti ito paraṃ atirekapadamattameva vaṇṇayissāma. Tattha sabbesūti🔽anavasesesu. Bhūtesūti sattesu. Ettha bhūtesūti kiñcāpi bhūtasaddo “bhūtasmiṃ pācittiya”nti
analyzed: paṭhama vagga vaṇṇanā  itas param khaggavisāṇa sutta niddesa vaṇṇanāya okāsaḥ anuppatto tattha sabbesu  bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍanti itas param atireka pada mattam eva vaṇṇayissāma tattha sabbesu iti  anavasesesu bhūtesu iti sattesu ettha bhūtesu iti kiñcā api bhūta saddaḥ bhūtasmim pācittiyanti
translated: Commentary on the First Chapter

original: evamādīsu vijjamāne, “bhūtamidaṃ, sāriputta, samanupassasī”ti evamādīsu khandhapañcake,
analyzed: evamādīsu vijjamāne bhūtam idam sāriputta samanupassasi iti evamādīsu khandha pañcake
translated: Now comes the turn for the commentary on the Khaggavisāṇa Sutta. Herein, we shall comment only on the additional words beginning with “having laid aside the rod of violence towards all beings.” Herein, all means without exception. Beings means living beings. Herein, although the word “bhūta” is found in such passages as “in a bhūta, an offence requiring a formal meeting of the Order” , in such passages as “Sāriputta, do you see this bhūta?” it is the five categories of aggregates that are meant;

original: “cattāro kho, bhikkhu, mahābhūtā hetū”ti evamādīsu catubbidhe pathavīdhātvādirūpe,🔽“yo ca kālaghaso bhūto”ti evamādīsu khīṇāsave, “sabbeva nikkhipissanti, bhūtā loke
analyzed: cattāraḥ kho bhikkhu mahābhūtāḥ hetu uti evamādīsu catubbidhe pathavī dhātu ādi rūpe  yaḥ ca kālaghasaḥ bhūtaḥ ti evamādīsu khīṇāsave sabbe iva nikkhipissanti bhūtāḥ loke
translated: in such passages as “Bhikkhu, the four great entities are the cause” , it is the fourfold materiality beginning with the earth element that is meant;

original: samussaya”nti evamādīsu sabbasatte, “bhūtagāmapātabyatāyā”ti evamādīsu rukkhādike,
analyzed: evamādīsu sabba satte evamādīsu rukkha ādike
translated: in such passages as “the bhūta that devours time” , it is those who have destroyed the cankers that are meant; in such passages as “all beings will lay aside their bodies in the world” , it is all living beings that are meant; in such passages as “for the purpose of avoiding the destruction of plants and trees” , it is trees, etc., that are meant;

original: “bhūtaṃ bhūtato pajānātī”ti evamādīsu cātumahārājikānaṃ heṭṭhā sattanikāyaṃ upādāya
analyzed: bhūtam bhūtataḥ pajānāti iti evamādīsu cātumahārājikānam heṭṭhā satta nikāyam upādāya
translated: and in such passages as “He knows what is the case as what is the case” ,🔽

original: vattati. Idha pana avisesato pathavīpabbatādīsu jātā sattā bhūtāti veditabbā. Tesu
analyzed: vattati idha pana avisesato pathavī pabbata ādīsu jātā sattā bhūtā ati veditabbā tesu
translated: In such passages as “He understands what is the case as what is the case” , it occurs with reference to the class of beings below the Four Kings. But here it should be understood in the non-specific sense of “beings” in the earth, mountains, etc.

original: bhūtesu. Nidhāyāti nikkhipitvā.🔽Daṇḍanti kāyavacīmanodaṇḍaṃ, kāyaduccaritādīnametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Kāyaduccaritañhi🔽daṇḍayatīti daṇḍo, bādheti anayabyasanaṃ pāpetīti vuttaṃ hoti. Evaṃ vacīduccaritañca
analyzed: bhūtesu nidhāya ati nikkhipitvā  daṇḍanti kāya vacī manaḥ daṇḍam adhivacanam kāya duccaritam hi  daṇḍayati iti daṇḍaḥ bādheti anaya byasanam pāpeti iti vuttam evam vacīduccaritam ca
translated: “Having laid aside the stick against all beings”: having put away the stick against all beings.🔽“The stick”: this is a term for the stick of body, speech, and mind. For bodily misconduct, etc.,

original: manoduccaritañca. Paharaṇadaṇḍo eva vā daṇḍo, taṃ nidhāyātipi vuttaṃ hoti. Aviheṭhayanti
analyzed: manaḥ uduccaritam ca paharaṇa daṇḍo eva vā daṇḍo tam vuttam hoti a viheṭhayanti
translated: are a “stick” because they “stick” to the body, etc., that is, because they afflict them and bring them to ruin. So too, verbal misconduct and mental misconduct are sticks. Or the “stick” is the stick for striking, and it is said “having laid aside” in order to include that.🔽“Without afflicting”: without afflicting others.🔽“Any one of them”: any one of them, any single one.

original: aviheṭhayanto. Aññatarampīti yaṃ kiñci ekampi. Tesampīti tesaṃ sabbabhūtānaṃ. Na🔽puttamiccheyyāti atrajo khettajo dinnako antevāsikoti imesu catūsu puttesu yaṃ kiñci
analyzed: a viheṭhayantaḥ aññataram pi iti yam kiñci ekam pi tesam pi iti tesam sabba bhūtānam na  puttam iccheyyāti atra jaḥ khetta jaḥ dinnakaḥ antevāsikaḥ iti imesu catūsu puttesu yam kiñci
translated: “Of them”: of all those beings.🔽“Would not wish for a son”: he would not wish for any one of the four kinds of sons, namely, the born son, the purchased son, the adopted son, and the son made by sorcery.

original: puttaṃ na iccheyya. Kuto sahāyanti sahāyaṃ pana iccheyyāti kuto eva etaṃ.
analyzed: puttam naḥ iccheyya kutas sahāyanti sahāyam pana iccheyya ati kutas eva etam
translated: “How much less a friend”: how much less would he wish for a friend?

original: Ekoti pabbajjāsaṅkhātena eko, adutiyaṭṭhena eko, taṇhāpahānaṭṭhena eko, ekantavigatakilesoti
analyzed: ekaḥ ti pabbajjā saṅkhātena ekaḥ adutiya ṭhena ekaḥ taṇhā apahāna ṭṭhena ekaḥ ekanta vigata kileso ti
translated: He is one in the sense of going forth, in the sense of being without a second, in the sense of abandoning craving, in the sense of being absolutely free from defilements,

original: eko, eko paccekasambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti eko. Samaṇasahassassapi hi majjhe vattamāno
analyzed: ekaḥ ekaḥ pacceka sambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ ti ekaḥ samaṇa sahassassa api hi majjhe vattamāno
translated: and in the sense of being fully enlightened in the supreme enlightenment of a Paccekabuddha. Even though he may be in the midst of a thousand monks,

original: gihisaññojanassa chinnattā eko, evaṃ pabbajjāsaṅkhātena eko. Eko tiṭṭhati, eko gacchati,
analyzed: gihi saññojanassa chinna ttā ekaḥ evam pabbajjā saṅkhātena ekaḥ ekaḥ tiṭṭhati ekaḥ gacchati
translated: he is one because he has cut off the fetters of the householder. Thus he is one in the sense of going forth. He stands alone, he walks alone,

original: eko nisīdati, eko seyyaṃ kappeti, eko iriyati vattatīti eko. Evaṃ adutiyaṭṭhena eko.
analyzed: ekaḥ nisīdati ekaḥ seyyam kappeti ekaḥ iriyati vattati iti ekaḥ evam adutiya ṭṭhena ekaḥ
translated: he sits alone, he lies down alone, he is alone and behaves alone. Thus he is one in the sense of being without a second.🔽“The man who has a craving for a second,

original: “Taṇhādutiyo puriso, dīghamaddhāna saṃsaraṃ;
analyzed: taṇhā dutiyaḥ purisaḥ saṃsaram
translated: wandering on for a long time,

original: Itthabhāvaññathābhāvaṃ, saṃsāraṃ nātivattati.
analyzed: itthabhāva aññathābhāvam saṃsāram na ativattati
translated: does not escape from the round of rebirths, from this state to that.”

original: “Evamādīnavaṃ ñatvā, taṇhaṃ dukkhassa sambhavaṃ;
analyzed: evam ādīnavam ñatvā taṇham dukkhassa sambhavam
translated: “Having understood the danger in craving, which is the origin of suffering,

original: Vītataṇho anādāno, sato bhikkhu paribbaje”ti. –
analyzed: vīta taṇhaḥ anādāno sataḥ bhikkhu paribbajeti
translated: the monk should wander mindfully, free from craving and grasping.”

original: Evaṃ taṇhāpahānaṭṭhena eko. Sabbakilesāssa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā
analyzed: evam taṇhā pahāna ṭṭhena ekaḥ sabba kilesā assa pahīnā ucchinna mūlā tālāvatthuka tā anabhāvaṃkatā
translated: Thus he is one in the sense of abandoning craving. All his defilements are abandoned, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so that they are no longer subject to future arising.

original: āyatiṃ anuppādadhammāti evaṃ ekantavigatakilesoti eko. Anācariyako hutvā sayambhū
analyzed: āyatim an uppāda dhammā ati evam ekanta vigata kileso ti ekaḥ an ācariyakaḥ hutvā sayambhū
translated: “It will not arise again in the future” : thus he is “alone” in being utterly rid of defilements.🔽Without a teacher, self-dependent,

original: sāmaññeva paccekasambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti evaṃ eko paccekasambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti eko.
analyzed: sāmaññā iva pacceka sambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ ti evam ekaḥ pacceka sambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ ti ekaḥ
translated: he has awakened to the supreme enlightenment by himself. Thus he is “alone” in having awakened to the supreme enlightenment by himself.🔽“He goes” : there are eight kinds of going:

original: Careti yā imā aṭṭha cariyāyo. Seyyathidaṃ – yā paṇidhisampannānaṃ catūsu iriyāpathesu
analyzed: cara iti yāḥ imāḥ aṭṭha cariyāyo sā iyyathidam yā paṇidhi sampannānam catūsu iriyāpathesu
translated: The going of those endowed with the aspiration for the four postures

original: iriyāpathacariyā, indriyesu guttadvārānaṃ ajjhattikāyatanesu āyatanacariyā, appamādavihārīnaṃ
analyzed: iriyāpatha cariyā indriyesu gutta dvārānam ajjhattika āyatanesu āyatana cariyā appamāda vihārīnam
translated: in the four postures; the going of those who guard the doors of the sense faculties in the internal sense bases; the going of those who dwell in heedfulness

original: catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu saticariyā, adhicittamanuyuttānaṃ catūsu jhānesu samādhicariyā,🔽buddhisampannānaṃ catūsu ariyasaccesu ñāṇacariyā, sammā paṭipannānaṃ catūsu ariyamaggesu
analyzed: catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu sati cariyā catūsu jhānesu samādhi cariyā  buddhi sampannānam catūsu ariya saccesu ñāṇa cariyā sammā paṭipannānam catūsu ariya maggesu
translated: in the four foundations of mindfulness; the going of those who are devoted to the higher mind in the four jhanas;🔽the going of those who are endowed with wisdom in the four noble truths; the going of those who are on the right path in the four noble paths;

original: maggacariyā, adhigataphalānaṃ catūsu sāmaññaphalesu paṭipatticariyā, tiṇṇaṃ buddhānaṃ
analyzed: magga cariyā adhigata phalānam catūsu sāmañña phalesu paṭipatti cariyā tiṇṇam buddhānam
translated: the going of those who have attained the fruits in the four fruits of recluseship; and the going of the three Buddhas🔽in the welfare of all beings. Herein, “in part” refers to the Paccekabuddhas and disciples,

original: sabbasattesu lokatthacariyā, tattha padesato paccekabuddhasāvakānanti. Yathāha –
analyzed: sabba sattesu lokattha cariyā tattha padesatas paccekabuddha sāvakānam ti yathā āha
translated: as it is said:

original: “cariyāti aṭṭha cariyāyo yā iriyāpathacariyā”ti vitthāro. Tāhi cariyāhi samannāgato🔽bhaveyyāti attho. Atha vā yā imā “adhimuccanto saddhāya carati, paggaṇhanto vīriyena🔽carati, upaṭṭhahanto satiyā carati, avikkhitto samādhinā carati, pajānanto paññāya🔽carati, vijānanto viññāṇena carati, evaṃ paṭipannassa kusalā dhammā āyāpentīti āyatanacariyāya🔽carati, evaṃ paṭipanno visesamadhigacchatīti visesacariyāya caratī”ti evaṃ aparāpi
analyzed: cariyā ati aṭṭha cariyāyaḥ yāḥ iriyāpatha cariyā ati vitthāro tāhi cariyāhi samannāgato  bhaveyya ati atthaḥ atha vā yāḥ imāḥ adhimuccantaḥ saddhāya carati paggaṇhantaḥ vīriyena  carati upaṭṭhahantaḥ satiyā carati a vikkhittaḥ samādhinā carati pajānantaḥ paññāya  carati vijānantaḥ viññāṇena carati evam paṭipannassa kusalāḥ dhammāḥ āyāpenti iti āyatana cariyāya  carati evam paṭipannaḥ visesam adhigacchati iti visesa cariyāya carati iti evam aparā api
translated: The meaning is that he would be endowed with these practices.

original: aṭṭha cariyā vuttā. Tāhi samannāgato bhaveyyāti attho. Khaggavisāṇakappoti khaggavisāṇo
analyzed: aṭṭha cariyā vuttā tāhi samannāgataḥ bhaveyya ati attho khagga visāṇa kappo ti khagga visāṇaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, there are also the following eight practices stated thus: “One who is resolved practices with faith, one who is energetic practices with energy, one who is mindful practices with mindfulness, one who is concentrated practices with concentration, one who understands practices with understanding, one who is conscious practices with consciousness, one who is practising the practice of the sense bases practices thus: ‘When I am practising in this way wholesome states of consciousness and its concomitants will enter and remain and be resolved upon in me,’ one who is practising the practice of distinction practices thus: ‘When I am practising in this way I shall attain distinction in the fruit of stream-entry or in the fruit of once-returner or in the fruit of non-returner or in the fruit of arahantship’” .🔽The meaning is that he would be endowed with these.

original: nāma khaggamigasiṅgaṃ.
analyzed: nāma khagga miga siṅgam
translated: The “practice of the rhinoceros” is the practice of the rhinoceros-like .

original: Kappa -saddo panāyaṃ abhisaddahanavohārakālapaññatticchedavikappalesasamantabhāvasadisādianekattho.
analyzed: kappa saddaḥ pana ayam abhisaddahana vohāra kāla paññatti cheda vikappa lesa samanta bhāva sadisa ādi aneka atthaḥ
translated: The word kappa is of many meanings: it means “belief,” “expression,” “time,” “definition,” “division,” “distinction,” “part,” “all round,” and so on.

original: Tathā hissa “okappanīyametaṃ bhoto gotamassa. Yathā taṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā”ti
analyzed: tathā hi ssa okappanīyam etam bhoto gotamassa yathā tam arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa ati
translated: For in such passages as “This is to be believed by the Blessed One, accomplished and fully enlightened” ,

original: evamādīsu abhisaddahanattho. “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, pañcahi samaṇakappehi phalaṃ🔽paribhuñjitu”nti evamādīsu vohāro. “Yena sudaṃ niccakappaṃ viharāmī”ti evamādīsu
analyzed: evamādīsu abhisaddahana atthaḥ anujānāmi bhikkhave pañcahi samaṇa kappehi phalam  paribhuñjitum ti evamādīsu vohāraḥ yena sudam nicca kappam viharāmi iti evamādīsu
translated: the meaning is that of confidence. In such passages as “Monks, I allow you to eat fruit after five kinds of work have been done to it” ,🔽the meaning is that of usage. In such passages as “Where I used to go for my meals” ,🔽the meaning is that of time. In such passages as “So the venerable Kappa” ,

original: kālo. “Iccāyasmā kappo”ti evamādīsu paññatti. “Alaṅkato kappitakesamassū”ti evamādīsu
analyzed: kālo evamādīsu paññatti alaṅkato kappita kesa massū ti evamādīsu
translated: the meaning is that of designation. In such passages as “Having trimmed his hair and beard” ,

original: chedanaṃ. “Kappati dvaṅgulakappo”ti evamādīsu vikappo. “Atthi kappo nipajjitu”nti
analyzed: chedanam kappati dvaṅgula kappo ti evamādīsu vikappaḥ atthi kappo nipajjitunti
translated: the meaning is that of cutting. In such passages as “Is a two-finger-breadths’ capacity allowed?” ,🔽the meaning is that of a measure. In such passages as “There is room to lie down” ,

original: evamādīsu leso. “Kevalakappaṃ veḷuvanaṃ obhāsetvā”ti evamādīsu samantabhāvo. “Satthukappena
analyzed: evamādīsu lesaḥ kevala kappam veḷuvanam obhāsetvā ati evamādīsu samanta bhāvaḥ satthu kappena
translated: the meaning is that of a space. In such passages as “Having lit up the whole of the Bamboo Grove” ,

original: vata kira, bho, sāvakena saddhiṃ mantayamānā na jānimhā”ti evamādīsu sadiso, paṭibhāgoti
analyzed: vata kira bho sāvakena saddhim mantayamānāḥ na jānimha ati evamādīsu sadisaḥ paṭibhāgaḥ ti
translated: the meaning is that of all round. In such passages as “We did not know that we were conversing with a disciple who was the equal of a Master” ,

original: attho. Idha panassa sadiso paṭibhāgoti attho veditabbo, khaggavisāṇasadisoti vuttaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ idha pana assa sadisaḥ paṭibhāgaḥ ti atthaḥ veditabbaḥ khagga visāṇa sadisaḥ ti vuttam
translated: the meaning is that of a counterpart, that is, a match. But here the meaning should be understood as a counterpart, a match, like the horn of the rhinoceros.

original: hoti. Ayaṃ tāvettha padato atthavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: ayam tāva ettha padataḥ attha vaṇṇanā
translated: This, firstly, is the word-commentary here.

original: Adhippāyānusandhito pana evaṃ veditabbo – yvāyaṃ vuttappakāro daṇḍo bhūtesu pavattiyamāno
analyzed: adhippāya anusandhito pana evam veditabbaḥ yvā ayam vutta ppakāraḥ daṇḍaḥ bhūtesu pavattiyamānaḥ
translated: But the meaning should be understood in this way according to the purport: the kind of punishment that, when inflicted on creatures,

original: ahito hoti, taṃ tesu appavattiyamānesu tappaṭipakkhabhūtāya mettāya hitūpasaṃhārena
analyzed: ahitaḥ hoti tam tesu appavattiyamānesu tad paṭipakkha bhūtāya mettāya hitu upasaṃhārena
translated: is harmful, when that is not inflicted on them, then, by the inclusion of welfare in the form of its opposite, namely, loving-kindness,

original: ca sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍaṃ, nihitadaṇḍattā eva ca yathā anihitadaṇḍā sattā
analyzed: ca sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍam nihita daṇḍa ttā eva ca yathā a nihita daṇḍā sattā
translated: and by laying aside the punishment for all creatures, and by the laying aside of the stick, just as creatures who have not laid aside the stick

original: bhūtāni daṇḍena vā satthena vā pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā viheṭhenti, tathā aviheṭhayaṃ,
analyzed: bhūtāni daṇḍena vā satthena vā pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā viheṭhenti tathā a viheṭhayam
translated: harm creatures with the stick or with a knife or with a clod of earth or with a whip, so he does not harm them;

original: aññatarampi tesaṃ imaṃ mettākammaṭṭhānamāgamma yadeva tattha vedanāgataṃ saññāsaṅkhāraviññāṇagataṃ
analyzed: aññataram pi tesam imam mettā kammaṭṭhānam āgamma yat eva tattha vedanā gatam saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇa gatam
translated: and he has done so by means of this meditation subject of loving-kindness, and he has seen whatever is included in feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness there,

original: tañca tadanusāreneva tadaññañca saṅkhāragataṃ vipassitvā imaṃ paccekabodhiṃ adhigatomhī”ti
analyzed: tat ca tad anusārena iva tad aññam ca saṅkhāra gatam vipassitvā imam pacceka bodhim adhigataḥ asmi iti
translated: and by inference from that he has seen whatever is included in formations here, and so he has reached this paccekabuddha enlightenment.”

original: ayaṃ tāva adhippāyo.
analyzed: ayam tāva adhippāyaḥ
translated: This, firstly, is the purport.

original: Ayaṃ pana anusandhi – evaṃ vutte te amaccā āhaṃsu – “idāni, bhante, kuhiṃ gacchathā”ti?
analyzed: ayam pana anusandhi evam vutte te amaccāḥ āhaṃsu idāni bhante kuhim gacchatha ati
translated: But the connexion is this. When this was said, the ministers said, “Where will your reverence go now?”

original: Tato tena “pubbapaccekasambuddhā kattha vasantī”ti āvajjetvā ñatvā “gandhamādanapabbate”ti
analyzed: tatas tena pubba paccekasambuddhāḥ kattha vasanti iti āvajjetvā ñatvā gandhamādana pabbata iti
translated: Then he thought: “Where did the former Private Buddhas live?” and knowing that they had lived on the Gandhamādana mountain,

original: vutte punāhaṃsu – “amhe dāni, bhante, pajahatha, na icchathā”ti. Atha paccekabuddho🔽āha – “na puttamiccheyyā”ti sabbaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ adhippāyo – ahaṃ idāni atrajādīsu yaṃ🔽kiñci puttampi na iccheyyaṃ, kuto pana tumhādisaṃ sahāyaṃ. Tasmā tumhesupi yo mayā
analyzed: vutte amhe dāni bhante pajahatha naḥ icchatha ati atha paccekabuddhaḥ  āha na puttam iccheyya iti sabbam tatra ayam adhippāyaḥ aham idāni atraja ādīsu yam  kiñci naḥ iccheyyam kutas pana tumhādisam sahāyam tasmā yaḥ mayā
translated: he said: “Now, Reverend Sir, you must abandon us, you do not wish us.” Then the Private Buddha said:

original: saddhiṃ gantukāmo mādiso vā hotuṃ icchati, so eko care khaggavisāṇakappo. Atha vā🔽tehi “amhe dāni, bhante, pajahatha, na icchathā”ti vutte so paccekasambuddho “na🔽puttamiccheyya, kuto sahāya”nti vatvā attano yathāvuttenaṭṭhena ekacariyāya guṇaṃ
analyzed: saddhim gantu kāmaḥ mādisaḥ vā hotum icchati saḥ ekaḥ care khagga visāṇa kappo atha vā  tehi amhe dāni bhante pajahatha na icchatha ati vutte so paccekasambuddhaḥ na  puttam iccheyya kutas sahāyanti vatvā attanaḥ yathāvuttena ṭṭhena eka cariyāya guṇaṃ
translated: “I would not wish a son,” etc. The meaning is this: I would not wish even a son, etc., among these, what to say of a friend like you. Therefore, if anyone wishes to go with me, or to be like me, he should go alone, like the horn of the rhinoceros. Or else,

original: disvā pamudito pītisomanassajāto imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: disvā pamuditaḥ pīti somanassa jātaḥ imam udānaṃ udānesi
translated: when they said: “Now, Reverend Sir, you must abandon us, you do not wish us,” that Private Buddha said: “I would not wish a son, what to say of a friend?” and seeing the virtue of his going alone in the sense stated by himself, he was delighted, and being filled with joy and gladness, he uttered this exclamation.

original: Tattha tasāti vipāsakiriyā. Thāvarāti khīṇāsavā. Bhayabheravāti khuddānukhuddakā
analyzed: tattha tasā ati vipāsa kiriyā thāvarā ati khīṇa āsavā bhaya bheravā ati khuddānukhuddakā
translated: Herein, tas is the act of relishing. Thāvaras are those whose cankers are destroyed. Bhayabheravas are the lesser and greater terrors of the heart.

original: cittutrāsā. Nidhāyāti chaḍḍetvā. Nidahitvāti ṭhapetvā. Oropayitvāti adhokaritvā.
analyzed: cittu trāsāḥ nidhāya ati chaḍḍetvā nidahitvā ati ṭhapetvā oropayitvā ati adhas karitvā
translated: Nidhāya is having laid aside. Nidahitvā is having put away. Oropayitvā is having let go.

original: Samoropayitvāti adhogataṃ vissajjetvā. Nikkhipitvāti tato apanetvā. Paṭippassambhitvāti sannisīdāpetvā.
analyzed: samoropayitvā ati adhas gatam vissajjetvā nikkhipitvā ati tatas apanetvā paṭippassambhitvā ati sannisīdāpetvā
translated: Samoropayitvā is having let go of what has gone below. Nikkhipitvā is having removed. Paṭippassambhitvā is having calmed down.

original: Ālapananti ādito lapanaṃ. Sallapananti sammā lapanaṃ. Ullapananti uddhaṃ katvā lapanaṃ. Samullapananti punappunaṃ uddhaṃ katvā lapanaṃ.
analyzed: ālapananti āditas lapanam sallapananti sammā lapanam ullapananti uddham katvā lapanam samullapananti punappunam uddham katvā lapanam
translated: Ālapanā is talking at the beginning. Sallapanā is talking properly. Ullapanā is talking with a high voice. Samullapanā is talking with a high voice again and again.

original: Iriyāpathacariyāti iriyāpathānaṃ cariyā, pavattananti attho. Sesesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: iriyāpatha cariyā ti iriyāpathānam cariyā pavattananti attho sesesu pi esa eva nayo
translated: Iriyāpathacariyā is the conduct of the postures; the meaning is, the occurrence of the postures. The same method applies in the other cases.

original: Āyatanacariyā pana āyatanesu satisampajaññānaṃ cariyā. Pattīti phalāni. Tāni hi pāpuṇīyantīti
analyzed: āyatana cariyā pana āyatanesu sati sampajaññānam cariyā pattī iti phalāni tāni hi pāpuṇīyanti iti
translated: Āyatana-cariyā is the conduct of mindfulness and full awareness in the sense bases. Pattī is fruits. They are so called because they are reached .

original: “pattī”ti vuttāni. Sattalokassa diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikā atthā lokatthāti ayaṃ viseso.
analyzed: patti iti vuttāni satta lokassa diṭṭhadhammika samparāyikāḥ atthāḥ loka tthā ti ayam viseso
translated: The difference between them is this. The world’s weal is the good of the world of beings in the present life and the life to come.

original: Idāni tāsaṃ cariyānaṃ bhūmiṃ dassento “catūsu iriyāpathesū”tiādimāha. Satipaṭṭhānesūti
analyzed: idāni tāsam cariyānam bhūmim dassento catūsu iriyāpathesu uti ādim āha sati paṭṭhānesu iti
translated: Now, showing the plane of these practices, he said “in the four postures” .

original: ārammaṇasatipaṭṭhānesupi vuccamānesu satito anaññāni, vohāravasena pana aññāni viya
analyzed: ārammaṇa sati paṭṭhānesu pi vuccamānesu satitaḥ anaññāni vohāra vasena pana aññāni viya
translated: In the foundations of mindfulness : although the foundations of mindfulness are spoken of as objects of mindfulness, they are not different from mindfulness. But they are stated as if they were different by way of designation.

original: katvā vuttaṃ. Ariyasaccesūti pubbabhāge lokiyasaccañāṇena visuṃ visuṃ saccapariggahavasena
analyzed: katvā vuttam ariya saccesu iti pubba bhāge lokiya sacca ñāṇena visum visum sacca pariggaha vasena
translated: In the noble truths : this is said by way of the noble truth of the path in the preliminary stage, by way of the knowledge of the mundane noble truth, and by way of the discernment of the truth in each case.

original: vuttaṃ. Ariyamaggesu sāmaññaphalesūti ca vohāravaseneva vuttaṃ. Padesatoti lokatthacariyāya
analyzed: vuttam ariya maggesu sāmañña phalesu iti ca vohāra vasena iva vuttam padesatas ti lokattha cariyāya
translated: In the noble paths and fruits : this is said by way of designation.🔽In part : in one part of the practice of benefitting the world.

original: ekadese. Nippadesato hi lokatthacariyaṃ buddhā eva karonti. Puna tā eva cariyāyo
analyzed: ekadese nippadesataḥ hi lokattha cariyam buddhāḥ eva karonti puna tāḥ eva
translated: For the Buddhas alone practice the benefitting of the world in its entirety.

original: kārakapuggalavasena dassento “paṇidhisampannāna”ntiādimāha. Tattha paṇidhisampannā🔽nāma iriyāpathānaṃ santattā iriyāpathāva ṭhitiyā sampannā akampitairiyāpathā bhikkhubhāvānurūpena
analyzed: kāraka puggala vasena dassentaḥ paṇidhi sampannānaṃ ti ādim āha tattha paṇidhi sampannā  nāma iriyāpathānam santattāḥ iriyāpathā ava ṭhitiyā sampannāḥ a kampita eriyāpathāḥ bhikkhu bhāva anurūpena
translated: Again, showing these very practices by way of the person who practices, he said “by those who are endowed with the vow” .

original: santena iriyāpathena sampannā.
analyzed: santena iriyāpathena sampannā
translated: Herein, those who are endowed with the vow are those who are endowed with the vow of the postures. They are endowed with the postures by way of the stability of the postures. They are endowed with the postures that are unshakable. They are endowed with the postures that are stable in accordance with the state of a bhikkhu.

original: Indriyesu guttadvārānanti cakkhādīsu chasu indriyesu attano attano visaye pavattaṃ
analyzed: indriyesu cakkha ādīsu chasu indriyesu attanaḥ attanaḥ visaye pavattam
translated: “Who guard the doors of the sense faculties”: they guard the doors of the six faculties, the eye, etc., by not allowing the eye faculty, etc., to grasp the sign and the particulars of the sense objects that come into their range.

original: ekekadvāravasena guttaṃ dvāraṃ etesanti guttadvārā, tesaṃ guttadvārānaṃ. Dvāranti🔽cettha uppattidvāravasena cakkhādayo eva. Appamādavihārīnanti sīlādīsu appamādavihāravataṃ.
analyzed: ekeka dvāra vasena guttam dvāram etesanti gutta dvārā tesam gutta dvārāṇam dvāranti  ca ittha uppatti dvāra vasena cakkha ādayaḥ eva sīla ādīsu
translated: “Who are moderate in eating”: they eat in moderation, not for the sake of enjoyment, not for the sake of physical beauty and attractiveness.

original: Adhicittamanuyuttānanti vipassanāya pādakabhāvena adhicittasaṅkhātaṃ samādhiṃ anuyuttānaṃ.🔽Buddhisampannānanti nāmarūpavavatthānaṃ ādiṃ katvā yāva gotrabhu, tāva pavattena
analyzed: adhicittam anuyuttānam ti vipassanāya pādaka bhāvena adhicitta saṅkhātam samādhim anuyuttānam  ādim katvā yāva tāva
translated: “Who are devoted to wakefulness”: they are devoted to the practice of wakefulness, to the practice of the four foundations of mindfulness.🔽“Who are strenuous”: they are strenuous in the practice of the seven factors of enlightenment.🔽“Who are mindful”: they are mindful in the practice of the four establishments of mindfulness.

original: ñāṇena sampannānaṃ. Sammā paṭipannānanti catumaggakkhaṇe. Adhigataphalānanti catuphalakkhaṇe.
analyzed: ñāṇena sampannānam sammā paṭipannānam ti catu magga kkhaṇe adhigata phalānam ti catu phala kkhaṇe
translated: “Who are wise”: they are wise in the practice of the five spiritual faculties.🔽“Who are of right livelihood”: they are of right livelihood in the practice of the four right strivings.🔽“Who are of right effort”: they are of right effort in the practice of the four foundations of mindfulness.🔽“Who are of right mindfulness”: they are of right mindfulness in the practice of the seven factors of enlightenment.🔽“Who are of right concentration”: they are of right concentration in the practice of the Noble Eightfold Path.

original: Tathāgatānanti tathā āgatānaṃ. Arahantānanti dūrakilesānaṃ. Sammāsambuddhānanti sammā🔽sāmañca sabbadhammabuddhānaṃ. Imesaṃ padānaṃ attho heṭṭhā pakāsito eva.
analyzed: tathāgatānam anti tathā āgatānam arahantānam anti dūra kilesānam sammāsambuddhānam anti sammā 🔽sāmañca sabba dhamma buddhānam imesam padānam atthaḥ heṭṭhā pakāsitaḥ eva
translated: “Who are of right wisdom”: they are of right wisdom in the practice of the four noble truths.🔽“Who are of right liberation”: they are of right liberation in the practice of the three true knowledges.

original: Padesato paccekabuddhānanti paccekasambuddhānaṃ ekadesato. Sāvakānanti sāvakānampi🔽ekadesato. Adhimuccantoti adhimokkhaṃ karonto. Saddhāya caratīti saddhāvasena pavattati.🔽Paggaṇhantoti catusammappadhānavīriyena padahanto. Upaṭṭhapentoti satiyā ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: padesataḥ paccekabuddhānam ti paccekasambuddhānam eka desataḥ sāvakānam ti sāvakānam pi  eka desataḥ adhimuccanto ti adhimokkham karonto saddhāya carati iti saddhā vasena pavattati  paggaṇhanto ti catu sammappadhāna vīriyena padahanto upaṭṭhapento ti satiyāḥ ārammaṇam
translated: ‘From the side of Paccekabuddhas’: from the side of Paccekabuddhas. ‘From the side of disciples’: from the side of disciples.🔽‘Has confidence’: makes confidence. ‘Has faith’: occurs by means of faith.🔽‘Makes the effort’: makes the effort with the energy of the four right endeavours. ‘Appoints his mind’: appoints the object

original: upaṭṭhapento. Avikkhepaṃ karontoti samādhivasena vikkhepaṃ akaronto. Pajānantoti🔽catusaccajānanapaññāya pakārena jānanto. Vijānantoti indriyasampayuttajavanapubbaṅgamena
analyzed: upaṭṭhapentaḥ a vikkhepam karontaḥ ti samādhi vasena vikkhepam a karontaḥ pajānantaḥ iti  catu sacca jānana paññāya pakārena jānantaḥ vijānantaḥ ti indriya sampayutta javana pubbaṅgamena
translated: with mindfulness. ‘Concentrates’: does not distract with concentration. ‘Understands’: understands by means of the understanding that knows the four truths.

original: āvajjanaviññāṇena ārammaṇaṃ vijānanto. Viññāṇacariyāyāti āvajjanaviññāṇacariyāvasena.
analyzed: āvajjana viññāṇena ārammaṇam vijānantaḥ viññāṇa cariyāya ati āvajjana viññāṇa cariyā vasena
translated: ‘Is conscious’: is conscious of the object with the consciousness that precedes the impulsions associated with the faculties. ‘Consciousness-tracks’: by means of the consciousness-tracks of the adverting consciousness.

original: Evaṃ paṭipannassāti sahāvajjanāya indriyacariyāya paṭipannassa. Kusalā dhammā āyāpentīti
analyzed: evam paṭipannassa ati sahāvajjanāya indriya cariyāya paṭipannassa kusalāḥ dhammāḥ āyāpenti iti
translated: ‘Thus he practices’: he practices with the faculties and the consciousness-tracks of adverting. ‘The profitable ideas lead him’:

original: samathavipassanāvasena pavattā kusalā dhammā bhusaṃ yāpenti, pavattantīti attho.
analyzed: samatha vipassanā vasena pavattā kusalā dhammā bhusam yāpenti pavattanti iti attho
translated: the profitable ideas that occur by means of serenity and insight lead him on; the meaning is that they occur.

original: Āyatanacariyāyāti kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ bhusaṃ yatanacariyāya, pavattanacariyāyāti
analyzed: āyatana cariyāya ati kusalānam dhammānam bhusam yatana cariyāya pavattana cariyāya ati
translated: By practice in the sense of the exercise of skill: by practice in the sense of the exercise of skill in the profitable ideas. By practice in the sense of occurrence: by practice in the sense of the occurrence of the profitable ideas.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Visesamadhigacchatīti vikkhambhanatadaṅgasamucchedapaṭippassaddhivasena🔽visesaṃ adhigacchati.🔽Dassanacariyā ca sammādiṭṭhiyātiādīsu sammā passati, sammā vā tāya passanti, pasaṭṭhā🔽sundarā vā diṭṭhīti sammādiṭṭhi, tassā sammādiṭṭhiyā nibbānapaccakkhakaraṇena dassanacariyā.
analyzed: vuttam hoti visesam adhigacchati iti vikkhambhana tad aṅga samuccheda paṭippassaddhi vasena  visesam adhigacchati  dassana cariyā ca sammādiṭṭhiyā ati ādīsu sammā passati sammā vā tāya passanti pasaṭṭhā  sundarā vā diṭṭhī iti sammādiṭṭhi tassā sammādiṭṭhiyā nibbāna paccakkha karaṇena dassana cariyā
translated: He attains distinction: he attains distinction by suppression, by cutting off the associated defilements, and by tranquillization.🔽And practice in seeing is right view: right is the same as above. They see with it, or it sees, or it is good, excellent, seeing, thus it is right view. Practice in seeing is the making of extinction evident by means of that right view.

original: Sammā saṅkappeti, sammā vā tena saṅkappenti, pasaṭṭho sundaro vā saṅkappoti sammāsaṅkappo.🔽Tassa ārammaṇe cittassa abhiniropanacariyā. Sammā vadati, sammā vā tāya vadanti,
analyzed: sammā saṅkappeti sammā vā tena saṅkappenti pasaṭṭhaḥ sundaraḥ vā saṅkappo ti sammā saṅkappo  tassa ārammaṇe cittassa abhiniropana cariyā sammā vadati sammā vā tāya vadanti
translated: Right is the same as above. They aim with it, or it aims, or it is good, excellent, aiming, thus it is right aim. Practice in aiming is the practice of directing the mind onto the object.

original: pasaṭṭhā sundarā vā vācāti sammāvācā, micchāvācāviratiyā etaṃ nāmaṃ. Tassā catubbidhavacīsaṃvarapariggahacariyā.
analyzed: pasaṭṭhā sundarā vā vācā ati sammāvācā micchāvācā viratiyā etam nāmam tassā catubbidha vacī saṃvara pariggaha cariyā
translated: Right is the same as above. They speak with it, or they are spoken with, or it is good, excellent, speaking, thus it is right speaking. This is a name for abstention from false speech. Practice in right speaking is the practice of the fourfold restraint in speech.

original: Sammā karoti, sammā vā tena karonti, pasaṭṭhaṃ sundaraṃ vā kammanti sammākammaṃ,
analyzed: sammā karoti sammā vā tena karonti pasaṭṭham sundaram vā kammanti sammākammaṃ
translated: He does it rightly, or they do it rightly by means of it, or it is rightly, well, done, is right action ;

original: sammākammameva sammākammanto, micchākammantaviratiyā etaṃ nāmaṃ. Tassa tividhakāyasaṃvarasamuṭṭhānacariyā.
analyzed: sammākammam eva sammākammantaḥ micchākammanta viratiyā etam nāmam tassa tividha kāya saṃvara samuṭṭhāna cariyā
translated: right action is the same as abstention from wrong action. Its practice is threefold as abstinence from bodily action consisting in killing living things, etc.,

original: Sammā ājīvati, sammā vā tena ājīvanti, pasaṭṭho sundaro vā ājīvoti sammāājīvo, micchāājīvaviratiyā
analyzed: sammā ājīvati sammā vā tena ājīvanti pasaṭṭho sundaraḥ vā ājīvo ti sammāājīvaḥ micchāājīva viratiyā
translated: He lives rightly, or they live rightly by means of it, or it is rightly, well, lived, is right living ; abstention from wrong living is what is meant.

original: etaṃ nāmaṃ. Tassa vodānacariyā parisuddhacariyā. Sammā vāyamati, sammā vā tena vāyamanti,🔽pasaṭṭho sundaro vā vāyāmoti sammāvāyāmo, tassa paggahacariyā. Sammā sarati, sammā🔽vā tāya saranti, pasaṭṭhā sundarā vā satīti sammāsati, tassā upaṭṭhānacariyā. Sammā
analyzed: etam nāmam tassa vodāna cariyā parisuddha cariyā sammā vā āyamati sammā vā tena vā āyamanti  pasaṭṭhaḥ sundaraḥ vā vāyāmo ti sammāvāyāmo tassa paggaha cariyā sammā sarati sammā  vā tāya saranti pasaṭṭhā sundarā vā satī iti sammā satī tassāḥ upaṭṭhāna cariyā sammā
translated: Its practice is purifying, stainless. He strives rightly, or they strive rightly by means of it, or it is rightly, well, striven, is right effort ;🔽its practice is exertion. He remembers rightly, or they remember rightly by means of it, or it is rightly, well, remembered, is right mindfulness ;

original: samādhiyati, sammā vā tena samādhiyanti, pasaṭṭho sundaro vā samādhīti sammāsamādhi,
analyzed: samādhiyati sammā vā tena samādhiyanti pasaṭṭhaḥ sundaraḥ vā samādhīti sammāsamādhi
translated: its practice is adverting. He concentrates rightly, or they concentrate rightly by means of it, or it is rightly, well, concentrated, is right concentration ;

original: tassa avikkhepacariyā.
analyzed: tassa avikkhepa cariyā
translated: its practice is non-distraction.

original: Takkappoti tena kappo, evarūpoti attho. Tassadisoti tena sadiso, “tassadiko”ti vā🔽pāṭho. Tappaṭibhāgoti tena paṭibhāgo tappaṭibhāgo, edisoti attho. Sādurasaṃ atikkantaṃ🔽loṇaṃ atiloṇaṃ. Loṇakappoti loṇasadisoti vuccati. Atitittakanti atikkantatittakaṃ,🔽pucimandādikappo tittakasadisoti vuccati. Atimadhuranti khīrapāyāsādikaṃ. Himakappoti
analyzed: takkappo ti tena kappo evarūpo ti attho tassadiso ti tena sadisaḥ tassadiko ti vā  pāṭho tad paṭibhāgo ti tena paṭibhāgaḥ tad paṭibhāgaḥ edisaḥ ti attho sādurasam atikkantam  loṇam ati loṇam loṇa kappo ti loṇa sadiso ti vuccati atitittakam ti atikkanta tittakam  pucimanda ādi kappo tittaka sadiso ti vuccati ati madhuranti khīra pāyāsa ādikam hima kappo ti
translated: “Like the sour one” means like the sour one, i.e. the sour one. “Like the salt one” means like the salt one, i.e. the salt one. “Like the bitter one” means like the bitter one, i.e. the bitter one. “Like the sweet one” means like the sweet one, i.e. the sweet one.

original: himodakasadiso. Satthukappoti satthunā buddhena sadiso. Evamevāti opammasampaṭipādanaṃ.🔽Tatrāyaṃ etassa paccekabuddhassa saṅkhepena vipassanāācikkhanavidhiṃ dassetvā gamissāma.🔽Tattha nāmarūpapariggahaṃ kātukāmo paccekabodhisatto rūpārūpaaṭṭhasamāpattīsu yaṃ🔽kiñci jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya vitakkādīni jhānaṅgāni ca taṃsampayutte ca phassādayo
analyzed: himodaka sadisaḥ satthu kappo ti satthunā buddhena sadisaḥ evam eva ati opamma sampaṭipādanam 🔽tatra ayam etassa paccekabuddhassa saṅkhepena vipassanā ācikkhana vidhim dassetvā gamissāma 🔽tattha nāma rūpa pariggaham kātu kāmaḥ pacceka bodhisatto rūpa arūpa aṭṭha samāpattīsu yam 🔽kiñci jhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya vitakka ādīni jhān aṅgāni ca tad sampayutte ca phassa ādayo

original: dhamme lakkhaṇarasapaccupaṭṭhānapadaṭṭhānavasena paricchinditvā “sabbampetaṃ ārammaṇābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: dhamme lakkhaṇa rasa paccupaṭṭhāna padaṭṭhāna vasena paricchinditvā sabbam petam ārammaṇa abhimukham
translated: Having discerned the states by their characteristics, their nature, their manifestation, and their immediate cause, he should next discern them as objects of consciousness, as follows:

original: namanato namanaṭṭhena nāma”nti vavatthapeti. Tato tassa paccayaṃ pariyesanto “hadayavatthuṃ🔽nissāya pavattatī”ti passati. Puna vatthussa paccayabhūtāni ca upādārūpāni ca passitvā
analyzed: namanataḥ namana aṭṭhena nāmanti vavatthapeti tatas tassa paccayam pariyesantaḥ hadaya vatthum  nissāya pavattati iti passati puna vatthussa paccaya bhūtāni ca upādā rūpāni ca passitvā
translated: He defines mentality by way of the characteristics, function, manifestation, and proximate cause of the states of consciousness and its concomitants. He defines materiality by way of the characteristics, function, manifestation, and proximate cause of the four great primaries and the materiality derived by them. Having thus defined mentality and materiality, he concludes: “All this is turned towards the object, and because of bending towards the object it is called mentality-materiality. ”

original: “idaṃ sabbaṃ ruppanato rūpa”nti pariggaṇhāti. Puna tadubhayaṃ “namanalakkhaṇaṃ nāmaṃ,
analyzed: idam sabbam ruppanataḥ rūpam ti pariggaṇhāti puna tat ubhayam namana lakkhaṇam nāmam
translated: Then, seeking the conditions for mentality-materiality, he sees that it occurs supported by the heart-basis. Then, seeing the heart-basis and the other material phenomena as the conditions for mentality, he concludes: “All this is materiality because of being molested . ”

original: ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ rūpa”nti evaṃ saṅkhepato nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapeti. Samathayānikavasenetaṃ
analyzed: ruppana lakkhaṇam rūpan ti evam saṅkhepataḥ nāma rūpam vavatthapeti samatha yānika vasena itam
translated: Then, defining the characteristic of bending as mentality and the characteristic of being molested as materiality, he defines mentality-materiality in brief.🔽This is said with reference to one who is a disciple of the vehicle of serenity .

original: vuttaṃ. Vipassanāyāniko pana catudhātuvavatthānamukhena bhūtupādāyarūpāni paricchinditvā
analyzed: vuttam vipassanāyānikaḥ pana catu dhātu vavatthāna mukhena bhūta upādāya rūpāni paricchinditvā
translated: But one who is a disciple of the vehicle of insight defines materiality by way of the analysis of the four primary elements and the derived materiality.

original: “sabbampetaṃ ruppanato rūpa”nti passati. Tato evaṃ paricchinnarūpassa cakkhādīni
analyzed: sabbam petam ruppanataḥ rūpanti passati tatas evam paricchinna rūpassa cakkha ādīni
translated: Then, seeing the eye, etc., as the conditions for mentality, he concludes: “All this is mentality because of bending towards the object. ”

original: nissāya pavattamānā arūpadhammā āpāthamāgacchanti. Tato sabbepi te arūpadhamme namanalakkhaṇena
analyzed: nissāya pavattamānāḥ arūpa dhammāḥ āpātham āgacchanti tatas sabbe pi te arūpa dhamme namana lakkhaṇena
translated: and the immaterial states that occur contingent upon it come into focus. Then he sees all those immaterial states as a unity by their characteristic of bending or inclining,

original: ekato katvā “idaṃ nāma”nti passati, so “idaṃ nāmaṃ, idaṃ rūpa”nti dvedhā vavatthapeti.
analyzed: ekatas katvā idam nāmanti passati saḥ idam nāmam idam rūpanti dvedhā vavatthapeti
translated: and he defines them as “name” and the materiality as “form.”

original: Evaṃ vavatthapetvā “nāmarūpato uddhaṃ añño satto vā puggalo vā devo vā brahmā vā natthī”ti passati.
analyzed: evam vavatthapetvā nāma rūpataḥ uddham aññaḥ satto vā puggalo vā devaḥ vā brahmā vā natthi iti passati
translated: Having defined them thus, he sees that “apart from name-and-form there is no being or person or god or Brahmā.”

original: Yathā hi aṅgasambhārā, hoti saddo ratho iti;
analyzed: yathā hi aṅga sambhārā hoti saddo ratho iti
translated: “As when the parts are rightly set, The word ‘chariot’ is applied,

original: Evaṃ khandhesu santesu, hoti “satto”ti sammuti. ;
analyzed: evam khandhesu santesu hoti satto ti sammuti
translated: So when the aggregates exist, The convention ‘living being’ is. ”

original: Evameva pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu santesu “satto puggalo”ti vohāramattaṃ hotīti evamādinā
analyzed: evam eva pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu santesu satto puggalo ti vohāra mattam hoti iti evamādinā
translated: So too, when the five aggregates as objects of clinging are present, there is merely the conventional expression “living being, person.”

original: nayena nāmarūpānaṃ yāthāvadassanasaṅkhātena diṭṭhivisuddhibhūtena ñāṇena nāmarūpaṃ
analyzed: nayena yāthāva dassana saṅkhātena diṭṭhi visuddhi bhūtena ñāṇena nāma rūpam
translated: In this way, by means of the knowledge consisting in the purification of view, which is called “seeing rightly” in the case of mentality-materiality,

original: pariggahetvā puna tassa paccayampi pariggaṇhanto vuttanayena nāmarūpaṃ pariggahetvā
analyzed: pariggahetvā puna tassa paccayam pi pariggaṇhantaḥ vutta nayena nāma rūpam pariggahetvā
translated: having discerned mentality-materiality, he again discerns its conditions. Having discerned mentality-materiality in the way already described,

original: “ko nu kho imassa hetū”ti pariyesanto ahetuvādavisamahetuvādesu dosaṃ disvā rogaṃ
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho imassa hetu uti pariyesantaḥ ahetu vāda visama hetu vādesu dosam disvā rogam
translated: “What is the reason for this?” He seeks and sees the fault in the theories of causelessness and wrong cause. He sees the disease,

original: disvā tassa nidānaṃ samuṭṭhānampi pariyesanto vejjo viya tassa hetuñca paccayañca
analyzed: disvā tassa nidānam samuṭṭhānam pi pariyesanto vejjaḥ viya tassa hetuñca paccayañca
translated: and seeking its origin and source, he seeks the cause and condition of the disease as a physician would.

original: pariyesanto avijjā taṇhā upādānaṃ kammanti ime cattāro dhamme nāmarūpassa uppādapaccayattā
analyzed: pariyesantaḥ avijjā taṇhā upādānam kammanti ime cattāro dhamme nāma rūpassa uppāda paccaya ttā
translated: He sees the four things, ignorance, craving, clinging, and kamma, as the cause of mentality-materiality,🔽because they are the reason for its arising, and he sees nutriment as the condition,

original: “hetū”ti. Āhāraṃ upatthambhanapaccayattā “paccayo”ti ca passati. Imassa hi kāyassa
analyzed: hetu uti āhāram upatthambhana paccaya ttā paccayaḥ ti ca passati imassa hi kāyassa
translated: because it is the condition for its maintenance. For in the case of this material body,

original: avijjādayo tayo dhammā mātā viya dārakassa upanissayā honti, kammaṃ pitā viya puttassa
analyzed: avijjā ādayaḥ tayo dhammā mātā viya dārakassa upanissayāḥ honti kammam pitā viya puttassa
translated: the three things, ignorance, etc., are the supporting conditions like a mother for a child; kamma is the progenitor like a father;🔽and nutriment is the sustainer like a nurse for a child.

original: janakaṃ, āhāro dhāti viya dārakassa sandhārakoti. Evaṃ rūpakāyassa paccayapariggahaṃ
analyzed: janakam āhāraḥ dhāti viya dārakassa sandhārakaḥ ti evam rūpa kāyassa paccaya pariggaham
translated: Having thus discerned the conditions for the material body, he again discerns the conditions for the mental body

original: katvā puna “cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇa”ntiādinā nayena nāmakāyassapi
analyzed: katvā puna cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇa nti ādinā nayena nāmakāyassa api
translated: in the way beginning, “With eye and forms as its conditions, eye-consciousness arises” .

original: paccayaṃ pariggaṇhāti, evaṃ pariggaṇhanto “atītānāgatāpi dhammā evameva vattantī”ti
analyzed: paccayam pariggaṇhāti evam pariggaṇhantaḥ atīta anāgatāḥ api dhammāḥ evam eva vattanti iti
translated: As he discerns thus, he sees that past and future states occur in the same way.

original: sanniṭṭhānaṃ karoti.🔽Tassa yā sā pubbantaṃ ārabbha “ahosiṃ nu kho ahaṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, na nu kho ahosiṃ,
analyzed: sanniṭṭhānam karoti  tassa yā sā pubbantam ārabbha ahosim nu kho aham atītam addhānam na nu kho ahosim
translated: He makes a resolve.

original: kiṃ nu kho, kathaṃ nu kho, kiṃ hutvā kiṃ ahosiṃ nu kho ahaṃ atītamaddhāna”nti pañcavidhā vicikicchā vuttā.🔽Yāpi aparantaṃ ārabbha “bhavissāmi nu kho ahaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, na nu kho bhavissāmi,🔽kiṃ nu kho bhavissāmi, kathaṃ nu kho bhavissāmi, kiṃ hutvā kiṃ bhavissāmi nu kho
analyzed: kim nu kho katham nu kho kim hutvā kim ahosim nu kho aham atītam addhānam ti pañcavidhā vicikicchā vuttā  yā api aparantam ārabbha bhavissāmi nu khalu aham anāgatam addhānam na nu khalu bhavissāmi  kim nu kho bhavissāmi katham nu kho bhavissāmi kim hutvā kim bhavissāmi nu kho
translated: And the fivefold doubt about the past stated thus: “Was I in the past? Was I not in the past? What was I in the past? How was I in the past? Having been what, what was I in the past?” ,

original: ahaṃ anāgatamaddhāna”nti pañcavidhā vicikicchā vuttā.🔽Yāpi etarahi vā pana paccuppannaṃ addhānaṃ ārabbha kathaṃkathī hoti “ahaṃ nu khosmi,
analyzed: aham pañcavidhā vicikicchā vuttā  yā api etarahi vā pana paccuppannam addhānam ārabbha kathaṃkathī hoti aham nu kho asmi
translated: and the fivefold doubt about the future stated thus: “Shall I be in the future? Shall I not be in the future? What shall I be in the future? How shall I be in the future? Having been what, what shall I be in the future?” ,

original: no nu khosmi, kiṃ nu khosmi, kathaṃ nu khosmi, ayaṃ nu kho satto kuto āgato, so kuhiṃ
analyzed: no nu khalu asmi kim nu khalu asmi katham nu khalu asmi ayam nu khalu satto kutas āgataḥ saḥ kuhiṃ
translated: and the sixfold doubt stated thus: “Am I? Am I not? What am I? How am I? Where has this being come from? Where is it bound?” ,

original: gāmī bhavissatī”ti chabbidhā vicikicchā vuttā, sā sabbāpi pahiyyati. Evaṃ paccayapariggahaṇena
analyzed: gāmī bhavissati iti chabbidhā vicikicchā vuttā sā sabbā api pahiyyati evam paccaya pariggahaṇena
translated: all this is abandoned. So it is by discerning conditions that this doubt is abandoned.

original: tīsu addhāsu kaṅkhaṃ vitaritvā ṭhitaṃ ñāṇaṃ “kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhī”tipi “dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇa”ntipi🔽“yathābhūtañāṇa”ntipi “sammādassana”ntipi vuccati.
analyzed: tīsu addhāsu kaṅkham vitaritvā ṭhitam ñāṇam kaṅkhā vitaraṇa visuddhi itipi dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇa ntipi  yathā bhūta ñāṇam tipi sammādassanam tipi vuccati
translated: The knowledge that stands, having dispelled doubt about the three periods of time, is called “purification by overcoming doubt” and also “knowledge of the way things are” and also “knowledge of discernment of ideas” and also “right view.”

original: Ettha pana tisso hi lokiyapariññā ñātapariññā tīraṇapariññā pahānapariññāti. Tattha
analyzed: ettha pana tissaḥ hi lokiya pariññāḥ ñāta pariññā tīraṇa pariññā pahāna pariññā ti tattha
translated: Herein, there are three kinds of mundane full-understanding, that is to say, full-understanding as full-understanding of what is known, full-understanding as investigation, and full-understanding as abandoning.🔽Herein,

original: “ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ rūpaṃ, vedayitalakkhaṇā vedanā”ti evaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ paccattalakkhaṇasallakkhaṇavasena🔽pavattā paññā ñātapariññā nāma. “Rūpaṃ aniccaṃ, vedanā aniccā”tiādinā pana nayena
analyzed: ruppana lakkhaṇam rūpam vedayita lakkhaṇā vedanā ati evam tesam tesam dhammānam paccatta lakkhaṇa sat lakkhaṇa vasena  pavattā paññā ñāta pariññā nāma rūpam aniccam vedanā aniccā ati ādinā pana nayena
translated: the understanding that occurs by discerning the individual characteristic of each of the various kinds of states, according to such instances as “Materiality has the characteristic of being molested; its function is to be broken up; its manifestation is susceptibility to injury; its proximate cause is the four great primaries” ,🔽is called full-understanding as full-understanding of what is known.

original: tesaṃyeva dhammānaṃ sāmaññalakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā pavattā lakkhaṇārammaṇikavipassanāpaññā🔽tīraṇapariññā nāma. Tesu eva pana dhammesu niccasaññādipajahanavasena pavattā lakkhaṇārammaṇikavipassanāva
analyzed: tesam yeva dhammānam sāmañña lakkhaṇam āropetvā pavattā lakkhaṇa ārammaṇika vipassanā paññā  tīraṇa pariññā nāma tesu eva pana dhammesu nicca saññā ādi pajahana vasena pavattā lakkhaṇa ārammaṇika vipassanā va
translated: The understanding that occurs by superimposing the general characteristics on those same states, according to such instances as “Materiality is impermanent, painful, not-self; feeling is … ; perception is … ; formations are … ; consciousness is … ” ,

original: paññā pahānapariññā nāma.
analyzed: paññā pahānapariññā nāma
translated: is called full-understanding as investigation.🔽The understanding that occurs by abandoning perception of permanence, etc., in those same states, is called full-understanding as abandoning.

original: Tattha saṅkhāraparicchedato paṭṭhāya yāva paccayapariggahā ñātapariññāya bhūmi. Etasmiñhi🔽antare dhammānaṃ paccattalakkhaṇapaṭivedhasseva ādhipaccaṃ hoti. Kalāpasammasanato🔽paṭṭhāya yāva udayabbayānupassanā tīraṇapariññāya bhūmi. Etasmiñhi antare sāmaññalakkhaṇapaṭivedhasseva🔽ādhipaccaṃ hoti. Bhaṅgānupassanato paṭṭhāya upari pahānapariññāya bhūmi. Tato ca
analyzed: tattha saṅkhāra paricchedataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva paccaya pariggahā ñāta pariññāya bhūmi etasmin hi  antare dhammānam paccatta lakkhaṇa paṭivedhassa iva ādhipaccam hoti kalāpa sammasanato  paṭṭhāya yāva udaya bbaya anupassanā tīraṇa pariññāya bhūmi etasmin hi antare sāmañña lakkhaṇa paṭivedhassa iva  ādhipaccam hoti bhaṅga anupassanato paṭṭhāya upari pahāna pariññāya bhūmi tatas ca
translated: Herein, the stage of full-understanding of the known is from the delimitation of formations up to the determining of conditions,🔽because in this section there is only predominance of penetration of the specific characteristics of states. The stage of full-understanding of the investigated is from the discerning of mentality-materiality up to the contemplation of rise and fall,🔽because in this section there is only predominance of penetration of the general characteristics. The stage of full-understanding of eradication is from the contemplation of dissolution onwards,🔽because in this section there is only predominance of the contemplation of dissolution.

original: paṭṭhāya hi aniccato anupassanto niccasaññaṃ pajahati, dukkhato anupassanto sukhasaññaṃ,🔽anattato anupassanto attasaññaṃ, nibbindanto nandiṃ, virajjanto rāgaṃ, nirodhento🔽samudayaṃ, paṭinissajjanto ādānaṃ pajahatīti evaṃ niccasaññādipahānasādhikānaṃ sattannaṃ
analyzed: paṭṭhāya hi aniccataḥ anupassanto nicca saññam pajahati dukkhataḥ anupassanto sukha saññam 🔽anattataḥ anupassantaḥ atta saññam nibbindantaḥ nandim virajjantaḥ rāgam nirodhentaḥ 🔽samudayam paṭinissajjantaḥ ādānam pajahati iti evam nicca saññā ādi pahāna sādhikānam sattannam
translated: Herein, the section on the formations up to the section on the determining of conditions is the plane of full-understanding as the known. For in this section the penetration of the individual essences of states is paramount. The section on the discerning of conditions up to the contemplation of rise and fall is the plane of full-understanding as investigation. For in this section the penetration of the general characteristics is paramount. The contemplation of dissolution and what follows it is the plane of full-understanding as abandoning. For from there onwards, seeing formations as impermanent, he abandons the perception of permanence; seeing them as painful, he abandons the perception of pleasure; seeing them as not-self, he abandons the perception of self; becoming dispassionate, he abandons delight; fading away, he abandons greed; ceasing, he abandons arising; relinquishing, he abandons grasping. So these seven contemplations beginning with that of impermanence are the means by which he abandons the seven kinds of perception of permanence, and so on.

original: anupassanānaṃ ādhipaccaṃ. Iti imāsu tīsu pariññāsu saṅkhāraparicchedassa ceva paccayapariggahassa
analyzed: anupassanānam ādhipaccam iti imāsu tīsu pariññāsu saṅkhāra paricchedassa ca iva paccaya pariggahassa
translated: and the predominance of contemplation.

original: ca sādhitattā iminā yoginā ñātapariññāva adhigatā.🔽Puna “yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā…pe… yaṃ dūre🔽santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ hutvā abhāvato aniccaṃ, udayabbayapaṭipīḷitattā dukkhaṃ,
analyzed: ca sādhita ttā iminā yoginā adhigatā  puna yam kiñci rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vāpe yam dūre  santike vā sabbam rūpam hutvā abhāvataḥ aniccam udaya bbaya paṭipīḍita ttā dukkham
translated: Thus, since the delimitation of formations and the discerning of conditions have been accomplished in these three kinds of full-understanding, the meditator has now reached the full-understanding as investigation.

original: avasavattittā anattā. Yā kāci vedanā… saññā… ye keci saṅkhārā … yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ🔽atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā🔽paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ hutvā abhāvato aniccaṃ, udayabbayapaṭipīḷitattā
analyzed: anattā yā kāci vedanā saññā ye keci saṅkhārāḥ yam kiñci viññāṇam  atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikam vā sukhumam vā hīnam vā  paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā sabbam viññāṇam hutvā abhāvataḥ aniccam udaya bbaya paṭipīḍita ttā
translated: Again, he discerns formations by aggregates, etc., in the following ways: “Any kind of materiality whatever, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—he defines all materiality as impermanent, suffering, and non-self.

original: dukkhaṃ, avasavattittā anattā”ti evamādinā nayena kalāpasammasanaṃ karoti. Idaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: evamādinā nayena kalāpa sammasanam karoti idam sandhāya
translated: Any kind of feeling … Any kind of perception … Any kind of formations … Any kind of consciousness whatever, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—he defines all consciousness as impermanent, suffering, and non-self” .

original: vuttaṃ “tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā”ti.
analyzed: vuttam ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā iti
translated: This is called “comprehension by groups” .

original: Evaṃ saṅkhāre aniccadukkhānattavasena kalāpasammasanaṃ katvā puna saṅkhārānaṃ udayabbayameva
analyzed: evam saṅkhāre anicca dukkha anatta vasena kalāpa sammasanam katvā puna udaya bbayam eva
translated: Having thus done the pervasion of the aggregates by way of impermanence, pain, and impersonality, he sees the rise and fall of the formations.

original: passati. Kathaṃ? “Avijjāsamudayā rūpasamudayo, taṇhākammaāhārasamudayā rūpasamudayo”ti.
analyzed: passati katham avijjā samudayā rūpa samudayo taṇhā kamma āhāra samudayā rūpa samudayo ti
translated: How? “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of material form. With the arising of craving, kamma, and nutriment there is the arising of material form.”

original: Evaṃ rūpakkhandhassa paccayāyattatādassanena rūpakkhandhassa udayaṃ passati, nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: evam rūpa kkhandhassa paccaya āyatta tā dassanena rūpa kkhandhassa udayam passati nibbatti lakkhaṇam
translated: Thus he sees the rise of the materiality aggregate by seeing the dependence of the materiality aggregate.

original: passantopi rūpakkhandhassa udayaṃ passati. Evaṃ pañcahākārehi rūpakkhandhassa udayaṃ
analyzed: passantaḥ api rūpakkhandhassa udayam passati evam pañcahā ākārehi rūpakkhandhassa udayam
translated: Seeing the characteristic of arising, he also sees the rise of the materiality aggregate. Thus he sees the rise of the materiality aggregate in five ways.

original: passati. “Avijjānirodhā rūpanirodho, taṇhākammaāhāranirodhā rūpanirodho”ti paccayanirodhadassanena🔽rūpakkhandhassa vayaṃ passati, vipariṇāmalakkhaṇaṃ passantopi rūpakkhandhassa vayaṃ
analyzed: passati avijjā nirodhā rūpa nirodho taṇhā kamma āhāra nirodhā rūpa nirodho ti paccaya nirodha dassanena  rūpa kkhandhassa vayam passati vipariṇāma lakkhaṇam passantaḥ api rūpa kkhandhassa vayam
translated: “With the cessation of ignorance there is the cessation of material form. With the cessation of craving, kamma, and nutriment there is the cessation of material form.”🔽By seeing the cessation of conditions, he sees the fall of the materiality aggregate.

original: passatīti evaṃ pañcahākārehi rūpakkhandhassa vayaṃ passati.
analyzed: passati iti evam pañcahā ākārehi rūpakkhandhassa vayam passati
translated: Seeing the characteristic of change, he also sees the fall of the materiality aggregate. Thus he sees the fall of the materiality aggregate in five ways.

original: Tathā “avijjāsamudayā vedanāsamudayo, taṇhākammaphassasamudayā vedanāsamudayo”ti
analyzed: tathā avijjā samudayā vedanā samudayo taṇhā kamma phassa samudayā vedanā samudayo ti
translated: “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of feeling. With the arising of craving, kamma, and contact there is the arising of feeling.”

original: paccayāyattatādassanena vedanākkhandhassa udayaṃ passati, nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ passantopi🔽vedanākkhandhassa udayaṃ passati. “Avijjānirodhā vedanānirodho, taṇhākammaphassanirodhā
analyzed: paccaya āyatta tā dassanena vedanā kkhandhassa udayam passati nibbatti lakkhaṇam passantaḥ api  vedanā khandhassa udayam passati avijjā nirodhā vedanā nirodho taṇhā kamma phassa nirodhā
translated: He sees the arising of the feeling aggregate when he sees the arising of its conditions. And when he sees the characteristic of arising,

original: vedanānirodho”ti paccayanirodhadassanena vedanākkhandhassa vayaṃ passati, vipariṇāmalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: vedanā nirodho ti paccaya nirodha dassanena vedanā kkhandhassa vayam passati vipariṇāma lakkhaṇam
translated: he sees the arising of the feeling aggregate. He sees the fall of the feeling aggregate when he sees the cessation of its conditions thus: “With the cessation of ignorance there is the cessation of formations, with the cessation of craving, kamma, and contact there is the cessation of feeling” . And when he sees the characteristic of change,

original: passantopi vedanākkhandhassa vayaṃ passati. Evaṃ saññākkhandhādīsupi.
analyzed: passantaḥ pi vedanā kkhandhassa vayam passati evam saññā kkhandha ādīsu pi
translated: he sees the fall of the feeling aggregate. So too with the perception aggregate, and so on.

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso – viññāṇakkhandhassa phassaṭṭhāne “nāmarūpasamudayā, nāmarūpanirodhā”ti🔽yojetabbaṃ. Evaṃ ekekasmiṃ khandhe paccayasamudayavasena ca nibbattilakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ viññāṇa kkhandhassa phassa ṭṭhāne nāma rūpa samudayā nāma rūpa nirodhā ti  yojetabbam evam ekekasmin khandhe paccaya samudaya vasena ca nibbatti lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: But there is this difference. In the case of the consciousness aggregate, “With the arising of name-and-form” should be construed in the place of “With the arising of contact.”

original: ca paccayanirodhavasena ca vipariṇāmalakkhaṇavasena ca udayabbayadassanena ca dasa
analyzed: ca paccaya nirodha vasena ca vipariṇāma lakkhaṇa vasena ca udaya bbaya dassanena ca dasa
translated: So by seeing the arising and fall of each aggregate in this way by means of the arising of its conditions and the characteristic of arising, and by means of the cessation of its conditions and the characteristic of change,

original: dasa katvā paññāsa lakkhaṇāni vuttāni. Tesaṃ vasena “evampi rūpassa udayo, evampi
analyzed: dasa katvā paññāsa lakkhaṇāni vuttāni tesam vasena evam pi rūpassa udayaḥ evam pi
translated: there are ten times ten, that is, a hundred characteristics stated. And by means of them it is said that “The arising of materiality is like this,🔽and its fall is like this” ,

original: rūpassa vayo”ti paccayato ceva khaṇato ca vitthārena manasikāraṃ karoti.
analyzed: rūpassa vayaḥ ti paccayataḥ ca iva khaṇataḥ ca vitthārena manasikāram karoti
translated: He gives attention to it by way of condition and by way of moment in detail.

original: Tassevaṃ karoto “iti kira ime dhammā ahutvā sambhonti, hutvā paṭiventī”ti ñāṇaṃ visadaṃ
analyzed: tassa ivam karoto iti kira ime dhammā a hutvā sambhonti hutvā paṭiventi iti ñāṇam visadam
translated: As he does so, the knowledge that “These states, it seems, arise through a condition, and having arisen they pass away” becomes very clear to him.

original: hoti. “Evaṃ kira ime dhammā anuppannā uppajjanti, uppannā nirujjhantī”ti niccanavā🔽hutvā saṅkhārā upaṭṭhahanti. Na kevalañca niccanavā, sūriyuggamane ussāvabindu viya🔽udakabubbuḷo viya udake daṇḍarāji viya āragge sāsapo viya vijjuppādo viya ca parittaṭṭhāyino,
analyzed: hoti evam kira ime dhammā anuppannāḥ uppajjanti uppannāḥ nirujjhanti iti  hutvā saṅkhārāḥ upaṭṭhahanti na kevalam ca sūri yuj gamane ussāva bindu  udaka bubbuḷaḥ viya udake daṇḍa rāji viya āragge sāsapaḥ viya vijjuppādaḥ viya ca paritta ṭṭhāyinaḥ
translated: “So these states, it seems, arise when they have not been, and having been, they vanish” .🔽They appear as formations that are impermanent,🔽not only as impermanent, but also as having no core, like a mass of foam, like a water bubble, like a mirage, like a plantain trunk, like a conjuring trick, like a dream, like the city of the Gandhabbas, like froth, like a palm leaf, etc.,

original: māyāmarīcisupinālātacakkagandhabbanagarapheṇakadaliādayo viya asārā nissārā viya🔽hutvā upaṭṭhahanti. Ettāvatā ca pana anena “vayadhammameva uppajjati, uppannañca
analyzed: māyā marīci supina alāta cakka gandhabba nagara pheṇaka dali ādayaḥ viya asārāḥ nissārāḥ viya  hutvā upaṭṭhahanti ettāvatā ca pana anena vaya dhammam eva uppajjati uppannam ca
translated: and as having no core, like a husk of grain.

original: vayaṃ upetī”ti iminā ākārena sammasanapaññāya lakkhaṇāni paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitaṃ udayabbayānupassanaṃ
analyzed: vayam upeti iti iminā ākārena sammasana paññāya lakkhaṇāni paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitam udaya bbaya anupassanam
translated: At this point, having penetrated the characteristics by means of comprehension through the kind of insight called “contemplation of rise and fall,” he reaches contemplation of dissolution.

original: nāma paṭhamaṃ taruṇavipassanāñāṇaṃ adhigataṃ hoti. Yassādhigamā “āraddhavipassako”ti saṅkhaṃ gacchati.🔽Athassa āraddhavipassakassa kulaputtassa obhāso ñāṇaṃ pīti passaddhi sukhaṃ adhimokkho
analyzed: nāma paṭhamam taruṇa vipassanā ñāṇam adhigatam hoti yassa adhigamā āraddha vipassakaḥ ti saṅkham gacchati  athassa āraddha vipassakassa kula puttassa obhāsaḥ ñāṇam pīti passaddhi sukham adhimokkhaḥ
translated: The first knowledge of insight is called “light-flash knowledge.” With its arising he is called “one who has entered upon the way.”

original: paggaho upaṭṭhānaṃ upekkhā nikantīti dasa vipassanupakkilesā uppajjanti. Ettha obhāso
analyzed: paggahaḥ upaṭṭhānam upekkhā nikanti iti dasa vipassanu pakkilesā uppajjanti ettha obhāso
translated: Then, when he is one who has entered upon the way, ten defilements of insight arise in the clansman who is developing insight: light, knowledge, rapture, tranquillity, bliss, resolution,🔽exertion, appearance, equanimity, and confidence. Herein, light is as follows.

original: nāma vipassanakkhaṇe ñāṇassa balavattā lohitaṃ sannisīdati, tena ca cittobhāso nibbattati.
analyzed: nāma vipassana kkhaṇe ñāṇassa balavat tā lohitam sannisīdati tena ca citta ubhāsaḥ nibbattati
translated: At the moment of insight knowledge the knowledge is strong, the blood is clear, and a light arises in the mind.

original: Taṃ disvā akusalo yogī “maggo me patto”ti tameva obhāsaṃ assādeti. Ñāṇampi vipassanāñāṇameva.🔽Taṃ saṅkhāre sammasantassa suddhaṃ pasannaṃ hutvā pavattati. Taṃ disvā pubbe viya
analyzed: tam disvā akusalaḥ yogī maggaḥ me patto ti tam eva obhāsam assādeti ñāṇam pi vipassanā ñāṇam eva  tam saṅkhāre sammasantassa suddham pasannam hutvā pavattati tam disvā pubbe viya
translated: Seeing that, the unskilled meditator relishes it, thinking, “The path has been reached by me.” Knowledge is insight knowledge.

original: “maggo”ti assādeti. Pītipi vipassanāpīti eva. Tassa hi tasmiṃ khaṇe pañcavidhā pīti
analyzed: maggo ti assādeti vipassanā api iti eva tassa hi tasmin khaṇe pañcavidhā pīti
translated: It occurs pure and clear in one who comprehends formations. Seeing that, he relishes it, thinking, “The path has been reached by me,” as before. Rapture is insight rapture. For at that moment the fivefold rapture, namely,

original: uppajjati. Passaddhīti vipassanāpassaddhi. Tasmiṃ samaye neva kāyacittānaṃ daratho,
analyzed: uppajjati passaddhī iti vipassanā passaddhi tasmin samaye na iva kāya cittānam darathaḥ
translated: and serenity is insight serenity. At that time there is no fatigue,

original: na gāravaṃ, na kakkhaḷatā, na akammaññatā, na gelaññatā, na vaṅkatā hoti. Sukhampi
analyzed: na gāravam na kakkhaḷa tā na akammañña tā na gelañña tā na vaṅka tā hoti sukham pi
translated: no heaviness, no rigidity, no unwieldiness, no unfitness, no crookedness in the body or in the mind. And the pleasure is

original: vipassanāsukhameva. Tassa kira tasmiṃ samaye sakalasarīraṃ abhisandayamānaṃ atipaṇītaṃ sukhaṃ uppajjati.🔽Adhimokkho nāma vipassanakkhaṇe pavattā saddhā. Tasmiñhi khaṇe cittacetasikānaṃ ativiya
analyzed: vipassanā sukham eva tassa kira tasmin samaye sakala sarīram abhisandayamānam ati paṇītam sukham uppajjati  adhimokkhaḥ nāma vipassana kkhaṇe pavattā saddhā tasmin hi khaṇe citta cetasikānam
translated: insight pleasure. At that time, it seems, very refined pleasure arises pervading the whole body.

original: pasādabhūtā balavatī saddhā uppajjati. Paggaho nāma vipassanāsampayuttaṃ vīriyaṃ.
analyzed: pasāda bhūtā balavatī saddhā uppajjati paggahaḥ nāma vipassanā sampayuttam vīriyam
translated: Resolution is faith occurring at the moment of insight. At that moment there arises a strong faith that is a high degree of confidence in the mental states. Exertion is energy associated with insight.

original: Tasmiñhi khaṇe asithilaṃ anaccāraddhaṃ supaggahitaṃ vīriyaṃ uppajjati. Upaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: tasmin hi khaṇe asithilam anacca āraddham su paggahitam vīriyam uppajjati upaṭṭhānam ti
translated: At that moment there arises energy that is neither too slack nor too strained, but well exerted. Alertness is mindfulness associated with insight.

original: vipassanāsampayuttā sati. Tasmiñhi khaṇe supaṭṭhitā sati uppajjati. Upekkhā duvidhā
analyzed: vipassanā sampayuttā sati tasmin hi khaṇe su paṭṭhitā sati uppajjati upekkhā duvidhā
translated: At that moment there arises well-established mindfulness. Equanimity is twofold

original: vipassanāvajjanavasena. Tasmiñhi khaṇe sabbasaṅkhāragahaṇe majjhattabhūtaṃ vipassanupekkhāsaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: vipassanā vajjana vasena tasmin hi khaṇe sabba saṅkhāra gahaṇe majjhatta bhūtam vipassanā upekkhā saṅkhātam
translated: by means of the adverting to insight. For at that moment the equanimity called equanimity of insight, which is the middle position in the grasping of all formations,

original: ñāṇaṃ balavantaṃ hutvā uppajjati manodvārāvajjanupekkhā ca. Sā ca taṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ🔽āvajjantassa sūrā tikhiṇā hutvā vahati. Nikantīti vipassanānikanti. Obhāsādīsu hi
analyzed: ñāṇam balavantam hutvā uppajjati ca sā ca tam tam ṭhānam  āvajjantassa sūrā tikhiṇā hutvā vahati nikantī iti vipassanā nikanti obhāsa ādīsu hi
translated: and by way of the adverting of insight. For at that moment the knowledge called equanimity of insight, which is neutral in the case of all the other kinds of apprehension of formations, arises powerful, and so does the equanimity of adverting that is the adverting of the mind-door. And that goes swiftly and sharply in one who adverts to this or that place.

original: ālayaṃ kurumānā sukhumā santākārā nikanti uppajjati. Ettha obhāsādayo kilesavatthutāya
analyzed: ālayam kurumānā sukhumā santa ākārā nikanti uppajjati ettha obhāsa ādayo kilesa vatthu tāya
translated: Attachment is the attachment of insight. For in the case of the light, etc., attachment arises subtle and peaceful in aspect, making its abode there.

original: “upakkilesā”ti vuttā na akusalattā. Nikanti pana upakkileso ceva kilesavatthu ca.🔽Paṇḍito pana bhikkhu obhāsādīsu uppannesu vikkhepaṃ agacchanto “obhāsādayo dhammā
analyzed: upakkilesā ati vuttā na akusala ttā pana upakkileso ca iva kilesa vatthu ca  paṇḍitaḥ pana bhikkhu obhāsa ādīsu uppannesu vikkhepam agacchantaḥ obhāsa ādayaḥ dhammā
translated: Herein, the light, etc., are called “defilements” because they are grounds for defilements, not because they are unwholesome. But attachment is both a defilement and a ground for defilements.

original: na maggo, upakkilesavimuttaṃ pana vīthipaṭipannaṃ vipassanāñāṇaṃ maggo”ti maggañca
analyzed: na maggaḥ upakkilesa vimuttam pana vīthi paṭipannam vipassanā ñāṇam maggo ti maggañca
translated: But a wise bhikkhu, instead of going astray when the light, etc., arise, defines the path and the not-so-path thus: “The light, etc., are not the path; but insight knowledge, which is free from defilements and is occurring in the cognitive series, is the path.”

original: amaggañca vavatthapeti. Tassevaṃ “ayaṃ maggo, ayaṃ na maggo”ti ñatvā ṭhitaṃ ñāṇaṃ
analyzed: amaggam ca vavatthapeti tassa ivam ayam maggaḥ ayam na maggo ti ñatvā ṭhitam ñāṇam
translated: When he knows thus, “This is the path, this is not the path,” the knowledge by which he abides resolved on this is called

original: maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhīti vuccati. Ito paṭṭhāya aṭṭhannaṃ vipassanāñāṇānaṃ
analyzed: magga amagga ñāṇa dassana visuddhi iti vuccati itas paṭṭhāya aṭṭhannam vipassanā ñāṇānam
translated: This is called “purification by knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path.”

original: vasena sikhāpattavipassanāñāṇaṃ navamañca saccānulomikaṃ ñāṇanti ayaṃ paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhi
analyzed: vasena sikhāpatta vipassanā ñāṇam navamam ca sacca ānulomikam ñāṇanti ayam paṭipadā ñāṇa dassana visuddhi
translated: From here on, the knowledge of the kinds of insight that have reached the culmination of the development of concentration is called “purification by knowledge and vision of the way” .

original: nāma hoti. Udayabbayānupassanāñāṇaṃ bhaṅgānupassanāñāṇaṃ bhayatupaṭṭhānañāṇaṃ ādīnavānupassanāñāṇaṃ
analyzed: nāma hoti udaya bbaya anupassanā ñāṇam bhaṅga anupassanā ñāṇam bhaya tu paṭṭhāna ñāṇam ādīnava anupassanā ñāṇam
translated: The eight kinds of knowledge are as follows: knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall, knowledge of contemplation of dissolution, knowledge of appearance as terror, knowledge of contemplation of danger,

original: nibbidānupassanāñāṇaṃ muñcitukamyatāñāṇaṃ paṭisaṅkhānupassanāñāṇaṃ saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇanti
analyzed: nibbidā anupassanā ñāṇam muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇam paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā ñāṇam saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇam
translated: knowledge of contemplation of disenchantment, knowledge of desire for deliverance, knowledge of contemplation of reflection, and knowledge of equanimity about formations.

original: imāni aṭṭha ñāṇāni nāma. Navamaṃ saccānulomikaṃ ñāṇanti anulomassetaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: imāni aṭṭha ñāṇāni nāma navamam sacca ānulomikam ñāṇanti anulomassa etam nāmam
translated: The ninth is knowledge in conformity with truth. This is called “conformity” .

original: Tasmā taṃ sampādetukāmena upakkilesavimuttaṃ udayabbayañāṇaṃ ādiṃkatvā etesu ñāṇesu
analyzed: tasmai tam sampādetu kāmena upakkilesa vimuttam udaya bbaya ñāṇam ādiṃkatvā etesu ñāṇesu
translated: So one who wants to perfect it should begin by developing the knowledge of rise and fall free from defilements and then apply himself to these kinds of knowledge.

original: yogo karaṇīyo. Udayabbayaṃ passantassa hi aniccalakkhaṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ upaṭṭhāti,
analyzed: yogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ udaya bbayam passantassa hi anicca lakkhaṇam yathābhūtam upaṭṭhāti
translated: For one who sees rise and fall the characteristic of impermanence becomes evident to him as it actually is.

original: udayabbayapaṭipīḷanaṃ passato dukkhalakkhaṇañca, “dukkhameva hi sambhoti, dukkhaṃ
analyzed: udaya bbaya paṭipīḍanam passataḥ dukkha lakkhaṇam ca dukkham eva hi sambhoti dukkham
translated: And to one who sees oppression by rise and fall the characteristic of pain becomes evident. For only pain arises and only pain goes on.

original: tiṭṭhati veti cā”ti passato anattalakkhaṇañca.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati veti ca ati passataḥ anatta lakkhaṇañca
translated: and stands still and vanishes.

original: Ettha ca aniccaṃ aniccalakkhaṇaṃ dukkhaṃ dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ anattā anattalakkhaṇanti
analyzed: ettha ca aniccam anicca lakkhaṇam dukkham dukkha lakkhaṇam anattā anatta lakkhaṇanti
translated: And here the impermanent is the characteristic of impermanence, the painful is the characteristic of pain, and the not-self is the characteristic of not-self.

original: ayaṃ vibhāgo veditabbo. Tattha aniccanti khandhapañcakaṃ. Kasmā? Uppādavayaññathattabhāvā,
analyzed: ayam vibhāgaḥ veditabbo tattha aniccanti khandha pañcakam kasmā
translated: This is how the exposition should be understood here. Herein, the five aggregates are impermanent. Why? Because of arising and disappea-ring and changing.

original: hutvā abhāvato vā. Aññathattaṃ nāma jarā. Uppādavayaññathattaṃ aniccalakkhaṇaṃ, hutvā
analyzed: hutvā abhāvataḥ vā aññathattam nāma jarā uppāda vayaññathattam anicca lakkhaṇam hutvā
translated: Or because of non-existence after having been. The changing is ageing. Arising, disappearing and changing are the characteristic of impermanence,

original: abhāvasaṅkhāto vā ākāravikāro. “Yadaniccaṃ, taṃ dukkha”nti vacanato tadeva khandhapañcakaṃ🔽dukkhaṃ. Kasmā? Abhiṇhaṃ paṭipīḷanato. Abhiṇhaṃ paṭipīḷanākāro dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ. “Yaṃ
analyzed: abhāva saṅkhātaḥ vā ākāra vikāraḥ yat aniccam tam dukkhanti vacanato tat eva khandha pañcakam  dukkham kasmai abhiṇham paṭipīḷanataḥ abhiṇham paṭipīḷana ākāraḥ dukkha lakkhaṇam yam
translated: or the alteration in aspect is the characteristic of impermanence.🔽The five aggregates are painful. Why? Because of oppression. The aspect of oppression is the characteristic of pain.

original: dukkhaṃ, tadanattā”ti vacanato tadeva khandhapañcakaṃ anattā. Kasmā? Avasavattanato.
analyzed: dukkham tat anattā ati vacanataḥ tat eva khandha pañcakam anattā kasmai
translated: The five aggregates are not-self. Why? Because of non-domination.

original: Avasavattanākāro anattalakkhaṇaṃ. Imāni tīṇipi lakkhaṇāni udayabbayaṃ passantasseva ārammaṇāni honti.
analyzed: anatta lakkhaṇam imāni tīṇi pi lakkhaṇāni udaya bbayam passantassa iva ārammaṇāni honti
translated: The aspect of non-domination is the characteristic of not-self. These three characteristics are only objects for one who sees rise and fall.

original: Punapi so rūpārūpadhamme “evaṃ aniccā”tiādinā vipassati, tassa saṅkhārā lahuṃ lahuṃ
analyzed: puna api saḥ rūpa arūpa dhamme evam anicca ati ādinā vipassati tassa saṅkhārāḥ lahum lahum
translated: He again contemplates the material and immaterial dhammas as impermanent, etc., and the formations come within his purview more and more quickly.

original: āpāthaṃ āgacchanti, tato uppādaṃ vā ṭhitiṃ vā pavattaṃ vā nimittaṃ vā ārammaṇaṃ akatvā
analyzed: āpātham āgacchanti tatas uppādam vā ṭhitim vā pavattam vā nimittam vā ārammaṇam a katvā
translated: Then, without taking their arising, presence, occurrence, or sign as the object,

original: tesaṃ khayavayanirodhe eva sati santiṭṭhati, idaṃ bhaṅgañāṇaṃ nāma. Imassa uppādato🔽paṭṭhāya ayaṃ yogī “yathā ime saṅkhārā bhijjanti nirujjhanti, evaṃ atītepi saṅkhāragataṃ
analyzed: tesam khaya vaya nirodhe eva sati santiṭṭhati idam bhaṅga ñāṇam nāma imassa uppādato  paṭṭhāya ayam yogī yathā ime saṅkhārāḥ bhijjanti nirujjhanti evam atīte api saṅkhāra gatam
translated: he abides only in the contemplation of their dissolution, cessation, and stilling. This is called knowledge of dissolution.🔽From the time of its arising,🔽this meditator considers thus: “As these formations break up and cease, so did the past formations break up and cease, and so will the future formations break up and cease.” He abides contemplating only cessation.

original: bhijji, anāgatepi bhijjissatī”ti nirodhameva passanto tiṭṭhati. Tassa bhaṅgānupassanāñāṇaṃ🔽āsevantassa bahulīkarontassa sabbabhavayoni gatiṭṭhiti sattāvāsesu pabhedakā saṅkhārā
