analyzed: attanaḥ gahaṭṭha kāle sūdassa guṇa makkhanā bhāvam sandhāya āha niddhanta kasā avamoho ti
translated: He is so called because of his lack of guile in concealing the good qualities of others, as he did when he was a householder.🔽He is “free from stain” because he has no stain, which is the delusion that is the opposite of the three kinds of clear vision.

original: ettha rāgādayo tayo kāyaduccaritādīni ca tīṇīti cha dhammā yathāsambhavaṃ appasannaṭṭhena
analyzed: ettha rāga ādayo tayo kāya duccarita ādīni ca tīṇi iti cha dhammā yathāsambhavam appasanna ṭṭhena
translated: Herein, the three kinds of delusion, namely, greed, etc., and the three kinds of bodily misconduct, etc., are called “stain” in the sense of lack of clarity,

original: sakabhāvaṃ vijahāpetvā parabhāvaṃ gaṇhāpanaṭṭhena kasaṭaṭṭhena ca “kasāvā”ti veditabbā. Yathāha –
analyzed: saka bhāvam vijahāpetvā para bhāvam gaṇhāpana ṭhena kasaṭa ṭṭhena ca kasāvā ati veditabbā yathā āha
translated: and in the sense of taking on another’s appearance by abandoning one’s own appearance, and in the sense of dirt. As it is said:🔽“Greed, delusion, and hate,

original: “Tattha katame tayo kasāvā? Rāgakasāvo dosakasāvo mohakasāvo, ime tayo kasāvā. Tattha katame aparepi tayo kasāvā? Kāyakasāvo vacīkasāvo manokasāvo”ti.
analyzed: tattha katame tayo kasāvā rāga kasāvaḥ dosa kasāvaḥ moha kasāvaḥ ime tayo kasāvā tattha katame apare pi tayo kasāvā kāya kasāvaḥ vacī kasāvaḥ manaḥ kasāvaḥ ti
translated: “Herein, what are the three corruptions? The corruption of lust, the corruption of hatred, the corruption of delusion. These are the three corruptions. Herein, what are the other three corruptions? The corruption of body, the corruption of speech, the corruption of mind” .

original: Tesu mohaṃ ṭhapetvā pañcannaṃ kasāvānaṃ tesañca sabbesaṃ mūlabhūtassa mohassa niddhantattā
analyzed: tesu moham ṭhapetvā pañcannam kasāvānam tesam ca sabbesam mūla bhūtassa mohassa niddhanta ttā
translated: Of these, the corruption of delusion that is the root of the five corruptions and of all of them,

original: niddhantakasāvamoho, tiṇṇaṃ eva vā kāyavacīmanokasāvānaṃ mohassa ca niddhantattā
analyzed: niddhanta kasāva mohaḥ tiṇṇam eva vā kāya vacī manaḥ kasāvānam mohassa ca niddhanta ttā
translated: is the corruption that is abandoned. Or alternatively, the corruption of delusion that is the root of the three corruptions of body, speech, and mind,

original: niddhantakasāvamoho. Itaresu nillolupatādīhi rāgakasāvassa, nimmakkhatāya dosakasāvassa🔽niddhantabhāvo siddho eva. Nirāsasoti nittaṇho. Sabbaloketi sakalaloke, tīsu bhavesu🔽dvādasasu vā āyatanesu bhavavibhavataṇhāvirahito hutvāti attho. Sesaṃ vuttanayeneva
analyzed: itaresu nillolupa tā ādīhi rāga kasāvassa nimmakkha tāya dosa kasāvassa  siddhaḥ eva nirāsaso ti nittaṇhaḥ sabbaloka iti sakala loke tīsu bhavesu  dvādasasu vā āyatanesu bhava vibhava taṇhā virahitaḥ hutvā ati attho sesam vutta nayena iva
translated: is the corruption that is abandoned. The corruption of lust is abandoned because of the absence of the stain of lust, and the corruption of hatred is abandoned because of the absence of the stain of hate.🔽The meaning is that he is devoid of craving for existence and non-existence in the three kinds of becoming or in the twelve bases. The rest should be understood in the way already stated.

original: veditabbaṃ. Atha vā tayopi pāde vatvā eko careti eko carituṃ sakkuṇeyyāti evampi🔽ettha sambandho kātabbo.
analyzed: veditabbam atha vā tayo api pāde vatvā ekaḥ cara iti ekaḥ caritum sakkuṇeyya ati evam pi  ettha sambandhaḥ kātabbaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, the construction can be made in this way: “Having thus spoken of the three feet, he said, ‘One should go alone like a horn of a rhinoceros’—one should be able to go alone.”

original: Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: dutiyam
translated: The second .

original: 143. Tatiye ayaṃ saṅkhepattho – yvāyaṃ dasavatthukāya pāpadiṭṭhiyā samannāgatattā
analyzed: tatiye ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ yvā ayam dasa vatthukāya pāpa diṭṭhiyā samannāgata ttā
translated: In the third stanza the meaning is this. He who is wicked because he possesses the tenfold wrong view

original: pāpo. Paresampi anatthaṃ dassetīti anatthadassī. Kāyaduccaritādimhi ca visame niviṭṭho.
analyzed: pāpaḥ paresam pi anattham dasseti iti anattha dassī kāya duccarita ādimhi ca visame niviṭṭho
translated: and who is a seer of non-utility because he shows non-utility to others, and who is fixed in the uneven because he is fixed in bodily misconduct, etc.,

original: Taṃ atthakāmo kulaputto pāpaṃ sahāyaṃ parivajjayetha, anatthadassiṃ visame niviṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: tam attha kāmaḥ kula putto pāpam sahāyam parivajjayetha anattha dassim visame niviṭṭham
translated: a clansman who desires his own welfare should avoid as a companion in the seen and the unseen a wicked man who is a seer of non-utility and is fixed in the uneven.

original: Sayaṃ na seveti attano vasena taṃ na seveyya. Yadi pana paravaso hoti, kiṃ sakkā
analyzed: sayam na seveti attanaḥ vasena tam na seveyya yadi pana paravasaḥ hoti kim sakkā
translated: He should not keep company with him of his own accord: he should not keep company with him by his own wish. But if he is obliged to do so by others, what can he do?

original: kātunti vuttaṃ hoti. Pasutanti pasaṭaṃ, diṭṭhivasena tattha tattha lagganti attho.
analyzed: kātum ti vuttam hoti pasutam ti pasaṭam diṭṭhi vasena tattha tattha laggam ti attho
translated: He is called “a dog” , the meaning is that he is stuck here and there by views.

original: Pamattanti kāmaguṇesu vossaṭṭhacittaṃ, kusalabhāvanārahitaṃ vā. Taṃ evarūpaṃ na seve
analyzed: pamattanti kāma guṇesu vossaṭṭha cittam kusala bhāvanā rahitam vā tam evarūpam na seve
translated: He is called “negligent” because his mind is addicted to the five cords of sense desires or because he is devoid of profitable development. He should not keep company with such a one,

original: na bhaje na payirupāse, aññadatthu eko care khaggavisāṇakappoti.
analyzed: na bhaje na payirupāse añña datthu ekaḥ care khagga visāṇa kappo ti
translated: should not associate with him, should not attend on him. He should go alone like the horn of the rhinoceros.

original: Niddese sayaṃ na seveyyāti sāmaṃ na upasaṅkameyya. Sāmaṃ na seveyyāti cittenapi na
analyzed: niddese sayam na seveyya ati sāmam na upasaṅkameyya sāmam na seveyya ati cittena api na
translated: In the commentary on the words “He should not keep company with him of his own accord” it is said: he should not approach him by himself. “He should not keep company with him” : he should not keep company with him even in mind.

original: upasaṅkameyya. Na seveyyāti na bhajeyya. Na niseveyyāti samīpampi na gaccheyya. Na
analyzed: upasaṅkameyya na seveyya ati na bhajeyya na niseveyya ati samīpam pi na gaccheyya na
translated: He should not visit. He should not frequent: he should not associate with. He should not attend on: he should not go near.

original: saṃseveyyāti dūre bhaveyya. Na parisaṃseveyyāti paṭikkameyya.
analyzed: saṃseveyya ati dūre bhaveyya na parisaṃseveyya ati paṭikkameyya
translated: He should not wait on: he should be far away. He should not wait on in a group: he should refuse.

original: Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: tatiyam
translated: Third.

original: 144. Catutthe ayaṃ saṅkhepattho – bahussutanti duvidho bahussuto tīsu piṭakesu atthato
analyzed: catutthe ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ bahussutanti duvidhaḥ bahussutaḥ tīsu piṭakesu atthato
translated: In the fourth, the meaning in brief is this. Learned: there are two kinds of learnedness: learnedness in the three Piṭakas is called learning in the whole of the scriptures ;

original: nikhilo pariyattibahussuto ca maggaphalavijjābhiññānaṃ paṭividdhattā paṭivedhabahussuto🔽ca. Āgatāgamo dhammadharo. Uḷārehi pana kāyavacīmanokammehi samannāgato uḷāro. Yuttapaṭibhāno
analyzed: nikhilaḥ pariyatti bahu ssutaḥ ca magga phala vijjā abhiññānam paṭividdha ttā paṭivedha bahu ssutaḥ  ca āgata āgamaḥ dhamma dharaḥ uḷārehi pana kāya vacī manaḥ kammehi samannāgataḥ uḷāraḥ yutta paṭibhāno
translated: and learnedness in the paths, fruits, higher knowledges, and discriminations is called learnedness in penetration .🔽He is a master of the tradition and a bearer of the Dhamma. But he is a great man when he is endowed with the great man’s characteristics of bodily action, speech, and mind.

original: ca muttapaṭibhāno ca yuttamuttapaṭibhāno ca paṭibhānavā. Pariyattiparipucchādhigamavasena
analyzed: ca mutta paṭibhāno ca yutta mutta paṭibhāno ca paṭibhānavā pariyatti paripucchā adhigama vasena
translated: He is eloquent when he is endowed with eloquence in speech, in ideas, and in both.🔽Or he can be understood as eloquent in three ways according to learning, questioning, and attainment.

original: vā tidhā paṭibhānavā veditabbo. Yassa hi pariyatti paṭibhāti, so pariyattipaṭibhānavā.
analyzed: vā tidhā paṭibhānavā veditabbaḥ yassa hi pariyatti paṭibhāti saḥ pariyatti paṭibhānavā
translated: For when someone’s learning is eloquent, he is eloquent in learning.

original: Yassa atthañca ñāyañca lakkhaṇañca ṭhānāṭṭhānañca paripucchantassa paripucchā paṭibhāti,
analyzed: yassa atthañca ñāyañca lakkhaṇañca ṭhānāṭṭhānañca paripucchantassa paripucchā paṭibhāti
translated: When his meaning, phrasing, and discrimination are eloquent when he is questioned about meaning, phrasing, and discrimination,

original: so paripucchāpaṭibhānavā. Yena maggādayo paṭividdhā honti, so adhigamapaṭibhānavā.
analyzed: so paripucchā paṭibhānavā yena magga ādayo paṭividdhāḥ honti saḥ adhigama paṭibhānavā
translated: He is one who is able to question and to give replies. He is one who is able to understand the path, etc., and is able to attain them.

original: Taṃ evarūpaṃ bahussutaṃ dhammadharaṃ bhajetha, mittaṃ uḷāraṃ paṭibhānavantaṃ. Tato🔽tassānubhāvena attatthaparatthaubhayatthabhedato vā diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaparamatthabhedato
analyzed: tam evarūpam bahu sutam dhamma dharam bhajetha mittam uḷāram paṭibhānavantam tatas  tassa anubhāvena atta ttha para ttha ubhaya ttha bhedataḥ vā diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika paramattha bhedato
translated: One should serve such a learned man, a bearer of the Dhamma, a friend of noble mind who is able to speak.🔽Then, by his power, one should understand the various kinds of meaning, either as one’s own good, another’s good, or both’s good, or else as the supreme meaning in this world and the next

original: vā anekappakārāni aññāya atthāni, tato “ahosiṃ nu kho ahaṃ atītamaddhāna”ntiādīsu
analyzed: vā aneka ppakārāni aññāya atthāni tatas ahosim nu kho aham atītam addhā ananti ādīsu
translated: , and then, in the matters of doubt beginning thus “Was I in the past? ”

original: kaṅkhāṭṭhānesu vineyya kaṅkhaṃ vicikicchaṃ vinetvā vināsetvā evaṃ katasabbakicco
analyzed: kaṅkhā aṭṭhānesu vineyya kaṅkham vicikiccham vinetvā vināsetvā evam kata sabba kicco
translated: one should dispel doubt, one should get rid of uncertainty. Having done all that should be done,

original: eko care khaggavisāṇakappoti.
analyzed: ekaḥ care khagga visāṇa kappo ti
translated: one should wander alone like the horn of the rhinoceros.

original: Catutthaṃ.🔽145. Pañcame khiḍḍā ca rati ca pubbe vuttāva. Kāmasukhanti vatthukāmasukhaṃ. Vatthukāmāpi
analyzed: catuttham  pañcame khiḍḍā ca rati ca pubbe kāma sukhanti vatthu kāma sukham vatthu kāmā api
translated: Fourth.🔽In the fifth stanza, play and delight have already been explained in the first stanza. Sensual pleasure is sensual pleasure as object.

original: hi sukhassa visayādibhāvena sukhanti vuccanti. Yathāha – “atthi rūpaṃ sukhaṃ sukhānupatita”nti.
analyzed: hi sukhassa visaya ādi bhāvena sukhanti vuccanti yathā āha atthi rūpam sukham sukha anupatitanti
translated: For sensual desires as object are also called “pleasure” as the domain, etc., of pleasure, according to the text, “There is material form that is pleasant and allied to pleasure” .

original: Evametaṃ khiḍḍaṃ ratiṃ kāmasukhañca imasmiṃ okāsaloke analaṅkaritvā alanti akatvā
analyzed: evam etam khiḍḍam ratim kāma sukham ca imasmin okāsa loke an alaṅkaritvā alanti a katvā
translated: “Without delighting in this world’s play and pleasures of sense” : without delighting in, without enjoying, this play and these pleasures of sense in this world of location.

original: “etaṃ tappaka”nti vā “sārabhūta”nti vā evaṃ aggahetvā. Anapekkhamānoti tena analaṅkaraṇena
analyzed: etam tappakam ti vā sāra bhūtam ti vā evam aggahetvā an apekkhamānaḥ ti tena an alaṅkaraṇena
translated: “Without grasping at it as ‘this is mine’ or ‘this is my self’ “ : without regarding it thus, without being intent on it thus,🔽“without concern” : having a nature that is unconcerned, not greedy, not desirous,

original: anapekkhanasīlo apihāluko nittaṇho. Vibhūsaṭṭhānāvirato saccavādī eko careti. Tattha
analyzed: an apekkhana sīlaḥ apihālukaḥ nittaṇhaḥ sacca vādī ekaḥ careti tattha
translated: “he should wander solitary as a rhinoceros” . Herein,

original: vibhūsā duvidhā agārikavibhūsā ca anagārikavibhūsā ca. Tattha agārikavibhūsā sākaṭaveṭhanamālāgandhādi,
analyzed: vibhūsā duvidhā agārika vibhūsā ca anagārika vibhūsā ca tattha agārika vibhūsā sākaṭa veṭhana mālā gandha ādi
translated: adornment is of two kinds, that is to say, householders’ adornment and bhikkhus’ adornment. Herein, householders’ adornment is such as necklaces, earrings, etc.,🔽and bhikkhus’ adornment is such as the bowl-adornment, robe-adornment, etc.

original: anagārikavibhūsā ca pattamaṇḍanādi. Vibhūsā eva vibhūsaṭṭhānaṃ, tasmā vibhūsaṭṭhānā
analyzed: anagārika vibhūsā ca patta maṇḍana ādi vibhūsā eva vibhūsa ṭhānam tasmā vibhūsa ṭṭhānā
translated: Adornment is also a place of adornment, thus it is a place of adornment.🔽So he is “restrained in the places of adornment” in the sense of refraining from the three kinds of adornment.

original: tividhāyapi viratiyā virato. Avitathavacanato saccavādīti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: tividhāya api viratiyā virataḥ avitatha vacanataḥ sacca vādī iti evam atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: And he is “a speaker of truth” in the sense of not speaking falsely. This is how the meaning should be understood here.

original: Pañcamaṃ.🔽146. Chaṭṭhe dhanānīti muttāmaṇiveḷuriyasaṅkhasilāpavāḷarajatajātarūpādīni ratanāni.
analyzed: pañcamam  chaṭṭhe dhanāni iti muttāmaṇi veḷuriya saṅkha silāpa vāḷa rajata jātarūpa ādīni ratanāni
translated: Fifth.🔽In the sixth stanza the word wealth is a collective term for such things as pearls, gems, coral, crystal, silver, gold, and so on.

original: Dhaññānīti sālivīhiyavagodhumakaṅkuvarakakudrūsakappabhedāni satta sesāparaṇṇāni
analyzed: dhaññāni iti sāli vīhi yava godhuma kaṅku varaka kudrūsa kappa bhedāni satta sesa aparaṇṇāni
translated: Grain is a collective term for the seven kinds of cereals, namely, rice, barley, wheat, kidney beans, millet, wild gram, and nue rompu , and for the seven kinds of vegetables, namely, beans, peas, gram, sesame, cucumber, ash-gourd, and pumpkin.

original: ca. Bandhavānīti ñātibandhu, gottabandhu, mittabandhu, sippabandhuvasena catubbidhabandhave.
analyzed: ca bandhavāni iti ñāti bandhu gotta bandhu mitta bandhu sippa bandhu vasena catubbidha bandhave
translated: “Relatives” : relatives by birth, relatives by clan, relatives by marriage, relatives by affiliation to a teacher.

original: Yathodhikānīti sakasakaodhivasena ṭhitāniyeva. Sesaṃ vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: yathā udhikāni iti saka saka odhi vasena ṭhitāniyā iva sesam vutta nayam eva ati
translated: “According to their respective spheres” : they are established according to their respective spheres. The rest is as already stated.

original: Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: chaṭṭham
translated: Sixth.

original: 147. Sattame saṅgo esoti attano upabhogaṃ niddisati. So hi sajjanti tattha pāṇino
analyzed: sattame saṅgaḥ esaḥ ti attanaḥ upabhogam niddisati saḥ hi sajjanti tattha pāṇino
translated: In the seventh verse, “The snare” : he shows his own enjoyment. For the living beings are caught there,

original: kaddame paviṭṭho hatthī viyāti saṅgo. Parittamettha sokhyanti ettha pañcakāmaguṇūpabhogakāle
analyzed: kaddame paviṭṭhaḥ hatthī viyāti saṅgo ettha pañca kāmaguṇa upabhoga kāle
translated: like an elephant fallen into a quagmire, thus it is a snare. “The little joy here” : at the time of enjoying the five strands of sense pleasure,

original: viparītasaññāya uppādetabbato kāmāvacaradhammapariyāpannato vā lāmakaṭṭhena sokhyaṃ🔽parittaṃ, vijjuppabhāya obhāsitanaccadassanasukhaṃ viya ittaraṃ, tāvakālikanti vuttaṃ🔽hoti. Appassādo dukkhamettha bhiyyoti ettha ca yvāyaṃ “yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ime pañca
analyzed: viparīta saññāyaḥ uppādetabbataḥ kāmāvacara dhamma pariyāpannataḥ vā lāmaka ṭṭhena sokhyam  parittam vijju ppabhāya obhāsita nacca dassana sukham viya ittaram tāvakālikam ti vuttam  hoti appassādaḥ dukkham ettha bhiyyas ti ettha ca yvā ayam yam kho bhikkhave ime pañca
translated: the joy is little because of the need to generate a perverted perception, or because it is included among the things of the sense-sphere.🔽It is little like the pleasure of seeing a small light. “The suffering here is great” means that it is temporary.

original: kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ kāmānaṃ assādo”ti vutto, so yamidaṃ
analyzed: kāma guṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukham somanassam ayam kāmānam assādaḥ iti vutto saḥ yam idam
translated: “The disappointment here is great” means that the pleasure called “the pleasure and joy that arise in dependence on these five strands of sense pleasure” is

original: “ko ca, bhikkhave, kāmānaṃ ādīnavo, idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto yena sippaṭṭhānena
analyzed: kaḥ ca bhikkhave kāmānam ādīnavaḥ idha bhikkhave kula puttaḥ yena sippa ṭṭhānena
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is the danger in sensual pleasures? Here, bhikkhus, a clansman by reason of sensual pleasures …

original: jīvikaṃ kappeti yadi muddāya yadi gaṇanāyā”ti evamādinā nayenettha dukkhaṃ vuttaṃ,
analyzed: jīvikam kappeti yadi muddāya yadi gaṇanāya ati evamādinā nayena ittha dukkham vuttam
translated: suffers the painful, racking, piercing feelings. Compared with that, the suffering and the danger in sensual pleasures are slight.

original: taṃ upanidhāya appodakabindumatto hoti, atha kho dukkhameva bhiyyo bahu, catūsu samuddesu🔽udakasadiso hoti. Tena vuttaṃ – “appassādo dukkhamettha bhiyyo”ti. Gaḷo esoti assādaṃ
analyzed: tam upanidhāya appa udaka bindu mattaḥ hoti atha kho dukkham eva bhiyyas bahu catūsu samuddesu  udaka sadisaḥ hoti tena vuttam appassādaḥ dukkham ettha bhiyyas ti gaḷaḥ eso ti assādam
translated: The suffering and the danger in sensual pleasures are like a drop of water compared with the water in the four great oceans.

original: dassetvā ākaḍḍhanavasena baḷiso viya eso, yadidaṃ pañca kāmaguṇā. Iti ñatvā matimāti
analyzed: dassetvā ākaḍḍhana vasena baḷisaḥ yat idam pañca kāmaguṇāḥ iti ñatvā matimā ati
translated: That is why it was said: ‘The danger in sensual pleasures is slight, but the suffering is great.’ ‘The bait’: just as a fish-hook is called ‘bait’ because it attracts the fish, so too are the five cords of sensual pleasure a bait in that they attract beings.

original: evaṃ ñatvā buddhimā paṇḍito puriso sabbampetaṃ pahāya eko care khaggavisāṇakappoti.🔽Sattamaṃ.🔽148. Aṭṭhamagāthāya dutiyapāde jālanti suttamayaṃ vuccati. Ambūti udakaṃ, tattha🔽caratīti ambucārī, macchassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Salile ambucārī salilambucārī. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: evam ñatvā buddhimā paṇḍito puriso sabbam petam pahāya ekaḥ care khagga visāṇa kappo ti 🔽sattamam 🔽aṭṭhama gāthāya dutiya pāde jālanti sutta mayam vuccati ambu uti udakam tattha 🔽carati iti ambu cārī adhivacanam salile ambu cārī salilambu cārī tasmin
translated: ‘Having understood thus’: having understood thus, the wise one, the man of discernment, should abandon all that and wander alone like the rhinoceros-horn.

original: nadīsalile jālaṃ bhetvā gataambucārīvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tatiyapāde daḍḍhanti daḍḍhaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nadī salile jālam bhetvā gata ambu cārī iva iti vuttam hoti tatiya pāde daḍḍhanti daḍḍha ṭṭhānam
translated: “The place burnt up” is said.

original: vuccati. Yathā aggi daḍḍhaṭṭhānaṃ puna na nivattati, na tattha bhiyyo āgacchati,
analyzed: vuccati yathā aggi daḍḍha ṭṭhānam puna na nivattati na tattha bhiyyas āgacchati
translated: Just as the place burnt up by fire does not return again, does not come back there again,

original: evaṃ maggañāṇagginā daḍḍhaṃ kāmaguṇaṭṭhānaṃ anivattamāno, tattha bhiyyo anāgacchantoti
analyzed: evam magga ñāṇa agginā daḍḍham kāma guṇa ṭhānam a nivattamāno tattha bhiyyas an āgacchanto ti
translated: so too, the place burnt up by the fire of path-knowledge, not returning again, not coming back there again,

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Sesaṃ vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: vuttam hoti sesam vutta nayam eva ati
translated: is what is said. The rest is in the same way as already explained.

original: Saṃyojanānīti yassa saṃvijjanti, taṃ puggalaṃ vaṭṭasmiṃ saṃyojenti bandhantīti saṃyojanāni.
analyzed: saṃyojanāni iti yassa saṃvijjanti tam puggalam vaṭṭasmim saṃyojenti bandhanti iti saṃyojanāni
translated: Fetters: the person in whom these exist is fettered, bound in the round.

original: Imāni pana saṃyojanāni kilesapaṭipāṭiyāpi āharituṃ vaṭṭati maggapaṭipāṭiyāpi. Kāmarāgapaṭighasaṃyojanāni🔽anāgāmimaggena pahīyanti, mānasaṃyojanaṃ arahattamaggena, diṭṭhivicikicchāsīlabbataparāmāsā
analyzed: imāni pana saṃyojanāni kilesa paṭipāṭiyā api āharitum vaṭṭati magga paṭipāṭiyā api kāma rāga paṭigha saṃyojanāni  anāgāmi maggena pahīyanti māna saṃyojanam arahatta maggena diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāsā
translated: These fetters can be brought in according to the order of the defilements or according to the order of the paths. The fetters of lust for sense desires and resentment🔽are given up by the non-return path. The fetter of conceit is given up by the Arahant path. The fetters of false view, uncertainty, and misapprehension of virtue and duty

original: sotāpattimaggena, bhavarāgasaṃyojanaṃ arahattamaggena, issāmacchariyāni sotāpattimaggena,
analyzed: sotāpatti maggena bhava rāga saṃyojanam arahatta maggena issāmacchariyāni sotāpatti maggena
translated: are given up by the path of stream-entry. The fetter of lust for becoming is given up by the Arahant path. The fetters of envy and avarice are given up by the path of stream-entry.

original: avijjā arahattamaggena. Maggapaṭipāṭiyā diṭṭhivicikicchāsīlabbataparāmāsaissāmacchariyā
analyzed: avijjā arahatta maggena magga paṭipāṭiyā
translated: ignorance by the Arahant path.

original: sotāpattimaggena pahīyanti, kāmarāgapaṭighā anāgāmimaggena, mānabhavarāgaavijjā arahattamaggenāti.
analyzed: sa utāpatti maggena pahīyanti kāma rāga paṭighāḥ anāgāmi maggena māna bhava rāga avijjāḥ arahatta maggena ati
translated: The views, uncertainty, misapprehension of virtue and duty, envy, and avarice are abandoned by the path of stream-entry. Lust for sense desires and resentment are abandoned by the path of non-return. Conceit, lust for existence, and ignorance are abandoned by the Arahant path.

original: Bhinditvāti bhedaṃ pāpetvā. Pabhinditvāti chindaṃ katvā. Dālayitvāti phāletvā. Padālayitvāti
analyzed: bhinditvā ati bhedam pāpetvā pabhinditvā ati chindam katvā dālayitvā ati phāletvā padālayitvā ati
translated: Having split: having caused a split. Having torn asunder: having cut asunder. Having shattered: having broken. Having smashed:

original: hīretvā. Sampadālayitvāti upasaggena padaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ.
analyzed: hīretvā sampadālayitvā ati upasaggena padam vaḍḍhitam
translated: having crushed. Having completely smashed: the word is repeated with the prefix upa-.

original: Aṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhamam
translated: The eighth.

original: 149. Navame okkhittacakkhūti heṭṭhākhittacakkhu, satta gīvaṭṭhīni paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapetvā
analyzed: navame okkhitta cakkhu iti heṭṭhā ākhitta cakkhu satta gīvaṭṭhīni paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapetvā
translated: In the ninth, with eyes cast down: with eyes cast down below. Having placed the seven neck bones in a row,

original: parivajjanapahātabbadassanatthaṃ yugamattaṃ pekkhamānoti vuttaṃ hoti. Na tu hanukaṭṭhinā🔽hadayaṭṭhiṃ saṅghaṭṭento. Evañhi okkhittacakkhutā na samaṇasārūppā hoti. Na ca pādaloloti
analyzed: parivajjana pahātabba dassana attham yuga mattam pekkhamānaḥ iti vuttam hoti na tu hanu kaṭṭhinā  hadaya ṭṭhim saṅghaṭṭento evam hi okkhitta cakkhu tā na samaṇa sārūppā hoti na ca pāda lolā ti
translated: he looks a plough yoke’s length away, it is said, in order to see without turning his head and abandoning what should be abandoned by avoiding. But he does not🔽touch the breast bone with the chin. For if he did, his casting down of the eyes would not be suitable for an ascetic. Nor does he walk with his feet turned in or out:

original: ekassa dutiyo dvinnaṃ tatiyoti evaṃ gaṇamajjhaṃ, pavisitukāmatāya kaṇḍūyamānapādo
analyzed: ekassa dutiyaḥ dvinnam tatiyaḥ iti evam gaṇa majjham pavisitu kāma tāya kaṇḍūyamāna pādaḥ
translated: he does not walk with his feet turned in or out like a bird’s or a crab’s, in order to abandon what should be abandoned by modification.

original: viya abhavanto, dīghacārikaanavaṭṭhitacārikavirato vā. Guttindriyoti chasu indriyesu
analyzed: abhavantaḥ dīgha cārika anavaṭṭhita cārika virataḥ vā chasu indriyesu
translated: or he is one who has no such thoughts, or one who has given up long walks and standing for long periods on sales-talk. “With guarded faculties”:

original: idha manindriyassa visuṃ vuttattā vuttāvasesavasena gopitindriyo. Rakkhitamānasānoti
analyzed: idha man indriyassa visum vutta ttā vutta avasesa vasena gopita indriyaḥ
translated: herein, since the faculty of mind is mentioned separately, he is one who guards the remaining five faculties by means of the faculty of mind. “With guarded mind”:

original: mānasaṃyeva mānasānaṃ, taṃ rakkhitamassāti rakkhitamānasāno. Yathā kileseti na viluppati,🔽evaṃ rakkhitacittoti vuttaṃ hoti. Anavassutoti imāya paṭipattiyā tesu tesu ārammaṇesu
analyzed: mānasaṃ yā iva mānasānam tam rakkhitam assa ati rakkhita mānasāno yathā kileseti na viluppati  evam rakkhita cittaḥ ti vuttam hoti anavassutaḥ ti imāya paṭipattiyā tesu tesu ārammaṇesu
translated: mind is the same as thought . He is one whose mind is guarded, thus he is “with guarded mind.” He is one whose mind does not ooze out ,🔽thus he is said to be “with guarded mind.” “Not excited”: by this he is one who is without the excitement of defilements towards these and those objects.

original: kilesaanvāssavavirahito. Apariḍayhamānoti evaṃ anvāssavavirahitā eva kilesaggīhi
analyzed: kilesa anvāssava virahitaḥ evam anvāssava virahitāḥ eva kilesa ggīhi
translated: “Not infatuated”: by this he is one who is not burnt by the fires of defilement.

original: apariḍayhamāno, bahiddhā vā anavassuto, ajjhattaṃ apariḍayhamāno. Sesaṃ vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: a pariḍayhamānaḥ bahiddhā vā an avassutaḥ ajjhattam a pariḍayhamānaḥ sesam vutta nayam eva ati
translated: Or alternatively, he is one who is not excited externally, and he is one who is not infatuated internally. The rest is as already stated.

original: Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvāti kāraṇavasena “cakkhū”ti laddhavohārena rūpadassanasamatthena cakkhuviññāṇena rūpaṃ disvā. Porāṇā panāhu –
analyzed: cakkhunā rūpam disvā ati kāraṇa vasena cakkhu iti laddha vohārena rūpa dassana samatthena cakkhu viññāṇena rūpam disvā porāṇā pana āhu
translated: “Having seen a visible object with the eye”: having seen a visible object with eye-consciousness, which is called “eye” in the sense of a reason . But the ancients say:

original: “Cakkhu rūpaṃ na passati acittakattā, cittaṃ na passati acakkhukattā, dvārārammaṇasaṅghaṭṭane
analyzed: cakkhu rūpam na passati acittakattā cittam na passati acakkhukattā dvāra ārammaṇa saṅghaṭṭane
translated: “The eye does not see visible objects, because it is without mind. The mind does not see visible objects, because it is without eyes. When there is a conjunction of door, object, and consciousness,

original: pana pasādavatthukena cittena passati. Īdisī panesā ‘dhanunā vijjhatī’tiādīsu viya
analyzed: pana pasāda vatthukena cittena passati īdisī pana esā dhanunā vijjhati itiādīsu
translated: “The eye does not see visible form because it is without consciousness, and consciousness does not see because it is without eye. But it is by the impact of the door and the object that there is seeing by consciousness that has the eye as its physical basis. But this is a mere figure of speech, like ‘The bow shoots’ ,

original: sasambhārakathā nāma hoti, tasmā cakkhuviññāṇena rūpaṃ disvāti ayamevettha attho”ti.
analyzed: sasambhārakathā nāma hoti tasmā cakkhu viññāṇena rūpam disvā ati ayam eva ittha atthaḥ ti
translated: ‘The mortar sings’ , and so on. So the meaning here is: ‘Having seen visible forms with eye-consciousness.’“

original: Nimittaggāhīti itthipurisanimittaṃ vā subhanimittādikaṃ vā kilesavatthubhūtaṃ nimittaṃ🔽chandarāgavasena gaṇhāti, diṭṭhamattavasena na saṇṭhāti. Anubyañjanaggāhīti kilesānaṃ
analyzed: nimitta ggāhi iti itthi purisa nimittam vā subha nimitta ādikam vā kilesa vatthu bhūtam nimittam  chanda rāga vasena gaṇhāti diṭṭha matta vasena na saṇṭhāti anubyañjana ggāhī iti
translated: He apprehends the sign: he apprehends the sign of a woman or a man or the sign of what is inspiring confidence, etc., which is a basis for defilements.

original: anubyañjanato pākaṭabhāvakaraṇato “anubyañjana”nti laddhavohāraṃ hatthapādahasitalapitavilokitādibhedaṃ ākāraṃ gaṇhāti.🔽Yatvādhikaraṇamenantiādimhi yaṃkāraṇā yassa cakkhundriyāsaṃvarassa hetu. Etaṃ puggalaṃ
analyzed: anubyañjanataḥ pākaṭa bhāva karaṇataḥ laddha vohāram hattha pāda hasita lapita vilokita ādi bhedam ākāram gaṇhāti 🔽yatvā adhikaraṇam enanti ādimhi yaṃkāraṇā yassa cakkhu indriya asaṃvarassa hetu etam puggalam
translated: He does not stop with mere seeing. He apprehends the particulars: he apprehends the mode, which is called the particulars because it makes the defilements manifest. The mode is classed as the hand, the foot, the smile, the speech, the look, etc.

original: satikavāṭena cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ apihitacakkhudvāraṃ hutvā viharantaṃ ete abhijjhādayo🔽dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ. Tassa saṃvarāya na paṭipajjatīti tassa cakkhundriyassa satikavāṭena
analyzed: sati kavāṭena cakkhu indriyam a saṃvutam apihita cakkhu dvāram hutvā viharantam ete abhijjhā ādayaḥ  dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyum tassa saṃvarāya na paṭipajjati iti tassa cakkhu indriyassa sati kavāṭena
translated: If the eye faculty is not guarded, not protected, the eye door is left unguarded, and then these states of covetousness, etc.,🔽might invade him. He does not practice restraint upon it: he does not practice restraint upon that eye faculty by means of the guarding of it with mindfulness by the method stated.

original: pidahanatthāya na paṭipajjati. Evaṃbhūtoyeva ca “na rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ. Na cakkhundriye🔽saṃvaraṃ āpajjatī”tipi vuccati.🔽Tattha kiñcāpi cakkhundriye saṃvaro vā asaṃvaro vā natthi. Na hi cakkhupasādaṃ nissāya
analyzed: pidahana tthāya na paṭipajjati evaṃbhūtaḥ yā iva ca na rakkhati cakkhu indriyam na cakkhu indriye  saṃvaram āpajjati itipi vuccati  tattha kiñcā api cakkhu indriye saṃvaraḥ vā asaṃvaraḥ vā natthi na hi cakkhu upasādam nissāya
translated: And it is one who is such that it is said: “He does not guard the eye faculty; he does not undertake the practice of restraint upon the eye faculty.”🔽Herein, although there is no restraint or non-restraint upon the eye faculty, since neither mindfulness nor forgetfulness arises in dependence upon the eye faculty,

original: sati vā muṭṭhassaccaṃ vā uppajjati, api ca yadā rūpārammaṇaṃ cakkhussa āpāthaṃ āgacchati,
analyzed: sati vā muṭṭhassaccam vā uppajjati api ca yadā rūpa ārammaṇam cakkhussa āpātham āgacchati
translated: nevertheless when a visible datum as object comes into the eye’s focus,

original: tadā bhavaṅge dvikkhattuṃ uppajjitvā niruddhe kiriyamanodhātu āvajjanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā
analyzed: tadā bhavaṅge dvi khattum uppajjitvā niruddhe kiriya manodhātu āvajjana kiccam sādhayamānā
translated: then after the life-continuum has arisen and ceased twice, the functional mind element accomplishing the function of adverting arises and ceases.

original: uppajjitvā nirujjhati, tato cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dassanakiccaṃ tato vipākamanodhātu sampaṭicchanakiccaṃ
analyzed: uppajjitvā nirujjhati tatas cakkhu viññāṇam dassana kiccam tatas vipāka manaḥ dhātu sampaṭicchana kiccam
translated: Then eye-consciousness arises and performs the function of seeing; then the resultant mind element performs the function of receiving;

original: tato vipākāhetukamanoviññāṇadhātu santīraṇakiccaṃ tato kiriyāhetukamanoviññāṇadhātu
analyzed: tatas vipāka ahetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu santīraṇa kiccam tatas kiriyā hetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: Then the resultant mind-consciousness element performs the function of adverting. Then the functional mind-consciousness element performs the function of determining.

original: voṭṭhapanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā uppajjitvā nirujjhati, tadanantaraṃ javanaṃ javati.🔽Tatrāpi neva bhavaṅgasamaye, na āvajjanādīnaṃ aññatarasamaye saṃvaro vā asaṃvaro
analyzed: voṭṭhapana kiccam sādhayamānā uppajjitvā nirujjhati tad anantaram javanam javati  tatra api na iva bhavaṅga samaye na āvajjana ādīnam aññatara samaye saṃvaraḥ vā a saṃvaraḥ
translated: Then the resultant mind-consciousness element performs the function of determining. Then the functional mind-consciousness element performs the function of adverting. After that, impulsion impels.

original: vā atthi, javanakkhaṇe pana sace dussīlyaṃ vā muṭṭhassaccaṃ vā aññāṇaṃ vā akkhanti
analyzed: vā atthi javana khaṇe pana sace dussīlyam vā muṭṭhassaccam vā aññāṇam vā
translated: Herein, there is neither restraint nor unrestraint at the time of the life-continuum or at the time of any one of the others beginning with adverting. But if unvirtuousness, or inattention, or unknowing, or impatience,

original: vā kosajjaṃ vā uppajjati, asaṃvaro hoti. Evaṃ honto pana so cakkhundriye asaṃvaroti
analyzed: vā kosajjam vā uppajjati asaṃvaraḥ hoti evam honto pana so cakkhu indriye
translated: or idleness arises at the impulsion moment, then there is unrestraint. And when it is thus, it is called “unrestraint in the eye faculty.”

original: vuccati. Kasmā? Yasmā tasmiṃ sati dvārampi aguttaṃ hoti bhavaṅgampi āvajjanādīni🔽vīthicittānipi. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā nagare catūsu dvāresu asaṃvutesu kiñcāpi antogharadvārakoṭṭhakagabbhādayo
analyzed: vuccati kasmai yasmai tasmin sati dvāram pi aguttam hoti āvajjana ādīni  yathā kim yathā nagare catūsu dvāresu a saṃvutesu kiñca api antar ghara dvāra koṭṭhaka gabbha ādayaḥ
translated: Why? Because when it is present, the door is unguarded, and the life-continuum, and the impulsions beginning with adverting,🔽are unguarded too. How so? Just as, when the four city gates are unguarded, then all the goods in the city are unguarded, though the houses inside may be well guarded;

original: susaṃvutā, tathāpi antonagare sabbaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ arakkhitaṃ agopitameva hoti. Nagaradvārena
analyzed: su saṃvutā tathā api antonagare sabbam bhaṇḍam arakkhitam a gopitam eva hoti nagara dvārena
translated: and just as, when the city gates are guarded, then all the goods in the city are guarded, though the houses inside may be unguarded.

original: hi pavisitvā corā yadicchanti, taṃ hareyyuṃ. Evameva javane dussīlyādīsu uppannesu
analyzed: hi pavisitvā corāḥ yat icchanti tam hareyyum evam eva javane dussīlya ādīsu uppannesu
translated: Just as when the city gates are closed, thieves can do as they wish inside the city but cannot get out, so too, when unvirtuousness, etc.,

original: tasmiṃ asaṃvare sati dvārampi aguttaṃ hoti bhavaṅgampi āvajjanādīni vīthicittānipīti.
analyzed: tasmin asaṃvare sati dvāram pi aguttam hoti bhavaṅgam pi āvajjana ādīni vīthi cittāni pi iti
translated: arise in the impulsions, then, there being no restraint in him, the door is unguarded, and the life-continuum and the consciousnesses of the cognitive series beginning with adverting are unguarded too.

original: Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hotītiādīsu na nimittaggāhī hotīti chandarāgavasena🔽vuttappakāraṃ nimittaṃ na gaṇhāti. Evaṃ sesapadānipi vuttapaṭikkhepena veditabbāni.🔽Yathā ca heṭṭhā “javane dussīlyādīsu uppannesu tasmiṃ asaṃvare sati dvārampi aguttaṃ
analyzed: cakkhunā rūpam disvā na nimitta ggāhī hoti itiādīsu na nimitta ggāhī hoti iti chanda rāga vasena  vutta ppakāram nimittam na gaṇhāti evam sesa padāni api vutta paṭikkhepena veditabbāni  yathā ca heṭṭhā javane dussīlya ādīsu uppannesu tasmin asaṃvare sati dvāram pi aguttam
translated: On seeing a visible object with the eye, he does not grasp at its signs and features: he does not grasp the sign and the features of the kind already described under greed. So too with the rest.

original: hoti bhavaṅgampi āvajjanādīni vīthicittānipī”ti vuttaṃ, evamidha tasmiṃ sīlādīsu
analyzed: āvajjana ādīni vīthi cittāni pi iti vuttam evam idha tasmin sīla ādīsu
translated: And just as it was said above, “When unvirtuousness, etc., arise in the impulsions, then, there being no restraint in him, the door is unguarded, and the life-continuum and the consciousnesses of the cognitive series beginning with adverting are unguarded too,” so too here it should be understood that when virtue, etc.,

original: uppannesu dvārampi guttaṃ hoti bhavaṅgampi āvajjanādīni vīthicittānipi. Yathā kiṃ?
analyzed: uppannesu dvāram pi guttam hoti bhavaṅgam pi āvajjana ādīni vīthi cittāni pi yathā kim
translated: arise in the impulsions, then, there being restraint in him, the door is guarded, and the life-continuum and the consciousnesses of the cognitive series beginning with adverting are guarded too. How?

original: Yathā nagaradvāresu saṃvutesu kiñcāpi antogharādayo asaṃvutā honti. Tathāpi antonagare
analyzed: yathā nagara dvāresu saṃvutesu kiñca api antar ghara ādayaḥ a saṃvutāḥ honti tathā api antar nagare
translated: Just as when the city gates are closed, although the houses, etc., inside the city are unguarded, nevertheless the thieves cannot get out of the city, so too,

original: sabbaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ surakkhitaṃ sugopitameva hoti. Nagaradvāresu pihitesu corānaṃ paveso🔽natthi. Evameva javane sīlādīsu uppannesu dvārampi guttaṃ hoti bhavaṅgampi āvajjanādīni
analyzed: sabbam bhaṇḍam su rakkhitam su gopitam eva hoti nagara dvāresu pihitesu corānam  natthi evam eva javane sīla ādīsu uppannesu dvāram pi guttam hoti bhavaṅgam pi āvajjana ādīni
translated: and all the goods are well guarded and well protected. When the city gates are closed, there is no way for thieves to enter. So too, when the javanas of virtue, etc., arise, the gate is guarded and the life-continuum is guarded by the adverting, etc.

original: vīthicittānipi. Tasmā javanakkhaṇe uppajjamānopi cakkhundriye saṃvaroti vutto.🔽Avassutapariyāyañcāti kilesehi tintakāraṇañca. Anavassutapariyāyañcāti kilesehi atintakāraṇañca.🔽Piyarūpe rūpeti iṭṭhajātike rūpārammaṇe. Appiyarūpe rūpeti aniṭṭhasabhāve rūpārammaṇe. Byāpajjatīti dosavasena pūtibhāvamāpajjati. Otāranti chiddaṃ antaraṃ. Ārammaṇanti paccayaṃ.
analyzed: vīthi cittāni pi tasmā java nakkhaṇe uppajjamānaḥ api cakkhu indriye saṃvaro ti vutto  avassuta pariyāyam ca ati kilesehi tinta kāraṇañca an avassuta pariyāyam ca ati kilesehi a tinta kāraṇañca  piya rūpe rūpe iti iṭṭha jātike rūpa ārammaṇe appiya rūpe rūpe iti aniṭṭha sabhāve rūpa ārammaṇe byāpajjati iti dosa vasena pūti bhāvam āpajjati otāranti chiddam antaram ārammaṇanti paccayam
translated: All goods are well guarded and well protected. When the city gates are closed, there is no entry for thieves. So too, when javanas of virtue, etc., arise, the door is guarded, the life-continuum is guarded, and the consciousnesses of the cognitive series are guarded. Therefore, though it arises at the javana stage, it is said that it guards the eye faculty.🔽“The unperverted and the unadulterated” : the unperverted and the unadulterated by defilements.🔽“In pleasant visible forms” : in visible forms of the kind that are liked. “In unpleasant visible forms” : in visible forms of the kind that are disliked. “He falls into aversion” : he falls into putridity through hatred. “A crevice” : a hole. “An object” : a condition.

original: Adhibhaṃsūti maddaṃsu. Na adhibhosīti na maddi. Bahalamattikāti punappunaṃ dānavasena uddhamāyikā bahalamattikā. Addāvalepanāti asukkhamattikadānā. Sesamettha uttānaṃ.
analyzed: adhibhaṃsu iti maddaṃsu na adhibhosi iti na maddi bahalamattikā ati punappunam dāna vasena uddha māyikā bahalamattikā addāvalepanā ati asukkha mattika dānā sesam ettha uttānam
translated: “They would overcome” : they would overpower. “They would not overcome” : they would not overpower. “A great deal of clay” : a great deal of clay for plastering again and again. “A coating of lime” : a coating of unbaked clay. The rest is clear.

original: Navamaṃ.
analyzed: navamam
translated: The ninth.

original: 150. Dasame kāsāyavattho abhinikkhamitvāti imassa pādassa gehā abhinikkhamitvā kāsāyavattho hutvāti evamattho veditabbo. Sesaṃ vuttanayeneva sakkā jānitunti na vitthāritanti.
analyzed: dasame kāsāya vatthaḥ abhinikkhamitvā ti imassa pādassa gehā abhinikkhamitvā kāsāya vatthaḥ hutvā ati evamatthaḥ veditabbo sesam vutta nayena iva sakkā jānitum ti na vitthāritam ti
translated: In the tenth, “having gone forth in the yellow robe” : the meaning of this phrase should be understood as “having gone forth from the house, having become one who wears the yellow robe.” The rest can be understood by the method stated, so it is not elaborated.

original: Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: dasamam
translated: The tenth.

original: Tatiyavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tatiya vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the third collection is finished.

original: 4. Catutthavaggavaṇṇanā
analyzed: catuttha vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: The fourth collection

original: 151. Catutthavaggassa paṭhame rasesūti ambilamadhuratittakakaṭukaloṇikakhārikakasāvādibhedesu
analyzed: catuttha vaggassa paṭhame rasesu iti ambila madhura tittaka kaṭuka loṇika khārika kasāva ādi bhedesu
translated: In the first of the fourth collection, “in tastes” : in the various tastes such as sour, sweet, bitter, pungent, salty, and astringent.

original: sāyanīyesu. Gedhaṃ akaranti giddhiṃ akaronto, taṇhaṃ anuppādentoti vuttaṃ hoti. Aloloti
analyzed: sāyanīyesu gedham akaranti giddhim akarontaḥ taṇham an uppādentaḥ ti vuttam hoti a lolaḥ ti
translated: “They make a nest” : they make a nest, they do not give rise to craving, is what is meant. “Not greedy” :

original: “idaṃ sāyissāmi, idaṃ sāyissāmī”ti evaṃ rasavisesesu anākulo. Anaññaposīti posetabbakasaddhivihārikādivirahito,
analyzed: idam sāyissāmi idam sāyissāmi iti evam rasa visesesu an ākulaḥ anañña posī ti posetabbaka saddhivihārika ādi virahitaḥ
translated: not confused about the various tastes, thinking “I will eat this, I will eat that.” “Not eating others’ food” : without a pupil or a co-resident to be fed,

original: kāyasandhāraṇamattena santuṭṭhoti vuttaṃ hoti. Yathā vā pubbe uyyāne rasesu gedhakaraṇalolo
analyzed: kāya sandhāraṇa mattena santuṭṭhaḥ ti vuttam hoti yathā vā pubbe uyyāne rasesu gedha karaṇa lolo
translated: satisfied with just maintaining the body, is what is meant. Or else, as before, in the park, not greedy for making a nest in the various tastes,

original: hutvā aññaposī āsiṃ, evaṃ ahutvā yāya taṇhāya lolo hutvā rasesu gedhaṃ karoti, taṃ🔽taṇhaṃ hitvā āyatiṃ taṇhāmūlakassa aññassa attabhāvassa anibbattanena anaññaposīti
analyzed: hutvā aññaposī āsim evam a hutvā yāya taṇhāya lolaḥ hutvā rasesu gedham karoti tam  taṇham hitvā āyatim taṇhā mūlakassa aññassa atta bhāvassa a nibbattanena anaññaposīti
translated: and was a consumer of others’ offerings, but now, having abandoned that craving by which, being greedy, one is a consumer of others’ offerings,

original: dasseti. Atha vā atthabhañjanakaṭṭhena kilesā “aññe”ti vuccanti, tesaṃ aposanena🔽anaññaposīti ayamettha attho. Sapadānacārīti avokkammacārī anupubbacārī, gharapaṭipāṭiṃ
analyzed: dasseti atha vā attha bhañjana kaṭṭhena kilesā aññe ti vuccanti tesam aposanena  an añña posi iti ayam ettha attho sa padāna cārī iti avokkamma cārī anupubba cārī ghara paṭipāṭim
translated: he shows that he is not a consumer of others’ offerings by not being reborn again with a selfhood rooted in craving. Or alternatively, the defilements are called “others” because they destroy the good, and he is not a consumer of others’ offerings because he does not feed on them.

original: achaḍḍetvā aḍḍhakulañca daliddakulañca nirantaraṃ piṇḍāya pavisamānoti attho. Kule
analyzed: a chaḍḍetvā aḍḍha kulam ca dalidda kulam ca nirantaram piṇḍāya pavisamānaḥ ti attho kule
translated: He goes from family to family: he goes without omitting, he goes in regular order; the meaning is that he enters for alms without skipping over either the wealthy or the poor, without omitting the round of houses.

original: kule appaṭibaddhacittoti khattiyakulādīsu yattha katthaci kilesavasena alaggacitto,
analyzed: kule appaṭibaddha citto ti khattiya kula ādīsu yattha katthaci kilesa vasena alagga citto
translated: He is not attached to families: he is not tied to any families by the defilements, such as by the defilement of lust;

original: candūpamo niccanavako hutvāti attho. Sesaṃ vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: canda upamaḥ nicca navakaḥ hutvā ati attho sesam vutta nayam eva ati
translated: the meaning is that he is like the moon, always fresh. The rest is as already explained.

original: Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhamam
translated: First tetrad.

original: 152. Dutiye āvaraṇānīti nīvaraṇāneva, tāni atthato uragasutte vuttāni. Tāni pana
analyzed: dutiye āvaraṇāni iti tāni atthataḥ uraga sutte vuttāni tāni pana
translated: In the second, hindrances = the five hindrances. They are given in the Snake Story .

original: yasmā abbhādayo viya candaṃ sūriyaṃ vā ceto āvaranti, tasmā “āvaraṇāni cetaso”ti🔽vuttāni. Tāni upacārena vā appanāya vā pahāya. Upakkileseti upagamma cittaṃ vibādhente
analyzed: yasmai abbha ādayaḥ viya candam sūriyam vā cetaḥ āvaranti tasmai āvaraṇāni cetasā uti  vuttāni tāni upacārena vā appanāya vā pahāya upakkilese iti upagamma cittam vibādhente
translated: Because they cover the mind as a cloud covers the moon or sun, they are called “coverings of the mind.”🔽They are abandoned by means of access concentration and absorption concentration.

original: akusale dhamme, vatthopamādīsu vutte abhijjhādayo vā. Byapanujjāti panuditvā vināsetvā,
analyzed: akusale dhamme vattha upama ādīsu vutte abhijjhā ādayaḥ vā byapanujjāti panuditvā vināsetvā
translated: “Defilements” are unwholesome states that defile the mind by approaching it. Or they are the greed, etc., mentioned in the passage beginning, “The mind defiled by greed does not attain concentration” .🔽“Having given up” means having rejected, having destroyed, having abandoned by means of the path of insight.

original: vipassanāmaggena pajahitvāti attho. Sabbeti anavasese. Evaṃ samathavipassanāsampanno
analyzed: vipassanā maggena pajahitvā ati attho sabbe iti anavasese evam samatha vipassanā sampanno
translated: “All” means without exception.🔽Endowed with serenity and insight,

original: paṭhamamaggena diṭṭhinissayassa pahīnattā anissito. Sesamaggehi chetvā tedhātukagataṃ
analyzed: paṭhama maggena diṭṭhi nissayassa pahīna ttā anissitaḥ sesa maggehi chetvā tedhātuka gatam
translated: he is “unattached” because he has abandoned attachment to views by means of the first path. By means of the other paths he has “cut off the fetter of craving that extends over the three planes” .

original: sinehadosaṃ, taṇhārāganti vuttaṃ hoti. Sineho eva hi guṇapaṭipakkhato sinehadosoti
analyzed: sineha dosam taṇhā rāgam ti vuttam hoti sinehaḥ eva hi guṇa paṭipakkhato sineha doso ti
translated: “Craving” is called a “fetter” because it binds one to the three planes. “Greed” is called a “greed-fetter” because it is opposed to the quality of non-greed.

original: vutto. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: vuttaḥ sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: The rest is as above.

original: Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: dutiyam
translated: The second.

original: 153. Tatiye vipiṭṭhikatvānāti piṭṭhito katvā, chaḍḍetvā jahitvāti attho. Sukhaṃ dukhañcāti
analyzed: tatiye vipiṭṭhi katvāna ati katvā chaḍḍetvā jahitvā ati attho sukham dukham ca ati
translated: In the third stanza, the words “having turned his back” mean having turned away, having abandoned. “Pleasure and pain” are the five cords of sensual pleasure.

original: kāyikaṃ sātāsātaṃ. Somanassadomanassanti cetasikaṃ sātāsātaṃ. Upekkhanti catutthajjhānupekkhaṃ.🔽Samathanti catutthajjhānasamathameva. Visuddhanti pañcanīvaraṇavitakkavicārapītisukhasaṅkhātehi
analyzed: kāyikam sāta asātam somanassa domanassanti cetasikam sāta asātam upekkhanti catuttha jhāna upekkham  catuttha jhāna samatham eva pañca nīvaraṇa vitakka vicāra pīti sukha saṅkhātehi
translated: Pleasant and painful bodily feeling. Joy and grief: these are pleasant and painful mental feeling. Equanimity: the equanimity of the fourth jhāna.🔽Tranquility: the tranquillity of the fourth jhāna itself. Purification: it is purified by being liberated from the nine impediments beginning with the hindrances and including applied thought, sustained thought, happiness, bliss, and concentration.

original: navahi paccanīkadhammehi vimuttattā atisuddhaṃ, niddhantasuvaṇṇamiva vigatūpakkilesanti attho.🔽Ayaṃ pana yojanā – vipiṭṭhikatvāna sukhaṃ dukkhañca pubbeva, paṭhamajjhānūpacārabhūmiyaṃyeva
analyzed: navahi paccanīka dhammehi vimutta ttā ati suddham niddhanta suvaṇṇam iva vigata upakkilesanti attho  ayam pana yojanā sukham dukkham ca pubbā iva paṭhama jhāna upacāra bhūmiyaṃ yeva
translated: The meaning is: it is like well-refined gold free from all dross.

original: dukkhaṃ, tatiyajjhānūpacārabhūmiyañca sukhanti adhippāyo. Puna ādito vuttaṃ ca-kāraṃ
analyzed: dukkham tatiya jhānu upacāra bhūmiyam ca sukham ti adhippāyaḥ puna āditas vuttam cakāram
translated: But the explanation is this. The intention is that he first separates out the pleasure and pain, and that the pain is in the neighbourhood of the first jhāna and the pleasure in the neighbourhood of the third jhāna.

original: parato netvā “somanassaṃ domanassañca vipiṭṭhikatvāna pubbevā”ti adhikāro. Tena somanassaṃ
analyzed: paratas netvā somanassam domanassam ca vipiṭṭhi katvāna pubbā iva ati adhikāro tena somanassam
translated: Then, after taking the “and” in the second line as referring back to that, the construction should be read: “Having first separated out joy and grief.”

original: catutthajjhānūpacāre, domanassañca dutiyajjhānūpacāreyevāti dīpeti. Etāni hi etesaṃ
analyzed: catuttha jhānu upacāre domanassam ca dutiya jhānu upacāre yeva ati dīpeti etāni hi etesam
translated: The meaning is that he first separates out joy in the neighbourhood of the fourth jhāna and grief in the neighbourhood of the second jhāna.🔽For these are the kinds of feeling that are respectively pleasant and painful in the two instances.

original: pariyāyato pahānaṭṭhānāni. Nippariyāyato pana dukkhassa paṭhamajjhānaṃ, domanassassa
analyzed: pariyāyato pahāna ṭhānāni nippariyāyato pana dukkhassa paṭhamajjhānam domanassassa
translated: and the abandoning of the remaining kinds of suffering, etc., is their place of disappearance in the ultimate sense.🔽And the first jhāna is the place for abandoning the applied thought and sustained thought,🔽the second jhāna is the place for abandoning the hindrances,🔽the third jhāna is the place for abandoning happiness,

original: dutiyajjhānaṃ, sukhassa tatiyajjhānaṃ, somanassassa catutthajjhānaṃ pahānaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Yathāha – “paṭhamajjhānaṃ upasampajja viharati etthuppannaṃ dukkhindriyaṃ aparisesaṃ
analyzed: dutiya jhānam sukhassa tatiya jhānam somanassassa catuttha jhānam pahāna ṭhānaṃ  yathā āha paṭhama jhānam upasampajja viharati ettha uppannam dukkha indriyam aparisesam
translated: the fourth jhāna is the place for abandoning bliss and pain.

original: nirujjhatī”tiādi. Taṃ sabbaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayena gahetabbaṃ. Parato pubbevāti tīsu🔽paṭhamajjhānadīsu dukkhadomanassasukhāni vipiṭṭhikatvā ettheva ca catutthajjhāne🔽somanassaṃ vipiṭṭhikatvā imāya paṭipadāya laddhānupekkhaṃ samathaṃ visuddhaṃ eko
analyzed: nirujjhati itiādi tat sabbam heṭṭhā vutta nayena gahetabbam paratas pubbā iva ati tīsu  paṭhama jhāna dīsu dukkha domanassa sukhāni vipiṭṭhi katvā ettha iva ca catuttha jhāne  somanassam vipiṭṭhi katvā imāya paṭipadāya laddha anupekkham samatham visuddham ekaḥ
translated: As it is said: “When he is concentrated in jhāna, the faculty of pain that has arisen in him is abandoned by him without remainder” , and so on. All this should be understood as already stated.

original: care iti. Sesaṃ vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: care iti sesam vutta nayam eva ati
translated: The rest is as already stated.

original: Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: tatiyam
translated: The third tetrad is finished.🔽In the fourth, he is called “one who has aroused energy” because he has aroused energy.

original: 154. Catutthe āraddhaṃ vīriyaṃ assāti āraddhaviriyo. Etena attano vīriyārambhaṃ ādivīriyaṃ
analyzed: catutthe āraddham vīriyam assa ati āraddha viriyaḥ etena attanaḥ vīriya ārambham ādi vīriyam
translated: By this he shows his own arousing of energy.

original: dasseti. Paramattho vuccati nibbānaṃ, tattha pattiyā paramatthapattiyā. Etena vīriyārambhena
analyzed: dasseti paramatthaḥ vuccati nibbānam tattha pattiyā paramattha pattiyā etena vīriya ārambhena
translated: He shows the fruit to be attained by means of the energy he has begun.

original: pattabbaphalaṃ dasseti. Alīnacittoti etena vīriyupatthambhānaṃ cittacetasikānaṃ alīnataṃ🔽dasseti. Akusītavuttīti etena ṭhānāsanacaṅkamādīsu kāyassa anavasīdanaṃ. Daḷhanikkamoti🔽etena “kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru cā”ti evaṃ pavattaṃ padahanavīriyaṃ dasseti. Yaṃ taṃ anupubbasikkhādīsu
analyzed: pattabba phalam dasseti alīna cittaḥ ti etena vīriya upatthambhānam citta cetasikānam alīna taṃ  dasseti a kusīta vuttī iti etena ṭhāna āsana caṅkama ādīsu kāyassa anavasīdanam daḷha nikkamaḥ ti  etena kāmam taco ca nhāru ca ati evam pavattam padahana vīriyam dasseti yam tam anupubba sikkhā ādīsu
translated: He shows the non-slackness of the consciousnesses and consciousness-concomitants that support the energy.🔽He shows the non-slackness of the body in postures, seats, and so on.🔽He shows the energy that is exerted in the way beginning “If he wishes ‘Let the flesh and sinews waste away’ ” ,

original: padahanto “kāyena ceva paramatthasaccaṃ sacchikaroti, paññāya ca naṃ ativijjha passatī”ti
analyzed: padahantaḥ kāyena ca iva paramattha saccam sacchikaroti paññāya ca nam ativijjha passati iti
translated: which is called “the energy of exertion” and is said to be “the body’s realization of the ultimate truth and its seeing of it by penetrating it with understanding.”

original: vuccati. Atha vā etena maggasampayuttavīriyaṃ dasseti. Tañhi daḷhañca bhāvanāpāripūrigatattā,
analyzed: vuccati atha vā etena magga sampayutta vīriyam dasseti tat hi daḷham ca bhāvanā pāripūri gata ttā
translated: Or alternatively, he shows the energy associated with the path. For that is strong because it is fulfilled by development,

original: nikkamo ca sabbaso paṭipakkhā nikkhantattā, tasmā taṃsamaṅgīpuggalopi daḷho nikkamo
analyzed: nikkamaḥ ca sabbaso paṭipakkhā nikkhanta ttā tasmā tad samaṅgī puggalaḥ api daḷhaḥ nikkamaḥ
translated: and it is exertion because it has gone out from all opposition. Therefore the person who possesses it is called “strong” and “exerted.”

original: assāti “daḷhanikkamo”ti vuccati. Thāmabalūpapannoti maggakkhaṇe kāyathāmena ñāṇabalena🔽ca upapanno. Atha vā thāmabhūtena balena upapannoti thāmabalūpapanno, thirañāṇabalūpapannoti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Etena tassa vīriyassa vipassanāñāṇasampayogaṃ dīpento yoniso padahanabhāvaṃ
analyzed: assa ati daḷha nikkamaḥ ti vuccati thāma bala upapanno ti magga kkhaṇe kāya thāmena ñāṇa balena  ca upapannaḥ atha vā thāma bhūtena balena upapanno ti thāma bala upapanno thirañāṇa bala upapanno ti  vuttam hoti etena tassa vīriyassa vipassanā ñāṇa sampayogam dīpentaḥ yonisaḥ padahana bhāvam
translated: “Steadfast” is said of one who is “of strong effort.” “Endowed with the strength of energy” means that he is endowed with bodily energy and the strength of knowledge at the moment of the path. Or else, “endowed with the strength of energy” means that he is endowed with the strength of steadfastness; he is endowed with the strength of firm knowledge.🔽This shows that his energy is associated with insight knowledge and that he is intent on the right object.🔽

original: sādheti. Pubbabhāgamajjhimaukkaṭṭhavīriyavasena vā tayopi pādā yojetabbā. Sesaṃ vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: sādhā iti pubba bhāga majjhima ukkaṭṭha vīriya vasena vā tayo api pādāḥ yojetabbā sesam vutta nayam eva ati
translated: “He is called ‘of firm endeavour’ ”: he is called “of firm endeavour” because of the firmness of his endeavour. “Endowed with the power of energy”: he is endowed with the power of bodily and mental energy at the time of the path. Or else, “endowed with the power of energy” means “endowed with the power of firm energy”; he is endowed with the power of firm knowledge, is what is meant. By this he shows the association of that energy with insight knowledge and so establishes its rational application. Or else, all three factors may be construed as “the energy of initial, middle and final stages respectively.” The rest is as already stated.

original: Catutthaṃ.🔽155. Pañcame paṭisallānanti tehi tehi sattasaṅkhārehi paṭinivattitvā sallīnaṃ, ekattasevitā
analyzed: catuttham  pañcame tehi tehi satta saṅkhārehi paṭinivattitvā sallīnam ekatta sevitā
translated: The fourth.

original: ekībhāvo kāyavivekoti attho. Jhānanti paccanīkajhāpanato ārammaṇalakkhaṇūpanijjhānato
analyzed: ekībhāvaḥ kāya vivekaḥ ti atthaḥ jhānanti paccanīka jhāpanataḥ ārammaṇa lakkhaṇa upanijjhānato
translated: In the fifth, “seclusion” is the seclusion of the mind from the various kinds of formations. “Solitude” is the solitude of the mind, its unity. “Jhāna” is the seclusion of the mind from its opposing states and from its object by its being intent upon the sign of concentration.

original: ca cittaviveko vuccati. Tattha aṭṭha samāpattiyo nīvaraṇādipaccanīkajhāpanato kasiṇādiārammaṇūpanijjhānato
analyzed: ca citta viveko vuccati tattha aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ nīvaraṇa ādi paccanīka jhāpanato kasiṇa ādi ārammaṇa upanijjhānato
translated: Herein, the eight attainments are called “jhāna” because they burn up opposing states, and because they cause the sign of the object to be brought into the field of the mind and then to be intent upon that.

original: ca “jhāna”nti vuccati. Vipassanāmaggaphalāni sattasaññādipaccanīkajhāpanato lakkhaṇūpanijjhānato🔽ca “jhāna”nti vuccati. Idha pana ārammaṇūpanijjhānameva adhippetaṃ. Evametaṃ paṭisallānañca
analyzed: ca jhānanti vuccati vipassanā magga phalāni satta saññā ādi paccanīka jhāpanato lakkhaṇa upanijjhānato  ca jhānanti vuccati idha pana ārammaṇa upanijjhānam eva adhippetam evam etam paṭisallānam ca
translated: and it is called jhāna because it burns up the defilements that are its opponents. And insight and the path and fruition are called jhāna because they burn up the defilements that are their opponents and because they are a burning up of the characteristics of the first three jhānas respectively. But here what is intended by jhāna is only the burning up of the object.🔽So he is one who does not abandon, does not relinquish, this seclusion and this jhāna.

original: jhānañca ariñcamānoti ajahamāno anissajjamāno. Dhammesūti vipassanupagesu pañcakkhandhādidhammesu.
analyzed: jhānañca ariñcamānaḥ ti a jahamānaḥ a nissajjamānaḥ dhammesu iti vipassana upagesu pañcakkhandha ādi dhammesu
translated: In the True Idea: in the ideas that are the proximate cause for insight.🔽Constantly: always, uninterruptedly.

original: Niccanti satataṃ samitaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ. Anudhammacārīti te dhamme ārabbha pavattamānena
analyzed: niccanti satatam samitam abbokiṇṇam anudhamma cārī iti te dhamme ārabbha pavattamānena
translated: A follower of the True Idea: one who goes by means of the idea that is the proximate cause for insight.

original: anugataṃ vipassanādhammaṃ caramāno. Atha vā dhammesūti ettha dhammāti nava lokuttaradhammā,
analyzed: anugatam vipassanā dhammam caramānaḥ atha vā dhammesu iti ettha dhammā ati nava lokuttara dhammā
translated: Or alternatively, in the True Idea: here the True Idea is the nine supramundane ideas;

original: tesaṃ dhammānaṃ anulomo dhammoti anudhammo, vipassanāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tattha “dhammānaṃ
analyzed: tesam dhammānam anulomaḥ dhammo ti anudhammaḥ vipassanāya itam adhivacanam tattha dhammānam
translated: the idea that is in conformity with those ideas is the True Idea; this is a term for insight. Herein, it should be said that he is one who constantly follows the True Idea in the ideas,

original: niccaṃ anudhammacārī”ti vattabbe gāthābandhasukhatthaṃ vibhattibyattayena “dhammesū”ti
analyzed: niccam anudhamma cārī iti vattabbe gāthā bandha sukha attham vibhatti byattayena dhammesu iti
translated: but for the sake of euphony the instrumental case has been used in the words “in the True Idea” .

original: vuttaṃ siyā. Ādīnavaṃ sammasitā bhavesūti tāya anudhammacāritāsaṅkhātāya vipassanāya
analyzed: vuttam siyā ādīnavam sammasitāḥ bhavesu ti tāya anudhammacāritā saṅkhātāya vipassanāya
translated: it might be said. He has discerned danger in existence: by means of insight consisting in the life of one devoted to mental development,

original: aniccākārādidosaṃ tīsu bhavesu samanupassanto evaṃ imāya kāyavivekacittavivekaṃ ariñcamāno
analyzed: anicca ākāra ādi dosam tīsu bhavesu samanupassantaḥ evam imāya kāya viveka citta vivekam ariñcamāno
translated: he sees the danger in the three kinds of becoming consisting in the aspect of impermanence, and so on. Thus he is one who has gone forth to the solitude of the body and the solitude of mind.

original: sikhāppattavipassanāsaṅkhātāya paṭipadāya adhigatoti vattabbo eko careti evaṃ yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: sikhāppatta vipassanā saṅkhātāya paṭipadāya adhigataḥ iti vattabbaḥ ekaḥ cara iti evam yojanā veditabbā
translated: He should be called one who has attained to the path called “insight that has reached maturity.” He should be called one who “goes alone” . This is how the construction should be understood here.

original: Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: pañcamam
translated: Fifth.

original: 156. Chaṭṭhe taṇhakkhayanti nibbānaṃ, evaṃ diṭṭhādīnavāya taṇhāya eva appavattiṃ.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe nibbānam evam diṭṭha ādīnavāya taṇhāya eva appavattim
translated: In the sixth verse, “the ending of craving” is Nibbāna, the non-occurrence of craving that sees danger in views, and so on.

original: Appamattoti sātaccakārī. Aneḷamūgoti alālāmukho. Atha vā aneḷo ca amūgo ca, paṇḍito
analyzed: appamatto ti sātacca kārī aneḷa mūgaḥ iti a lālā mukhaḥ atha vā aneḷaḥ ca a mūgaḥ ca paṇḍito
translated: “The heedful one” is the one who acts with perseverance. “The one without a stick” is the one without a goad. Or else, “without a stick” means “without a goad,” and “without a goad” means “without a mouth” . The wise one is what is meant.

original: byattoti vuttaṃ hoti. Hitasukhasampāpakaṃ sutamassa atthīti sutavā, āgamasampannoti
analyzed: byattaḥ iti vuttam hoti hita sukha sampāpakam sutam assa atthi iti sutavā āgama sampannaḥ ti
translated: “The one who has heard much” is the one who has the much-heard that brings about welfare and pleasure. The one who has the scriptures is what is meant.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Satīmāti cirakatādīnaṃ anussaritā. Saṅkhātadhammoti dhammūpaparikkhāya
analyzed: vuttam hoti cirakata ādīnam anussaritā saṅkhāta dhammo ti dhamma upaparikkhāya
translated: “The mindful one” is the one who recollects what was done long ago, and so on. “The one who has investigated the Dhamma” is the one who has investigated the Dhamma by means of the investigation of the Dhamma.

original: pariññātadhammo. Niyatoti ariyamaggena niyāmaṃ patto. Padhānavāti sammappadhānavīriyasampanno.
analyzed: pariññāta dhammaḥ niyataḥ ti ariya maggena niyāmam patto padhānavā ati sammappadhāna vīriya sampanno
translated: He has fully understood the Dhamma. “He has reached the fixed course”: he has reached the fixed course by means of the noble path. “He is endowed with energy”: he is endowed with the energy of right effort.

original: Uppaṭipāṭiyā esa pāṭho yojetabbo. Evametehi appamādādīhi samannāgato niyāmasampāpakena
analyzed: uppaṭipāṭiyā esa pāṭhaḥ yojetabbo evam etehi appamāda ādīhi samannāgataḥ niyāma sampāpakena
translated: The reading should be construed in this way, by alternation. Thus he is endowed with heedfulness, etc., and with the energy that brings about the fixed course.

original: padhānena padhānavā, tena padhānena pattaniyāmattā niyato, tato arahattappattiyā
analyzed: padhānena padhānavā tena padhānena niyataḥ tatas arahatta ppattiyā
translated: “He is endowed with energy”: he is endowed with the energy that brings about the fixed course. “He has reached the fixed course”: he has reached the fixed course by means of that energy. Then, by attaining arahatship,

original: saṅkhātadhammo. Arahā hi puna saṅkhātabbābhāvato “saṅkhātadhammo”ti vuccati. Yathāha
analyzed: saṅkhāta dhammaḥ arahā hi puna saṅkhātabba abhāvataḥ saṅkhāta dhammaḥ ti vuccati yathā āha
translated: he has fully understood the Dhamma. For the arahat is called “one who has fully understood the Dhamma” because he has nothing more to understand. As it is said:

original: – “ye ca saṅkhātadhammāse, ye ca sekkhā puthū idhā”ti. Sesaṃ vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: ye ca saṅkhāta dhammā āse ye ca sekkhā puthū idha ati sesam vutta nayam eva ati
translated: “Those who have fully understood the Dhamma, And the many disciples in training here” . The rest is as already explained.

original: Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: chaṭṭham
translated: The sixth chapter

original: 157. Sattame sīhoti cattāro sīhā – tiṇasīho, paṇḍusīho, kāḷasīho, kesarasīhoti. Tesaṃ
analyzed: sattame sīhaḥ iti cattāro sīhā tiṇasīhaḥ paṇḍusīhaḥ kāḷasīhaḥ kesarasīhaḥ ti tesam
translated: In the seventh chapter, “lion” : there are four kinds of lions: the grass lion, the white lion, the black lion, and the kesara lion.

original: kesarasīho aggamakkhāyati, eso idha adhippeto. Vāto puratthimādivasena anekavidho.
analyzed: kesarasīhaḥ aggam akkhāyati esaḥ idha adhippetaḥ vātaḥ puratthima ādi vasena anekavidhaḥ
translated: The kesara lion is considered the best. That is the one meant here. “Wind” is of many kinds, according to the directions, etc.

original: Padumaṃ rattasetādivasena. Tesu yo koci vāto yaṃ kiñci padumaṃ vaṭṭatiyeva. Tattha
analyzed: padumam ratta setā ādi vasena tesu yaḥ koci vātaḥ yam kiñci padumam tattha
translated: “Lotus” is of many kinds, according to the red, white, etc. Any kind of wind is suitable for any kind of lotus.

original: yasmā santāso attasinehena hoti, attasineho ca taṇhālepo, sopi diṭṭhisampayuttena🔽vā diṭṭhivippayuttena vā lobhena hoti, sopi ca taṇhāyeva. Sajjanaṃ pana tattha upaparikkhāvirahitassa
analyzed: santāsaḥ atta sinehena hoti atta sinehaḥ ca taṇhā ālepo saḥ api diṭṭhi sampayuttena  vā diṭṭhi vippayuttena vā lobhena hoti saḥ api ca taṇhāya iva sajjanam pana tattha upaparikkhā virahitassa
translated: For anxiety is due to self-love, and self-love is defilement by craving. That is either associated with views or dissociated from views. And that is craving. But the wise man, who is not devoid of investigation, should investigate thus:

original: mohena hoti, moho ca avijjā. Tattha samathena taṇhāya pahānaṃ hoti, vipassanāya avijjāya.🔽Tasmā samathena attasinehaṃ pahāya sīho viya saddesu aniccadukkhādīsuasantasanto,🔽vipassanāya mohaṃ pahāya vātova jālamhi khandhāyatanādīsu asajjamāno, samatheneva
analyzed: mohena hoti mohaḥ ca avijjā tattha samathena taṇhāya pahānam hoti vipassanāya avijjāya  tasmā samathena atta sineham pahāya sīhaḥ viya saddesu anicca dukkha ādīsu asanta santaḥ  vipassanāya moham pahāya vātaḥ uva jālamhi khandha āyatana ādīsu a sajjamānaḥ samathena iva
translated: For anxiety is due to self-love, and self-love is a stain of craving. That is due either to greed associated with views or to greed unassociated with views, and that is craving. But the “clinging” is due to delusion in one who is unpractised in the investigation of that . And that delusion is ignorance. Herein, craving is abandoned by serenity, and ignorance by insight.

original: lobhaṃ, lobhasampayuttaṃ eva diṭṭhiñca pahāya, padumaṃva toyena sabbabhavabhogalobhena alippamāno.🔽Ettha ca samathassa sīlaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ, samatho samādhi, vipassanā paññāti evaṃ tesu
analyzed: lobham lobha sampayuttam eva diṭṭhiñca pahāya padumam iva toyena sabba bhava bhoga lobhena a lippamānaḥ 🔽ettha ca samathassa sīlam padaṭṭhānam samathaḥ samādhi vipassanā paññā ti evam tesu
translated: So, abandoning self-love by means of serenity, like the lion that is unafraid of any sound, unafraid of any sign, unafraid of any place, unafraid of any time, unafraid of any company, unafraid of any action, unafraid of any defilement, unafraid of any person, unafraid of any creature, unafraid of any being, unafraid of any ghost, unafraid of any spirit, unafraid of any human, unafraid of any god, unafraid of any visible-form, unafraid of any sound, unafraid of any odour, unafraid of any flavour, unafraid of any tangible, unafraid of any mind-object, unafraid of any plane, unafraid of any destiny, unafraid of any station of consciousness, unafraid of any sphere of influence, unafraid of any rebirth, unafraid of any world, unafraid of any creature, unafraid of any being, unafraid of any ghost, unafraid of any spirit, unafraid of any human, unafraid of any god, unafraid of any visible-form, unafraid of any sound, unafraid of any odour, unafraid of any flavour, unafraid of any tangible, unafraid of any mind-object, unafraid of any sign of visible-form, unafraid of any sign of sound, unafraid of any sign of odour, unafraid of any sign of flavour, unafraid of any sign of tangible, unafraid of any sign of mind-object, unafraid of any sign of the world, unafraid of any sign of creatures, unafraid of any sign of beings, unafraid of any sign of ghosts, unafraid of any sign of spirits, unafraid of any sign of humans, unafraid of any sign of gods, unafraid of any sign of visible-form, unafraid of any sign of sound, unafraid of any sign of odour, unafraid of any sign of flavour, unafraid of any sign of tangible, unafraid of any sign of mind-object, unafraid of any sign of the world,

original: dvīsu dhammesu siddhesu tayopi khandhā siddhā honti. Tattha sīlakkhandhena surato
analyzed: dvīsu dhammesu siddhesu tayo api khandhā siddhā honti tattha sīla kkhandhena surataḥ
translated: When the two things are accomplished, the three aggregates are accomplished. Herein, he is “gentle” through the virtue aggregate,

original: hoti, so sīhova saddhesu āghātavatthūsu akujjhitukāmatāya na santasati, paññākkhandhena
analyzed: hoti saḥ sīhaḥ uva saddhesu āghāta vatthūsu a kujjhitu kāma tāya na santasati paññā kkhandhena
translated: because he is not ill-tempered in the way beginning “He is not angry when angry things are being done to him” . He is “not agitated” through the understanding aggregate,

original: paṭividdhasabhāvo vātova jālamhi khandhādidhammabhede na sajjati, samādhikkhandhena🔽vītarāgo padumaṃva toyena rāgena na lippati. Evaṃ samathavipassanāhi sīlasamādhipaññākkhandhehi🔽ca yathāsambhavaṃ avijjātaṇhānaṃ, tiṇṇañca akusalamūlānaṃ pahānavasena asantasanto
analyzed: paṭividdha sabhāvaḥ vātaḥ uva jālamhi khandha ādi dhamma bhede na sajjati samādhi kkhandhena  vīta rāgaḥ toyena rāgena na lippati evam samatha vipassanāhi sīla samādhi paññā kkhandhehi  ca yathāsambhavam avijjāta ṇhānam tiṇṇam ca akusala mūlānam pahāna vasena
translated: because he is not caught in the mesh of the views about aggregates, etc., like a fish in a net. He is “unstained” through the concentration aggregate,

original: asajjamāno alippamāno ca veditabbo. Sesaṃ vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: a sajjamānaḥ a lippamānaḥ ca veditabbo sesam vutta nayam eva ati
translated: like a lotus leaf by drops of water. He is “not agitated” and so on should be understood as the abandoning of ignorance and craving and of the three roots of the unprofitable by means of serenity and insight and the virtue, concentration, and understanding aggregates, respectively, as appropriate. The rest is as already stated.

original: Sattamaṃ.
analyzed: sattamam
translated: Seventh.

original: 158. Aṭṭhame sahanā ca hananā ca sīghajavattā ca sīho. Kesarasīhova idha adhippeto.
analyzed: aṭṭhame sahanā ca hananā ca sīghajavattā ca sīhaḥ kesarasīhaḥ uva idha adhippeto
translated: In the eighth, the lion is the one with a jaw’s strength, the swift gait, and the roar. Here it is the lion, the king of beasts, that is intended.

original: Dāṭhā balamassa atthīti dāṭhabalī. Pasayha abhibhuyyāti ubhayaṃ cārīsaddena saha
analyzed: dāṭhā balam assa atthi iti dāṭha balī pasayha abhibhuyya ati ubhayam cārī saddena saha
translated: He has the strength of a jaw, thus he is “jaw-strong” . He is “not overawed” and “not frightened” by both .

original: yojetabbaṃ pasayhacārī abhibhuyyacārīti. Tattha pasayha niggayha pavāhetvā caraṇena
analyzed: yojetabbam pasayha cārī abhibhuyya cārī iti tattha pasayha niggayha pavāhetvā caraṇena
translated: He should be one who goes about after overcoming and after suppressing .🔽Herein, he is one who goes about after overcoming by going about after overcoming and suppressing and rejecting .

original: pasayhacārī. Abhibhavitvā santāsetvā vasīkatvā caraṇena abhibhuyhacārī. Svāyaṃ kāyabalena
analyzed: pasayha cārī abhibhavitvā santāsetvā vasīkatvā caraṇena abhibhuyha cārī svāyam kāya balena
translated: He is one who goes about after suppressing by going about after suppressing and overcoming and mastering .🔽Herein, he is one who goes about after suppressing by bodily strength;🔽he is one who goes about after overcoming by energy.

original: pasayhacārī, tejasā abhibhuyyacārī. Tattha sace koci vadeyya “kiṃ pasayha abhibhuyyacārī”ti.
analyzed: pasayha cārī tejasā abhibhuyya cārī tattha sace koci vadeyya kim pasayha abhibhuyya cārī iti
translated: Herein, if anyone should say, “What is the use of overcoming and suppressing? ”

original: Tato migānanti sāmivacanaṃ upayogatthe katvā “mige pasayha abhibhuyyacārī”ti paṭivattabbaṃ.
analyzed: tatas migānanti sāmi vacanam upayoga atthe katvā mige pasayha abhibhuyya cārī iti paṭivattabbam
translated: then the answer is that he is one who goes about after overcoming and suppressing by using the deer as the example.

original: Pantānīti dūrāni. Senāsanānīti vasanaṭṭhānāni. Sesaṃ pubbe vuttanayeneva sakkā jānitunti na vitthāritaṃ.
analyzed: pantāni iti dūrāni senāsanāni iti vasana ṭṭhānāni sesam pubbe vutta nayena iva sakkā jānitun ti na vitthāritam
translated: The words “far-reaching” are “far” . “Resting places” are places of living. The rest can be understood in the way already stated .

original: Aṭṭhamaṃ.🔽159. Navame “sabbe sattā sukhitā bhavantū”tiādinā nayena hitasukhūpanayanakāmatā
analyzed: aṭṭhamam  navame sabbe sattā sukhitāḥ bhavantu uti ādinā nayena hita sukha upanayana kāma tā
translated: The eighth .🔽In the ninth, the wish to bring about welfare and pleasure in the way beginning, “May all beings be free from enmity, “ is loving-kindness .

original: mettā. “Aho vata imamhā dukkhā vimucceyyu”ntiādinā nayena ahitadukkhāpanayanakāmatā
analyzed: mettā aho vata imamhā dukkhā vimucceyyun ti ādinā nayena ahita dukkha apanayana kāma tā
translated: The wish to remove harm and pain in the way beginning, “May they live happily” is compassion .

original: karuṇā. “Modanti vata bhonto sattā, modanti sādhu suṭṭhū”tiādinā nayena hitasukhāvippayogakāmatā
analyzed: karuṇā modanti vata bhonto sattāḥ modanti sādhu suṭṭhūti ādinā nayena hita sukha a vippayoga kāma tā
translated: Sympathetic joy is the wish for beings not to be deprived of happiness, in the way beginning, “Let them not be deprived of their happiness” .

original: muditā. “Paññāyissanti sakena kammenā”ti sukhadukkhesu ajjhupekkhanatā upekkhā. Gāthābandhasukhatthaṃ
analyzed: muditā paññāyissanti sakena kammena ati sukha dukkhesu ajjhupekkhanatā upekkhā gāthābandha sukha attham
translated: Equanimity is the state of mind that looks on with impartiality at the happiness and suffering of those who are not related to one, in the way beginning, “They will experience the fruits of their actions” .🔽But in order to make the metre come out, equanimity is mentioned first and sympathetic joy last.

original: pana uppaṭipāṭiyā mettaṃ vatvā upekkhā vuttā, muditā ca pacchā. Vimuttinti catassopi🔽hi vimuttī. Etā attano paccanīkadhammehi vimuttattā vimuttiyo. Tena vuttaṃ – “mettaṃ🔽upekkhaṃ karuṇaṃ vimuttiṃ, āsevamāno muditañca kāle”ti.🔽Tattha āsevamānoti tisso tikacatukkajjhānavasena bhāvayamāno, upekkhaṃ catutthajjhānavasena
analyzed: pana uppaṭipāṭiyā mettam vatvā upekkhā vuttā muditā ca pacchā vimutti nti catasso pi  hi vimuttī etāḥ attanaḥ paccanīka dhammehi vimutta ttāḥ vimuttiyaḥ tena vuttam mettam  upekkham karuṇam vimuttim āsevamānaḥ muditam ca kāleti  tattha āsevamāno ti tissaḥ tika catukka jhāna vasena bhāvayamāno upekkham catuttha jhāna vasena
translated: And all four are “deliverances” because they are delivered from the opposing states,🔽as will be shown in the following verses.🔽Herein, “he cultivates” is one who develops by making the three kinds of jhāna, namely, the triple-quadruple jhāna, the quadruple-quadruple jhāna, and the jhāna consisting of unification of cognizance accompanied by happiness .🔽“Equanimity” is the fourth jhāna.

original: bhāvayamāno. Kāleti mettaṃ āsevitvā tato vuṭṭhāya karuṇaṃ, tato vuṭṭhāya muditaṃ,
analyzed: bhāvayamāno kāleti mettam āsevitvā tatas vuṭṭhāya karuṇam tatas vuṭṭhāya muditam
translated: “He cultivates” is one who develops by making the fourth jhāna.

original: tato itarato vā nippītikajjhānato vuṭṭhāya upekkhaṃ āsevamānova “kāle āsevamāno”ti
analyzed: tatas itaratas vā nippītika jhānataḥ vuṭṭhāya upekkham āsevamānaḥ iva kāle āsevamānaḥ iti
translated: “In due course” is in due course, after emerging from the jhāna called “sympathetic joy” and from that called “equanimity” or from the other jhāna called “equanimity” .

original: vuccati, āsevituṃ phāsukāle vā. Sabbena lokena avirujjhamānoti dasasu disāsu sabbena🔽sattalokena avirujjhamāno. Mettādīnañhi bhāvitattā sattā appaṭikkūlā honti, sattesupi
analyzed: vuccati āsevitum phāsu kāle vā sabbena lokena a virujjhamānaḥ ti dasasu disāsu sabbena  satta lokena a virujjhamānaḥ mettā ādīnam hi bhāvita ttā sattāḥ a paṭikkūlāḥ honti sattesu pi
translated: is said. Not in conflict with the world means not in conflict with any of the living beings in the ten-thousand world-systems. For beings become non-hostile through the development of loving-kindness, etc., and they are not hostile to anyone.

original: virodhabhūto paṭigho vūpasammati. Tena vuttaṃ – “sabbena lokena avirujjhamāno”ti.
analyzed: virodha bhūtaḥ paṭighaḥ vūpasammati tena vuttam sabbena lokena a virujjhamānaḥ ti
translated: is said. At the time of ease in cultivation: in the time of ease in the development of loving-kindness, etc. Not in conflict with the whole world: not in conflict with the whole world of beings in the ten-thousand world-element. For, through the development of loving-kindness, etc., beings are not hostile, and the hostility that has arisen is appeased. Therefore it is said: “Not in conflict with the whole world.”

original: Sesaṃ vuttasadisamevāti.
analyzed: sesam vutta sadisam eva ati
translated: The rest is as already stated.

original: Navamaṃ.
analyzed: navamam
translated: The ninth.

original: 160. Dasame saṃyojanānīti dasa saṃyojanāni, tāni ca tena tena maggena sandālayitvāna.🔽Asantasaṃ jīvitasaṅkhayamhīti jīvitasaṅkhayo vuccati cuticittassa paribhedo, tasmiñca🔽jīvitasaṅkhaye jīvitanikantiyā pahīnattā asantasanti. Ettāvatā saupādisesanibbānadhātuṃ
